A busy-body local municipal government tells me I can't erect a white picket fence across the front of my property (if I wanted to) or landscape with fake grass to cut down on an enormous water bill (which I've considered doing).As one who loves London above all other cities visited, I'm left with this quote by James Boswell noted in HUBBUB about a journey within that metropolis:"... the noise, the crowd, the glare of the shops and signs agreeably confused me ... my companion (in the coach) could not understand my feelings."But, perhaps more to the point of HUBBUB, this quote from Jean-Paul Sartre's play "No Exit":"Hell is other people."

In DISTANT ANNIHILATION, Tarquin Collingwood, formerly an officer in the 9th Berkshire Hussars posted with his unit to the U.N. peacekeeping force in the Balkans, now finds himself on a Mission Improbable to the Central Asian republic of Azakistan to foil an evil plot by the Iranians and some disreputable Russians to bring the world to the nuclear brink.Author Azam Hossain persistently refers to the Iranians as "Persians." He apparently doesn't like Persians much.I actually read about two-thirds of this e-book, and then skimmed to the end.If you're a fan of the espionage genre and used to such authors as John le Carré, Gerald Seymour, Len Deighton, and the late Adam Hall (Elleston Trevor), you will perhaps appreciate a visual analogy of DISTANT ANNIHILATION with any of the books by the aforementioned authors which will best describe my opinion of the former.DISTANT ANNIHILATION is like any episode of the frivolous The Man from U.N.C.L.E.: The Complete Series compared to the exemplary BBC production of either Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy or Smiley's People.While I realize that the author was attempting to write a tribute to Bond and Flashman, DISTANT ANNIHILATION is positively ridiculous and doesn't deserve any sort of sequel as the "hero" is in no way engaging. Oh, please not.

(Note: This review is of an uncorrected advance proof of the book.)Pat Scannon, Ph.D, M.D. founded the biotech company Xoma Corporation, though he later gave up the management of it so he could disappear into his office and work on ... well, technical stuff. But, he got bored. So, in 1993 he tagged along on an underwater treasure hunting expedition to the Western Pacific Ocean island of Palau, a trip that got sidetracked with the search for a Japanese trawler sunk by (future President) George H. W. Bush in World War II, his first "kill." Among the underwater wrecks also dived was that of an American B-24 bomber shot down in 1944 while attacking the Japanese-occupied island. After returning home, Scannon did research that revealed to him that the plane was one of three B-24s downed there in August and September of '44. The locations of two of the aircraft were known; the resting place of the third, presumably underwater, was not.VANISHED is New York Times Magazine contributor Wil Hylton's narrative of Pat's decade-long obsession with finding the third plane and its lost crew and the several expeditions he led to Palau to do just that.  His wife was apparently glad to get him out of the house.Hylton ranges far and wide to create the back-story, including describing the early lives and training of some of the lost aircrew - particularly Jimmie Doyle and Johnny Moore - and the enduring grief of surviving family members, the environment of the B-24 bases on Los Negros and Wakde islands, the overall U.S. strategy for the conquest of the Pacific on the final thrust at Japan, the battle worthiness and effectiveness of the B-24 Liberator, and the ongoing efforts of the American military's Joint POW/MIA Accounting Command (JPAC) to bring home the remains of U.S. servicemen and women missing in action and presumed dead.I think, however, that the author got a little too carried away with background. Did I really need to know about Scannon's parents' experiences in Europe during the war, or the health problems of several Japanese secret police officers stationed on Palau in `44, or the eminently tolerable conditions of Japanese P.O.W. camps for captured Germans in World War I? (World War ONE! Really?)Above all, VANISHED is a fine tribute to the admirable mission of JPAC in general and to the personal efforts, albeit derived from an obsession, of Scannon in particular to help the families of the crewmembers of that "lost" B-24 to achieve some closure on the disappearance of their loved ones so many years past. However, that said, I also got the impression that the tensions sure to have occurred between the family members, Scannon's search group BentProp, and the U.S. military authorities -  tensions almost certain to have erupted into shouting matches - were glossed over by the author to make the overall effort appear more heroically harmonious in print than in actuality. By the end of the book, I was beginning to fidget.I'm awarding VANISHED four stars on the conditions that the final, published version undergoes significant editing for content and typos and includes additional relevant photographs. At minimum, it's an effort worth honor.

DEATH IN THE FAST LANE by Chris Jay Becker is a quickly-read e-novel which would be an e-short story with more spirited editing. The plot has LAPD Robbery-Homicide detectives T.S. "King" Leary and Thurston Howell "Millionaire" Adler investigating two deaths and one near-miss apparently caused by maliciously modified automobile brakes.The crime mystery is neither suspenseful nor particularly interesting. The author seems more focused on creating glib and clever dialogue between characters reciting their lines against a backdrop of the city's then-and-now rock and roll scene, a milieu that held no interest for me whatsoever.From the very beginning, the reader knows that the evildoer pulling the strings is the Angel of Righteousness, a religious nut case. (Gee, you think? Well, this is California.) When his identity is finally revealed by the evolution of the storyline, the revelation is pretty much ho-hum.This is not to say that DEATH IN THE FAST LANE is completely without merit. As a novice thriller writer, Becker does very well at defining the different personalities of his characters; they don't end up being essentially identical cookie-cut pieces differentiated by name only. With the main protagonist in future episodes, Leary, the author now needs to concentrate at making him more sympathetic to the reader by developing his vulnerabilities and internal conflicts; flawed heroes are more appealing than unblemished ones. Similarly, Becker needs to develop any future story's main villain and bring him into more intimate and energized conflict with Leary. In DEATH IN THE FAST LANE, the final (and only) confrontation between the detective and the Angel was so fleeting and tension-free as to be laughable.

"During and since the War the steps of the Fountain have been occupied by an untidy fringe of foreigners, provincials, soldiers, sailors, and their lady friends ... The centre of Piccadilly Circus, which used to look so lovely with its baskets of primroses and violets in spring, its roses in summer and its dahlias in autumn, is now, in my opinion, one of the most depressing and regrettable spectacles in the capital. I have an idea that sitting around Eros began during the War with the Americans, who chewed their gum there and mournfully smoked their cheroots, wondering why the heck they were in London." ‒ H.V. Morton in IN SEARCH OF LONDONWell, you know what they said about Yanks in England during the war: "Overpaid, oversexed, overfed, and over here."Having been to London almost more times than I can count, I could have been on any visit part of that "untidy fringe" except that sitting in the middle of what amounts to a busy road junction on the steps of an unimposing statue has never held much attraction. Other than that, London is my personal-favorite city in the whole world and reading H.V. Morton's IN SEARCH OF LONDON reminds me why I love it so much.Morton's book is product of his fourth visit to the city which occurred in or somewhat before 1951. England and its capital were still recovering from the destructive effects of World War II, and George VI was still King. As the author is careful to point out in order to give some idea of the changes he'd seen over time, his first visit was as a child in the closing years of Victoria's reign.While IN SEARCH OF LONDON could perhaps have been used as a walking-tour guidebook for a contemporary tourist when it was first published, now it couldn't serve as such at all. Too many things have changed (even during the period between my first and most recent visits, 1975 and 2010). There aren't as many second-hand book stores along Charing Cross Road as there used to be. The Royal United Service Museum, once housed in the Banqueting Hall of the old Palace of Whitehall, is apparently no longer there, though I can't seem to discover with a Web crawl where it went ‒ if anywhere. With the increased security around public buildings after 9/11, I suspect tourists can no longer scurry past the gate guards into St. James's Palace for a cursory look-see. Though one can still go by motor launch from Westminster Pier to Greenwich, the latter is now a stop (Cutty Sark Station) for Docklands Light Rail. And the Royal Naval College in Greenwich closed its doors in 1998.IN SEARCH OF LONDON serves best as a reminder ‒ if such is needed ‒ that the metropolis is chock-a-block filled with sights and history just waiting to be discovered by the city explorer of any era. And Morton takes the armchair tourist even further into what perhaps could only be experienced after special arrangements and efforts (which are probably beyond the casual visitor), e.g., a climb up Big Ben to inspect the bells and the clock and its workings, attend an auction at Sotheby's, descend into the Royal Vaults beneath Westminster Abbey's Chapel of Henry VII, or observe the grueling examination on London's streets administered to cabbie wannabes.H.V. Morton is a travel essayist of the utmost eloquence and possessing boundless enthusiasm. (If I may be so plebeian, his passion for his subjects reminds me of Huell Howser, host of the American public television program CALIFORNIA'S GOLD.) In any case, I've read and enjoyed him in the past (In Search Of England), and I'll most certainly do so again.

Roderick Usher (Vncent Price- PIT AND THE PENDULUM) has a serious medical condition. He is stricken w/ a severe heightening of the senses, turning the slightest touch, sight, sound, taste, or smell into abject agony! Roderick also believes that he and his sister, Madeline (Myrna Fahey) are doomed to impending insanity and death (it's a family curse). So, the Usher house is NOT a happy place! Enter Mark Damon as Madeline's fiance, who's bent on getting her out of this dreary atmosphere. Big trouble erupts when Roderick insists upon her staying put, to the point of burying her alive! Can her betrothed save her before it's too late? Not if Roderick can help it! Meanwhile, true to the title, the very house is crumbling around them! (THE FALL OF) THE HOUSE OF USHER is a solid Roger Corman / Poe adaptation w/ lots of ghastly charm. One of Price's best, brooding performances...

It's always worthwhile to watch Vincent Price (THE ABOMINABLE DR. PHIBES, DR. PHIBES RISES AGAIN) in a humorous role. After playing such eeevil characters as the insane, murdering Richard III in TOWER OF LONDON, or the odious WITCHFINDER GENERAL, it's a blast to watch a film like THE COMEDY OF TERRORS! Price plays the inept undertaker, Waldo Trumbull, who can barely keep his head above water. Owing a year's rent, he sets out to make big money... fast! With his sidekick, Felix Gillie (Peter Lorre- THE RAVEN, TALES OF TERROR) in tow, Trumbull attempts to drum up some business, by relieving people of their burdensome lives! Hilarity ensues. Price and Lorre are very funny, as are Boris karloff (THE TERROR, DIE MONSTER DIE!) and Basil Rathbone (SON OF FRANKENSTEIN)! The gorgeous Joyce Jameson (TALES OF TERROR) is also great as Trumbull's wife, Amaryllis! A rollicking rib-tickler from Director, Jacques Tourneur (CAT PEOPLE, I WALKED WITH A ZOMBIE, THE LEOPARD MAN, CURSE OF THE DEMON) of all people! Highly recommended...

In ISLE OF THE DEAD, Boris Karloff (THE BODY SNATCHER, BEDLAM) plays Greek army General Nikolas Pherides. After arriving on the title island, Pherides finds himself trapped there after the plague strikes. We watch as his mind unravels, while he succumbs to an enemy he cannot see or defeat. This movie has a wonderful subtext of modern science vs. superstition and dread. It also deals w/ a woman's fear of being buried alive. Let's just say that her worst nightmare is realized! Director, Mark Robson, definitely gets across a sense of impending death and claustrophobic doom! Bleak and bleaker! Highly recommended...

THE LEOPARD MAN (1943) is about a psychopathic serial killer on the loose. Or is it a straightforward story concerning an escaped black panther / leopard? Director, Jacques Tourneur (CAT PEOPLE, I WALKED WITH A ZOMBIE, CURSE / NIGHT OF THE DEMON), has fashioned a darkly twisted tale that's years ahead of its time. Years before PSYCHO, we are shown the depths of human depravity, turning a man into a stalking, bestial predator.  The unlikely monster is hidden in plain sight, due to this person's apparent normality and gentle facade. Another Tourneur / Lewton masterpiece!...

I WALKED WITH A ZOMBIE stars Tom Conway (CAT PEOPLE, BRIDE OF THE GORILLA, THE ATOMIC SUBMARINE) as Paul Holland, a man whose wife, Jessica (Christine Gordon), is either mentally ill, or has actually been turned into a zombie. Director, Jacques Tourneur, packs this terror tale w/ loads of eerie sequences -including a riveting scene involving a nocturnal walk through the sugarcane fields and that damned human scarecrow!-  and an overall atmosphere of bleakness and dread! Producer, Val Lewton, hit gold w/ Tourneur, turning a cheeezy-sounding title into one of the greatest zombie films ever made! Only WHITE ZOMBIE can compete w/ this classic! Watch immediately...

The events in CURSE OF THE CAT PEOPLE take place four years after Irena's final trip to the panther cage- in CAT PEOPLE. Oliver and Alice are now married and have a daughter. The little girl is very imaginative, and has a "friend" whom no one else can see. She meets an old woman who lives in a big house nearby. The two become close, causing great pain for the woman's own, alienated, adult daughter. Oliver is increasingly worried about his daughter's over-active fantasy life, especially when she tells him that her imaginary friend's name is Irena! Fantasy and reality come together in the end. Instead of being a typical sequel, filled w/ rushed ideas and Hollywood garbage, COTCP takes a completely different direction from the original. It's a ghost story through the eyes of a child. A classic in its own right...

Oliver Reed (Kent Smith) was strolling through the zoo, minding his ow business, when suddenly, there she was, sketching a black panther. Her name was Irena (Simone Simon). Oliver was immediately captivated by her, unable to think of anyone / anything else. What was it about this shy young girl? What secrets floated behind those eyes? Oliver soon married Irena. That's when the trouble began. CAT PEOPLE is Tourneur's masterwork of love, longing, guilt, and fear. Irena is a tragic figure, doomed by her own inner terrors and torments. Oliver loves her, but cannot understand Irena's beliefs, or her obsessive dread over consummating their marriage. Does she really believe that she'll turn into a cat? How can she think this way and still be sane? Enter Dr. Judd (Tom Conway- I WALKED WITH A ZOMBIE), Irena's psychiatrist. He figures it's all in her head. Is it? Oliver turns to his friend, Alice (Jane Randolph) for solice. Irena, driven by suspicion and jealousy, reveals what she truly is. CAT PEOPLE uses strong characters and atmosphere to build suspense and tell the story. Irena is unforgettable! Highest recommendation...

Julien (Vincent Price- HOUSE OF WAX, THE MASQUE OF THE RED DEATH, THEATER OF BLOOD) keeps his brother, Edward (Alister Williamson), chained in a room in their mansion. Poor Edward went quite mad after being disfigured by a voodoo priest in Africa. Fortunately for Edward, he has friends who are willing to aid in his escape. By using more voodoo, they will give Edward the appearance of death, and whisk him away at the opportune moment. Easy-peasy. Wellll, unfortunately, these "friends" are more interested in money than in Ed's freedom! Just when you think things can't possibly get worse for him, dear brother Julien nails him into a coffin and buries him alive! After a serendipitous happenstance releases him from his grave, Edward winds up under the care of Dr. Newhartt (Christopher Lee- THE MUMMY, THE WHIP AND THE BODY, ISLAND OF THE BURNING DAMNED), who helps him recover physically, while, shockingly, his mind is completely gone. Edward does what anyone in his position would do, donning a red velvet mask, he becomes his own avenging angel, going on a killing spree! THE OBLONG BOX is a nice, ghoulish Gothic, perfectly suited for cold, damp nights...

TOWER OF LONDON has Vincent Price (HOUSE OF USHER, PIT AND THE PENDULUM, THE CONQUEROR WORM) as the utterly insane, homicidal Richard III. He will stop at nothing to secure his place on the throne of England. Anyone in his way is terminated expeditiously. Uh-Oh! Poor Richard never counted on being pestered by the ghosts of his victims! He's soon overrun by spooky spirits, bent on having him join their ranks! Another fantastic Vincent Price / Roger Corman collaboration! Price's Richard is gleefully packed w/ malice, mania, and murder! Highly recommended...

GODZILLA (GOJIRA) was meant, in its original form, as an analogy of the twin bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki (as well as US bomb tests in the South Pacific), ending Japan's involvement in World War 2. The monster is a representation of the horrors of nuclear / atomic holocaust, and its aftermath. Director, Honda, was ingenious in his use of the big lizard as a metaphor for his nation's greatest human tragedy. Obviously, America had to bring it stateside, soooo, scenes w/ Raymond Burr doing narration were added in order to tell us what's "really" going on, because we're too dense to possibly understand Honda's original idea. Unfortunately, much of the story's devastating power was lost in translation. GODZILLA: KING OF THE MONSTERS was born. If this is the only version -which I still love- you've ever seen, then I highly recommend the Japanese original as well. While the Americanized version is just a movie about the title monster running amok, it's a good one! I enjoy both films immensely...

Things you might want to know about THE RAVEN: Thing #1- No, it's not a "faithful" adaptation of the dark poem by Edgar Allen Poe. #2- Yes, it is a horror / comedy from Director, Roger Corman, so expect a lot of good, cheeezy fun! #3- Yes, both Vincent Price and Boris Karloff are great in this movie! Especially the classic "duel of the sorcerers" scene! Both men show their hammy, hilarious sides. So does Peter Lorre! #4- Yes, there's an actual raven, and it doth quoth a bit. #5- Jack Nicholson is as good in this as he is in THE TERROR. What can you say? He's Jack! Watch this right now, you won't be sorry...

In THE DEVIL WALKS AT MIDNIGHT (aka: THE DEVIL'S NIGHTMARE), seven tourists get stuck at a spooky castle for the night. Their host is a Baron / alchemist w/ a disturbing history / legacy. His family is cursed, and each room in the castle has seen a murder or two over the centuries.  Enter Erika Blanc as a mysterious visitor. She instantly steals the show as she slinks and slithers her way throughout the castle, seducing the unwary guests w/ their favorite, individual vices. Each person's particular appetite leads to their doom. Blanc is the perrrfect succubus / female demon, who has arrived in order to satisfy her hunger for destruction, and to please her master (hope you guessed his name!). The only hope seems to be a Priest who is able to resist the temptress' wiles, even when seeing her naked! A must-have for the Erica Blanc fanatic!...

KING KONG is more than a monster movie. Even though I love the stop-motion work by Willis O'Brien, all the adventure on Skull Island, and Kong's eventual New York rampage, there's more going on than simple action. KING KONG tells several tales, including the primal "man vs. beast", the environmental "nature vs. man's exploitation / destruction of it", and the obvious, forbidden love story between Kong and Ann Darrow (Fay Wray). The ferocity of Kong is matched by his protective, gentle stance toward her. The fact that O'Brien was able to animate a tiny model, and make it not only look huge, but also make it a living, sympathetic character in the film, is nearly miraculous! People cry when Kong meets his end, and they also know that he was ultimately exploited and abused, and suffered unto death, due to the greed of man. KING KONG is a morality tale that causes self-examination. Within that glued-on rabbit fur beats a real, living heart. So many decades after its original release, I still cry every damned time he climbs the Empire State Building...

Danny is a tad unusual, due to his having been exposed to radiation as a baby. When he and his grandfather encounter a group of campers in the woods, strange events occur. Simultaneously, a group of corporate thugs arrives, from the very same corporation that conducted the research that allegedly killed Danny's mother! Did you get all that? Well, unsurprisingly, the goons kill gramps, and it's up to Danny's still-living, rampaging mum to exact vengeance. Yep, she's a mutant! Oh yeah, there's a mutated rabbit-rat-thing roaming around as well. Blah-blah-blah! Ten years pass, Danny's an adult, and the movie doesn't improve one iota! Even the nudity is dull! PLUTONIUM BABY is a "Budget? What's A Budget?", ultra-schlock "horror" movie from 1987. Intolerable dialogue mixes w/ insufferable non-acting to create this toxic sludge of a "movie". The worst part is just how boring this thing is! My god! Not even the most desperate gorehundt will be able to endure this pile of stinking entrails! If Ed Wood had trained a monkey to use a movie camera, and the monkey had dreamed of making a film, but suffered a mind-scorching stroke while filming, this would be the end result! Enduring this is like swallowing a handful of angry bees! Don't do this to yourself!...

EL MONSTRO DEL MAR! (aka: MONSTRO!) is about three wild, insane, homicidal women, named Beretta (Nelli Scarlet), Blondie (Karli Madden), and Snowball (Kate Watts), out for a good time. Fans of Russ Meyer, especially his sublime FASTER PUSSYCAT KILL! KILL! will adore these women, even though they're a bit more on the sadistic / psychopathic side than Meyer might have dared to put on film. Not surprisingly, their idea of fun involves cold, bloody murder. After taking care of a pair of overly helpful gents, and taking their car, the terrible trio head out to the beach for a swim. What they don't know is that they've happened upon more than just another good time. Ignoring the cryptic warnings of a local old man, the girls settle in for a night of partying in a beach house, unaware of the lurking terror outside. With a new-found friend named Hannah (Kyrie Capri) in tow, the women rave on, while a group of fishermen is devoured nearby. It appears that a sea monster is hungry for human flesh! Will the three "man-killers" recognize the danger they're in, before it's too late? Have they finally met their match? EL MONSTRO DEL MAR! is a well-made, low-budget Australian film from writer / director Stuart Simpson. Very gory, it still manages to have a decent story-line. The monster itself is actually quite menacing! The gooshy finale -almost- enters into blessed DEAD ALIVE territory! Meanwhile, I like to think that the late, great Tura Satana looks down upon this film and smiles...

THE CREATURE WALKS AMONG US has the gill-man hunted down, captured, and brought to a compound belonging to the rich, and very odd, Dr. William Barton (Jeff Morrow- THIS ISLAND EARTH, KRONOS, THE GIANT CLAW). Barton turns the creature into a land-dwelling, air-breathing humanoid! Mayhem commences! Very different in mood and overall atmosphere from the two preceding CREATURE films, TCWAU is far more somber and introspective. As an object of pathos, the new "lung-man" is a brooding, pitiful beast, held behind an electric fence like a zoo attraction. Morrow's Barton is subtly eeevil, letting his sadistic nature out only a little at a time. Opposing him, is Dr. Thomas Morgan (Rex Reason- THIS ISLAND EARTH), his moral opposite. In the end, it's the creature that doles out the judgement on his tormentor. Though it's slow in spots, it remains a terrific finish to the CREATURE films...

THE BRIDE OF FRANKENSTEIN (1935) is, obviously, the sequel to 1931's FRANKENSTEIN. Director, James Whale returns, as do Colin Clive as Henry Frankenstein, and the inimitable Boris Karloff as the monster. The film opens w/ a gathering of Lord Byron, Percy Shelley, and his wife, Mary (Elsa Lanchester), discussing her legendary book. As the evening progresses, we learn that Mary has another story to tell. It's a continuation of her first tale. The scene switches to the familiar, burnt ruins of a certain windmill, where we discover that the monster is quite a bit healthier than we were led to believe! Enter Dr. Pretorius (Ernest Thesiger), who's tracked down Henry, in order to join forces on a little project. Pretorius has talents and ideas of his own, leading to a venture never dreamed of by Henry. Pretorius thinks it's time for a female version of Henry's creation. Meanwhile, the monster goes through its / his own dark night of the soul, encountering the wrath of the villagers he once terrorized. Escaping their clutches, the monster heads out toward freedom, and his date w/ destiny. The eventual meeting of monster and mate (Lanchester again) is nothing short of glorious! THE BRIDE OF FRANKENSTEIN is a fascinating movie, building on the melodramatic horror elements of the first. This time, much light and dark humor is added to the mix, giving BRIDE a strange, satiric flavor. Karloff gives more life and personality to his role, re-inventing it as he goes along. This all works together to make one of the greatest sequels ever released! While many see BRIDE as superior to FRANKENSTEIN, I see them as equals, each having different aspects that elevate them beyond mere horror, and into the realm of high art. Sheer genius...

FRANKENSTEIN, like DRACULA, is a film that transcends its genre, having become a masterpiece in its own right. Boris Karloff, an unquestionable legend of horror, literally becomes the monster, imbuing it / him with a humanity that belies the gruesome, murderous shell containing it. Karloff, like Lon Chaney Sr. before him, has a rare ability to not only portray a role, but to enter into it, becoming someone / thing other than himself. Beneath the incredible, iconic make-up, Karloff moves this shambling creation along, giving it life, just as it is shown on screen. When Henry Frankenstein (Colin Clive) shouts those immortal lines, "It's alive! Alive!", we absolutely believe him, because Karloff raises this creature from the dead! I don't believe that anyone else, save for the aforementioned Chaney, could possibly have made this work. Watch and see if you don't agree...

To call this movie "boring" would be like calling a super-massive black hole "a bit dense". Words lose their meaning in the face of such mind-deadening stuff as this! THE SNOW CREATURE is a sub-zero-budget "monster" movie, w/ a tall guy in fuzzy clothes standing in for the monster. He's supposed to be a yeti / bigfoot / abominable snowman, but is more like a wookie / teddy-man in need of a long bath. He kills someone, leading a group into the mountains to track him down. We get to see the creature dance back and forth, in and out of the shadows, over and over, until our skulls crack open. No kidding! Wilder -the guilty director- uses the same shot of the SC coming at us, then running it backward, some 13-14 times! Anyway, the beast somehow winds up back in Los Angeles (it had been in the Himalayas), escapes, and roams around aimlessly. Truly, the only experience comparable to watching this movie, would be to use anvils as cymbals, w/ your head in between them...

MONSTER MADNESS: MUTANTS, SPACE INVADERS, AND DRIVE-INS picks up where the first MM left off, taking us into the fantastic world of the 1950's! As the title implies, big changes were under way in Hollywood, and horror was mostly replaced by science fiction. DESTINATION MOON, THE MAN FROM PLANET X, and ROCKETSHIP XM were some early releases that ushered in the sci-fi explosion. The unknown aspect of outer space created a vast array of incredible story-lines- male astronauts captured by beautiful female aliens were popular scenarios, as in CAT WOMEN ON THE MOON. The UFO craze led to cinematic creations like EARTH VS. THE FLYING SAUCERS, PLAN 9 FROM OUTER SPACE, INVASION OF THE SAUCERMEN, and the classic THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL. The cold war and fear of nuclear annihilation were great influences on the movies of the 50's. Roger Corman's DAY THE WORLD ENDED is discussed as a good example of the atomic mutant film. THE THING FROM ANOTHER WORLD shows the lethal alien invader at its most terrifying. Giant people, reptiles, insects, invertebrates, etc., roamed the Earth. THE AMAZING COLOSSAL MAN, TARANTULA, THEM!, etc. are examined. Ray Harryhausen's stop-motion work is also given its due. The influence of CREATURE FROM THE BLACK LAGOON is undeniable. Big pictures like THIS ISLAND EARTH and FORBIDDEN PLANET are contrasted, w/ FORBIDDEN PLANET seen as the more serious, influential film. The McCarthy era's anti-communist paranoia is shown w/ INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS. Fans of FIEND WITHOUT A FACE, HIDEOUS SUN DEMON, PLAN 9, LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS and FAMOUS MONSTERS OF FILMLAND magazine will love their segments! Drive-in theaters are covered for their horror / teenager exploitation potential. I WAS A TEENAGE WEREWOLF, I WAS A TEENAGE FRANKENSTEIN, and TEENAGE CAVEMAN were naturals for the then-emerging teen market! Interviews w/ Rex Reason, Anne Francis, Yvette Vickers, Kevin McCarthy, Robert Clarke, Dolores Fuller, Roger Corman, and many more, round out this wonderful tribute / documentary. Highly recommended to all fans of the genre...

The teaming of Director, Tod Browning (FREAKS) and Bela Lugosi is one of those legendary cinematic "miracles". The look and feel of DRACULA is remarkably bleak, especially the castle sequences toward the beginning. Lugosi IS the role he plays, embodying the Count w/ an eerie, carnal ferocity, like a barely-controlled animal that could leap and tear its prey to pieces at any second! There are shots of him simply standing still, giving off some sort of aura I've never seen in any other film, horror or otherwise! His face takes on a mystical, otherworldly quality that transcends mere acting.Though NOSFERATU was itself a masterpiece, DRACULA takes that film's more feral, rat-spider-like creature of the night, and exposes a wicked sensuality within the beast. Damn, I love this movie! Co-stars Dwight Frye as the haywire, crackpot Renfield, and Edward Van Sloan as Van Helsing. Helen Chandler is also good as Nina...

THE WOLF MAN is, of course, the film that propelled Lon Chaney Jr. into the upper echelon of horror icons. Unlike Karloff or Lugosi, Chaney brings a more down-to-earth, natural approach to his role as Lawrence Talbot. Attacked by a werewolf, he begins his accursed life of murderous, full moon transformations. Loaded w/ dark, heavy atmosphere, THE WOLF MAN is one of the rare 1940's Universal films that stands alongside the stellar releases of the 30's. Claude Rains plays Talbot's father, while Bela Lugosi plays the gypsy named... Bela! Plus, Maria Ouspenskaya is unforgettable as Bela's tiny mum, Maleva! Highly recommended...

THE MUMMY'S HAND is an interesting film, in that, while it's the first sequel to the original Karloff classic, it's also the least serious, more light-hearted of the MUMMY films. With Dick Foran and Wallace Ford in full Abbott and Costello mode, we find the two, as archaeologists, trying to find the tomb of Ananka. After teaming up w/ an equally comical magician and his daughter (Cecil Kelloway and Peggy Moran), they set out on their expedition. Obviously, problems must arise, in the form of the nefarious Professor Andoheb (George Zucco), who also happens to be an eeevil high priest and servant of the mummy Kharis (Tom Tyler)! In addition to Kharis, Tanna leaves, as an agent of eternal life, are introduced here. Silly from start to finish, THE MUMMY'S HAND is still the most fun of all the sequels...

Some folks don't care for the original THE MUMMY, calling it "slow", "tedious", and / or "boring". Well, for these viewers, I would recommend the sequels, which are chock-full of spooky, lumbering, killer mummy action! THE MUMMY is a showcase for Boris Karloff, whether in the moldy bandages or out, he's superb throughout! His Imhoptep is mysterious, sinister, and sympathetic. The infamous "stare" scene alone, is enough to establish his horror icon status forever! Karloff was / is the only such actor on the same level as Lon Chaney sr., and that's no small achievement! His eternal love for his lost soul-mate, for whom he paid the ultimate price, is riveting. Zita Johann is Helen Grosvenor, the seeming reincarnation of Imhoptep's only desire. Together, they are the perfect horror movie romance! Tragic and doom-ridden, THE MUMMY is essential viewing...

In SON OF FRANKENSTEIN, Basil Rathbone plays title character, Wolf Von Frankenstein. Rathbone nearly explodes w/ histrionic energy! To call his performance "over-the-top" would be like calling the Pacific ocean "wet"! He's amazing! Also, Boris Karloff returns as the monster, this time in a cool, furry shirt! Bela Lugosi is the sinister Ygor, who has gained control of the creature. Lugosi spouts great, verbose dialogue, even through big, fake teeth! Lionel Atwill is along for the fun as Inspector Krogh. Many of the classic scenes in SON were parodied beautifully by Mel Brooks in his masterpiece, YOUNG FRANKENSTEIN. Much enjoyment is to be had when viewing the two films back to back! Watch now!...

MONSTER MADNESS: THE GOLDEN AGE OF HORROR tracks the history of horror movies, along w/ the birth of Universal studios under Carl Laemmle sr. From the silent 1925 PHANTOM OF THE OPERA and THE HUNCHBACK OF NOTRE DAME w/ Lon Chaney sr., through the 1930's and DRACULA, FRANKENSTEIN, BRIDE OF FRANKENSTEIN, THE MUMMY, DRACULA, THE BLACK CAT, etc. w/ Lugosi and Karloff. Peter Lorre (M, MAD LOVE), Frederick March (DR. JECKYLL AND MR. HYDE), Charles Laughton (ISLAND OF LOST SOULS) are also discussed. Horror / sci-fi Special FX, beginning w/ KING KONG, A TRIP TO THE MOON, METROPOLIS, etc., are noted. Next, the monster movie sequels get their due. The 1940's bring the decline of Universal, and the rise of Val Lewton, w/ classics like THE BODY SNATCHER (Karloff and Lugosi together again!). Meanwhile, Universal put out the "Monster Rally" films, w/ all of the big name creatures in combo roles, battling it out, w/ cheeezey results. This is epitomized by the Abbott and Costello / Monster comedies of the period. This is a wonderful documentary for all monster / horror film fans!...

Dominant, unbalanced "Psychic" medium, Myra (Kim Stanley), and her long-suffering husband, Billy (Richard Attenborough), live in her huge old house. Myra carries out her seances there, making a meager living. However, she dreams of bigger things, and has a foolproof plan to improve life for herself, and yes, for Billy as well. After much preparation, the time has come to enact her scheme. Billy does the dirty work, snatching the little girl, Amanda, from right in front of her school building! After some unexpected resistance, he whisks her back to the house. Myra will have her way. She will use the girl to get the income she deserves, as a simple means to an end. The ransom letter is sent, leaving no room for uncertainty. What could possibly go wrong? After all, Myra has a superior "gift", a very real ability. So, why is Billy so very concerned? SEANCE ON A WET AFTERNOON is a fascinating psychological thriller, fueled by the genuineness of the main characters. Ms. Stanley's Myra is as pitiable as she is coldly terrifying, while Attenborough plays Billy w/ just the right amount of downtrodden loss of spirit. At times, one almost believes in Myra's "supernatural" sight, in spite of everything. It's even tempting to hope, if only half-heartedly, that her plot is successful. The final seance is gripping, unnerving, and terribly sad. Patrick Magee is excellent in his short role as Inspector Walsh. This movie is a definite must-see for lovers of dark suspense in particular, or classic cinema in general...

Well, it just had to happen. FRANKENSTEIN MEETS THE WOLFMAN is one of those blatantly absurd, yet absolutely enjoyable films, created after someone said, "Hey! Let's find a way to get these two monsters to fight each other!". Forget about the original films and their stories. Bah! Who needs a plot? FMTW has Lon jr. reprising his fuzzy Larry Talbot role, now trying to find a way to be exterminated, in order to end his accursed, lycanthropic torment. This leads him to his old gypsy friend, Maleva (Maria Ouspenkaya!), who leads him to Dr. Frankenstein, who turns out to be dead. Luckily, the castle ruins remain, and someone tall, green, and grimacing, is trapped in the catacombs below! Enter the lumbering Frankenstein's monster, now played by Bela Lugosi! The Wolfman growls and the monster grunts, and the epic battle is on! Of course, you'll have to wait a while, since the ultimate confrontation is saved for the explosive finale. Zany fun for the creature fanatic! Even Dwight Frye makes an appearance!...

COCAINE FIENDS concerns a guy named Eddie, and his hopeless search for his "drugged-out" sister, Jane (Lois January). Jane became a shriveled up sleaze-bucket after being introduced to a useless drug-peddler named Nick (Noel Madison). Along the way, Eddie himself is given cocaine by a girl he meets, sending him deep into the bowels of depravity! Oh, if only these 30 year old "kids" had steered clear of Satan's nose-powder! Now, there may be no hope! Watch and shudder! Extra points for spotting the rodent wallpaper in the "Dead Rat Cafe". Thankfully, though it does drag a bit, it's only about an hour long...

Dr. Cameron (George Zucco) is a scientist who's been experimenting on his handyman, Petro (Glenn Strange), by injecting him w/ a serum that transforms him into a ravenous werewolf by night! Cameron's been using wolf's blood (funny, since the creature in his lab cage looks suspiciously like a coyote) to make his serum. Petro thinks he's been sleepwalking, when all along, he's been on a murderous rampage! Cameron's been using the poor sap, in order to exact vengeance upon the other scientists who were critical of his ideas. You see, Cameron wants to create an army of werewolves to help out w/ the war effort! Zucco looks stern and crazed throughout, while Strange does his best to keep his dignity, under the poof-y wig and cheeeze-tastic makeup he's forced to wear. MAD MONSTER isn't a total wash-out, but don't expect a lost werewolf classic...

Ted Osbourne (Phillip Reed) and Carol Lane (Virginia Grey- TARGET EARTH) charter a ship to take them to the uncharted island of the title. The couple is in search of actual, living dinosaurs! Along w/ Captain Tarnowski (Barton Maclane), his crew, including John Fairbanks (Richard Denning- CREATURE FROM THE BLACK LAGOON, CREATURE WITH THE ATOM BRAIN, DAY THE WORLD ENDED, THE BLACK SCORPION), they head for the high seas. After an attempted mutiny, it's clear sailing to the island of living fossils. Yep, decades before Crichton and Spielberg, UNKNOWN ISLAND covered some very similar ground- minus the cloning of course! -Obviously, even this film's release date (1948) is relatively recent, when compared to the silent 1925 classic, THE LOST WORLD (based on Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's novel). Even so, it proves that there's nothing new under the sun- Upon hitting the beach, the adventure begins. Many familiar, giant reptiles make their appearance, devouring various, expendable crew-members. Of course, the friction between the humans proves to be almost as dangerous. There's no O'Brien /  Harryhausen stop-motion this time, just puppets and men in rubber dino-suits. Still, a worthy addition to the dinosaur / monster movie genre...

BRIDE OF KILLER NERD takes the emphasis off of Harold Kunkle (Toby Radloff), and puts it on his new girlfriend, Sally (Heidi Lohr). Equally backward, Sally is just as socially excluded as Harold. Her ultimate transformation into a murderous maniac is a wonder to behold! BRIDE is a bit darker than the original KILLER NERD, making it seem more interesting / bleak than it was probably meant to be. Obviously, expect beyond-terrible "acting", sub-sub-zero-budget production values, and a lot of gory, goofy fun...

In the twisted tradition of TOXIC AVENGER, TROMA studios unleashes KILLER NERD! Harold Kunkle (the inimitable Toby Radloff) is the pitiful, picked-on creature of the title, pushed to an eventual spree of bloody violence. Kunkle is an obvious basket case, suffering from many deficits. Radloff plays Kunkle so convincingly, that it's hard to believe he could possibly memorize his lines! His performance goes far beyond wooden, into petrified forest territory! With no production values whatsoever, KILLER NERD's "genius" lies in its over-use of its anti-charismatic star. Watch and be astonished!...

Director, Ishiro Honda (GODZILLA, RODAN) made this alien invasion epic from 1957. THE MYSTERIANS gets going right away, when a chain of catastrophic events occur, causing mayhem and many deaths. During their investigation, a team of scientists and soldiers encounter a titanic robot on a rampage. Said robot resembles a gargantuan aardvark in a metallic baseball catcher's uniform. Look out! It shoots laser beams from its googly eyeballs! Luckily, the military blows it up. Uh-oh! Suddenly, activity is discovered on the dark side of the Moon! The rise of THE MYSTERIANS has begun! Lovers of Japanese monster movies in general, and Honda films in particular, will find much enjoyment here!  The earthlings are told by the invaders that they require human women to marry! They must re-invigorate the old MYSTERIAN gene pool! Obviously, the women must be young and extremely beautiful. Several prime females have already been kidnapped. Is the Earth doomed to a fate resulting in a pretty woman shortage? No way! Let the war commence! Who cares if THE MYSTERIANS have superior technology and firepower? Our babe supply is at stake! Now, all mankind must unite, in a final battle for the planet! From THE MYSTERIANS' zit-like terror dome, to the groovy "Earth-Force" battle-cruiser, this movie is a flat-out blast! Watch immediately!...

THE HEARSE is a rather slow-moving supernatural mystery / thriller w/ Trish Van Devere as the central character, Jane. She moves into her dead aunt's house, only to find herself plagued by a town full of snotty folks, a cranky lawyer (Joseph Cotten- THE ABOMINABLE DR. PHIBES, LADY FRANKENSTEIN), and the title vehicle. While not the best horror movie I've ever seen, it's not altogether terrible. There are a couple of -relatively- creepy moments, and an explosive finale! Worth a watch on a lazy afternoon...

DR. TERROR'S HOUSE OF HORRORS is a 5-segment anthology film from Amicus studios. Five men on a train encounter the mysterious Dr. Schreck (Peter Cushing- THE FLESH AND THE FIENDS, HORROR EXPRESS) of the title. He tells each man's future w/ a deck of Tarot cards. Story #1 concerns an ancient manor, a werewolf, and a family curse. Story #2 is about a jazz musician who pisses off a voodoo god, inciting its wrath. The third tale is best described as a killer plant / vine movie (sort of a cousin of DAY OF THE TRIFFIDS). The fourth installment stars Christopher Lee (THE SKULL, THE OBLONG BOX) as a pompous art critic, plagued by an artist's (Michael Gough- HORRORS OF THE BLACK MUSEUM, KONGA, HORROR HOSPITAL) disembodied extremity. The final segment stars Donald Sutherland (INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS '78) as a newlywed whose bride just might be a vampire. The wrap-around story winds things up w/ a beautifully bleak, "twist" finale! DTHOH is my favorite anthology film. Give me this, ASYLUM, and TALES FROM THE CRYPT, and I'm good! A proper DVD release was long overdue...

An orbiting satellite goes through THE FLAME BARRIER, causing it to crash in the dense jungles of Mexico. Meanwhile, Carol Dahlmann (Kathleen Crowley- TARGET EARTH) hires Dave Hollister (Arthur Franz- INVADERS FROM MARS, MONSTER ON THE CAMPUS, THE ATOMIC SUBMARINE) and his brother to help her find her lost husband. She fears for him, since he's gone in search of the missing satellite. The trio set out on their trek, encountering many perils along the way, including wildlife, such as Mexican monkeys (?!) and hyenas (??!!). Of course, there's the "big snake on a tree limb" scene as well. They also encounter a tribe of Hollywood Indians in matching wigs. Onward they go, deeper into the unforgiving foliage. More be-wigged, Hollywood Indians appear, just in time to be enlisted as baggage-carriers! Amazingly, Mrs. Dahlmann's hair remains full and manageable, in spite of the jungle heat! Hey, wasn't there a satellite out here somewhere? And what about the Hollywood Indians that keep melting to death? Romance blooms, so I guess Mrs. D's forgotten all about her husband! Oh look! A chimpanzee! THE FLAME BARRIER is a typical jungle adventure, disguised as a sci-fi epic. As such, it is fairly interesting, especially when the reason behind the melting Indians is finally revealed. A novel idea for sure! Killer, amorphous blob-lovers will be ecstatic! A worthwhile watch for the 50's schlock fanatic...

In FUTUREWORLD, the sequel to WESTWORLD, Peter Fonda (RACE WITH THE DEVIL) plays investigative newspaper reporter, Chuck Browning. When a source, w/ information about the WESTWORLD disaster, is murdered, Browning is compelled to look into the Delos resort. Delos is trying to improve its image after the catastrophe of the first film. Browning finds himself competing w/ television reporter, Tracy Ballard (Blythe Danner). Of course, the two decide to join forces in order to get the Delos story. As in WESTWORLD, there are three separate sections in the resort complex. This time, it's MEDIEVALWORLD, SPAWORLD, and the title resort. Browning and Ballard are soon "blasting off"  for their "safe", simulated adventure! The reporters discover quickly that something is obviously being covered up. Their quest leads them into the computerized bowels of the complex, where they uncover a vast conspiracy! The first two thirds of this movie are actually pretty dull, picking up a bit for the finale, where a familiar face returns (yep, Yul Brynner makes an obligatory appearance in an utterly absurd "dream" sequence). While the cheeeze-factor is sky-high, especially in regard to anything attempting to appear "futuristic", FUTUREWORLD does try to make the best of its lesser, "follow-up" status. Unfortunately, it simply isn't all that intriguing or exciting. Neither Fonda nor Danner seem all that enthused about their roles, though Delos technician, Dr. Schneider (John P. Ryan- IT'S ALIVE 1 and 2) is suitably creepy, and Arthur Hill (THE ANDROMEDA STRAIN) is serviceable as the overly-kind, Dale Coba-like Delos executive, Duffy. Though FUTUREWORLD isn't altogether terrible, it certainly lacks the fun, re-watch-ability of the original...

David Gale (RE-ANIMATOR) stars as Dr. Blake, the host of the INDIVIDUAL THINKING tv show. Blake is just a front for an eeevil alien brain -sort of a combination of the critters in FIEND WITHOUT A FACE and THE BRAIN FROM PLANET AROUS- that is causing mass hallucinations. This odious monster wants to take over our Earth by turning us into mindless tele-zombies! Hmmm, hasn't this already happened in reality? Anyway, the brain-beasty is hysterical, and David Gale nearly explodes w/ over-the-top goodness! Thought he was great in RE-ANIMATOR? Well, he's absolutely rabid here! Watch this right this minute!...

JOURNEY TO THE SEVENTH PLANET has John Agar (THE BRAIN FROM PLANET AROUS, ATTACK OF THE PUPPET PEOPLE) as a Captain Kirk-ish astronaut on a UN (?!) space mission in that distant year of 2001. With his commander and crew, Agar sets out to explore the planet Uranus. Unbeknownst to them, a strange life-form (aka: giant green brain-monster w/ one eye) has read their minds during their arrival on Uranus, and recreated a familiar Earth landscape from their memories. It has also populated the place w/ beautiful uberbabes, including the eye-popping Greta Thyssen! OK, I want to go to Uranus! Right now! Anyway, the big green brain creates a giant rat beast and a big tarantula to attack them. John Agar smirks throughout. A priceless addition to any sci-fi schlock collection!...

INVISIBLE INVADERS "stars" John Carradine (BLUEBEARD, BIGFOOT, THE SENTINEL) as a scientist who blows himself up, only to be re-animated / possessed by an invisible alien entity. He is used as a messenger to warn Earth of an impending invasion. Well, the "invasion" mostly consists of stock footage of buildings burning or crumbling. The highlight has the dead rising from their graves, shambling along somewhat convincingly. Yep, it's a zombie holocaust! Meanwhile, another scientist, his cute daughter, her whiney boyfriend, and an army major (John Agar- TARANTULA, HAND OF DEATH, NIGHT FRIGHT) seal themselves in an underground facility and frantically search for a way to thwart the alien onslaught. Not bad for low-budget, 50's sci-fi cheeeze...

SNOW BEAST (2011) is the -sort of- remake of the original frozen cheeeze-log, of the same name, from 1977. John Schneider (THE CURSE, CONJURER) stars as wildlife researcher, Jim Harwood, who takes his teen daughter, Emmy (Danielle Chuchran), along to Canada on a research project. He and his team set out to do their work, unaware that a a huge yeti-monster is on a rampage, slaughtering innocent humans. Of course, the divorced Harwood is accompanied by a beautiful colleague, named Marci (Kari Hawker). Could romance be far off? Not if the SNOW BEAST can tear them apart first! Meanwhile, Emmy gets herself into various scrapes, committing acts of hijinks and frivolity. Oh yeah, and the SNOW BEAST continues to lower the skier / snow-boarder population in the area, in bloody ways. This is no plodding, "slow" beast either! This thing can move! While not the scariest or most realistic-looking creature, the SB does have a certain charm. It looks a lot like a very angry version of the Bumble Snow Monster from RUDOLF THE RED-NOSED  REINDEER! Yukon Cornelius would certainly have his hands full w/ this fuzzy fiend! This is an odd film, in that it has its sudden death scenes, interspersed w/ touching father / daughter moments. It's almost like a Hallmark film w/ added gore! Very bizarre indeed. Still, not a bad way to waste an evening in front of the fireplace... P.S.- Remember, "Bumbles bounce!"...

After opening w/ a blank screen, accompanied by a narrator reciting a "protective spell", BURN WITCH, BURN! (aka: NIGHT OF THE EAGLE) begins. College professor, Norman Taylor (Peter Wyngarde) is a logical, non-superstitious man. He scoffs at all things outside of the normal, natural world. This proves challenging, since much of Norman's work and social circle consists of practitioners of the occult! Of course, Norman's cynical attitude terrifies his wife, Tansy (Janet Blair), as she's also a firm believer in witchcraft. To Norman it's all preposterous rubbish. As his wife reveals her true convictions and fears concerning the other faculty members, he sets out to prove her wrong. It's Norman's rationality vs. what he sees as absurd hocus pocus. After gathering and destroying all of Tansy's protection charms and magical objects, Norman's luck suddenly changes, and his life takes an inexplicable turn for the worse. Norman soon finds himself up against forces he can neither explain nor defeat. BURN WITCH, BURN! is one of the best movies of its type, making the most of an overarching sense of dread and inevitable doom! The black and white filming only adds to the bleak atmosphere. This is especially evident during the nightmarish finale! Co-stars Margaret Johnston as the perrrfectly eeevil Flora Carr! Highly recommended for fans of horror and supernatural suspense...

WATCH THE SKIES! is a hit and miss collection of three minor sci-fi entries. Movie #1> THE COSMIC MAN- A UFO crash-lands on Earth, causing great concern for the military. A scientist is called in to examine the craft. He discovers a free-floating orb, hovering about six feet off the ground. Of course, the Colonel in charge sees it as a weapon, or a way to dominate space travel. Unbeknownst to anyone, a visitor from another world (John Carradine- INVISIBLE INVADERS, THE ASTRO ZOMBIES, THE HOWLING) has come via the orb. Why is he here? What does he want? At first, he spends his time as a shadow-figure (a cropped-in negative), silently creeping about, causing panic. Eventually, he takes on a more "human" appearance. Trouble starts when the military attempts to take control of the spaceship. Soon, THE COSMIC MAN reveals his agenda. This is another movie that owes a great deal to THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL. Movie #2> THE FLYING SAUCER- An international playboy (Mikel Conrad) and his nurse (Pat Garrison) are sent to a cabin in Alaska to learn the secrets behind THE FLYING SAUCER. Things bog down to a crawl, as the movie turns into a nature film. Absolutely nothing of interest occurs until 40+ minutes into the "action". In the meantime, we are treated to endless footage of the Alaskan hinterlands! While not a bad story, there's just too much padding, turning this into one looonng, dull experience! Movie #3> STRANGER FROM VENUS- Pretty much the British version of THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL, it contains many similar elements, including an alien visitor (Helmut Dantine) w/ an agenda / ultimatum for the wayward Earthlings. It even co-stars Patricia Neal (THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL) as the alien's only human friend! Certainly, STRANGER FROM VENUS is a smaller, lower-budgeted film, but it still manages to get its point across. So, this three movie set has two good movies and one that could have been much better. Worth owning for the sci-fi fanatic...

BITE ME! Stars the ever-lovely and talented Misty Mundae as Crystal, a stripper at the STRIP-O-SAURUS club. All is well, until a crate of bio-engineered pot arrives, which also happens to be full of blood-thirsty, mutant spider monsters! Can Crystal and the other ladies defeat the creeping horde. while a moralistic DEA agent tries to arrest them? How will this terror ultimately affect their dance routines? BITE ME! is a wonderfully silly horror spoof by Director, Brett Piper, w/ some nice stop-motion critters and obligatory nakedness...

After being savagely raped by a hideous mutant, a woman gives birth to its offspring. Seventeen years later, junior returns to the town of his conception, and begins hunting down various town-folk. Grisly murders abound, while the teen also begins a strange metamorphosis into something more like his dad! The town's darkest secrets are revealed, and the guilty are doomed! THE BEAST WITHIN is gruesome, grotesque, and great! The final transformation scene is quite memorable, as the special FX reach their splatter-y peak! Co-stars Ronny Cox (DELIVERANCE, THE CAR, ROBOCOP), R.G. Armstrong (RACE WITH THE DEVIL, EVILSPEAK, CHILDREN OF THE CORN), and L.Q. Jones (THE BROTHERHOOD OF SATAN)...

Okay, almost half of SILENT NIGHT DEADLY NIGHT PART 2 is made up of "flashback" footage from the -absolutely superior- original SNDN. So, what we get is about half of a sequel that was made strictly to cash in on the first one! This is a shame, as the last 10-15 minutes are fairly suspenseful! If only they'd built on that, instead of rushed out this abomination! Ugh... It's coal in everyone involved w/ this movie's stockings this year...

Watching this now, it's difficult to believe that it was so controversial when it debuted in theaters, back in 1984. M.A.S.S. (Mothers Against Slaying Santas) were out in force, protesting what they saw as a movie that just might bring about Armageddon. In reality, SILENT NIGHT DEADLY NIGHT is just another slasher film w/ a holiday theme. The killer Claus, far from being blasphemous, is absurd, but perfectly suited for the subject matter. This is a story about bloody vengeance against those on this not-so-jolly-old-elf's naughty list. The whole mood of it lets us know immediately, in no uncertain terms, that this is NOT to be taken seriously! Good Lord, Linnea Quigley's (THE RETURN OF THE LIVING DEAD, CREEPOZOIDS, NIGHT OF THE DEMONS, GRADUATION DAY, etc.) "death-by-antlers" scene alone should tip you off to the silliness of the whole affair! Sheesh! Just relax, sit back, and put some mindless mania in your stocking this year...

Opening w/ the release of an alien TV signal from across the universe, and one of THE BEST theme songs of any cheeeze-a-thon ever produced, TERRORVISION is on!  Swingers, Stanley (Garrit Graham- IT'S ALIVE 3: ISLAND OF THE ALIVE, CHOPPING MALL) and Racquel (Mary Woronov- SILENT NIGHT BLOODY NIGHT, DEATH RACE 2000, NIGHT OF THE COMET, EATING RAOUL) and their family are busy living their suburban lives, unaware that their new satellite dish is now picking up the malevolent, alien signal. Strange things begin happening when Grandpa messes w/ the TV controls, bringing a mutant life-form into the house! Grandpa's bunker / bomb shelter is awesomeness! His gooshy, head-imploding death is a masterpiece for the ages! When Stan and Racquel bring another couple home for some carnal fun, the real mayhem begins! Their machine-gun-toting son Sherman, his dizzy sister Suzy (Diane Franklin), and her dimwit boyfriend, O.D., add to the hilarity. Can horror hostess, Medusa (Jennifer Richards) save the day? Nothing in TERRORVISION is even remotely serious. It has a sort of dreamlike quality, that makes the humor and glop go together like liver and ice cream! Graham and Woronov are brilliant in their absurd roles. Lovers of idiotic 80's movies, filled w/ ghoulish goulash will be ecstatic! Be prepared for utter weirdness...

QUEEN OF BLOOD (aka: FLIGHT TO A FAR PLANET) is directed by horror-meister, Curtis Harrington (NIGHT TIDE, WHAT'S THE MATTER WITH HELEN?, WHOEVER SLEW AUNTIE ROO?, THE KILLING KIND, THE DEAD DON'T DIE). After receiving a message from an alien race, the Earth awaits the arrival of its first extra-terrestrial visitors. Instead, a probe arrives and reveals that the aliens have crash-landed on Mars. Earth scrambles to put together a Mars mission, to investigate the fate of the distant travelers. Some snappy special FX, and some "borrowed" sound effects (From WAR OF THE WORLDS and FORBIDDEN PLANET), indicate that the mission is underway. Blasting off from a moon base, the astronauts, including Dennis Hopper (NIGHT TIDE), locate the alien spaceship, and enter it, finding only one occupant, and he's dead! A second mission, this time w/ John Saxon (CANNIBAL APOCALYPSE, BLACK CHRISTMAS, A NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET) aboard, is dispatched in a hurry. Saxon and company find a comatose female alien (Florence Marly) and rescue her. Saxon joins the first mission, and the QUEEN OF BLOOD regains consciousness. Green, beautiful, and mysterious, the title character is both eerie and alluring. Ms. Marly pulls off a predatory air w/ ease. Without a word, she devours those around her w/ her eyes. Not surprisingly, she has a bewitching affect on the males of the crew. Horror occurs when the QOB begins to slake her thirst. This is an excellent example of horror / sci-fi from 1966. A fantastic twist on the vampire legend, w/ a nifty, doomsday finale! Saxon is believable in his heroic role. Co-stars Basil Rathbone, pretty much reprising the same role he played in VOYAGE TO THE PREHISTORIC PLANET, stuck in the lunar command center. Also, watch for Forrest J. Ackerman as Rathbone's assistant. Highly recommended...

We have a lot of regular coconut oil, which is generally solid at room temperature.  This is a nice alternative - fractionated coconut oil in liquid form.This makes a great carrier oil for blending with essentials oils.  So if you are an EO fan like myself, this is a great product to have on hand.Great for massage and moisturizing skin.  I use coconut oil all the time, but it's not always the most convenient to have to scoop out hardened coconut oil, whereas this you can pour/drip on your skin.  I even use this on my face after showering, but it is great for hands, feet, legs, and more.I have even used this on my daughter's hair, which is extremely thick and frizzy.  I use a little on my hands, rub my palms together, and apply to her hair.  Makes her hair look shiny and manageable!The bottle is amber colored helping maintain freshness.I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

My kids spend a lot of time in the water, so a swim band seems to be a useful idea to help reduce swim ear.  This is simply a thin neoprene band that Velcros around your child's head.The size medium fits the head of my 9 year old, so not adult size, by any means.Easy to get on and off since it has a Velcro closure.My children found that is also doubles as a blind fold.  (Imagination is great!)I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

Our kids spend a lot of time in the water, so a swim cap is useful.This is stronger and stretchier than most WM brand caps.Designed with extra room for your ears.  My teenager who has waist length hair can get all of her hair into the cap, which is great.  Means less tangling and mess with hair!Easy to put on and take off, but creates an insane amount of static.I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

I love tea, so I couldn't pass up a sampler of teas.  These teas come in a little cardboard tray that slides out of a cover, and there is also a little white cardboard tray over the tray.There are ten tea varieties in the box and each comes sealed in a foil envelope.  You tear off the top but the envelopes are resealable.I like the varieties, which include black, green, oolong, white, and chai.  I am interested in trying most although there are one or two I might pass off to a friend.The teas are all loose, so I use them in my tea infuser.The teas I have tried taste good, but not phenomenal.  For example, the Jasmine tea.  Jasmine is usually a favorite of mine because it is so fragrant and floral, but this seemed on the weaker side and the bag was labeled that it was picked in 2014.  Although I don't really mind, I'm not sure I would want to be giving or getting it as a gift if labeled that the tea is over a year old.  I think the teas are kept decently fresh in the packaging, so who knows if it is the age or if the tea is just weaker than I expected.Overall, a nice set of teas especially if you want to sample different kinds.  Also good to have on hand for if you have guests - I can never seem to keep track of what kinds of tea people are going to want!I received a discount on this product for my honest review.

I am a big fan of children's products that are made from wood and not plastic.  This is an adorable kitchen that has lots of great features and is a great alternative to a plastic kitchen.The kitchen assembles easily, as everything is carefully labeled and the instruction manual is clearly printed on large paper.  They really did a great job of taking out any guesswork in assembly.  The pieces fit together well and there were no issues - all you need is a screwdriver.I will warn that the box does have a picture of the kitchen on it - so be careful if you are ordering this as a gift.There are so many features to this kitchen, from an oven to a microwave, sink, and shelf space.  I like having the extra space for accessories or whatnot, as we have had another kitchen that does not have any spot to stash things.There are a few accessories, like a spatula and some food jars.  A bit random to have a spatula as your only cooking accessory, but no problem as it keeps the kids busy!This kitchen is a nice, solid toy and offers so much imaginary play time.  I love the classic look of this, without plastic and lights and sound effects.  It is a perfect toy to spark your child's creativity.I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

My girls don't have an 18" doll, but they love their stuffed animals and this bed is perfect.  They have been asking for a doll bed for a while and they thoroughly enjoy this mini bed!The bed came carefully packaged.  There is a picture of the doll bed on the box, so be careful if you are ordering this as a gift and you don't want the surprise to be ruined.Assembly is very easy.  The bed comes with a large, nicely printed manual on 8.5"x11" paper, and you just need a screwdriver.  The bed goes together quickly and it only took me a short time to put it together without issue.The bed comes with a white "mattress", and a nice satin bed set including a pillow and comforter.  I love the colors, pattern, and the overall look of the set with the bed.The bed is a nice quality, but I would just be careful that your child is careful with it and doesn't sit in the bed!  We have another solid wood doll bed for our older daughter, and the kids have sat and stood in it (despite me telling them not to).  This Olivia's Little World bed would not be able to handle that kind of weight!Overall, a cute, well-made set!I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

My daughter likes to read in bed, and she had a cheap reading light that broke, so we got this as a replacement.This is more or less your typical clip-on reading light, but it also has a charger you can connect to USB, which sets it aside from other lights we have had.The unit takes 3 AAA batteries, which are easy to install.The light has two settings, with nice bright LED lights.  You turn it on with a button on the top of the light.The clip is easy to use.  My daughter's bed has a really thick top rail, so the clip has to be able to fit on to the vertical bars in the headboard, and it is no problem to fit this on, plus it has some foam padding so that the clip stays secure and doesn't damage furniture.Overall a perfect light for reading at night.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

We do a lot of camping and spending time outdoors, and I love the idea of a portable hammock.This hammock is easy to set up, and you need to find two trees at an ideal distance apart.The hammock is made from a nylon material, and I like the 'natural', earthy colors.The recommendation is to sit sideways in it, not lengthwise, but I think it is based on comfort.This product all fits nicely into a nylon bag, which is nice, as I have had other hammocks that do not fit everything into the bag.  When you are camping or traveling, it would be too easy to lose track of stuff that doesn't fit into the bag.The kids loved this hammock so much that there wasn't much opportunity for mom or dad!  I wouldn't mind having another one of these for when we go camping, because it is nice to have a comfortable place to lounge.  I love getting some relaxation in with a good book, and this hammock would be perfect!I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

I got this for my friend's son, and he was thrilled to play with this set.This is a cute pretend tool set, and there are lots of different accessories and tools to play with.  It keeps little ones engaged with lots of bright colors, shapes, and activities.The great part is that all the pieces store right inside the little chair/bench, so you don't have pieces all over the place.  Not to mention the frustration of not being able to find a part when your child wants to play!The case/chair is small and compact, at just over a foot long at the widest point.  The size and storage make it a good toy for traveling, like when visiting relatives.I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

My kids love playing with their dolls and stuffed animals and were super excited about this play kitchen that is sized for an 18" doll.The kitchen is easy enough to put together.  The instruction booklet is printed on 8.5"x11" paper, with plenty of directions.  The pieces are all carefully labeled with stickers and baggies.  I recommend a large and small screwdriver.My box had an invoice on the top, covering the picture on the box, but just be careful if you are ordering as a gift, as I worry about ordering presents and having the boxes arrive marked.There was scuffing along one of the pieces that makes the top of the kitchen right above the clock, so it is kind of noticeable.  The pieces seemed to be packaged carefully enough, but apparently pieces rubbed together.  Also when I put the "faucet" on the countertop, the bottom of the faucet split a little bit.  It still seems to be tightly held to the counter but it's too bad.The set is super cute and the kids love it.  This gets plenty of play and is adorable.  The knobs don't move, but the oven door does open.My only other complaint is that it seems a little odd that the hinge is on the left and the handle is on the top, and I was worried the result could be some rough handling, but fortunately my kids are a little older and more careful.  I just wish the design had the handle on the right side of the cabinet.Otherwise the construction and features are well crafted and very appealing.Overall, this is a cute mini kitchen whether your kids use it for a doll or stuffed animals.  My girls long outgrew their kid-sized play kitchen but they love this one!I received a discount on this product for my honest review.

Coconut oil is great for so many uses - from eating to skincare.  This product is a perfect choice because it is 100% organic.This product comes in a nice glass jar (as a set of 2).  I like having the set of 2 since I can keep one in my kitchen and one in the bathroom or on my nightstand.It is usually solid at room temperature, unless it gets warm, at which point it becomes a liquid.I use this for cooking, for example in baking.  Coconut oil makes for really good cookies!I love using coconut oil on my skin.  I stopped using skincare products a long time ago.  Now, I stick with coconut oil.  I love using Cocozia on my skin because it is 100% organic and has nothing added.  It is perfect after showering and before bed.  I use it on everything from my face to my legs, and I usually put some on my hands and feet right before I go to bed.  You can also make your own body products like body butter.  I made one with coconut oil whipped with shea butter, jojoba oil, and essential oils.  Smells amazing, feels amazing, and I know just what is in it!  So many body products at the store are full of chemicals and synthetic fragrances, and this is a fantastic way to avoid those.You can even use this on hair.  I have friends who use it on their hair to smooth and prevent frizz.  My hair is on the fine side but it would be an easy way to use an all natural product to make hair healthier.I have a lot of issues with my teeth, and I use Cocozia coconut oil as a rinse.  I use it a little bit like oil pulling and swish it around my mouth for a while before rinsing.  It is amazing how it can brighten and whiten teeth in 10-15 minutes!Overall, a great product for going natural whether you are looking for a way to eat healthier or use natural skincare.I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

Taking probiotics is very important to us, especially for the kids.  We don't always have tiem to eat a well balanced diet and since probiotics can help with things like my daughter's eczema or stomach issues, this is a useful supplement.These probiotics are little "pearls".  At first I thought they were chewable, as they have a sort of "chalky" look to them, but it is recommended that you swallow these whole.  It is Orangesicle flavor, but the package says "for best results, don't chew".My kids are 6 and 8, and they both have tried these.  They aren't a big fan of the flavor when chewing these, but they are picky as far as vitamins and flavors.  I will have to see if I can get my 8 year old to swallow these whole, as they are just the right size and shape to practice.  I was thinking of crushing this in food, but not if it reduces the efficacy of the product.I appreciate the ingredients of these probiotics - no artificial colors or additives.  The label also reads "Free of gluten, lactose, wheat, soy, eggs, shellfish, tree nuts, chemicals, and artificial ingredients.  Contains trace amount of milk protein."  My daughter has a peanut allergy so the label threw me a little bit, but the ingredients look to be peanut safe and she had no problem when taking this supplement.There are 3 billion CFUs in this product, which is good, because I always pick billions (not millions).  This product seems to do well keeping the kids digestive systems on track, and they haven't been sick this school year.  Apparently most of our immune system is in our gut, so I am all for supporting a healthy gut.  This is a really easy way to get your kids their probiotics.I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

My kids love toothbrushes and toothpaste.. go figure!  So they were really excited when these toothbrushes arrived - they couldn't wait to rip open the packages.These toothbrushes come in two different varieties, and each comes with a toothbrush holder that suctions to the mirror.The holder is easy to use - suction it to the mirror, and lift up the animal head to insert the toothbrush head, then close.  The holders are nice at home, but also for traveling, because it acts as a toothbrush holder and also for hanging up when away from home.The toothbrush is cute, with a cow print on it.  The brush head is small and soft, so better suited to younger kids.  The bristles are a dark gray color, which is unique.  There is also a texture on the back of the toothbrush head, I assume for brushing your tongue.Overall, lots of great features for a kid's toothbrush, and I love that it is appealing for little ones!I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

My kids are really into drawing and coloring, especially those really detailed coloring books (like the adult relaxation coloring books).  So at ages 6 and 8, this is the perfect pack for them!Not only are lots of different colors to choose from, but different kinds - classic, glitter, metallic, neon, pastel and swirl.  The kids love having not only a great color selection, but that they have options of things like glitter or metallic.Each pen has a matching cap, which is a great way to keep track of them.The pens all seem to work well and the kids have had a lot of fun with them.The only thing I might improve is that there isn't any kind of rubbery grip around the barrel of the pen for comfort/grip.I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

My kids do a lot of coloring, and they have some of these detailed coloring books.  I got this coloring book when we had relatives in town with their dog - so it was the perfect coloring activity to do with kids and adults.There are 32 images in the book, with a list in the back of all the dog breeds.  I like that there are all different dogs and breeds to give the book variety.Each page is different, with a different breed as well as a different sort of theme, as each dog is doing something different and often staged with various items (e.g. surfboard).The paper is nice bright white, and thick enough so that it holds up decently.  For fine coloring like this, we use things like gel pens or color pencils.The only improvements I would make:~ I would like the pages to be perforated so that they can be torn out~ the pages aren't numbered, so the numbered list of dogs can be confusing, especially if you cut out pages - so numbering or labeling pages might be useful.I received this coloring book in exchange for my honest review.  Lots of fun to do especially when the kids ask you to color with them!  I am going to get another for a friend!

I haven't worn a whole lot of jewelry since having my kids, but I like the idea of natural stones (agate) for these pendants.You get three color agate pendants, and a cord necklace to put them on.Each agate is cut flat on the back, and the front has the original gem shape.  The purple and turquoise ones have more shape to them, and the white one has a "tighter" formation.  Each pendant is fairly wide and solid, with a gold "paint" around the sides with a matching loop on the top to attach to a necklace.The colors are beautiful, and the white is a nice option to have too.It is easy to switch out the pendants on the necklace.  Just slide them on, and the length of the necklace is a little adjustable (about an inch or two).Overall a nice set to have, a little thick/chunky for my style, but inexpensive.I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

When I first saw this portable charger, I thought I saw the capacity wrong - this is 20,000mAh - whereas most of my other portable chargers are between 2,000-5,000.This is a decent size/weight portable charger, and well over the size and weight of my other smaller chargers.  The design is nice and sleek, the exterior is black with plastic "stitching" along the edges.There is a readout screen on this portable charger, which I love.  I need at least a power indicator (such as lights), but this is even better as far as giving the exact percentage.The charger comes with a nice little drawstring bag.  Although I don't really need a carry bag for my smaller chargers, it is nice to have it for this one for things like traveling and because this is a heavy item.I have used this a few times to bring up the battery level on my iPhone, and it definitely has plenty of power.  Where I usually don't consider recharging our iPads while we travel (e.g. camping), this charger has the ability to do that.I received this product in exchange for my honest review - an excellent charger!

I do all the yard work at my house (other than mowing), and I also prefer using hand pruners over hedge trimmers (for a more natural look).  I use hand pruners a lot.  These are similar to several other pair that I have.These have a comfortable rubberized handle.  I like the bright green handle as I tend to put my pruners down outdoors and lose track of where I put them, so the brighter the better!  The handle makes it easier to grip especially with sweaty hands.The blades are nice and sharp, with a nice tight design so that the blades clip very well.
