The holes all line up, the on/off and volume controls work just fine, and it works great on my wireless charging station - the standard charging station that you can pick up at the Verizon store. When I got my Turbo at the Verison store, I got a case from their display and paid a whole lot more. It is a fine case, but it has a sdesign on the back that makes the phone hard to get into my pants pocket.It is a larger than normal phone and hard enough as it is to get in and out of a pocket. I saw this particular case on Amazon and liked the idea that it was smooth and the price was right, so I got this as a backup. I can go back and forth if I want. However, after putting this case on my turbo, it might just stay there.The case is slick and slides easily in and out of my pocket. Because it is slick, if you set your phone on a table and try to use it, you might have issues with it sliding around. I do not use my phone like this, preferring to hold it when I am using. Some of the lines on the case stand out and may feel sharp to some when you are holding the phone, but they are definitely not sharp enough to cut you and I like the feel of the lines as they give me a more secure feeling when I am holding the phone. The white plastic piece on the back clips onto the case itself. I guess it is there for decoration and to make the case slippery. It does that for sure. Before you put the case on the phone, you should attach the white piece and then put the case on the phone. The white piece clips on easily before the case slips on the phone, but after the case is on the phone, the white piece is harder to get on. I guess that is good as it will not fall off after the case is attached to the phone.This case fits my Droid Turbo perfectly. I have no complaints of the finish. The holes for earphones, usb plug, camera line up exactly. The on/off switch and the volume controls work fine through the case. It feels good in my hands. Even though it is slick, it is perfect for the way I use my phone. The white may scuff during everyday use. I have not had mine long enough to determine how rugged the case is. But right now, I really have no issues with this case. It is perfect for the way I use my phone.

I recently purchased a Sony HX50V camera. This was my first exploration away from those inexpensive cameras with digital zoom. This Sony has a real optical lens and takes great pictures. But it came with one battery and no charger. I have to charge it by connecting it to my computer with a USB cable or using a USB wall charger that came with my smartphone and connect that to the camera with a USB cable. While it is charging, I cannot use my camera since the battery has to stay in the camera while charging.Then, I was offered the opportunity to receive a charger and battery that was compatible with my HX50V camera in return for an honest review. When I looked at the specs for this package, there is a long list of Sony cameras this combo is compatible with. My HX50V camera was included in the list, so I thought it would be great to have this with my camera.When the package arrived, I compared the battery in the package with my Sony camera battery - Exactly the same size and configuration. Same specs printed on the battery. Looks exactly the same with just a different label. I have supplied a picture of the batteries side-by-side. You can see they look pretty much the same.The charger itself is pretty basic. It weighs practically nothing and made from thin plastic. Not sure how well it will hold up if it gets banged around a lot. But the battery fits securely in the slot in the charger and it does the job charging the battery. The charger has an LED light next to the OAproda brand name on the charger case that shows red while the battery is charging. The light changes color when the battery is charged.I have used my camera off and on for a week and the battery still shows fully charged on my camera screen. So, it appears that this battery holds a charge as well as the original Sony battery that came with my camera. I checked the Sony website for the Sony NP-BX1 battery and their list price is $49.99. So here is a replacement battery that costs 1/5 the OEM version and includes an external charger so you can be charging one battery while using the other in the camera. This is a great buy!Bottom line - This appears to be a great direct replacement for the Sony NP-BX1 battery. It is working great in my Sony camera and appears to have similar life as the Sony battery which costs a lot more.

You know when you go to some hotels and they have those big shower-heads and they feel so luxurious? Well, looking at this kind of shower-head makes you think of a luxurious hotel. I was given the opportunity to try out one of these in exchange for an honest review and these are my thoughts.Pros:1) This is a well made shower head. It feels substantial and it has a LOT of nozzles - 200 of them!2) It installed easily on my existing water pipe extending from the wall. It comes with a small roll of plumbers tape to help make a tight fit on the water pipe you attach it to.Cons:1) You better have good water pressure because 200 nozzles is a lot to push water through. I like a stimulating shower but the water that finally exits all these holes was more gentle than I like. The wife liked it better so that ups the rating.2) This shower head is better suited for  a water line coming out the ceiling so that the shower head aims straight down. This gives even distribution from all the jets in the head. From the picture I am submitting, my pipe comes out the side wall, so the water that comes out of the far end of the shower head is weaker than what comes out of the side closest to the water line.Bottom line - If you like a gentle gush of water on your head, you will like this. If you like a more stimulating shower where the water hitting you has some force, you will probably not like this shower head. It is kind of up to your own taste. This shower head is better suited to a water line coming out of the ceiling so you get even distribution of water out all the jets.

I have seen nightlights with all different kinds of shapes, but this nightlight is really different. Most nightlights broadcast their light outwards in a 360 degree path but don't direct the light up and down. This nightlight, when plugged into a standard outlet, directs the light up to the ceiling and down to the floor. This shows up the floor better so you can see where you are stepping.The light output is similar to other LED lights, it is just directed in a different direction. The other thing I like about this light is that it has a flat footprint which makes it easier to pack away for trips. The product pictures on the Amazon product page do not clearly show that this light looks the same on both sides. It has a lens on the front and back and directs light out both ends which turn out to be up and down when you plug it in.I like this light and we took it on a trip recently and it was perfect for the bathroom of our guest's house. The light output is not bright, but good enough to see your way around the bathroom and not bright enough to keep you awake from its glow in the bathroom. I have one in our bathroom and one at the top of my stairs that lead to 2 bedrooms in my house.

I live out in the boonies on a lake. Because we have a nice lake and good fishing, we have a lot of guests that come up and stay overnight. Our guest bedrooms have doors that open to a loft area where I have my computer desk. As a night owl, I am on my computer until 2am-3am so I obviously need a light up there. The problems I have with lighting up there are many:1) I don't like having the overhead light on because it is too bright and makes me feel like I am on display at night2) Table lamps are too bright and take up a lot of space on my desk.3) When guests are here, I don't like having a lot of light on in the loft for fear of keeping guests awake. Even with the bedroom doors shut, there is a space under the door that lets light leak into the rooms.I have tried small lamps of various configurations and they all have their faults. When I was given the opportunity to try out this particular light in exchange for an honest review, I jumped at the chance because this looked like the perfect solution for my problem. And I was not disappointed.Pros:1) First of all, this light is very elegant looking. It looks very nice sitting on a desk.2) The lighted part folds down out of the way giving it a fairly small footprint.3) The base is solid and even when the LED light part is extended completely horizontal, it does not want to tip over.4) The light can be positioned at many different angles so it shines completely horizontally and then down to it's closed position.5) The light can be plugged into a USB port of your computer to power it up and recharge its battery. It will run for hours on its battery.6) The light has several degrees of brightness so it can be adjusted to the level you need. I have mine sitting right next to my computer and shining down on my keyboard which sits on a slide-out panel under the computer monitor.7) This arrangement puts light right on my keyboard where I need it and the rest of the room stays dark, so guests are not disturbed and I do not feel I am on display.I really like this light. The only negative, if you could call it that, is that if you don't have a spare USB port on your computer to charge the lamp, you will need a USB charging module, similar to what you get with your cell phone. I use the one that came with my android cell phone and it works just fine. The lamp comes with a USB cable that you can plug into a USB port on your computer or plug it into a 110v to USB power module like your cell phone charger module. The lamp does not come with the charging module - you have to supply that if you need it. The light lasts a long time with just the battery, but eventually, you will have to recharge it.This would also make a good reading light on a nightstand in the bedroom. With it's different light levels and adjustable head, you could set it so as not to bother your bed partner.

We live out in the boonies. There are no streetlights or power poles. It gets really dark at night. In my back yard, I have a 16' x 12' shed where I store my riding mower, snow blower, tiller, power tools, garden tools, etc. Many times I find myself needing something from the shed after dark. So, I have to hunt up a flashlight - usually the batteries are weak and I have to live with it or stop to change the batteries if I can find fresh ones - and then head out in the dark to find the shed, unlock the door, and get what I need. It can be a hassle sometimes.Then, I was offered the opportunity to try out this great looking light in exchange for an honest review. This looked like the perfect solution for my situation. As the picture I have included shows, I installed this light above the right side of my shed door. It was easy to do as the light comes with a couple of screws and anchors if you need them. There is also a tool to enable the light to turn on after shipping. You stick a thin wire (included) into a small hole in the light housing, and that takes the battery out of standby and enables it to do its job. I used a cordless drill to make a hole for the mounting screw directly into the header above the door. Solid connection and the light was ready to do its job when it got dark. The photo I have included shows where the light is located and the light working after dark. It provides plenty of light to see the key hole in the door knob making it easy to lock and unlock the door.There are several things I really like about this light:1) It is solar powered - no batteries to replace. They charge in the daytime and last all night.2) It has a low output mode so that it glows all night but has low battery drain. The glow is bright enough that I can see the shed in the dark yard and head right to it.3) It has a motion sensor and goes to full brightness when you get within 10 feet or so. The low light mode lets me see where the shed is and head to it and then it bumps up several magnitudes when I get close, making it easy to see the knob on the door and find the key hole.4) I haven't timed it, but after you leave the range of the motion sensor - more than 10 feet, after about 30-45 seconds, it goes back into the low light mode. I am a night owl and don't go to bed until 3am or so. I have checked the light at 3am and it is still glowing at about the same brightness as when it first got dark.5) I have installed the light under the eve of the shed above the door. The solar panels do not get direct sunlight. But they still charge with the ambient light around the shed during the day and they last all night. So, these do a good job of charging when not in direct sunlight.6) Living in the boonies, going out in the dark is kinda creepy because there are all sorts of critters out there. I have seen fox running through the yard. Some neighbors have seen a bobcat and coyotes. There is something calming about having a beacon out in the dark showing you where to go and keeping the critters staying in the dark.This is a quality made product. I feel it will last a long time. I love it and am very happy to have it out on my shed to make my life easier.

We have a lot of devices in the family that are charged via USB chargers. The wife and I each have android smartphones and a kindle fire tablet. When the kids come up, their phones also seem to always be plugged in wherever they can find an outlet in the house. Then, we have teenage grandkids who bring their devices up and they seem to always be running low on juice. Many times they forget their cords and have to borrow one of ours and sometimes we never see it again. So, it is handy to have extra cords around.I picked up a charging hub on Amazon that has 5 USB ports on it. Until I ran across this offering with 10, cool looking cords, we used whatever cords were available in the house - usually long cords that got tangled easily. What I like about these cords is that they are only 7-inches long. I can plug my charging hub into an outlet in the kitchen out of the way and connect  5 of these cords to the 5 ports on my charging hub and just leave it available all the time. When someone needs a charge, they just pick a spare cord and plug in their phone/device. Because they are short, the don't get tangled with each other. Also, being flat instead of round, makes them less likely to get tangled.I have not found any of the 10 cords that don't work. I love all the colors. They look cool snaking out of my charging hub. Plus, this is an excellent price for 10 cords.I was given a set of these in return for an honest review. However, I would have easily bought this set if I had know they existed. I may buy a couple more and give them as gifts to members of the family who seem to be losing theirs all the time. Or, each member of the family can be assigned a color specific to them and that is the one they use when they come to visit. As long as the cord stays connected to the hub, they can't get lost.

I have a new Scag Liberty Z, Zero turn mower. The Engine on my mower is a Kohler 24 HP KT-735. After the first 10 hours of use, I am supposed to change the oil and filter. So, I hit my first 10 hours and looked for the same filter on Amazon that came with my Scag - it was a kohler 12 050 01 filter. I could not find that particular filter, but ran across this one with the same number but with a "S" at the end of the part number. I could not find anything that explained what the "S: meant, but otherwise the part number was the same. So, I gave it a chance.So, it looks like the "S" at the end of the part number stands for "Short." This filter is shorter than the one that came on my mower, but it fit just fine and seems to work fine. So, I am happy with this filter and would order it again. I do not like to use aftermarket filters and prefer to use genuine manufacturer parts for things I paid a lot of money for - like this mower.

This turned out to be a great action movie. I liked the cast of characters - some you wanted to hate and hope they got their just rewards. The slow motion action is spectacular.Note - there is a lot of swearing - especially the "F" word. The movie could have done without that, but if you can ignore the swearing and just enjoy all the action, it was a great movie.

I have a 25 year old garden cart that has been sitting in the shed for years. The tires had dry rot so they wouldn't keep air. When I recently picked up a new zero turn mower for mowing my 1 acre of land, I decided to add a hitch to my mower and put the cart to use. I couldn't find new tires locally that were this size, so I looked on amazon. I was actually looking for just the tires and not the wheel itself, but it turned out that the tires already mounted on the wheel were less expensive than just buying the tire - so I went with these. The wheel has a 3/4-inch shaft which is what I needed for my cart. Most of the tires of this size out there have a 5/8" shaft, so you have to watch what you are ordering.These tires turned out to be an exact replacement for my old ones - down to the color and look of the wheel base. They fit over the axle on my wagon and were a perfect fit. So, now I have my cart back and can haul things around my acreage.

I have never heard of this Ragi Atta, but I do know what millet flour is. I was offered the opportunity to try this product for an honest review and being an adventurous cook, I decided to try it.I am always in the kitchen and make most of the meals in our house. My specialties in the breakfast area keep my wife guessing about what "concoction" I might come up with to surprise her. So, when I received this bag of millet flour, I started adding it to some of my normal recipes to see how it worked out.The first thing I made for breakfast is one of my wife's favorites - baked oatmeal. When I make baked oatmeal, it has chopped apples, cinnamon, pecans, buttermilk, maple syrup, and of course old fashioned oats. Everything is mixed together and baked in the oven. Then you spoon it into a bowl and add milk. I like to spoon some vanilla ice cream on top and let it melt into the warm oatmeal. So, it is almost like a dessert for breakfast - ha..ha.. In this instance, Instead of the 2 cups of oats, I used 1 2/3 cups oats and 1/3 cup of Ragi Atta. The millet flour gave it kind of a nutty flavor, so it turned out great. Plus I liked the tecture of the baked oatmeal a little better. So, the first experiment worked great.One thing I discovered is that this flour has a rather strong smell/taste of millet. So, if you use too much, the flavor takes over the dish and that is all you can taste. I discovered that when I made sour dough pancakes for breakfast using my own sour dough starter. I used too much of this flour and ended up with a lot denser pancake than normal and the millet taste was dominant. So, for making pancakes, you don't need more than a couple tablespoons in your batter.I made banana nut muffins one morning and used about 1/3 cup of this flour along with 1 1/2 cup of spelt flour and a packet of an organic instant oatmeal to give it texture. This one turned out great in texture and flavor. The millet flavor goes well with mashed bananas and chopped pecans.So, I like this new flour and am adding it to my pantry. It adds protein and an interesting flavor profile to baked goods. I am sure that everyone has different taste buds, and I found that in some cases I added too much millet flour in some recipes so that the flour took over from the other flavor ingredients that I like. So, you will have to experiment to get the right amounts for your own tastes.

I have been reading about the health benefits of drinking alkaline water. The water out here where we live is pretty acidic and this ionizer is supposed to raise the PH to around 10 which is very alkaline. Plus, my water has a lot of minerals. We use a Keurig coffee machine and the water reservoir always seemed to be collecting a scale inside where the water sits. Plus the nozzle got clogged up now and then with scale so I had to clean it often. I had a carbon filter device attached to my cold water tap in the kitchen but that didn't stop the scale build-up in the water reservoir. So, I went looking on Amazon for a better filter and that lead me to discovering the health benefits of alkalized water. So, I picked this particular device to give it a try.We keep this pitcher on the kitchen counter, always with water in it. We drink it instead of the tap water and we use it in the Keurig coffee machine.First of all, this filtered water tastes a lot better than the tap water. It has more flavor. So, it is easy to remember to pour a glass of water from the pitcher when you are thirsty. Also, I no longer see little floaty things in the water reservoir of my Keurig machine. Plus, the Keurig water reservoir seems to be keeping perfectly clean. I see no mineral build-up inside the reservoir. And - the coffee tastes great!So, for me, this was a great purchase and I am very happy with this particular product.

We live in a gated lake community and are retired. We have lots of get togethers with other retired friends here at the lake, playing cards or just getting together for conversation and wine. Yes, wine is a big thing with us and our friends. When we play cards and are hosting the group at our house, I like to have a bottle of red and a bottle of white sitting out on the counter so drinkers can refresh their glasses during the evening. The whites always start cold, but by later in the evening the whites are warmer than I would like and lose flavor.When I was offered the opportunity to try out this ingenious device in return for an honest review, I jumped at the chance, since it fulfills a need I have all the time.So, this device has 3 components, the stainless steel rod which you put in the freezer, the aerator that is made of acrylic with some holes in it that screws onto the stainless steel rod and fits in the top of the wine bottle, and a stopper that goes into the top of the aerator. The stainless steel rod is solid - no wine goes through it. You put the rod in the freezer for at least 4 hours to get really cold. The aerator then screws onto the top of the cold rod and you insert it into the wine bottle. The aerator has a graduated soft middle part that allows it to fit into different size bottle tops and has a pour spout on the top. The pour spout is an interesting design that they say eliminates drips. I found this to be true. The stopper just fits into the pour spout to seal the wine until you want to drink more.So, how does it work? Just great!I tried this on 2 different kinds of bottles, screw top and corked bottles and the pour spout fits in both types. It provides a secure fit so there are no leaks around the spout where it fits in the wine bottle.I tried a bottle of red wine that had sat at room temperature (68 degrees in our house). Inserted the cold rod for about 20 minutes and then poured myself a glass of wine. It was the perfect drinking temperature. You could feel the temperature change just holding the bottle which felt much cooler after the 20 minutes. So, it works fine cooling a red wine down to the right temp.For a white wine that was cold to start with, it kept the wine cold enough to enjoy for about an hour and a half and by then, the wine was gone. I didn't test it for hours and hours, but it is good for at least an hour and half.The aerator/pour spout also works as advertised. The spout does not leak wine down the side of the bottle, so you get clean pours. Also, I tasted the wine before going through the aerator and after going through the aerator and the aerator definitely makes a difference depending on what kind of wine you are drinking. I have found in the past - using a much more expensive dedicated aerator device, that drier red and white wines can be improved greatly by aerating before drinking. But with sweeter wines, most people can't tell the difference. This aerator definitely smooths out the taste of a drier wine. I like it.So, the stainless steel rod is supposed to be filled with a gel that keeps it cold when you remove it from the freezer. Therefore, it does not have any holes in it that the wine goes through before exiting the bottle. It is a solid rod. The holes for the wine to exit the bottle are up on the pour spout itself. So, the design of the aerator holes that the wine goes through makes the wine stream a little weaker than normal. Therefore, the wine comes out of the pour spout a little slower than you are used to. It takes a little longer to pour yourself a glass of wine. But that is not a big deal with me. It just means it is harder to splash the stuff outside the glass if you are usually a messy pourer.Bottom line - this is a great wine tool with a reasonable price. It makes a great pour spout, it cools reds down and keeps whites cold as advertised, plus it makes dry, red and white wines taste smoother. The wine stopper fits tightly and does its job well.

Several years ago, I tore the meniscus in my left knee. I had surgery to repair it, but it still "tweaks" me to let me know it is not happy when I do some things - like bowling. So, for protection, and to make it happy, I wear a brace when I bowl in my 3 leagues. The braces I have used in the past have metal bars on both sides of the knee and they are cumbersome and large and very hot. They also tend to slide a little and I have to readjust them after I start sweating during a game. After a night of bowling, I am sweating so bad underneath, my skin is wrinkled. Also, there are places on my old braces that rub my skin raw. I dislike wearing them, but I don't like the alternative.Then I received the opportunity to try out this new brace in return for an honest review. It looked a lot better than the ones I have been using, so I jumped at the chance to get it and see how it worked.First of all, it comes in a nice carrying bag, making it easy to stow away in my bowling bag or in the glove box of my car. The carrying bag is nylon-looking, light, and with a netting that lets the brace breath which may help over the long run with sweat odors or drying out when I don't have the brace on and it is stowed somewhere.The brace itself looks of high quality. The seller's price is very reasonable for the quality of this brace. There is padding everywhere on the underside which means no rubbing raw of skin or blisters on your skin. The underside is a very nice blue color and there are some soft, wavy-looking silicon strips on the upper and lower parts of the brace so it doesn't slip when you have it on. The neoprene that is used in this brace is soft and comfy and has holes in it to allow circulation of air. I couldn't believe how comfortable it is when I put it on.The box comes with no instructions for putting it on, so I had to play with it a little to figure out what was best for me. The best way I found was to straighten my leg out in the front of me (not bend it), position the knee hole over the top of of my kneecap, and then start with the lower strap to Velcro it in a comfy position - go to the middle strap, and then end with the top strap to position and fasten it. I tried going the opposite direction, but the lower part of the brace would bunch a little making it harder to fasten the way I wanted. Starting at the bottom solved the bunching problem as the top part doesn't do that.Once it is on, I couldn't believe how much support it gave my knee- plus it is really comfortable. I ran up to the bowling alley which is only a mile from my house and tried it out on several games. Perfect fit and perfect support for my sliding leg. This brace is following me to the bowling alley from now on! It is so much better than what I have put up with in the past. Also, I have a big yard and garden. Sometimes when I am outside working in the yard, I am up and down pulling weeds, picking veggies, trimming things, and my knee starts tweaking me. I can wear this brace around the yard doing my gardening tasks and that seems to make my knee happy. The soft stabilizers on each side of the brace do a great job keeping my knee from twisting too much when I am out and about and I almost forget it is on.Bottom line for me is that this is the best brace I have ever run across for my favorite sport, bowling. Plus it is comfortable enough to wear around the yard when I am out put-zing. The only problem with the put-zing use is that I get it dirty quite often so it has to be cleaned more often than I like. Cleaning is via hand washing- not machine washing, so it takes a little more effort to keep it clean depending on what activities you do when you are using the brace.

We live out in the boonies. We get huge lightning storms, tornadoes, and bad thunderstorms out here in the Summer. It is not unusual to lose power out here at night, and I keep flashlights around the house so when the power goes out, I can find a flashlight - after stumbling around a little - and not kill myself until the power comes back on.My last flashlight bit the dust and I was going to go buy another one when I was offered this particular device to try out in exchange for an honest review. Good timing! This motion sensor light is perfect for our household and the way we live.First of all, it appears to be very well built - plus it looks cool. It has some heft, so it feels solid. I weighed the entire device at 6.8 oz. on my kitchen scale. It is about 5-1/8" tall and 2-3/8" wide. It has a charging base that plugs into a standard 110 vac wall outlet. The sensor itself fits onto the base unit via a built in magnet plus there is a small lip on the bottom of the charging unit to help secure it so it charges properly. It came fully charged from what I could see after I opened the box.On the front of the motion sensor is an "eye" of sorts that detects movement near the sensor and turns on a light that covers the whole face of the sensor. I have found mine to work when I am anywhere up to 10 feet away from the sensor. The light is actually located behind the sensor eye, but its brilliance is distributed across the whole front face of the sensor giving out a soft glow that is bright enough to allow you to see where you are going, but not blinding like an overhead light when you turn on the light switch. At the top of the sensor are 2-very bright LEDs which you can use as a flashlight by pressing a switch on the side of the sensor. The switch turns off the face light and turns on the flashlight or turns off all the lights.So, the operation is pretty easy. You plug the base unit into a wall outlet and then put the remote sensor onto the base unit. Because it is magnetized, the remote unit sits securely on the base. The whole thing is dark until you get within 10 feet of the sensor and then the face glows for about 25 seconds. If the power goes out, the face of the sensor glows like a beacon for up to 1.5 hours making it very easy to find in the dark. When you press the switch on the side, it turns into a flashlight that will get you by in an emergency or until the power comes back on. It makes a good flashlight for everyday use too, although the beam of the LEDs is not real focused. Even though it is not focused like a regular flashlight, it gives off plenty of light to get you by.So, the wife and I really like this as a nightlight. I have it set up in the bedroom on a wall outlet just inside the bedroom door. We have a king-sized bed, and I sleep on the side farthest from the bathroom. Before having this sensor, I would frequently stub my toes on the bed frame when I got up in the night to use the toilet. I would have to feel my way to the bathroom and sometimes would bump into the wife's dresser or a corner of the wall until I could see the nightlight that is in the bathroom. My path takes me within 10 feet of this device and now that I have it, it "sees me coming" and lights my way to the bathroom with no problem. It's glow does not wake the wife. It turns off after 25 seconds. On the way back to bed, it sees me again and glows my path back to the bed. By the time I climb in and cover up, it turns off. So, the off timing is perfect for the way we live.Bottom line is, we really like this light because it fulfills a lot of our needs in one device - a nightlight, a flashlight, and an emergency light when the power goes out. It stays charged as long as you keep it in the base when not in use. All this at a very reasonable price.

The wife and I are retired and while our health is good, we like to travel. Last year we did some traveling in England, Scotland, and wales. When we returned, and I retrieved my luggage from baggage claim at Ohare, I noticed - again - that the TSA had inspected my luggage and the lock was gone. I have lost 3 locks while travelingin the last 5 years. Perhaps the TSA is not locking them properly after inspection, or just the crappy locks I buy fall off. I don't know.When I was offered this lock in exchange for an honest review, well I couldn't say no, could I? I had to buy a new one anyway and perhaps this one would not lose itself and end up where all lost TSA locks go.So, my impressions when I received this lock - solid construction. This thing weighs more than my previous locks. So, it seems to be more sturdy. The instructions to set it up with your own code are pretty much the same as all the TSA locks I have purchased. It worked fine and I set the code. I locked it and unlocked it - there is a noticeable "click when you lock it and unlock it. Again, that makes it seem more substantial. I like the 3-digit code rather than the locks with 4 digits because the code is easier to remember. I know having 4 digits is more secure, but I figure that if someone wants to get into my suitcase at the airport, if they can't get it open in a minute or so, they will just go to the next easier target. 3 digits is enough to take someone a while to go through all the combinations and it just isn't worth it for most thieves.I used it on a recent trip to Disney World - worked great and it didn't disappear. So, I am happy. Next time I need a TSA lock, I will pick up another one of these.

This light definitely makes a statement in your garden.Pros:- Looks expensive from a distance.- Looks great in my garden.- Larger than most solar garden/path lights- 24 LEDs under the silver dome provide excellent light output- Light output is higher than most solar garden/path lights- High capacity NiMH batteries make the light last a long time.Cons:- Not sure how long this light would last in the elements. It is made from light plastic. The silver dome looks metallic, but is actually plastic painted with silver.- The stainless steel tube that the light sits on is very thin and comes in 2 pieces. The two pieces are joined by a plastic plug/connector. I had trouble pushing the 2 tube pieces onto the connect to join them into one tube. The stainless steel is very thin and I was worried about putting a dent in the tube or collapsing it because it was not easy to slide either tube onto the connector. You have to use some muscle as the fit is very tight. Same for fitting the light itself onto the tube. I never did get it all the way seated, but close enough to do the job.- The light is made in china.This light sits about 25 inches off the ground, so it casts a wide arc of light around your garden.  I have to say that this light really looks good in my garden and lasts a lot longer than the other solar LED lights that I have scattered around on my deck and into my Rock garden. I am writing this at almost 1am and my other solar lights are dead while this one looks just as bright as it did at sundown. So, performance-wise, this is a 5-star product. I knocked it down a notch because I am not sure how long it will last sitting out in the weather up here in Northern Illinois. It does not feel as substantial as it looks. Only time will tell.  I like the way the light works and illuminates my garden. The picture I submitted shows the light output at 1am in my garden. It has been on for about 5 hours. I hope it lasts for a while as it adds class to my night garden.Note that I received a complimentary light in return for an honest review.Update: Well, I am really liking this light. It has been out in my garden for about a week now and has withstood some nasty rain and wind storms. It stays lit all night, doing it's silent vigil with it's steady illumination - still going when the sun rises. All my other solar lights along my brick walkway are long dead while this light is still showing up strong when the sun comes up. I have had visitors comment on how nice it looks out there at night. This light is definitely a keeper!

Function-wise, this tray has a lot of uses that aren't described by the name. It does look like it might be made of rubber, but it is plastic, instead. Because it is lighter plastic, without anything sitting in the tray, it tends to not sit flat on a flat surface and a corner may pop off the ground. That is why I gave it 4-stars instead of 5. But when you start putting things into the tray, it lays flat just fine.In my case, I am using it in my garden. I grow onions and potatoes here in Northern Illinois. When potatoes are ready to dig, I usually dig them up, throw them in a bucket, and take them to where I have a hose to wash the dirt off them to prepare for storage. After washing each off individually, I throw them in the grass beside me and grab the next one. In the end, the wet potatoes have picked up grass and dirt from the yard and I have to wipe each one off again and set it somewhere else to dry. If I put them back in the bucket, they are stacked upon each other and never dry out. This tray is perfect to throw the washed potatoes in, spread them out, and let them easily dry before storage.When the onions are ready to pick, I used to pull them out, clean off the dirt, and let them sit on the deck for a couple days to dry out. The problem with that is they tend to roll around on the deck and get in the way of us using the deck. With this tray, I can set them in the tray out of the way and the sides of the tray keep them from rolling around.When not holding potatoes or onions, you can set the tray anywhere in a sunny spot and fill up with potted plants. When you water your plants, the water stays in the tray and does not run all over your deck or wherever you have it. You can group your plants in the tray for colorful arrangements.Another use my wife has is for holding craft items - like skeins of yarn, rolls of wrapping paper, quilting blocks, and things like that in her craft room. The tray is large enough to accommodate a lot of different items and the sides keep them situated in one place instead of scattered around in different hidey holes where they can get lost. When she is working on a project, she can keep those items she is using handy in the tray sitting next to her work table and sometimes on it off to the side.So, these are some of the uses I have found around our household. You can spread a tray's usefulness for all year with different projects that happen at different times of the year. If it had been made of rubber, I might have tried sitting my gas and oil cans in the tray to keep my garage floor clean. But I do not know if the plastic in this tray could hold up under spilled gas, so I didn't try it.Note that I received a complimentary tray in return for an honest review. I discovered a lot more uses than I would have thought.

I just purchased a SCAG Liberty Z, Zero Turn mower for keeping my acre of land mowed. It is orange with black trim. I have a cart that I wanted to pull with my Scag, but it didn't have a trailer hitch. This hitched looked like the perfect fit. What I liked about this hitch is the slots on the back side which would allow it to accommodate different bolt hole configurations. My scag had a couple of bolts that were 3.5 inches apart and this hitch allowed me to bolt it to the backside of my Scag. It fits perfectly and the black color matches the trim on my mower.This hitch is plenty heavy-duty for my cart which will hold about 800 pounds of dirt, mulch, bricks, and other "stuff" that I haul around my property.

I have never seen a product like this. When I was offered the opportunity to try it at a discounted price, I took the offer. I am always interested in alternative products that provide healthy benefits compared to similar products that are made with junk ingredients. Toothpaste is an example of a product with junk ingredients. Although regular toothpaste is good for freshening your breath and cleaning your teeth, it contains some nasty ingredients that give me the willies every time I brush.I did some googling on the term "Miswak" and discovered it has been used for centuries for brushing the teeth. so, there is some history. Reviews all around the web are pretty positive. So, I thought - What the heck - I will give it a try.The packaging is very interesting. It is in a nice box that has pulls on the sides so the inside of the box slides out the side revealing another box with the separately wrapped Miswak sticks resting inside. The sticks are in a plastic holder, like a pen casing. So you take the cap off and the stick slides out. Storage is easy as you just pop it back in the pen-shaped case and pop the cap back on. One thing that might drive you crazy is the plastic coating that you have to remove to get to anything. First the box itself has a plastic/cellophane covering that you have to get off before getting into the box. Then each "pen" with a Miswak stick inside is wrapped in a kind of bubble wrap that is difficult to get off. I had to get a sharp knife out and remove the wrap. It was not easy and somewhat time consuming. The 2 pens are individually wrapped, so you have to go through the same procedure for each. But finally, you can get to the actual product.The seller e-mailed me a 1-page instruction to show how it works. There is nothing on the box. Each stick has some kind of coating - it reminds me of wax - that you have to scrape off to get to the actual Miswak root underneath. So, you take a sharp knife and shave off about a half inch of the waxy substance to get to the hard root. Then you bite around the root part a few times and it turns into a bristle of sorts - a wet bristle since it has your spit on it. From here you can rub it up and down on each tooth and the bristles get between your teeth and actually do a pretty good job of cleaning. It is a lot harder to get to the back side of your teeth, so you kind of have to work at it a little more.After using it a little, some of the bristles start to fall off in small pieces, so it is good for one use and then you have to cut off the used part, shave some more of the waxy substance off, and start a new set of bristles for the next brushing. You can pop the stick back into the pen holder for storage between brushings.So, here are my observations.Pros:- The Miswak brush does do a pretty good job of cleaning your teeth. After a day of eating/drinking, I sometimes have a little scum between my teeth and gums and this cleans that off really well. After using it, my teeth feel very clean. The bristles also do a pretty good job of cleaning food out between your teeth,too.- This would be great for camping because you don't need water. Just a pocket knife for shaving the waxy coating and the rest you can do with your mouth.- The pen holder thing makes it convenient to carry around as it has a pocket clip so you can slide it into your pocket just like it was a pen.After a few days of use, my teeth do seem to be slightly whiter. I would have to use it for a while to see if there is any significant kind of whitening. I am an old guy with lots of years of coffee drinking. I always thought my teeth were stained beyond help. If this thing can at least keep them from getting darker, then it is worth it to use them. I cannot see these sticks giving you the white movie star smile that is probably expensive veneers.Cons:- The stick has a funky smell to it. However, to my taster, it didn't taste like it smelled. I couldn't actually detect any taste.- Since it has no taste, it didn't really freshen my breath like a minty kind of toothpaste would do. so, if you are used to brushing your teeth with a minty toothpaste and have a pleasant minty breath afterwards, you won't get that with this stick. It doesn't give you bad breath, it is just kind of neutral. Your mouth may be different, but that is how it works with mine.- Brushing the back side of your teeth is not so easy because of the length of the stick. When you get down to a nub after many uses, you can fit it back there more easily. Front of your teeth is very easy.- When using the Miswak stick, it takes a lot longer to brush your teeth. First there is the issue of shaving off the outer covering, then chewing on the end a little bit. Then you have to work on each tooth in your mouth individually, both front and back. It will take you twice a long to clean your teeth versus a toothbrush. But if you are out camping or traveling, this is much more convenient than getting out a toothbrush, finding water, brushing your teeth, and washing your mouth out.So, I like these and will continue using them on occasion. Depending on how much work you are willing to do to clean your teeth, you might like them or not. It was worth trying for me and I am glad I did.

My wife is the secretary of our Sunday Night mixed bowling league. For our end of season banquet, she was looking for something cool to give to all the bowlers that bowled in our league. My idea was to make a refrigerator magnet for each person showing their final average, high game, and high series of the season. So, I created a template that got 10 magnets on a page. Each is about 3.5-inches wide and 2-inches high. There were 40 bowlers so 4 sheets was enough to cover the league. I created a graphic for the ladies and a different graphic for the men. I have an HP 5650 color inkjet printer and I fed each sheet through the printer separately to make sure no sheets stuck together because of the magnetism. The printing quality on these sheets was excellent. I cut out each magnet using my wife's craft cutting wheel and board and a ruler to keep the lines straight.The magnetism in each individual's stats magnet was just right to stick well on the fridge. These were a big hit at the banquet. These worked great for this application and I will probably do it again next year as my wife was elected secretary again for next years league.

Okay - Our 41 year old daughter was up here to the lake to visit, so we decided to check out the movies on the Fire TV Stick. We saw Big Hero 6 was available and decided to watch it. The audience was our 41 year old daughter, my wife at 67 years old, and me at 68 years old. So, a little range in ages watching. We all thought the movie was great. The previews would make you believe this might be suitable for only younger kids, but we were entertained throughout the movie as you got into the story. 5-stars from this household.

I have one of these for our household and I bought one for my daughter's household. We both have 46-inch LED HDTV sets and fast wireless routers in our houses.The Fire TV stick is very easy to set up when you first plug it into your HDMI port on your TV. It walks you through the setup. You don't really need the manual. It was also easy to set up streaming on our wi-fi router. We were up and running in no time. Amazon has a great lineup of programming, It is actually mind-boggling what you can get via the Fire TV stick. There is so much content to watch, that I cannot even begin to list things we discovered. It is fun just going through the program guide, which kind of reminds you of Windows 8, and discovering interesting channels. Some channels (or apps if you will), like Netflix, will cost you  to watch. But there is a ton of free stuff if you are an Amazon Prime member. You get a trial subscription to Amazon Prime when you buy one of these, but I am an Amazon junkie, so I already have Prime Membership. Prime is well worth the $99/year when you see the large amount of programming that is available to you. I buy a LOT of stuff on Amazon because I live in the boonies and it is easier to get stuff on line than drive for miles and waste gas. So I use my Prime membership mostly to get free 2-day shipping. Free programming content via the Fire TV stick is just a bonus for me.We have not had any issues with program lags because of slow Internet connections. The Fire TV stick does some kind of magic buffering in the background so that you can watch shows without any program freezes on the screen. This is a great buy and may wean you from cable or satellite TV.

We play Hand & Foot and Sevens from Heck in a card group here at the lake. Our cards are always wearing out. These are a good buy for replacement decks as they wear out. They have held up well and I like to keep several decks in the cupboard when we need them. You can go to the dollar store and get decks of cards, but they are thin and don't hold up. These are better quality and last a lot longer.

This is a great hat! I have had a lot of fun wearing it around and having people ask me if it is my real hair. Since I am a gray haired old guy, it matches my sideburns pretty well, so most of the time it just looks like I have a wild and crazy hairdo.I have paid a lot more for hats that were a lot lower quality. This hat is well worth the $20 charged. It is high quality and adjustable for any size head. I have a large head and it is hard to find hats that fit, but the adjustable band on the back will make it so that it fits even a lard-head like mine. I now have 2 of these hats - the other one is green/gray chex. I also bought a USA hat for my grandson who doesn't have gray hair, but he likes the shocked looks he gets from his friends - ha..ha..This is a great hat and you can have a lot of fun with it. It will also keep your head warm on cold days.

Our household is not an Apple household. In fact, I dislike Apple business practices that always makes it feel like there is a hand on your wallet/purse. So, we have all android and Windows devices in the house. The wife has a Droid RAZR smartphone and so do I. We also have a Kindle Fire. The kids and grandkids, when they visit us, have android devices and they are always losing their charging modules/cables causing their devices to always be low on juice. Seems like we are always looking for the chargers for these things to keep them charged. I have a drawer full of charging modules for devices we have had over the years. You have to stop and think, "which device is this particular module for?" when you want to charge something. We could throw most of them away if we weren't paranoid about throwing away one we might really need later.So, when I saw this product that had 5 USB ports on it, I jumped at the chance to evaluate this unit in exchange for an honest review. First impressions, when it arrived, was that this is a solid piece of gear. It has substantial weight and a solid feel. It looks and feels like a quality piece of gear. The power cord that comes with it is heavy duty, too. The specs say that it weighs 5-ounces, but it feels more substantial than that. Other specs that are quoted include:-Superfast technology: Detects your device to deliver its fastest possible charge speed up to 2.4 amps per port or 8 amps overall.- 40W power output among 5 charging ports, Simultaneously charge any five of your USB compatible devices at full speedAlso, the product description would lead you to believe that it's "Mart Detect Power IQ" Detects only certain devices to deliver the fastest charge.  Those devices are I-Phones, Samsung phones, Galaxy, HTC One, and Nexus phones, and the I-Pad. When I queried the seller about this, they replied that my Motorola Droid phones and my Kindle Fire would be detected and charged accordingly. So, I took a chance.This charger is substantial enough that you can set it on a table on its side with the USB charging ports aligned vertically. This saves a lot of space on the desktop and this is how I have it set up. Plug the AC cord into the unit and into the wall and you are ready to go. The ac input is 100-240 volts, 50-60 hertz, so it will work internationally too. It does not come with plug adapters, so if you use this overseas, you need a plug adapter at the ac end to match up with whatever country you are in.I plugged my RAZR and my wife's RAZR phones into 2 of the USB ports and then plugged my wife's Kindle Fire into a 3rd. They all showed they were charging. A small complaint I might have is that there is no light on the unit itself to show that it is live and working. You will know it is good when you plug in your device and your device shows that it is charging.This thing does charge a lot faster. My RAZR's stock charger module says that it is 0.6 amps max. It takes hours for my RAZR phone to charge. Plugged into this charger, my RAZR went from 50% to 100% in less than an hour. That usually takes at least 2 hours using the factory charger. The Kindle Fire is also normally slow in charging, but it took about 45 minutes to charge the Kindle from about 40% battery. So, this charger is really a lot faster than the stock ones that come with our devices. The grandkids stopped off today and we had 5 devices plugged into this charger and they were all charged before they left.So, first impressions are very positive. My wife had to make a trip out of state to see her mother in Iowa who is having some health problems. Our 40 year old daughter went with her. She has a Galaxy S3 phone and my mother-in-law has a Galaxy S4. My wife "borrowed" the charger from my computer desk and took it with her. She texted me that it works great with the 2 galaxy's and her RAZR plugged in. Very convenient to have one charger that handles it all. While here at home, I just leave the cords plugged into the charger and route them behind the charger itself when not in use. When somebody needs a charge, the just grab a cable that is already plugged in, bring it to the front, plug it into their phone, and the charging begins. In no time at all, our devices are ready to go on their own. I really like this charger.

Our household has a couple of Droid RAZR smartphones. My wife has the RAZR MAXX while I have just the RAZR, which means my battery is about half the capacity of hers so mine is always running down. I have several backup batteries that I use to charge it while out and about and off the grid, but they are similar to the size of my smartphone and flat like my smartphone. So, it is like carrying around two smartphones.I was offered the opportunity to try a complimentary charger/flashlight in return for an honest review. It is interesting the clever ways manufacturers improve a product to make it easier or more functional than the competition. There are zillions of device chargers out there, but here is one that is also a flashlight and that makes it stand out. I liked the form/function of this charger, so I was happy to get one and try it. It is something that I would buy myself if I knew it worked as advertised.So, here is the rundown.I have a postage scale that weighs in tenths of an ounce accuracy. This charger/flashlight weighs 2.8 ounces. My cell phone weighs 5.4 ounces, so this device is pretty light in comparison to my cell phone.Dimensions are 4.25" long and about 7/8 inches in diameter. So, it looks like a mini-flashlight. It has both metal and plastic construction. It feels solid. You can actually unscrew the bottom and get to the guts of the flashlight including the battery which is soldered to the circuit board that has the USB plugs and electronics to run the functions of the charger/flashlight. So, a handy person with a soldering iron could change the battery if it ever failed.The top screws off to get to the bulb, but it appears to be a special module with the bulb built in, so you could not go to the hardware store and just get a replacement bulb if that ever failed.As a flashlight, this thing is very bright. There is a small button on the bottom of the unit  that turns it on near 2 USB connectors. Push once and you get a very bright solid light. Press again and you get a dimmer solid light. Press a 3rd time and you get an emergency flasher. Press yet again and everything is turned off. The light is very bright, so if you carried this around with you in the dark, you could use it to feel safe and too see quite a bit in front of you. If you are stranded on the road, it definitely gives you a very bright warning flash to attract attention for help.As a charger, the unit comes with a short USB charging cable with a mini-USB connector on one end along with an adapter that converts the mini-USB to another version of a mini-USB that can be found on other devices besides a smartphone. So, you get the option to pick from 2 different styles of mini-USB depending on your device. The other end is a standard 1/2-inch USB connector which will plug into your PC or your cell phone wall charger.The bottom of the unit has two USB connectors, a standard USB connector that you use for charging other devices and a mini-USB connector that is used for charging this device. So, depending on whether you are using it as a charging device or charging it from another source, you just turn the cable that comes with it around and plug it into the appropriate connector depending on what you are doing with this charger/flashlight. The other end then goes into the device you are charging or a PC/AC charging module. This device does not come with an AC charging module. You use a PC or the charging module that comes with your smartphone if it has a standard USB connector on it.Performance - When I received this charger/flashlight, I plugged it into my cell phone AC charging module and let it charge fully. It has a light on the bottom that shows reddish/orange to show it is charging. When it is done, the light goes out. My Droid RAZR was showing 50% battery, so I plugged it into this charger and a blue light comes on the bottom of the charger showing it is charging something. This charger charged my RAZR to 100% in about 50 minutes. It usually takes my RAZR's AC charge about an hour to charge my phone from 50%, so this actually performs better than my cell phones regular charger. When recharging the device, it took a lot longer - several hours. But that could be because of my AC wall module that came with my cell phone. It is rated at 750 ma max for charging.It would be nice if there was some way to gauge the state of discharge of this device. I have no clue how much juice is left after charging my cell phone for 50 minutes. The flashlight still was plenty bright and so was the strobe, so it looked like there was plenty of juice left to charge another phone or device.This is a great charger and flashlight. The strobe part doesn't bother me like some other reviewers have noted it bothers them. I like having something like this in my car for emergency purposes, but it is small enough that I can throw it in my pants pocket and carry around with me or the wife can carry it in her "packed fulla' junk" purse and it will fit in there without much problem. It's dual function is great. I am glad to have this and might buy a few for Christmas gifts for family members.

The wife and I love to cook so we have a big kitchen and lots of different kinds of knives. The knives we use most are our cutco knives and though they are quality knives, our frequent use means they get dull. I have several kinds of sharpeners that all work to a degree. What I liked about this sharpener is that it has a nice handle that works for either right or left-handed people and it also has a rubber bottom that makes it grip the counter top very well. I feel very safe using this sharpener as my hands are away from the blades so if there is a slip of some kind - like the blade flips out of the slot - my hand is far enough away to stay out of danger. Plus, there is a protective lip on the holder between your hand and the sharpening slots to give added protection.It also has a 2-stage sharpening system as compared to most sharpeners who just have one place you run your knives through.The first stage uses courser Tungsten carbide blades for when your knife is really dull and it gets the sharpening going quickly. You don't want to push real hard - just a few easy strokes through the slot will take a lot of dullness out.The second stage is for the final sharpening stage. It uses ceramic rods to hone the knife for final use. If your knives are already fairly sharp but just need to be touched up, you can skip the first stage and just run them through the second stage ceramic rods.We have run most of our kitchen knives through the sharpener and are very pleased with the results. It does work great. When you run your thumb across the sharpened blade, you can feel like you will slice your thumb open if you gave any pressure at all. So, they are very sharp. The unit is very easy to clean. There are no hidden places that might collect metal filings or grime.Bottom line - I love this sharpener. It performs as advertised and does a fantastic job of sharpening my knives. Just remember not to press down too hard when sharpening - use a light touch and you will like the results.One note - The Amazon product page for this sharpener says that one of the benefits of this sharpener is that it can be used on serrated knives. I have tried it on a serrated bread knife and it works great. However, the box that the sharpener comes in says in big letters. "Warning - This product cannot be used on serrated Knives and scissors." I contacted the seller and they were very responsive. They told me that the box is inaccurate and they are redesigning the box to correct that statement. The sharpener cannot be used on scissors, but it works fine on serrated knives. Since I have used my sharpener on a serrated knife, I know that this is a true statement. So, for now, you can't pay attention to the warning on the box if you get one of these in the old design box.Another note - I received a complimentary sharpener from the seller in exchange for an honest review. I brought the mis-worded warning on the box to their attention and they have told me the box is being redesigned to correct that warning statement.

The wife and I are retired and one of our vices is Mickey Mouse. Yes, we are Mickey Heads. We belong to the Disney Vacation club so we are "forced" to travel the 1,100 miles South to Orlando at least twice a year to get our money's worth out of our annual park passes and to use our vacation club points. That is really not a problem since we like to take family and friends with us sometimes and sometimes we just go down by ourselves.One of the activities we have become really involved in is pin trading with the cast members and with the park goers. My sister is also a big Disney Head and likes to trade pins. She mounts hers on the wall in big picture frames that her husband makes. We like to keep our pins in albums. The albums are pretty expensive when you buy them at the Disney parks. They sell the albums with the inserts but we have not been able to find the inserts by themselves. I hate to buy more albums just to get the inserts, so when I ran across these on Amazon, I grabbed them to see if they were the same inserts as what comes with the whole album - and they are!The package gives you 5 Felt Covered Pin Pages and 5 Pin Dividers that match the ones in the album. So, we are able to add pages as we get more pins and don't have to spring for more albums, yet.For our purposes, this was a great find. At $23, it is expensive, but the album is $40 so at least you are saving some money by being able to continue to use your existing albums for a while longer.

Several years ago, I tore my right knee meniscus. My right leg swelled up something fierce clear down to my ankle and foot. Surgery fixed it for a while, but while i was helping my mother-in-law with some tree trimming duties, I had to climb ne of her trees and apparently tweaked it again. While the knee does not hurt, my right leg below the knee has been swelling up and down and bothering me. I read that compression socks could help reduce the swelling so I thought I would give it a try and ordered these socks to see if they worked.I am 6-2" tall and weigh about 200 pounds. The circumference of my ankle is about 10 1/2 inches around. My calf, at it fattest part, is about 15 1/2 inches around. I ordered the LARGE size sock and it turned out to be perfect for my leg. It does come ll the way up to my knee and provides a snug fit to keep my leg from swelling. It is hard to get on and off because of it;s length, so you have to work to get it to slide up your leg and pull tight up to your toes. But once on, it is comfy and I hardly notice it is on. I have other regular socks that are the same color, so I use one compression sock on the bad leg and a regular sock on the other leg. That way, when the one compression sock gets dirty, I have the other one to wear while the first one is washed.Note that these socks packaging says they must be washed by hand and air dried - not in a dryer. So, they are highr maintenance than a regular sock. I don't know how long they will hold up, but for the first few wears, they are working great and are doing the job to keep my right leg from swelling up like a balloon. I suppose I need to go back to the doctor, but I dislike going to the doc and I don't want more surgery which puts a cramp on my lifestyle for a long time.

My wife used these to make a baby quilt for a friend. It turned out fantastic and the mother was floored. The other side of the baby quilt was made from another piece of Dr. Suess material I found on Amazon.

My wife wanted this material to make a baby quilt for a friend who just had a baby. The baby's room is decorated all Dr. Seuss. The quilt came out fabulous and the baby's mother was pretty excited to get it. I am not the sewer, so you have to take my wife's word for it that this was a great buy and that it worked great for the baby quilt.

My computer desk is a mass of wires. I have a laptop that acts like a desktop so it sits on my desk all the time. I don't move it around. I have two printers, a network cable that goes to my router, an external hard drive, a cord that connects my computer to a stereo speaker system, a usb cable that I use to connect my smartphone to download pictures I take on my smartphone and an external keyboard that I hook up to my laptop and use instead of my laptop's keyboard. This leaves a mass of cables all around my computer.The colorful clamps in this organizer package is perfect for my use. Each of the stick-on rubberized clamp/holder will hold at least 2 cables - one in each slot. If you have smaller wires, like a stereo cord for your speakers and a usb keyboard cord, you can get 2 wires into one slot. A larger cable, like a network cable takes up most of the room in a slot.These clamps have a peel off backing that exposes the stickup that lets a clamp stick to a surface on your desk. I have them stuck on my destop and also on a side wall of my desk behind the laptop. They appear to stick really well. I have not had any problem with a clamp un-sticking or falling off any surface they are attached to in my configuration.The package comes with 6 clamps. 3 clamps took care of my configuration leaving me 3 more which I used at my mother-in-law's house. She is 90 years old but is a big computer user. She has an old house with really old wiring. Her spare room, where her desktop is located, does not have any wiring for cable. When mediacom installed her Internet service, they put the cable box in her bedroom where she originally had her computer. Later on, she wanted her computer moved out of the bedroom and into the spare room. I had to leave the router in her bedroom on top of a dresser and route a network cable back under her florr, through her basement, and up through a furnace grate in the bedroom. This means routing the cable around a door frame in the spare room to get it to the computer desk where her desktop now resides. I used these clamps to route the cable around the door frame. They stuck fine on her wall. I didn't have quite enough and had to go to home depot to get some generic cable holders - like what you would use for a telephone wire, and I had trouble getting them to stick on the wall. Any weight from the network cable would pull them off. But these cable organizer clamps help fine. We will see how they perform long term, but right now, I am very happy with their performance.Plus they are cool colors. They are made of some kind of rubberized material which makes it easy to pop a cable into a slot and pull it out again without dislodging the clamp from the surface it is attached to. The price is reasonable.Note that I received a complimentary package of clamps to try out and provide an honest review of how they worked for me.

All I can say is - This is an amazing device!What you get in the box:- Spiral vegetable slicer- Cleaning Brush- 3-In-1 Rotating Magic Slicer- Ceramic PeelerThe spiral vegetable slicer is the magic tool in the box. The cleaning brush is handy because the blades in the spiral slicer are very sharp and you want to get the brush down in there instead of a soft finger to clean out any residue after using. The ceramic peeler is also a useful tool to have around the kitchen. However, the Rotating 3-in-1 Magic Slicer could be dangerous. Basically, it is a round plastic cover over 3 different kinds of very sharp blades that give you different slicing effects. These blades are very sharp and you could easily cut yourself while cleaning this tool. Getting the thing to rotate through the different blades is also a head scratcher as there are no instructions in the box in how to use it. There is a white disk in the middle that you have to press down on one side to make the disk flip out so you have a handle you can grab with your fingers to rotate the blades that are inside the plastic disk. I am on the fence with this tool. The ceramic peeler that also comes in the box has the same function as one of the blades on the rotating peeler and I feel that the ceramic peeler is safer to clean than this rotating thing. Personally, the main tool in the box, the veggie spiral slicer is the the tool you will use and the other devices are things you might just throw in your kitchen drawer and forget about.So, on to the spiral slicer. It has comfortable metal hand grips on either side of the slicer which has two chambers. Each chamber has a different sized blade so you can get really slim veggie noodles, or thicker ones that are more like spaghetti depending on which chamber you use. I have never seen a tool like this before and was somewhat skeptical when I first looked at it. It works best with zucchini or similar kinds of squash that are somewhat firm, long, and round. So, you cut the ends off your zucchini, stick one end into the slicer and turn the zucchini with your hand. Out the side of the slicer comes nice long stings of zucchini - just like noodles. It works great. Just collect the sliced zucchini in a bowl for the next step of preparation.When you get down to where there is about 2-inches of zucchini left, there isn't enough finger room left to keep turning it with your hand. So, the slicer is provided with a cap that has short rods on the underside that you stick into the top of the zucchini to hold it tight and then you turn the cap to get as much of what zucchini is left through the slicer. You will still have a very short piece of zucchini left that you just can't get through the slicer, so I just cut the rest into small strips with a knife and throw it in with the rest of the "noodles." You will also end up with a small core which is the middle of the zucchini that pops out the bottom of the slicer. This will be the seedy middle. You can throw that away or slice it up and throw it in with the rest of the zucchini that you just noodled.The whole thing is very slick. Two medium zucchini will give you  a pretty good sized bowl of zucchini noodles. The way I used them, I added Mrs. Dash onion-herb seasoning and black pepper and mixed it well with the zucchini in the bowl. Get out a big skillet and pour in a couple tablespoons of EV olive oil or a couple tabs of butter. When hot, put the seasoned zucchini in the skillet and saute it for about 8-10 minutes or until it is crisp-tender. Then add some spaghetti or pasta sauce and let it cook a few more minutes to heat up the sauce. Sprinkle Parmesan cheese on top and eat up. We like to add organic chicken sausage sometimes along with the zucchini and let it cook with the zucchini noodles before adding the sauce later. What you end up with tastes a lot like real spaghetti but with none of the carbs.I believe, this slicer with change the way we eat pasta dishes. Zucchini noodles taste just as good, if not better than real pasta and they are a lot healthier. So, this will be a regular dish at our house for the foreseeable future.When you buy the slicer, you also get a link to an on-line recipe book which is in pdf format. It has pretty yummy looking recipes, most of which use zucchini for the noodles. Zucchini and yellow squash are the perfect size and shape to run through the spiralizer. There is some mention of using sweet potatoes in the spiralizer, but if you were to do that, you need to make sure your sweet potato is fairly long and skinny or it won't fit into the spiralizer opening. If you have to trim the sweet potato to fit, you will be losing some sweet potato or you will have to use a knife to cut the leftover waste into strips. Carrots are too small around to run through the spiralizer effectively. Basically, you should think zucchini and yellow squash for the main veggies to use with this tool. But the recipe book has some great ideas. My suggestion would be for the maker of this device to include the recipe book in the box instead of having you go to a website to download the recipes.All in all, this is a great tool. I am going to buy some for Christmas presents for several family members who are gluten intolerant and can't eat regular noodles. I received the unit I am reviewing for free in exchange for an honest review.

The wife and I have 3 devices we take with us on trips. We both have Motorola Droid RAZR phones and we have a kindle fire. This plug will handle all 3 at once, although the console area gets a little busy with so many devices plugged in.My wife's car is a chevy traverse and the lone cigarette lighter plug in the front seat is located in the center floor console under the car radio and to the right of the transmission stick shifter. There are plenty of cubby holes here - like a couple of cup holders, that will hold the phones while charging. Just be sure to use the USB individual cable that goes with the device you are charging. For the Motorola Droid RAZR, using a generic USB cable may make the phone charge a lot slower or not at all.The plug is compact, but fits our cigarette lighter just fine. Nice and tight and it doesn't stick out to get in the way of anything else. It has a couple small orange LED lights that glow when you plug it in to show that the device is working and doing its job. The ports are not marked, so you don't really know which one is the higher capacity port. It charges our RAZR phones just fine in all the ports. My wife has a RAZR Max which has a bigger battery that takes longer to charge than the standard battery in my RAZR, so it is hard to compare charging time. In my case, I don't really care about length of time to charge our phones. We live out in the boonies, so a trip anywhere takes some time. We have found that this plug works just fine for keeping our phones going when we are out and about. It took about 45 minutes to charge my phone from about 50% in what I think was the top connector which has more charging power than the other two.I like having the multiple connectors so we can charge are phones together. You can buy car chargers for our phones from Verizon, but at a premium price. The price for this plug is very reasonable in comparison, so it is a no-brainer to go this route for charging our phones.This plug appears to be well built, it works great, and compared to the expensive chargers at the Verizon storefront, this charger is a bargain. We like it a lot and use it a lot and have not had any problems.Note - I received an evaluation unit from Bolse in return for an honest review of the product.

I only recently learned about home pulse oximeter devices when I was asked if I wanted to evaluate such a device. I am a retired older gent (age 67) who tries to live a healthy lifestyle and the idea of being able to check my own blood oxygen levels was very intriguing. Like most guys, I don't like to go to the doctor and try to do my own self evaluations for health conditions. My wife says I am going to die on her someday because I don't see the doc when I should. But it is hard to change.I wear a pedometer and my goal is 10,000 steps per day, even if I am sick. I actually average 14,000 steps per day, so that is pretty good, I think. With all that walking, you would think that my body should be good at moving oxygen around to where it is needed in all my nooks and crannies. So, I was very interested in seeing what this device would measure.I recently had knee surgery to repair a torn meniscus and also had some sinus work done and both required general anesthesia at the hospital. When you are in the operating room, they clamp an oximeter to your finger and the stats display on a roll around screen so the anesthesiologist can monitor your breathing and pulse while you are under. So, I have seen these in action at the hospital and know what my readings were while I was there. I did not know you could get a model for home use until I saw this device on Amazon.For those who don't know about oxygen saturation in the human body, oxygen saturation is a term referring to the concentration of oxygen in the blood. The human body requires and regulates a very precise and specific balance of oxygen in the blood. Normal blood oxygen levels in humans are considered 95-100 percent. If the level is below 90 percent, it is considered low, resulting in hypoxemia. Blood oxygen levels below 80 percent may compromise organ function, such as the brain and heart, and should be promptly addressed. Continued low oxygen levels may lead to respiratory or cardiac arrest.So, that is a quick rundown. I received my oximeter and was surprised at how small it is. It fits over your finger just like the one at the hospital. This particular oximeter comes in a nice nylon carrying case and also has a lanyard that you can attach so you could carry it with you around your neck. Perhaps, as an athlete, you might want to keep it with you for when you are working out and want to check your heart-rate and how your body is delivering oxygen to your brain. I am not an athlete, so checking every now and then is good enough for me.So, how do one of these gadgets work? The big fold-up sheet 2-sided manual that comes with this oximeter has a huge amount of technical gobble-de-gook with equations and charts that will make no sense to a non-scientist.
