It was an enjoyable way to absorb information about one of the greatest bands in music history, and it's the kind of book you take in small pieces.  This book, "The Quotable Beatles", is similar in that it is made up of small snippets, but it's organized into more detailed categories--think of this as more of a reference, and a carefully researched one from the looks of it.  Where Rock Candy will wander into in-depth analysis of the music, "The Quotable Beatles" is more about the band and their experiences as they changed the world--and all of it straight from the horse's mouth.  It also includes some great quotes from other people too--not just those close to the band, but also people like Gene Simmons (Kiss), Mickey Dolenz (The Monkees), and even Ziggy Marley.The Beatles wrote some wonderful music, but they were also four very charming, witty, and smart people.  The Quotable Beatles reminds you how much their positive energy really contributed to the whole.  If you're a fan of The Beatles you will very much enjoy reading this collection of their brilliance.

Writing a trivia book is pretty easy to do; writing one that is also an enjoyable read is a different matter altogether.  While many trivia books take a "Just the facts, ma'am" approach to compiling information, Scott Robinson has assembled the information in a way that logically flows and delightfully entertains.  He does a great job moving between simple factoids and deep dives--there are entries that deconstruct the music, talk about the way albums were composed, and can get deeply technical about the artistry behind one of the greatest bands in the world.I really enjoyed the way Robinson tells the longer stories.  For example, my favorite is "What happens in Manila, Stays in Manila", his recounting of the disastrous and terrifying trip the Beatles took to The Philippines:  it's broken up into "The Snub", "The Escape", and "The Result."  We get a simple chart of the Beatles' number one hits...and then a walkthrough of each and its history.If you're a fan of The Beatles, "Rock Candy" is the book for you.  It is well written and painstakingly researched.  As the author advises, take it in small bites and enjoy each piece.

The Microsoft Docking Station for Surface Pro and Surface Pro 2 completely wins in the sense that it is the easiest fit.  Designed specifically to slide into place around your Surface Pro or Pro 2, it is also very sturdy, propping your device at an angle that makes it easy to read, touch, and swipe.  It is also really the only custom option for a Surface Pro or Pro 2:  everything else is generic and the Pro 3 docking station isn't backwards compatible.However, the Docking Station also has a few oddities that keep it from being perfect.  Probably the worst is that the physical network port is only a 10/100...with as long as gigabit Ethernet has been around, that's quite an unusual downgrade.  The power plug isn't the same as the one that comes with a Surface Pro, it's a custom plug--you'd think they'd use the same system to connect the power as the Surface Pro so the adapter wouldn't be unique.  There is no need to 'install' anything, though the package does warn you to make sure your Windows is up to date before connecting the device...and for me, I had to reboot to get the audio to work properly.Once you get these minor annoyances out of the way, the Docking Station makes great sense for when you're not on the go.  It can charge the unit, you get a USB 3.0 port and three USB 2.0 ports, plus headphone and microphone jacks for plugging in a headset, and last, if you want to make your very own workstation, the DisplayPort will be the perfect way to hook up a monitor.So what about the Touch or Type keyboards?  It's hard to tell from the pictures, but YES, you can keep the keyboard connected and use it if you'd like:  there's just enough clearance at the bottom of the dock for your favorite keyboard to stay connected.I'm living in an apartment right now, so the Docking Station is a great way to save space but quickly switch to a working mode:  I dock on the coffee table in front of the couch, hook up to the TV, and with my Bluetooth mouse I'm ready to do anything.  When I move back into a house, this is probably going to make my home office setup lean & mean:  just dock & go.If you have a Surface Pro or Pro 2 and are considering a docking station for it, now might be the time to take the plunge:  I've seen the price go up on these and I found my local retailer was charging nearly double the retail price for the ones they had in stock.  The Surface Pro 3 dock is out and I couldn't even get the Microsoft Store to acknowledge this item still exists.

Works perfectly!  I used this to be able to change the batteries on my daughter's beloved (and old!) Pokémon games.  The only drawback I encountered was finding that the batteries themselves need to be specifically purchased pre-wired and I'd need to do some soldering to swap them out...not the fault of the screwdriver, but something to be aware of. :)  A great choice and I'd buy it again if I needed to.

I really like the 4-port Monster power strip better than this one for when I'm lugging equipment with me:  for example, needing to plug in a laptop and a powered USB hard drive or two.This Outlets to Go 3-outlet power strip with USB is a great solution for a slightly simpler need:  when I'm mobile and need to top off a USB-charge unit it's just fine.The Outlets To Go power strips are a bit heavy because they have a sturdy design to the outlets, the cable and the plug.  The plastic plate on the front of the plug has an unfortunate tendency to fall off or even break, but that doesn't affect the function--I have one of mine stuck back on with double-sided tape on the back.However, the other drawback is that the USB charging port is a slow trickle that's better suited for either topping off a device when it's a bit low or leaving a device overnight for a long charge.  For example, it works fine to put my Kindle on when I go to bed, but I wouldn't expect it to save my phone when it's nearly dead and I need it in an hour.I recently bought two of these for a perfect home use though:  I have two of those "charging valets", small boxes that let you thread a lot of charging cables out of sight and poke the connectors out through the lid.  One is for my room and one I bought for my daughter.  A standard-size power strip would be awkward and huge--if not impossible--to tuck into so small of a box, so I use the smaller Outlets To Go to plug in all the chargers, and the USB goes for my Kindle, which doesn't mind a slow overnight charge.If you lower your expectations a bit, the quality of the Outlets to Go is pretty consistent with its price.  The USB charger could use a bit more power, but the outlets and the way the cord folds up are both very convenient.

I recently bought this to replace the Energizer charger, which worked great for a while but developed a weird quirk where it refused to charge some controllers.  The Energizer charger that I had also couldn't do a Move controller, and leaving one more device out (the special charger for the Move controller) when the Move is almost barely used was a bit of a nuisance.So far, this one has worked very well for an incredibly low price.  I don't like to leave the PS3 turned on for hours just to charge a single controller, so this makes things easier for me.  I will say there are two things that might have been better off if they'd done it a bit differently:1) the neon-blue glow doesn't just light up when something is connected, it's glowing all the time.  I found this distracting so close to my TV, so I put the charger in an entertainment center's cabinet.2) the USB ports are a nice plus, but being on the back of the unit is a little inconvenient for plugging in a device to charge.  On the sides or front would have been a bit more helpful.These are minor quibbles though:  overall this charger is a helpful addition to your PS3.

The short summary:  the M570 works well for a good price, but might be inconvenient for people with large hands or long fingers.  If you're considering the M570 for portability, its small size makes a great choice to drop into a laptop bag:  no need for counter-space in your favorite café because the trackball doesn't need to move around on a tabletop to work.  I have no complaints with the hardware, but the software was a bit of a problem.the full review:I used to love using trackballs, but they were all much bigger than the M570.  They were also heavier:  the M570 is very lightweight and almost feels hollow.  It closely resembles the Microsoft Trackball that leaves all the mouse movements to your thumb, and I found I preferred that to the kind of trackball that uses your fingertips.  The M570 has an excellent design in that the single AA battery easily fits in the underside and the shape of the trackball is very comfortable for small to medium sized hands.  I find it a bit too small for my medium-to-largish hands (I'm 5'11" tall, with a ring size of 10) but for general computing it gets the job done.  If you're considering the M570 for portability, its small size makes a great choice to drop into a laptop bag:  no need for counter-space in your favorite café because the trackball doesn't need to move around on a tabletop in order to work.The trackball is a responsive piece of equipment, and from a gaming perspective I always loved that slight edge I could get from being able to spin so quickly.  However, I'm not sure a pro who's used to their own customized gaming mouse would want to give that up for the M570:  we're still working at wireless speeds.Which brings me to the wireless.  This isn't Bluetooth, which is a shame, but it is the Logitech Unifying Device system, and that can be a pretty nice system indeed.  I've had some really weird problems with Bluetooth mice and keyboards in Windows 7 (that I blame the OS for) but Plug & Play for the Unifying Device was a breeze.  The signal is emitted from a tiny USB connector that barely pokes out of the port you plug it into.  Windows 7 had the drivers for it automatically installed in under a minute and the trackball was immediately ready to go.Unfortunately, I couldn't get any of the Logitech software to work.  The website for the M570 confusingly asks if you want the latest Unifying Device or SetPoint software, but I couldn't get either to properly function--instead, I just left it in Plug & Play's hands.  If you want to use SetPoint you might want to keep this in mind.  My problem was that the software would install, but could never actually pair with the trackball, so after several tries I just gave up and the track ball works fine.If you remember how enjoyable a trackball was, or you want to try the idea, the M570 makes a great choice.  I enjoy using it, and though I was a bit disappointed in flaky software I'm perfectly happy with the Plug & Play solution.

The short version: I've used and worked on a lot of wireless products over the years. I bought this to go with my Netgear R6300 and it's almost been too good. The external antennas that improve signal quality, coupled with the fact that the device has 5 Gigabit Ethernet Ports *and* a USB connection (for a READYSHARE storage device or a printer) make it a perfect fit for a tech-heavy home where you want a strong high-speed signal for a lot of devices.The full review:Right now I live in an apartment complex that has problems at the edges of my unit, most likely because I'm surrounded by so many other wireless networks. When I move back in to a house, this is going to make a perfect addition for another reason: the place your Internet Provider can bring your connection into the house isn't always the place you put your entertainment center. I plan on running physical cables into this extender for my HTPC, television, consoles and Yamaha Receiver, so again this will do quite nicely.The AC1200 (EX6200) looks very similar in shape and size to my R6300 router, though it is deliberately colored with red trim pieces to make it visually different. It can be wall-mounted or the included stand can be used to set it upright on a table--for now, mine is on top of a cabinet. Setup is extremely simple if you have WPS:- Turn on the extender- Push the WPS button on the extender- Push the WPS button on the router- wait- Power down and back on if the connectivity light is flickering or you have 5GHz on the router and the extender's 5GHz light isn't litOne note about this last step: I'm not sure the 5GHz light will be lit if no devices are trying to access a 5GHz connection. I say this because the 5GHz light isn't always on, but if I log into the Extender it indicates the 5GHz band is connected and running. Unless you're having throughput issues, this slight difference in how the light behaves might not mean anything to you. It's easy to test your speeds using various wireless speed testing apps, and you can explicitly connect to the Extender only for this test because it will appear by name as "[your network name]_2GEXT" for 2.4 GHz and "[your network name]_5GEXT" for 5GHz.If you don't have WPS, all is not lost; you can log directly into the unit and manually point it to your network and it will act as an extension of that network. The physical documentation included in the package is minimal, but the online docs and the interface are all fairly easy to use for those familiar with technology. I logged into the unit and found that the interface was very similar to the one for my router, but was tailored specifically to this device's role as an Extender: in other words, this wasn't just a router that had been colored differently and tweaked, it really is dedicated hardware and software.  As an added bonus, the back has a slide-out card with all the information you might need at a glance:  model, serial number, MAC Addresses and PIN.NOTE: There are some customers here that have problems with specific MAC address filtering, and from what I've seen Netgear's response is that this is the nature of Extender technology. If you have MAC filtering enabled, I suggest you stop by Netgear's site and read the manual before purchasing an extender.This product is compatible with the Netgear speed measuring tool offered through the Google Play store and it easily fits in with the Netgear Genie.I've been very happy with the quality of Netgear products, and the AC 1200 (EX6200) is no exception - it's as feature-rich as the R6200/6300 routers but also as easy to use as their other products have been for me. If you're having signal problems or want to set up a dedicated home entertainment center station, this Extender makes a great choice.

If you're having signal problems or want to set up a dedicated home entertainment center station, this Extender makes a great choice.

I love the way this book lays out the entirety of Team Foundation Server 2012, but it should be noted that the focus is more towards those first steps of getting it going.  There are lots of very useful sections about what TFS is, how you should configure the environment based on the size of your organization, and how to configure TFS for your organization.  But then we get into some really good deep-dive material that's aimed at helping you make decisions:  the authors describe the options and what they mean, and then they also provide suggestions as to when to choose which one.  I'm thinking in particular of the sections on Version Control and Project Management.One thing I like in particular is they address some very real-world scenarios, such as using TFS with Eclipse, or migrating from Visual Source Safe or Eclipse.  Third-party tools and some of the options you have in integrating with them are very worthwhile reading if your shop uses them.Team Foundation Server can be a massive undertaking.  If you're new to it, you should take it one step at a time.  Professional Team Foundation Server 2012 does a good job of walking you through those steps.

This is my second foray into this series of books (and I'm about to delve into the 2013 edition), and I can't recommend them enough.  Whether you're using Visual Studio on its own or with Team Foundation Server (which I highly recommend), this is the book that speaks to the nuts & bolts of the business.  It gives you a lot of information about how the SDLC components in Visual Studio work and it is written in a way that lets you make specific decisions about how you want to implement Visual Studio / TFS in your business.  It also serves as a good reference to learn the individual components of Visual Studio if all you want to do is model diagrams, or mockups, or just Bugs & User Stories.My organization used this book extensively for our Project Managers and Business Analysts.  We had testers but the materials on Testing are probably enough to make an entire book unto itself, so you won't get a lot of specifics on that here.  However, the way Work Items are used, the Architecture Explorer, and the way you can model your application's work and/or do mockups is covered very well.  Visual Studio 2012 changed the way things work quite a bit, but the changes have ultimately been for the better.  I'm very pleased with how much this book extends the also-excellent 2010 version.  The language is good for a non-technical person to understand and the level of detail is just about right for beginner to intermediate level use of Visual Studio / TFS.If you want to talk about the technical side of implementing Team Foundation Server, such as how to install, configure, or transition your team, I also recommend the book "Professional Team Foundation Server" - think of that book as your 'Initiation Phase' guide and this book as your 'Planning & Implementing Phase' book.

I love these goggles:  I can't think of a single thing that doesn't work as I'd hoped it to or better.  For example, I'd expected the band to be no big deal and instead I get an easy-to-use plastic clasp and the adjustment system lets you pull the straps from either side.  It easily clicks more or fewer notches for tightness.  I've just used them a couple of times now, but the lenses themselves are really clear and on a bright day that mirror tinting helps.  They fit comfortably around my eye sockets and don't have to create too much pressure to keep the water out.  The gaskets around the eyepieces are probably what solves this problem because they're thick and curved in a way that will probably fit most faces.There have been a couple of times that the lenses have fogged up briefly:  both were after swimming in a cold pool and then standing in very hot summer air for a bit--taking them off for half a minute solved the problem.I also like the fact that we have a hard case to protect the googles from scratches:  it locks closed with a twist of the plastic knob on the end.My wife and I both have a pair and will be ordering a third for our daughter:  for the price, you really get a lot of great details and a good clear view.

It's really easy to make Nazis the bad guys in a game--but after all the Call of Dutys and Medal of Honors, what's hard is making a game that centers around Nazis and can still make the bad guys seem original and new.  I'm someone who's played every incarnation of the "Castle Wolfenstein" games, even a very strange kiosk that you could pay-to-play the older 486 PC version using a joystick and a VR headset.  Having recently re-played the "Return to Castle Wolfenstein", it was a real experience to pick up this newest entry in the series."Wolfenstein: the New Order" is a great update to this classic series.  First-Person Shooters have changed a lot in the many years this series has been around, and the updates here really give a classic concept the feel of the latest & greatest that FPS games have to offer.  There is a good storyline, complete with top-drawer voice talent and the return of our hero B. J. Blascowicz.  We have weapon choices that include dual-wield, fast action with many a melee opportunity, and the same feel of collecting medkits and armor and occasionally overcharging your health for an upcoming rampage that made all of The New Order's predecessors so much fun.  Probably the best nod to the more recent games is the fact that there's more than one way to complete a level:  this isn't just a matter of being able to navigate the map through different paths, it's also that you can make choices that let you vary between stealth and run-and-gun.  FPS games don't often have the ability to view the map these days, so that makes for a nice bonus that is carried over from the earliest days of the Wolfenstein series.What makes the story fresh is that we are playing to an alternate history:  after an opening mission in 1946, our hero is out of commission until 1960, and it's a world where the Nazis won the war, all has been lost, and now B.J. is left to try to pick up the pieces entirely on his own.  Each level is a movie-quality step towards saving the world, and each level has a purpose that advances the main story.  The alternate 1960 is a mix of technologies that has a fairly believable look and feel, and some of the 'newer' technology mirrors the strangeness we saw in the depths of 'Return to Castle Wolfenstein' and the occult-driven more recent entry that was just called 'Wolfenstein'.As much fun as the game is, there are a few drawbacks.  I've had times where climbing a ladder is still the bane of Our Hero's existence and I spend time bobbling around looking for the grip point.  Switching weapons isn't a fast way to keep the firepower flowing when the bullets are low--sometimes it's just a trip to a quick death.  Changing ammo with the radial wheel can be clumsy.  I have a real problem with grenades:  sometimes I bump the shoulder button to throw (hold down means you want to select weapons) and nothing happens.  I won't spoil the story for you, but there is one particular mission that sounds like a great squad-based opportunity but by the time you reach the end you find yourself wondering what the point was.Still, "Wolfenstein:  the New Order" is a great title, and I think with time I'll come to love it as much as its predecessors, some of which I still play today.

I've been using the Gillette Mach 3 for years, and even though I've tried others from time to time, I keep coming back to their three-blade system.  These cartridges have been a great replacement, but I think there's something important you should consider when buying them.  There are negative reviews here where customers say they got fake or knock-off replacements.  I added this to cart by picking a Prime eligible product that says "Shipped from and sold by Amazon", and the package that arrived is the real deal.If you're new to the Mach 3, it's a great razor for a lot of things.  I have a friend who swears by it for shaving his head, but says you have to be slow and careful.  For me, it does a great job on my face and neck.  The three hyper-sharp blades in the Mach 3's head really do a nice job of paring down the daily stubble without cutting me up or roughing up my face.  That said, there are some basics to shaving that also make a difference, regardless of what you use:- drag slowly- drag in the direction the hair grows (and learn the parts of your face where it changes direction)- don't press down- do repeat strokes for problem areas- expect to feel some stubble no matter what--the goal is to minimize it, but it'll never go away unless you pluck the hairs out (ouch!)- when you towel off, pat your skin, don't scrub- if you're going to put something on your skin afterwards, avoid anything with alcohol in it: alcohol burns your skin while lotions moisturizeI use these in a standard Mach 3 handle and in one that vibrates using a AAA battery.  The latter is a bit easier to use, but not necessary:  either will work for you just fine.  There is a more expensive version of these blades for sensitive skin that is supposed to have better lubricating strips, but I don't find that to be worth the extra money...if anything the strips on the 'Sensitive' just wear out quicker than these do.If you're new to the Mach 3, it's a great razor. But unless shaving gives you real skin problems, you probably don't need the extra 'Sensitive' strip...these cartridges do a great job.

I've been using the Gillette Mach 3 for years, and I've used both these "Sensitive" heads and the standard blue-colored ones off and on.  I have the normal Mach 3 handle and the one that vibrates using a AAA battery--which I have to admit does seem to work a little bit easier.The idea behind this "Sensitive" version of the Mach 3 blades is that there's an more soothing kind of whatever goo Gillette feels will soothe the burn of dragging three hyper-sharp blades of steel across your face.I love the Gillette Mach 3 razor, don't get me wrong...but I see little additional benefit in the Sensitive versus the regular, and I don't care for how quickly it wears out.  If you want to save a bit of money, the normal ones should do you just fine.  Part of shaving is knowing the nuances of the act itself:- drag slowly- drag in the direction the hair grows (and learn the parts of your face where it changes direction)- don't press down- do repeat strokes for problem areas- expect to feel some stubble no matter what--the goal is to minimize it, but it'll never go away unless you pluck the hairs out (ouch!)- when you towel off, pat your skin, don't scrub at it- if you're going to put something on your skin afterwards, avoid anything with alcohol in it:  alcohol burns your skin while lotions moisturizeIf you're new to the Mach 3, it's a great razor.  But unless shaving gives you real skin problems, you probably don't need the extra 'Sensitive' kind.

The Final Rip-Off was a labor of love on the part of the Pythons:  released in the late '80s, this collection was not only a fun sampling of some of their best comedy skits, it was also very lovingly remastered.  Some of the original versions of these skits didn't have the musical flourish that they have here.  There are pieces lifted from the movie "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" and others that come straight from the record albums, such as from "Monty Python's Instant Record Collection".  While some fans don't care for particular recordings of this or that skit (in particular, some of the live versions are a point of contention), I really enjoy it all.There is an important thing to know about the CD though, and it's what kept me from replacing my factory cassette version of The Final Rip-Off for years.  The first printings had some problems:  a friend of mine bought the discs and they rotted after a few months.  She managed to convince the store to swap out for her, and the replacements rotted too...I'm pleased to say that the CDs I purchased only this year (2014) have been of excellent quality and worked well.If you enjoyed Monty Python's comedy, The Final Rip-Off is a very nice collection of some of their funniest bits.  Some jokes are better seen than heard, but still the recordings hold up well.  Extra effort was put into this release, though that was some time ago, and today it's still loads of fun to listen to.  A completist might want to go back and find all the individual albums, and gain more material, but for me this is a nice distillation of some of Monty Python's best.

This tuner was fairly easy to install, though it did require a little bit of help from Kenwood to get my DDX-500 to recognize the unit.  Kenwood's phone support was friendly and helpful, and after a couple of adjustments to the settings, we were off and running.  Installation is simple, and because it has a pass-through to your car's antenna, it doesn't matter where this tuner box goes--you can stick it under the dash or behind some stuff and your car's antenna is what picks up the HD Radio signal.If you've got a Kenwood head unit that is compatible with this tuner box, and it says "HD Ready" or "HD Capable", then hooking this up will not change your AM/FM radio availability--instead it will expand it so that any signals broadcast in HD Radio will automatically come through clear as a bell.  I didn't get the HD quality sound until I moved to a different area, but I did notice that when HD Radio comes through, it works well.  Some stations will even include metadata that pops up on your screen, like artist, album and title (and some head units can even show a thumbnail image of the station or album art).

Futurama is an animated comedy from Matt Groening, the creator of 'The Simpsons'.  The Simpsons often cracked us up with social satire, but Futurama turned the Simpsons' reality-based sandbox into a completely free and open playground of the future for the writers' minds to run free.Set in the year 3000, the main character Fry is a dimwit with heart.  He is from our time, and when an accident gets him cryogenically frozen for 1,000 years, we get to see Groening's bizarre future through his eyes.  He voices our 20th-century opinions, and he sets up some of the best jokes in the series.  Fry meets a lot of unusual people, and the core stable of characters that are introduced to us will have you and your friends regularly debating the merits of your favorites.When Futurama first aired on Fox, it got a weird mix of 'show it to everybody' airings of each week's episode across multiple time slots...and also got Fox's 'try to kill it' treatment of randomly moving the new episodes.  Somehow, it managed to survive, and if you watch this first season, you can see why Futurama wasn't just "Simpsons in Space", but was instead a huge green field for these clever writers to play upon.  Drawing on the entire history of science fiction, Futurama satirizes our modern-day society with ease.  We have an opening episode featuring suicide booths, an alcoholic robot with a criminal mind, an everyday New New York City (yes, I typed that correctly) whose definition of 'normal' boggles the 20th-century mind, and hilarious series of laugh after laugh.I own this particular box set, and I really enjoy the fact that I get director's commentary--but if you're contemplating buying the entire series, you might want to look into the collected versions:  they don't appear to leave anything out and they might have even a bit more to offer than this collection.  Either way, Futurama is one of my favorite shows of all time.

Just about every song on this album was a hit when the movie came out.  Years later, I got an itch to finally replace my cassette so I could hear all these great songs again, and the only way to do it was to buy a real CD--no MP3 album?  How quaint!  How far we've come from the days when a CD was the most amazing way to hear music.Which brings us to the music.  We have Patti LaBelle's "New Attitude" kicking off the music nicely.  She comes back later with the energetic '"Stir It Up", and in between, the Pointer Sisters' "Neutron Dance" was the song that seemed to run all summer long back when this album came out.  "Gratitude" by Danny Elfman was my first exposure to that delightfully quirky voice (and who knew back then what a great composer he would become?)--it led me to Oingo Boingo's excellent album "Dead Man's Party."  Glenn Frey is also solo from The Eagles, doing "The Heat Is On", complete with classic '80s keyboards and sax, and that song also got tons of play back in the day.  Probably very few people remember Shalamar, but their song here, "Don't Get Stopped in Beverly Hills", couldn't compare to their hit "Dancing in the Sheets".  "Rock n' Roll Me Again" has classic '80s guitar notes, but like "Emergency" by Rockie Robbins, just fails to stand out.So here's some trivia for you:  this isn't the first release of the Beverly Hills Cop soundtrack!  I bought my cassette the week it was released and that release was recalled.  There was a Rick James track named "BHC (I Can't Stop)" that was pulled and replaced with "Emergency".  Sad, but I'm also sorry to say that even if you're a Rick James fan you probably wouldn't be blown away by his original song either.If you loved Beverly Hills Cop or just want to grab one of the most memorable '80s pop movie soundtracks, this soundtrack makes a great pick.

The Lazy Winner is a great all-purpose book for a working professional to balance their life.  As a parent who also has to work the hard, random hours of IT, I found it to be part philosophical guide, part psychological self-help.  Continuing on the success of his excellent book "The Lazy Project Manager", Peter Taylor describes to you how to organize your thoughts and your day to put you on the path to success.  I found The Lazy Project Manager at a time in my career when I had to take on a lot more challenges than I ever had before--it helped me figure out how to be a hero without a Superman complex.  The Lazy Winner reminded me that at some point my life could probably use a little of that Project Management methodology in my home life too.  IT can all too easily lure you with the Siren Song of 80-hour weeks bringing success...use The Lazy Winner to remind you that if you plan your life a little better, you won't let yourself be run into the ground.

This pair of 6-foot HDMI cables is the latest spec and appears to be well built.  The cables are thick with a sturdy outer layer and the sleeves at each end don't look cheap:  they are molded on well enough to hold together.  The right-angle adapter makes this an even better deal though:  when your TV is close to the wall or you're plugging up in a tight space, this is what will save your cable because the neck of your cable won't need to be bent and/or crushed against anything.  Two adapters might have been nice, but chances are most people wouldn't need more than one--so given the price, I can't complain a bit.  As an added bonus, my box even contained a tiny keychain flashlight, perfect for trying to peek behind my Dad's TV when I was trying to set up his cabling.The cable ties are simple Velcro strips, but the useful part is that they're labeled with Twisted Veins' name:  if you use these to tie and bundle a set of cables, you'll be able to tell at a glance which bundle you're reaching for.  If you've ever had to go back behind your A/V equipment and redo things, you'll appreciate this little extra touch.

I've recently fallen in love with the newer 3DTV technology, and this simple set of 4 glasses was just what I needed for my family and I to watch our movies on my Vizio 47" 3DTV.  They are a little more comfortable than the 2 pair that came with the TV, and that's nice; but the price was also reasonable.

I've used several of Samsung's SSD products in the 830 and 840 series, but in the past, price had kept me from going for the EVO.  This time around, I had the luck (and money) to do so, and I don't regret it.  If you really get deep down in the technical jargon and start looking at things like MLC/TLC, IOPS and Random/Sequential reads, for most people the numbers aren't substantially different...but the EVO line's prices have started to come down, and that makes things very different indeed.I bought the 1TB version and it's dedicated to gaming:  my OS is on a smaller Samsung 840 EVO mSATA drive, and although there are slight differences in the mSATA spec, performance for my system is really even across the board.  If you have the money and you don't have SSD yet, this is about as good as it gets.  You'll be amazed at the huge increase in speed coming from an older hard drive.  If you're already using SSDs, the 840 EVO series is a great bet for performance-heavy work like gaming, animation, video production, etc.The only drawback you should be aware of is the Samsung tools that come with the drive.  They can be hit or miss.  When they work, it's a beautiful thing, and you can migrate your entire computer from the old drive to the new, then slip the new drive in and you're ready to go.  When they don't work....they just *won't* work.  I had one Samsung Magician migration that told me because it couldn't defragment the empty SSD drive, it wouldn't copy my machine's hard drive to it (can't we just defrag it AFTER loading files on?  SSDs don't really "defrag" the same way anyway--fragmentation shouldn't be an issue).  Samsung's support was decent, but they told me to give up and use Macrium Reflect.  Macrium Reflect works great, but this was annoying.  On another occasion though, the migration worked perfectly.  The same is true of the optimization tools:  sometimes they won't detect my drive, and I'd have to manually tweak performance; and other times (like with this volume), all was well and I could very easily choose whether I wanted speed, storage, or long life.If you're in the market for an SSD, I highly recommend Samsung's 840 series.  If you have the extra bit of cash to go for the EVO line, if you're looking for performance you won't be disappointed.

The Sandman story is a very long saga that helped break the mold of comic book writing.  Among a handful of other titles at the time it ushered in the term 'graphic novel', surprised people by being labeled 'not for sale to minors', and garnered author Neil Gaiman the distinction of being the first comic book author to be recognized (and rewarded) by the Science Fiction Writers of America (thank you, Harlan Ellison).  The story is at times fantasy, horror, or everyday people whose lives become surreal, and it rubs shoulders with a wide variety of already-established characters--both superhero and non--in the DC Comics universe.  Our protagonist is literally the personification of Dream:  Morpheus, the Lord of the Dream Realm, and his godlike nature makes it easy to move our story to limitless times and places.This Omnibus edition is a massive slab of a book.  It is huge and heavy.  The binding appears to be sewn to keep it together (it is over 1,000 pages), and the print quality, from paper to coloring, is excellent.  This 'Omnibus Vol.1' represents approximately half of the story arc of The Sandman and I'm delighted to have it in my collection now.  If you're pondering this book, chances are you're already familiar with and a fan of the story, and in my case I am proud to say I purchased this in order to be able to share the world of The Sandman with my daughter.  Compared to the price of tracking down all the individual trade paperbacks, the high price is actually a very good deal, particularly given the quality of the book.

X-Men Origins: Wolverine (the film that came before this one) had some disappointing moments, particularly to the hardcore fans.  I really enjoyed "The Wolverine" though, and if there's one real flaw to this movie, it's just that there wasn't a particular need to make it.  This is a great one-off story about The Wolverine.  It takes place after the events of the third X-Men movie ("X-Men III:  The Last Stand") and in some ways this story attempts to address some of the issues with that movie, filling in bits that legitimize some of the unpleasant tragedies that for some fans really marred that film.The Wolverine has some really great moments.  It starts with an interesting backstory set during World War II and as it brings the story forward to modern day, Logan has a chance to explore his own needs.  He questions what it means to go on living, and he examines the things that have happened in the past.  I'm reluctant to spoil this story too much for you, so I'll focus on some of the basics:- it has some fantastic martial arts sequences- it has one of the best 'top of a train' fight scenes I've ever seen--a sequence that reminds me of the excitement of the highway battle in the second Matrix movie because it gives a couple of nods to that scene.- our hero has the proverbial rug pulled out from under him:  he isn't as strong as he usually is, there is a lot more real danger for him, and because the movie takes place almost entirely in Japan, he's in unfamiliar territory- Hugh Jackman pulled out all the stops in trying to give Logan emotional depth while still keeping his character the warrior that he is--we get some great acting in this film, particularly at the very beginning and very end.This review is for the 3D Blu-Ray though, so I have to take a moment to say that this is a pretty full package.  I like the fact that we get both the original and Extended editions.  The 3D aspect is a lot more mature:  the movie doesn't use 3D to see how many things it can throw at your eyes.  Instead it tries to paint a three-dimensional world.  I watched this on my Vizio 47" 3D HDTV in 1080p and loved the feel of it:  the 3D look made my TV more like a window with the action inside of it.If you haven't seen this movie yet because one of the previous films disappointed you, I think you'll be pleased with the improvement here.  If I had to compare "The Wolverine" to "X-Men Origins: Wolverine", I'd say I'm much happier to have this movie than that one, and glad I paid a bit extra for the Extended Edition.  It doesn't have any critical story tie-ins to the new movie "X-Men: Days of Future Past", so consider this an entertaining side story.

The Vita version of the Final Fantasy X/X2 HD remaster is a small-screen version of the PS3 release.  However, there is one thing you should be aware of about this edition:  the PS3's Blu-Ray holds both games, but the Vita's game card can't--you'll need to download X2 on your own and this package contains the download code for you.That said, since this is an HD remaster of a PS2 classic, the new look is great on the Vita.  The gameplay isn't going to do anything different in the remaster, it's just an upgraded port.  But the game still plays well today, and looking at both versions I don't see a visual difference between either the PS3 or the Vita system.

Windows 7 was one of those rare occasions where I pre-ordered the OS, and since its release in 2009 I haven't been disappointed.  I bought this one specifically for a friend of mine who's building a machine from scratch and lives in a country where it's hard to get the English version of the OS--but I've used the 64-bit OEM myself many a time.If you've been spending the last 8 years in Windows Vista, you're way overdue for a Windows 7 system.  You'll find a much friendlier interface, fewer UI nags about security and permissions, a more stable OS, and a lot more driver compatibility.  Although this is a 'System Builder' DVD, it will let you install over the top of an existing Vista install and will even attempt to keep your old files.  Technically you're expected to use an upgrade for that job though (and it's cheaper).If you're weighing Windows 7 against Windows 8 (and this week we're getting our first sneak peeks at Windows 9!), then the biggest reason to pick up an OEM Windows 7 right now is compatibility.  Windows 8 doesn't have higher system requirements than 7, but it does have a harder time catering to older apps than Windows 7 does, and there have been issues with some older programs (and some people REALLY don't like the Windows 8 interface).Probably the biggest difference in compatibility is that Windows 7 offers a feature called Windows XP Mode, which isn't the same as "XP Compatibility Mode"--we still have that too--but Windows XP Mode is in fact a real Windows XP Virtual Machine that you can download, install, and add yourself under the covers in Windows 7.  The Virtual Machine will run to let you specifically launch picky XP-only programs in the background and maintain much closer compatibility.I have a great desktop computer that I upgraded from Windows 7 to 8.  Unfortunately, there were just too many minor issues in Windows 8 that my machine couldn't cope with, and back to my OEM 7 disc I went.  Windows 7 is still a great OS today, so if like me you have a downgrade situation, this might be just the thing for you.

The authors of the Brady guide went to great lengths to try to document the gameplay of Final Fantasy X/X2, and while the new HD remaster isn't extremely different from the original, it does look like they reviewed the material and updated the guide to read like it's for the remaster.Final Fantasy is a game series that usually requires you to do some digging online or have a book like this because the games can be very rich and complicated:  Final Fantasy X is very much like this, with parts of the game being "If you don't get it the first time, you won't have another chance without starting over!"  It's times like these that having a strategy guide is incredibly handy.The only real drawback here is in the details.  The section on Final Fantasy X is somewhat short.  There were times I wanted to get some advice on the best way to equip my party, and the advice was inline with the walkthrough.  I'd like to see this sort of thing laid out in a separate table.  There were a few occasions that I would have appreciated a bit more information.  For example, there's a quicktime-styled event that they're good enough to warn you will only take place one time and you want to save before trying it so you can reload until you get it (if you're a completist), but then I didn't really have good advice on how to succeed--I had to rely on a lot of trial and error.I think as strategy guides go, this is still the most useful (printed) guide that you'll find.  I think the Piggyback guides to Final Fantasy XIII spoiled me though--I'd like a little bit of those extras here.

I've had a variety of Samsung (and other) SSDs, and while I don't always reach for the EVO line, in this case, the EVO was just about my only option.  This is an mSATA SSD, and my laptop uses mSATA for its primary drive, so finding a good mSATA SSD with a decent size isn't easy.I'm glad I did this upgrade.  I've had great performance with a variety of 830, 840, and EVO series Samsung SSD drives, and the mSATA is no different.The Samsung software that comes with the drives can be hit or miss:  tools like the Samsung Magician have worked just fine for me to tweak the performance and check all the OS settings to be sure TRIM is enabled, etc.  Sometimes in the past though I've had the tool be unable to recognize a drive.  I've also had the backup tool that transfers an OS from a different drive to my Samsung SSD work perfectly or not work at all, with little in between.  Your mileage may vary.This was a clean install of Windows 8.1 and all went very well.  I'm still a satisfied Samsung customer.

I use this two-bay drive carrier mostly for shuffling files around between external disks stored at different locations.  I find it very handy to be able to use a single carrier and only one USB 3 port when making file copies.  I like that each drive gets its own link and activity LED so you know that the drive is connected to the computer and when it is active.Because the drive carrier is a single USB device, you cannot eject individual drives from Windows.  Instead, it will only let you “eject” the Mediasonic device which means both installed drives will disappear at the same time.  This isn’t a problem for me but it is something to be aware of.The clone feature works well for making an exact copy of a drive.  Everything from the partition table and master boot record (MBR) with drive signature is cloned.  Using two OCZ SSD drives, I got 300MB/s when cloning: impressive!  During cloning the four LEDs for link and activity change function and become a progress indicator (25/50/75/100%).  Pretty handy way to know how far along a clone is.Best of all on the cloning, you don’t need the carrier connected to a USB port to clone drives; it is completely self contained.  So if you decide to upgrade the main drive on your laptop, you simply physically remove it from the laptop, clone it in the carrier, then put the new drive back into your laptop and you’re done.  That’s a lot easier than using some drive cloning software.I mention that even the MBR and drive signature are cloned.  This can cause you problems with Windows if you later try to mount two cloned drives at the same time.  Because they have the same drive signature, Windows will consider this an error and will silently decide not to show you one of the drives.  Fortunately, you can go into the disk manager and bring it online manually by right-clicking on the drive and choosing “online”.So far I’m very happy with the Mediasonic drive docking station.  I use it a lot and it has worked great so far.

This is hands down the best body trimmer I've used.  Other trimmers I've used suffer from one or more of these problems such as terrible battery life, difficulty in cutting, or just plain nicking and cutting my skin!  This Panasonic doesn't have those problems.  With the body hair attachment installed, this trimmer glides over even the most sensitive skin and does not cut you.  Most of your hair is trimmed down in just one pass.The battery life is quite good and I love that it has an LED indicator to tell you how much power is left.  I also love that you can use this while plugged in just in case you do have a dead battery.  Small complaint, but I wish this had a lithium-ion battery for those times when it sits unused for a few weeks.  The batteries in this will slowly deplete, even when sitting unused.The trimmer can work in water and that makes it very easy to rinse and clean.  It also includes lubricating drops to keep the blade system in tip-top shape.  Overall this product seems built to last a lifetime.  Everything is very finely machined and sturdy.  I expect it to last a very long time.Wish list:I wish that when trimming body hair, the length was adjustable.  Instead it seems to shoot for skin close.  I don't want that everywhere on my body.  What I do to fix this is I don't snap the hair guide all the way onto the trimmer head.  That leaves a little length and doesn't cut skin tight.  As long as I don't push too hard, it keeps that length and works great.  It does come with an adjustable trimmer attachment for long hair, but that hair guide has huge openings and you could easily get your skin stuck in there (and cut yourself) if you trimmed any sensitive body parts.  I don't recommend using the longer hair guide except for trimming your head!Note:If you are trimming body hair, you need to follow the instructions and only trim hair that is already about 1/2 or shorter.  If you go longer than that, it will get jammed up and result in some painful hair yanking.  So long as you maintain regularly, you won't have a problem.  I made this mistake once and it was painful.

This 5-drawer chest was not my first foray into self-assembled furniture but it is definitely the nicest looking of those that I’ve owned.  The final product looks right off a showroom floor.This box is almost 100 pounds and is pretty difficult to move by yourself.  I ended up sliding it inside the front door and then opening the box and pulling out the pieces in groups and carrying them to my assembly area.The box was fairly dented on the corner but thankfully this is packaged well and large foam buffers inside the carton absorbed all of the damage and the product was in perfect condition.Assembly took me nearly 3.5 hours of uninterrupted work.  There are so many pieces and so much to study.  I budgeted about 90 minutes for this so I was quite surprised at how long it was taking.  Everything is very well documented though you might need a magnifying glass for the instructions if you’re over 40.  The assembly was tedious but straightforward.  The only part I struggled with was the drawers: they are a pain and took a lot of manhandling to get some of the holes to line up properly.  I found that using groove joint pliers (plumbers pliers) with a protective rag was the easiest way to snap in the main plastic guide pieces used for the drawer rails.  Hammering them in (as the instructions stipulated) didn’t work that well as the pieces bounced around a bit.Also, the instructions clearly state that you shouldn’t use power tools but I used a cordless screwdriver and it easily saved me 20-30 minutes of tedious screwing.  Just make sure not to strip things out.The unit comes with a system for mounting it to your wall to avoid tip overs: this is good because it is not very deep and thus is a bit tipsy.  I could easily see this thing falling forward if you had heavy stuff in the top drawer and opened it.  Definitely use the wall security mount if you have small kids around.As I said, the finished product has a high-end look.  The only time you can tell you’re dealing with something relatively inexpensive is when you look at the fit and finish of the drawers (they don’t line up perfectly and sometimes they won’t stay closed) and when you open the drawers (the drawer insides are not finished and look very cheap).  Still, for the price, this is a great value.  The slight misalignment of the drawers disappears because of the black color and even though I’m very picky, I only notice it when I look for it.Based on my experience so far, I would buy more of these in a heartbeat: just make sure to budget a few hours for the assembly!

This is a good value for a remote control car but be prepared to shell out big bucks for batteries (or buy rechargeables).This car does great on perfectly flat surfaces.  I’ve used it on carpet, wood, and tile flooring and it works perfectly.  It only has one speed (full!) so it is a bit of a challenge to drive in small spaces.  The high speed and hard, pointy front bumper make me limit this to outdoor use only because I don’t want my wood baseboards beaten up.Outdoors on concrete the car performs well.  You can easily drive this over a block before losing control of it.  In fact, you’ll probably have a hard time seeing it before it loses control from the remote control.The working headlights and reverse lights make this car fun to drive at night.  The lights are very bright and make this very easy to steer on even dimly lit streets.Because of the low profile and small wheels, this car will only work on a perfectly flat surface.The car is pretty fast and the steering is very twitchy.  Much like the throttle, there is no such thing as partial steering: it’s all or nothing.  This leads to a lot of over compensating followed by more overcompensating in the opposite direction.  The best technique is to point it where you want it to go and let it do what it’s good at: go straight!  So far, the car tracks straight as an arrow so that works pretty well.The remote uses three AAA batteries and those haven’t worn out yet.  Unfortunately, the car uses 6 AA batteries and those wear out if you forget to turn the car off.  This was surprising because the car has an “auto-off” feature that turns it off after a short period of inactivity.  But apparently this auto-off feature still drains the batteries because I went to use the car the next day and the batteries were dead.  You pretty much have to invest in one (possibly two) sets of 6 rechargeable AA batteries unless you own stock in a battery company.  I’m not shocked that this thing eats batteries, but it was surprising that they oven bothered to add an auto-off feature when it clearly does nothing (except give you a false sense of security).Overall this car is a hit and the price is excellent.  So long as you’re setup with a steady supply of batteries, your kids will get a lot of fun out of this.  It seems durable and I’m expecting it to last a long time.

This is a good cleaner for granite and travertine.  I'm always worried about using solutions such as Windex and 409 because they have color additives that I fear will leach into the natural stone.  With this product, the really isn't any color so I don't have to worry about that.When I use this on my granite countertop, it ends up clean and very smooth.  The towel glides across the granite as if on ice.I use this on travertine as well and find it equally effective.  I use a semi-matte sealant on my travertine and this does not disturb the sealant or make things too shiny.  It just adds a "clean" look.  I would not use this on travertine floors because this makes them very slippery.  I tried it on a couple of tiles and later that day I almost fell over walking on them.  My mistake!I like that this is not heavily scented as I don't really like it when I clean something and then have to smell the product for hours to come.My only reservation about giving this 5 stars is that it takes a lot of product to do the cleaning.  Because you're not diluting with water, you go through the bottle faster than you might using other cleaning products.  Still, this works well and I will keep using it.

This watch is much nicer than it's pricetag would suggest.  The band is beautiful and quite heavy: it feels like a luxury watch should feel.  The face is also beautiful and is larger like a modern watch without being too large or gaudy.  All of the metal is brilliantly polished and shines like highly polished silver.The band is adjustable by removing links.  I was able to remove a number of links to get this to fit perfectly on my wife's small wrist.  She's quite happy with the fit.  The removable links allow for about 1 inch of adjustability.If you're giving this as a gift, the external packaging is quite nice and will give a great first impression.  One caution is that before you wrap this, you should open the box and remove the protective plastic that adorns the watch and the band.  Because of the intricate metal pattern on the band, the packaging plastic took me over 5 minutes to peel off.  Fortunately this is only a one-time thing but it is something you will want to do to maximize the first impression when giving this to a loved one!So far I'm very happy with this watch and highly recommend it. For the quality, I'd expect to pay hundreds of dollars so this is a really great value on Amazon.

This chin strap works well for keeping my mouth shut while I'm sleeping.  The material is comfortable against my skin and breathes well.  I usually wash these in hot water after about 4 uses.  They seem to last me more than a year.My lone complaint for the first month or so these have a horrible chemical smell.  Repeated washing diminishes the smell but it still lasts for quite awhile.  The smell is so strong that even after showering I can still smell it on my face.  If these didn't have the smell, I'd give them 5 stars.

The TrendNet cloud camera is an excellent hardware solution that is limited by the mediocre software.  The camera hardware is well built and provides an excellent high definition image under all lighting conditions.  It has a very good dynamic range and can see well even when part of the room is well lit and other parts are dim.  The high definition is detailed and crisp and looks better than any image I’ve seen from a wireless camera.The automatic nightvision is also impressive.  It easily shines 30-40 feet and illuminates a wide area.  Nightvision mode is fully automatic and will engage and disengage as lighting conditions dictate.Where this camera falls short is the usability experience provided by the TrendNet software.  First, it is fairly clunky to setup.  The instructions are adequate but there appear to be a number of unwritten rules.  For example, I initially hard wired the camera to my Ethernet network.  During this time I was constantly prompted to install a firmware update.  No matter which client I used (phone, PC, etc…), the firmware update would fail.  Later I enabled wifi and suddenly firmware update worked perfectly.  Nowhere was this limitation covered in the documentation.  There are many things like this.Using the iPhone app, I can pan and tilt the camera view but even over a fast wifi connection, the camera lags behind my clicks by about 10-20 seconds.  This makes it very time consuming to position the camera to a new view.  I also notice that when I change the camera resolution to 720p high def, suddenly it loses a lot of frames.  Again, this is over a fast wifi network.  At 480p, the camera does better.I find it deceitful that they say this camera has two-way audio.  It does not really...what it does have is a headphone jack so you can add your own speaker.  Indeed, if you use your own speaker, this camera is able to relay two-way audio and the audio quality is very good.Another pseudo-deceit is that they’ve called this a PTZ camera.  “PTZ” is a widely used acronym that means a camera can pan (left/right), tilt (up/down), and zoom (in/out).  This camera does pan and tilt, but it does not zoom.When a remote client is viewing the camera, a green LED on the front blinks.  This gives you an easy way to know when you’re being watched.Overall, I’m not happy with the usability of this camera.  It’s so slow to manipulate that I think I almost have to treat it as a non-moving camera.  And while the high def video is crisp, the fact that it doesn’t deliver more than one frame every 2-3 seconds makes it useless.  This makes me go down to 480p which isn’t all that crisp.  A good firmware update could probably fix what ails this camera, but until that comes out (if ever), I can’t recommend this.  I’ve used the D-Link cloud cameras and they are far easier to use for about the same amount of money.

The most important thing I can tell you about these gloves is that the size is one size too small.  So buy a size larger than you normally buy and you'll be very happy.  I wear a size "Large" in every other glove product I've ever used but size large of this product is painfully tight and the fingers are too short.  My wife typically wears size "Medium" and these fit her perfectly.These are very strong gloves that are difficult to tear.  They are thin enough that your hands have good feeling through them and they stay grippy even when wet.  The long length gives you protection all the way past your wrist.  You can operate touchscreen device like an iPhone while wearing these which is handy in a pinch.

This foot cream does a good job of keeping your feet smooth and free of skin cracks but the scent is overwhelming and prevents me from using it.This is a very thick cream and a dime size application is enough to do my entire foot.  It seems to absorb pretty easily and does not leave a greasy residue on my hands or feet.  Unfortunately, the strong floral scent is pleasant but way too strong.  Once you use this, you'll have to wash your hands for a long time to erase the smell.  And then you'll still be able to smell your feet.  The strong scent has driven me back to using Cetaphil cream.  It works about as well but doesn't have the pungent scent.  I'd only consider going back to this if they made an unscented/low-scented version.

This cabana provides light shelter from the elements and is comfortable for two adults in folding chairs.  It’s an easy way to bring some shade along with you.This travels as a 2’ duffle bag (included) with a shoulder strap.  It only weighs a tad over 5 pounds so you probably won’t even notice that you’re carrying it.I can assemble this by myself in under 10 minutes.  You lay the entire structure flat and then thread the three included flexible poles into the fabric.  From there, you just kind of “lift” up from the center and jab each of the ends of the poles into the ground.  It’s definitely easier with two people but one works in a pinch.  Once assembled, you can jam the included metal spikes into the ground for some extra stability.The front of the structure is designed to be pretty flexible: there is an extra flap of material that can either be lifted up to form a fourth wall or can be laid down to provide a small “driveway” in front of the cabana.  Or you can roll it up and get it out of the way.  You can even put it up as a half-height fourth wall so you get some wind blocking but can still see out.  Very neat design and very useful.  When you do use it as a fourth wall.The material blocks all sunlight and stops wind and water.  Strangely, even though the interior is shaded, the temperature is exactly the same as it is out in the sun.  I measured this with an infrared thermometer and found no difference in the temperature inside or outside the cabana.The material is water proof but the structure itself is not.  Even if you close up the front and both windows, copious amounts of rain water will enter the structure through the sides of these openings and there is no way for it to drain out so you’ll be swimming in the water.The cabana has two windows, but they’re too small to let much air circulate through the structure.  This makes positioning very important.  You’ll be a lot more comfortable if you can position the open end of the structure so that wind comes in through the front.  This way you get nice circulation while sitting completely shaded.  In fact, on a sunny day with not much wind, I found it more comfortable sitting outside of the cabana just because I got some air circulation versus the complete stillness in the cabana.  So definitely make sure to position things just right to catch whatever wind you can.I’m happy with this cabana as a way to get out of the sun with minimal hassle.  So far I haven’t found anything that I don’t like about it.  Just make sure to get it pointed towards the wind and this is a very comfortable way to spend an afternoon.MISCELLANEOUSI love the mesh pockets as they give you a place to get important items up and off the ground.  You can throw your cell phone, and wallet in these and they will be off the ground and in a fixed location.I’ve only used this in light winds of 5 to 10 miles per hour but it holds up fine to these gusts.The floor is not made of a heavy duty material.  I’m not sure how long it will last with my metal chair legs rubbing on it.  So far it’s holding up but I’ve got my eye on it.When wet, it drys out really fast.  The material doesn’t absorb any water so as soon as you can shake off any rain and give it a short amount of time to dry, it will be completely dry and ready for storage.

Poo-Pourri works as advertised and is a great way to avoid an embarrassing aftermath for nature's necessities.  The Deja-Poo sent has a strong citrus note.  Because you have to use this product before you take care of business, I feared that the scent would be overpowering to me.  In fact, while you can smell the citrus smell, it is not overpowering at all and it does prevent any unpleasant odors.  This is unlike using lysol or another "cover-up" spray because those fill the air with a flowery or "clean" smell whereas this product leaves very little smell.  I wouldn't go back to aerosols after using this.I also tried Vanilla Mint and Royal Flush scents.  Both are very effective, just as Deja-poo is.  Vanilla mint is my absolute favorite as it doesn't have a floral scent.  It smells like mint-chip ice cream.I'm putting this in every bathroom in my house and my wife took the 2oz version to work with her. The 2oz size is great for travel but I would't carry it on your person unless it's in a ziplock bag.  The smell is too strong and you wouldn't want to risk it pouring out.

I like this portable alarm clock.  The projection ability is something that I have at home and always miss when I go on the road.  To have a small/compact alarm clock like this that comes with a projector is pretty impressive.I like that they silk-screened the instructions onto the flip-out base for this clock.  No more racking your brain to remember how to change the daylight savings time setting.I love that it has a USB port built into the side so you can charge your phone.  I don't love that they did not include a power adapter for the very short power cord.  Instead, they give you a USB cord and you have to supply your own power converter.  I guess this is somewhat offset by the ability to charge your phone through the clock, but still, I'd prefer that they include a power plug with it.The clock has three brightness settings (no backlight, dim backlight, bright backlight) so no matter what you prefer, it will work for you.  It uses two AAA batteries but does not project to the ceiling when running only on battery power.The projection onto a 8-9 foot ceiling is large and easy for me to read, even without glasses.  I guess this part depends on how good your vision is.  But it is just as good as my other non-portable projection alarm clocks.Aside from the lack of a power cord, my other complaint is that the viewing angle of the LCD screen has a sharp cut-off if the clock is positioned above you.  So if your night stand is higher than your bed, you will not be able to read the time on this clock as the entire screen looks blank.  This may be partially due to how thin the clock is, or possibly just due to the manufacturer cheaping out a bit.

The Petcube is a refreshingly well done product that gives you a two-way connection to your pets when you’re away from home.  I say “refreshingly well done” because the Petcube has worked flawlessly since the moment I took it out of the box. There hasn’t been an endless parade of firmware updates or steady improvement to the functionality: because it didn’t need any.Setup was very easy.  They have you install an app on your phone and then connect to a wifi network being temporarily broadcast by your Petcube.  Once done, the app will configure your Petcube and help join it to your local wifi network.  From there, you’re done and you can launch the app and access the audio/video from the Petcube.Video quality is decent but not stellar.  The camera has a very wide viewing angle so you can see a large area of the room.  The frame rate is decent so motion video is fairly smooth.  You can definitely get a good view of what your pets are up to when you’re not around.  So far everything has worked well when I’m away from home using cellular networks.Audio quality seems comparable to using a Bluetooth headset.  My wife and I were able to talk to each other using the audio capability and we could hear each other just fine (save for the echo, more on that later).  No matter what I did, I could not get my dogs to acknowledge the audio from the Petcube.  It’s like they don’t even hear it.  Cats might be different.The laser pointer feature works quite well.  Out of the box, you do have to go through a very simple and fast “calibration” exercise within the Petcube app.  After that, you can move the pointer around fairly accurately.  My dogs go bonkers over the pointer and I can keep them playing for quite a long time just by moving the dot around and watching the scramble to chase it.  I love being able to get them active when I’m not home…the only problem is getting them to notice the laser dot when you first turn it on.  But once they see it, the fun begins.The app has worked flawlessly for me.  I really commend this company for producing a product that works as-advertised right out of the box.  This is increasingly rare.The product is very nice looking and seems to be made out of real aluminum.  Compared to the shiny plastic in competing products, the Petcube is something I don’t mind having visible in my house.  It is quite small and kind of disappears into the background once you get it positioned.  The camera is pointed somewhat downward from the Petcube so it is designed to be placed at counter height or higher in your house.  The bottom has a standard “tripod” mount screw so there are a ton of mounting options that you can separately purchase for mounting on a wall or other surface.The Petcube has a couple of annoyances/limitations.  First, there is no night-vision.  This means that in a dark room, all you’ll see is a black screen.  Secondly, the Petcube has an obnoxiously bright LED on it that I ended up covering with black electrical tape.  Ironically, the LED was not bright enough to allow the Petcube to see in a dark room.  But it was bright enough to wake me up at night.  Lastly, when you use the audio feature, anything that you say is echoed back through your phone about 2 seconds later.  This is distracting and also makes the audio feature kind of noisy to use if you’re at work or in a public place because everything you say is blaring back at you.Overall I’m very happy with the Petcube and I’m getting a lot of use out of it.  My dogs are enjoying the extra “play time” when I’m gone.

This was an easy replacement for my existing Kwikset lock.  Installation required a flathead and phillips screw driver and took me about 15 minutes.  The SmartKey functionality is amazing- you can program this lock to your existing key in about 30 seconds.  It sure beats the old way of having a locksmith swap out the pins.The finish is very attractive and the doorknob has a very smooth engagement.  So far it is very solid, no wiggles.

Several years ago I suffered ruptured disks in my lower back.  At that time I learned that my "core strength" was not enough to hold my spin in place and that I would continue to have back problems unless I made some changes.  One change I made was to stand while at work.  But when I want to sit, I love using a balance ball like this.  The balls let you take a load off your feet while still keeping your core muscles engaged holding your spine in place.Once you start sitting on it, you'll get used to it right away and won't even realize that your muscles are working constantly to keep you up just like when you're standing up, you don't notice all of your muscles working to keep you from falling over.They claim this chair will work for people up to 5'11, but I am 5'11 and I find it just a hair too small.  My wife is 5'7 and it is perfect for her.The wheels are on the cheap side.  They include a locking mechanism so you can hold this chair in place, but because the wheels are hard plastic, you might still slide around a bit.  I'd prefer the wheels have a rubber outer coating on them.  That said, this is a nice chair and we are happy to have it.

This is an amazing replacement for the cheap white paper filters I've used my whole life.  I can't believe how much better the 3M respirator is.  It is far easier to breath and because of the way it exhausts my breath, my glasses don't fog over.I used this while doing some bondo work (horrible smelling chemical) and I couldn't smell a thing.  Also used while fertilizing my back yard and, again, I couldn't smell any of the chemicals until I took this off.The easy-breathing makes working in 90-100 degree temperatures much more comfortable.I won't go back to paper respirators.

This is a very tasty option for a convenient, low calorie meal.  The seasoning is just right and I didn't feel the need to add any additional salt or pepper.  The noodles are soft but no worse than other canned/boxed soups.  The chicken chunks are small, about the same as in the canned campbell's.Just for comparison sake, I tried this back-to-back with a box of Pacific Organic Chicken Noodle Soup (Low Sodium).  The Campbell's tasted a lot better.  I'd have to add salt to make the Pacific brand taste as good as the Campbell's.My only complaint is that the sodium, at 690mg per serving, is rather high if you eat the whole box at once. This is typical of other soups I've eaten so I can't really complain.The box has two servings and each serving is 2 points plus for those of you on weight watchers.

This is a durable toy and my puppy loves carrying it around the house.  I laugh every time I see it has been relocated to a new location as I know that she has been busy playing with it.The ball has really good bounce, which I find unusual for a squeak ball.  The squeaking is pretty hard to activate and probably only a dog 80+ pounds can even get their mouth around it to squeeze it.  So far I've never heard my dogs squeak it, but they do like chasing it around.It seems to be of very high quality construction and so far my dogs haven't been able to do any damage to it..  There is a mild "rubber" smell.  It doesn't seem to be deterring my dogs from playing with it.

This glass does everything it claims.  It has excellent insulation and your drink stays colder for far longer than if you pour it into a traditional mug, even a frozen mug.The glass does not sweat at all.I love that it has a firm rubber bottom so that I know it won't mark or scratch my counters or tables.  The built-in bottle operner works great.I don't drink from plastic cups because I can always taste the plastic so I like that this is stainless steel on the inside.My only complaint is that the blue band around the outside is kind of loosey-goosey and easily falls. off.  I guess it's meant to help you identify which glass is yours out of a group.  I ended up getting annoyed by it and taking it off.Overall, this is great and lets you enjoy your cold beverage without cold/wet fingers.

This rubber bone has provided a ton of fun for my two dogs.  It fits comfortably in the mouth of both my 45lb and 80lb dogs.  They run through the house with it and sometimes gnaw on it.  Neither has been able to put a dent in it yet.  It's fun watching them chase each other around the house as they fight to take possession.I've had good luck with a lot of West Paw toys.

This was designed for holding credit cards with your phone but I mounted it on the inside of the door of my fire safe.  From there, I have it holding 3-4 spare credit cards.  This doesn't take up any space and saves me from having to dig around to find less-used credit cards when I need them.  So far it seems like it is going to adhere forever and the stretchy material seems quite happy with 3-4 credit cards.
This has good elasticity which makes it easy to fit "just right" for keeping sweat out of your eyes.  So far it has retained its color after several washes.  I'm happy with it.

I've had this in my fire safe for several months now and the interior is completely free of musty odors.  I love that it comes with instructions on how to revitalize it by sticking it in the oven.  If you have any type of safe, make the investment in one of these or you could end up with moldy documents.

I love the way Pentel EnerGels write, but I don't think the alloy version is as good as the plastic versions.  The pen is hefty but doesn't feel like it's built to last.  When I buy replacement ones, I'll save the extra money and buy plastic Energels again.As for the ink, they write smoothly and are smudgeproof almost immediately.  Great pen, just not worth the extra money versus the plastic version.

I used this to hang my Stihl edger on the wall.  It was easy to install and is plenty strong to handle the 12lb edger.  I love having my edger on the wall instead of having to trip over it on the floor or having to worry about it knocking over when leaning against the wall.  Great product!

I use this on my CPAP mask every other day.  It gets rid of all of the oil from my face and leaves the mask smelling fresh and clean.  It does not make the mask hard or discolor the material over time.  A bottle seems to last me several months.  I also use the Citrus II mask wipes to clean my tubing and the rest of my headgear and those work well too.

This soundbar speaker provides an excellent upgrade to the speakers in my 50" Samsung TV without adding rumbling bass that will disturb people in other rooms.  With the speaker installed, I can crank up the volume while using loud fans and exercise equipment and all dialog is crystal clear, even at very high volumes.Installation was very easy.I attached this speaker to my Samsung TV using the included optical cable.  I then went into the settings on my Samsung and disabled the internal speaker so that the only sound would come from this soundbar.I have a DirecTV HR24 DVR in the room so I went into the remote control settings menu and configured "AV1" to control a VIZIO SOUNDBAR.
