I then went into the "remote lock" setting of the DirecTV menu and told it that I wanted all sound controls to be routed to the AV1 device.  In doing so, the remote control of my DirecTV DVR now is able to adjust the volume and mute the soundbar without any extra fiddling!  Perfection!  At this time, the speaker works as seamlessly as if it was built into my TV.I made two adjustments to the configuration of the speaker.  Firstly, I cranked down the bass all the way.  If you live in close quarters, this is going to help prevent your neighbors from hearing things because bass travels through the walls more easily than treble.  Secondly, I disabled the "eco" feature so that the speaker would stay on 24x7.  That way I don't have to power it on each time I want to use it.  Both of these adjustments were very easy and were covered in the well-written printed documentation that came with the soundbar.From my experience, I think the 38" is the right answer if you have a big TV (42" or larger).  The built in speakers of a 42" or larger TV are probably powerful enough that the 29" version of this soundbar won't make enough of a difference.

These scrubbing sponges live up to the promise of not gunking up when you use them to clean stuff like cheese, eggs, and caramel.  The scrubber side works as you'd expect, but stays free of entrenched goo.  What little bit of cheese adhered to the sponge pushed off easily with my finger when run under tap water.I'm a big fan of Scotch Brite sponges, I usually use the blue ones in my kitchen.  But they do get clogged up with grime and I'm going to switch to these going forward.My only complaint would be that these are not individually wrapped.  That means once you open the package, the remaining sponges dry out and become like pieces of styrofoam.  They still work fine though.  I ended up taking the remaining sponges and sealing them in a ziploc to keep them moist.

This fan makes a lot of noise but manages to move a lot of air.PROs---------------------+ powerful+ fairly thin+ very easy to move & maneuver+ easy to adjust tilt angleCONs---------------------- makes a lot of noise- short cordUsing outdoors, you can easily feel the breeze from this fan 10 to 15 feet away.  That may not sound like much, but try it with an ordinary fan and you'll see that it is powerful.Indoors, the fan is able to circulate air throughout a large garage without problems.  Because the air is trapped indoors, the effects of the fan are much more pronounced.The design makes it really easy to move around.  First, it has two large grab handles on the top that make it a cinch to pick up and carry.  Secondly, it has wheels along one side that make it easy to roll around on a hard surface.On the negative side, the fan is loud.  It isn't just the whirring of the blades but also the racket of metal as the cage of the fan shakes against itself.  Also, the cord is about 6' but seems short since it starts at the middle of the fan, thus leaving only about 4' of usable cord, or even less depending on how you position the fan relative to your power outlet.  You'll definitely want a heavy duty extension cord to go with this.Overall, I’m very happy and wouldn't hesitate to recommend this for dry outdoor or shop/large garage use.  I usually expect a lot of noise from a fan of this size so that doesn't bother me.  And the short cord is kind of a universal problem these days.

This balance pad is made of a very durable material and it appears that it will last.  The surface has enough resistance that you can easily plant your foot on it doing step exercises and it won't slide around.  The thickness is quite good and if you're doing balance exercises, you'll easily get the instability that you need to force your muscles to work harder.I had back surgery and part of my recovery therapy involved various exercises on this type of balance pad.  It's amazing how just standing planted on this with your eyes closed for 3-4 minutes per day can improve your balance and help you avoid stumbling when walking on uneven terrain.The size of this is good but not great for a large man.  I can stand on it comfortably but I have little room for error.  I'd prefer a slightly larger one for my size frame but for most people this is a very good size.BTW, if you're using this for balance, I highly recommend you invest in a Bosu Ball as well.  They are fantastic for a number of easy to difficult balance exercises!

I've used these fertilizer spikes for years and have had great results.  When I moved into my house in 2003, I began using these as-directed around a couple of oak trees I my front yard. My neighbor's oak trees were the same type, size, and age.  After 10 years, my oak trees are about double the size of his and have a lush, full canopy.  I can't think of any other reason why my trees are so much bigger.Despite a plastic cap to cover the tops, these spikes tend to fracture into pieces when I hammer them into the tough Texas clay. My technique is to hammer a pilot hole into the ground using a crowbar.  Then I pull the crowbar outp and hammer in the fertilizer spike. This makes the process much easier and less frustrating and let's me get the spike deep into the ground.One major problem I've had with these is that when I use them in parts of my yard that don't drain well, my grass is ruined in the late summer by an ugly fungus that makes brown rings (called "brown spot" or "brown patch" in Texas).  To avoid this, you need to make sure your yard drains evenly and doesn't have areas where water can build up and allow a fungus to take over.  I've since leveled my yard and the fungus isn't a problem anymore.If you need to jump start some young trees, I highly recommend this product. The results are quite tangible after a few growing seasons!

This set looks pretty and makes a nice gift for a young girl.  The three pieces are a perfect match and seem well made.  The stones are very nicely crafted and have a good sparkle.  The necklace is quite thin and I do fear that it could break easily if it got caught on something.Overall, this is about what I'd expect for the price.  I'm happy that I haven't had any reactions to the metal.  Sometimes inexpensive jewelry gives me a rash or leaves black marks on my skin but this has been perfect so far.One negative is that the packaging is extremely cheap looking.  Mine was even somewhat crushed.  If you give this as a gift, that won't be a good first impression.  Because of this, I recommend you take it out of the package before wrapping it.Still, a nice set that will make a young girl very happy.

So far the DD45E is doing a very good job of helping keep our indoor humidity levels lower.  It seems to have no problem managing humidity in a 1500 square foot space.  Having the DD45E programmed for 40% humidity, it can drop the humidity of that space from 50% to 46% in about 8 hours.  During that time it pulls about two liters of water from the air.  I can already notice an increase in the comfort of our home in the first week of usage.The programmable display is extremely easy to use as there are only a few options.  You can specify what your target humidity value is (from 30 - 80%) or it can run the condenser continuously.  You can also set the fan speed between two settings.  The timer function lets you run it for a set amount of time before it turns off.The DD45E is quite powerful and moves a lot of air to get the job done.  As a result, it's fairly loud.  If you've ever used a window air conditioner, it's about that loud.  Fortunately, the sound is extremely uniform and hasn't bothered me or kept me awake.  When the condenser cycles off, things get a bit quieter because the fan automatically slows down.When running with the condenser on, I measured the DD45E using 400 Watts of electricity.  At that rate, figure a cost of less than $1.50/day to operate.  Whenever it runs fan-only, the power usage drops to about 75 Watts.  Even when you hit your target humidity level, the fan keeps running.  I don't love this but it makes sense: the unit needs to circulate the air in order to detect if humidity is building up.If you can't make use of the drain hose to outlet water to a floor drain or sump, the built-in tank has a floater so it won't over-fill during usage.  Basically it will just turn off to prevent water flooding everywhere.The machine's humidity sensor reading seems to be accurate as it is within about 1% of the reading that my thermostat reports.

With this keyboard, your iPad is effectively converted into an extremely lightweight laptop.  The 11" MacBook Air weighs in at 2.4lbs and an iPad Air 2 + this case weighs only 1.9lbs!  Both have 128GB of storage but my iPad also has cellular networking which gives it a leg up on the MBA.  I'm typing this review using the QODE.Besides serving as a fairly rugged hardcase for my iPad Air 2, the QODE also gives you a pint-sized keyboard.  To Belkin's credit, the letter keys are full sized and spaced identically to a normal laptop keyboard.  Belkin shaved two inches off of the width of the keyboard by shrinking the keys along the side: think "shift", "return", "apostrophe".  The upside of this is that I can type very swiftly on the QODE; far faster than I can type on Apple's virtual keyboard. The downside is that I end up hitting "return" about 50% of the time when I'm trying to hit "apostrophe".  Oh well, I'm getting better at it!The case has it's own battery.  I was bummed that it uses a USB cable.  Now I have to drag around two cables to charge my iPad + case.  I wish they would have used a lightning cable to let me get by with one cord.  Fortunately, the battery seems to last a really long time under normal use.  I'd say you can go at least two days of moderate use before you need to charge it.If I could change one thing, it would be to make the key-repeat rate adjustable.  Sometimes I hold down an arrow key or the backspace key and want it to move a bit faster than the default setting.As far as serving as a case and stand, the QODE is perfectly competent.  It makes use of magnets to hold itself closed and to let you choose from three different pivots for adjusting the viewing angle of your iPad.  I love this because at the most severe viewing angle, I'm able have my iPad on a counter while I stand and read from it; the angle is just right.  The other viewing angles work great when you're seated at a table.A few miscellaneous notes....- The keys are fairly quiet.  If you're in a classroom taking notes I don't think you'll get any dirty looks from classmates or professors.- You can wake up your iPad just by tapping one of the keys.- I tried typing while holding it on my lap but it doesn't have enough surface area to lay flat on my two legs so this didn't work.- Their are dedicated keys for your iPad "home" button and to launch Siri.- Via FN keys, you can play/pause music, change apps, or even launch the iPad virtual keyboard in case you need it for something.So far the only problem I've had is that one time the keyboard quit working.  I was typing but no keypresses were showing up.  I finally disabled bluetooth on the iPad and then re-enabled it and the keyboard synced back up and has worked fine since.  If this becomes a recurring thing I'll update my review.I love that I have the best of both worlds now.  I have an awesome tablet but when I need it, the function of a laptop.

This facial treatment really works.  After three weeks of usage my face feels so much softer and smoother.  My skin is moist which is great because I always struggle with dry skin.  This is making a big difference.  I don't notice any difference on wrinkles yet.My only complaint is that if you follow the directions, this is a time consuming process.  You're supposed to leave it on your face for two minutes each morning and evening.

These shredding claws beat the pants off of using a fork to shred large quantities of meat. They are comfortable in my hands and do a great job of shredding.  So far I've used with smoked turkey, smoked brisket, and chicken.  In all cases, they work great.A couple of comments:- leave yourself a large amount of room for the shredding process. If you try to do this in a cramped counter space, you won't have as easy of a time- use one claw to hold the meat in place and use the other claw to tear away from the holding claw. Repeat this motion in quick succession and you'll be done in a hurryThe rubberized grip does get a bit slippery when your hands are covered in grease. I found that if I extended my index finger onto the metal prongs, things become much easier to control, even when my hands are slippery.So far these work great and I'm pleased with how much time they save me.

I bought this for my Nikon 50mm F1.4G lens.  It fits perfectly on the lens and the rotating polarizer lets you dial in the best light angle for your shots.  The glare reduction of this filter gives your pictures a great burst of color.  You can bring out the green in grass and the blue in the sky much better with a polarizer like this installed on your lens.

I originally rated this as a 5-star product, but during my initial time playing with it I blew one of the speakers.  After that, it couldn't play music without continuous popping or crackling.  I'll take partial blame for this; I had turned up the volume fairly loud.  I blame the speaker maker too for not putting a hardware limit on the volume and keeping it within the limits of the speaker.After blowing the speaker, I felt the desire to test the product claim that this product can survive drops.  I did 10 repeated drops from 3-4 feet in the air onto a concrete surface and I was impressed with how rugged this product is.  It did not suffer anything other than minor scratches during this abuse.  Very cool.I'm still bummed that I blew the speaker and won't be able to use this anymore.----------------- Original review --------------------This wireless speaker is the size of a small purse but has good sound and enough power to run pretty much all day.Setup was very simple.  It arrived with a fully charged battery and when I turned it on, it immediately gave a verbal cue that it was ready to pair.  I went to my phone's Bluetooth settings, found the speaker, and added it.  The entire process took about 10 seconds.  Since then it's working great and always connects to my phone right away when I turn it on.Sound quality is quite nice.  There isn't much bass, but it blows away what you'll get straight out of your phone's speaker or out of some of the portable speakers I've used in the past.  If you turn it all the way up, I found it to get garbled some.  In my usage, going to about 80% of maximum volume is the most you can do without getting distortion.  You can control the volume on your phone or on the speaker, but they are both separate volume controls.  You can also fast forward/rewind from either the speaker or your phone.The Bluetooth works well for about 10 feet.  It reaches well beyond 10 feet but I noticed some periodic glitches in the sound when I had the speaker 15 feet away from my phone.I ran it for 4 hours at full volume and didn't even consume half of the battery.The solar panel has a durable matte finish and does a good job at pulling in available light.  Even indirect sunlight is enough to start charging things.  The unit has a "charging" indicator that gets brighter or dimmer depending on how much solar power it is actively pushing into the battery.  This helps you know whether you're picking up enough light or not.  With the battery half depleted, it took about 6 hours of bright sunlight to recharge it back to full.  Even if the sun isn't shining directly on it, it will capture enough solar power to do some charging.  I really like that you can plug your phone into the speaker and charge it from the internal battery & solar panel.  On a sunny day, you're good for a full day of fun.I tested the IPX4 splash rating by sprinkling water on all sides of it, similar to what would happen if you had this out by the pool and someone jumped in and splashed you.  The speaker lived up to the claim and had no problems with the exposure to water.  All of the openings for USB and AUX have little rubber flaps that snap into them to keep the water and sand out.So far this has proven to be a great outdoor speaker.  It has good sound and volume, a little water or sand won't hurt it, the sun won't make it overheat but will keep it charged.

This digital steamer has quickly become my go to choice for steaming vegetables.In the past I would alternate between stovetop steaming (when I had time and wanted great results) and microwave steaming (when I was in a hurry).  Steaming on the stovetop yields great results but it takes awhile to get the water boiling on my gas stovetop and then you can plan on a healthy amount of time for the steam process.  The microwave is a lot easier and more than twice as fast but the results are sketchy at best.  Vegetables steamed in my microwave often get an unattractive wilt due to the combination of steam and microwave energy.The hamilton beach digital steamer is the best of both worlds.  It heats up quickly (steam billows out in about 3 minutes) and the timer and delay function make it a breeze to coordinate the results to match other parts of your meal so you can serve everything at one.  The actual resulting food is  every bit as good as the results I can get over the stovetop.  Overall, expect this steamer to take about twice as long as a microwave steaming at 50% power.Cleanup is easy.  There are several plastic pieces that can be quickly wiped down.  The sides of the steamer remain cool during operation so after you use it, you can pick it up and dump out any extra water into the sink.The unit stores in a relatively small space because a lot of the components collapse and fold into each other.  The size of the unit is about the size as a 2.5qt slow cooker.The cooking compartment is made of several removable pieces so you can configure it a number of ways.  If you need to do something large, you can make it tall or if you need to do a lot of something you can turn it into a double-decker.So far I'm very happy with this.  I really love that it doesn't get hot to the touch as that makes it a lot safer to use.  The results are perfect and the timer and delay start feature makes it so easy to coordinate finish times.

I gave these to my son to try out, as he's a type 1 diabetic. I also gave them a try myself before I handed them over. While I'm not bought into the restorative properties of copper, these *are* good socks that tend to collect less odor than other stocks of the same style.I found them extremely comfortable to wear, both with and without shoes. I work from home, so I tend to go without shoes for most of the day. They fit well, and didn't slide around on my foot as some short socks can tend to do. The bottom part seemed to have a thicker padding than the rest of the sock, which was perfect for comfort. When I wore them with my shoes, they don't bunch up and create folds (which I hate).One thing that these socks have which is nice is a lip on the back portion of the ankle. This lines up well with where you normally have the higher portion of the running shoes, and it cuts down on excessive wear on the Achilles tendon (where I tend to get blisters).Both my son and I have noticed that they have far less odor after daily wear. Based on the sales pitch for copper, that might be the bacteria getting killed off. Again, I don't know if that's indeed the case, but it seems to have that effect.I'd be happy to have a drawer full of these to replace my regular cotton socks.Disclosure:Obtained From: Copper ClicksPayment: Free

I don't know why I do this to myself... I read a Robin Cook novel, thinking I'll like the story (I enjoy medical thrillers). But as I get deeper into it, I find myself disliking the book as it's nothing more than a skeleton to push some medical injustice or soapbox that Cook has picked out. I swear I won't read another one... until the "another one" comes out and I try again...... and I end up with Host.The storyline isn't bad. Actually, it's the only thing that kept me reading. Healthy younger guy goes into the hospital for a relatively minor surgery (knee repair). Something goes horribly wrong, and he ends up in a coma. Two medical students (one of which is his lover) decide that they need to dig into his case to see how something could go so wrong. What they uncover is a conspiracy that links the hospital and a pharmaceutical firm in a scheme that is unthinkable (and of course, highly illegal).There's some soapboxing here about the evils of drug companies, the amounts they charge, and the way they spend their money. I'm used to that, and I'll forgive a bit of it. What really turned me off was the characters and dialogue. The two students, best friends, are extremely smart and top of their class. They are fourth year med students, so I'd expect them to know a lot. But it seems like basic medical conditions and terms seem to be beyond them (causing lots of late-night research). I got *very* annoyed with the dialogue, as it was stereotyped and completely unrealistic. Michael is a large black guy, and his "hip and cool" phrasing goes completely overboard. Even if they are friends, I can't imagine people talking like that. Lynn isn't much better, though. She's attacked later in the story, and she's telling Michael what happened. Saying things like "We've stumbled onto a hornets' nest, and my tete-a-tete with the goon got worse." Really? You've just escaped getting raped, and you're saying stuff like that? Couple the dialogue with a large number of situations where you have to suspend belief beyond what is normal, and it was just too much.I might be a bit more forgiving with a first-time author trying to get it right and find their style. Cook should do far better at this point. I think I'll likely stay away from future Cook novels... just like I've said in the past.Disclosure:Obtained From: LibraryPayment: Borrowed

This is a beautiful gown by Ekouaer that looks great on my wife. I was unsure as how the quality would be given the low price, but this is as good (if not better) than what you'd get from name brands like Victoria's Secret.I was pleased that the sizing chart was accurate, so what I ordered for my wife fit exactly as expected. The fabric has some stretch to it, so it's forgiving for various curves that are not model-esque. It draped well for a fit that looks attractive from both the front and rear.My wife appreciated the adjustable straps, as she was able to get a fit that was perfect for her. The lace trim is just as soft as the main fabric, and she can wear this both as sleepwear, or as a black slip underneath a dress.If you're looking for a shorter nightgown or something racy, this is an excellent option. We're very pleased with it, and we wouldn't hesitate to get additional colors of this style.Disclosure:Obtained From: EkouaerPayment: Free

I'll admit I was sold on this just for the Minion case alone. :) The artistic angle was pure frosting (with a cherry on top).This was the first item at a bat mitzvah that was opened and played with immediately. The biggest hit were the felt tip markers, which produced vivid colors with a myriad of combinations. After coloring a couple of the images in a separate coloring book, she went to work with the crayons and the pencils. She's coming up with some great images... as well as she loves the minion on the cover of the box like I did.The only suggestion I'd made is to include a pencil and crayon sharpener if you give this as a gift. It may be that they already have one, but otherwise the pencils will have a short life after they lose their initial edge.Disclosure:Obtained From: Amazon Vine Review ProgramPayment: Free

I've been recovering from a surgical procedure on my right arm, but my left side neck and deltoid has been giving me fits (mismatched balance after wearing a brace on my right arm after the operation). I've been using ice packs to relieve the irritation, but it's hard to get them to stay in one place for a decent period of time. This therapy belt has been working VERY well for me.The bag allows me to fill it up with ice cubes to where it's about 5 to 6 inches deep. I screw on the top and slip the lip of the bag into the hole of the neoprene sleeve. Velcro holds it in place, and it's good for an hour or two before I need to re-freeze or refill the bag.I've been using it on my upper arm to hit my medial deltoid. While it's easier to put on and secure if you have a helper, you can get it in place on your own with a little practice. If I was using this on a knee, it'd be a piece of cake to put on.I definitely recommend this if you need an icing solution that is easy to work with and stays in one place.Disclosure:Obtained From: BracooPayment: Free

I don't do a lot of home repair or DYI stuff, but I do have occasion when I need a shim to hold something in place while I adjust something else. It's a safe bet that I don't have wedges or spare wood to do that, so I'm usually stuck trying to use my foot (or something else) to hold things in place (with the associated results that you'd expect). I was intrigued when I was contacted about the Anybest Air Wedge Inflatable Shim. After trying it out, I'm impressed.At its core, it's an inflatable pouch that is designed to lift up to 200+ lbs as high as 2 inches. With no weigh on it, it will actually go as high as 2.5 inches, but of course it will compress a bit depending on how much weight it's carrying. The air bulb works pretty much like a blood pressure cuff... you squeeze the bulb to push air into the pouch, and then you push the valve button to release the air when when you want it to deflate. It's a very simple design that works remarkably well.I didn't have any immediate tasks that needed a shim, but I tried putting it under a few heavier objects to see how the inflating worked. When placed under one of the legs of a twin bed, it definitely lifted the leg by the advertised 2 inches. Because of the rounded nature of the pouch, it rolled off (the bed post had roller legs), but if it had been a normal post or something flat like a door or window, it would have stayed put.I'm impressed at how well this works, and how easy it is to operate. This is going into my toolbox immediately for the next time I need something to raise a door or other item by an inch or two. It'll work FAR better than trying to fold cardboard to get the right height.Disclosure:Obtained From: AnybestPayment: Free

This body slimming tank top is one of most comfortable slimming clothing items I've worn. I've been using regular t-shirt style slimming items. but this style has a lot more going for it, both in terms of style and comfort.One of the downsides of the compression shirts is the struggle to put it on. The tank top style makes it a lot easier to put on, and the struggle is much less. I'm struggling with a shoulder issue after some arm surgery, and I like how this style allows for an ice pack to be held in one place.I like how this has a good level of back support in addition to abdominal support. It's not constraining, but it provides that mix of support and comfort that is hard to find.This isn't going to turn you from a slob into a supermodel, but it definitely helps hold everything in place, as well as adding some support if you're in need of it. I like it a lot.Disclosure:Obtained From: ImagePayment: Free

Bottom line is that I *love* copper mugs. A friend of mine introduced me to Moscow Mules done properly in copper mugs, and I haven't been the same since. These hammered copper mugs are not only well made, but the hammered effect make them look really classy.The mug holds 16 oz of liquid, so no problems with capaciity for your favorite cocktail. It's nickle-lined, and it takes on a nice patina after regular use and washing. It's possible to polish that out, but I like it as it makes each one even more unique. The handles are securely soldered onto the side, and I don't think that's ever coming loose. Like I mentioned at the start, I really like the hammered effect as opposed to the smooth finish. It looks great and has a nice tactile feel.I know that copper mugs do *not* keep drinks colder in reality, but it sure feels and tastes that way when I'm drinking out of one. The traditional drink for this mug is the Moscow Mule, but I turn to this mug for just about anything I'm drinking at home.If you're looking for a set of copper mugs, you won't go wrong with these.Disclosure:Obtained From: SiggióPayment: Free

This is an excellent drawer organizer in our kitchen. We just replaced all our cabinets as part of a kitchen remodel, and this was the perfect option for us.The fact that it's bamboo makes it look far better than those plastic-type kitchen utensil organizers that I've grown up with. It's also staying a lot cleaner than what we had before. The adjustable nature of the organizer, both side to side and with the dividers, pretty much assures that it'll fit any drawer size as well as create any configuration that works best for your needs.I'm thinking that I might get a couple more of these for our larger knives and baking utensils, as well as one for our junk drawer. This may be one of the most functional parts of our new kitchen (definitely the cheapest part!)Disclosure:Obtained From: Home-CompletePayment: Free

These bamboo cutting boards came at a perfect time. We just finished a kitchen remodel, and these look far better than what we had before. :)The mix of 13", 11", and 8" sizes work nicely for various tasks. The large one works well for when I'm cutting meat, while the other two work better for veggies and other smaller cutting options. They've been very resistant to showing any knife cuts, so they still look like new. Clean-up is very easy, and I feel better knowing that I'm working with bamboo and not something else that can aid the growth of bacteria.In our non-remodeled kitchen, we had a few plastic "boards" that were looking very ratty. They also curled over time. These boards obviously don't have any of those issues, as well as just looking great. I'm very happy with these cutting boards, and I'm looking forward to years of use.Disclosure:Obtained From: Premium KitchenPayment: Free

Based on a friend's recommendation, I started the Graham's Resolution series by A. R. Shaw with the first volume titled The China Pandemic. It's a post-apocalyptic story of a group of people trying to survive a pandemic that has wiped out 98% of the world's population. I was thinking this would be interesting, but I didn't expect to get sucked in as much as I did by the characters and their interactions. I ended up caring for every one of the characters.The virus started as a mutated bird flu virus that got out of control in China. It rapidly spread worldwide with no vaccine or way to stop it. Only two percent of the population showed immunity to the virus, but even then they still became carriers for anyone who hadn't been exposed yet.The main character, Graham, has lost his entire family to the disease. As he's burying his father, a Korean lady who is near death brings her son to him, making him promise to take care of him. Graham has NO idea of how to raise a five year old that he doesn't know, but he doesn't see that he has much of a moral choice. His plan is to head up to his father's cabin as a refuge against predators and killers. Along the way, he picks up two teenage girls, an elderly man, and a woman around his age. This strange assortment of people have to figure out how to survive in a world that's completely foreign to them, as well as how to get along as a default family.There are a few parts of the story where things are just a little too convenient in terms of finding what's needed, or how certain conflicts arise. Still, the characters and interactions were very real and likeable. I fought off sleep for the last couple of nights as I was trying to read "just one more chapter", and I decided to buy volumes 2 and 3 from Amazon since my library didn't have them. Very much looking to starting the next one this evening.Disclosure:Obtained From: LibraryPayment: Borrowed

I've had a few Android devices around the house for review lately, and the latest is the  iNOVA EX756 7" tablet. I tried out the EX780 first, and this is very similar. About the only realistic difference is the screen resolution (1024x600 for the EX780 vs. 800x480 for the EX756). This one is about $10 less expensive than the EX780, but they're both great deals. The only visual difference between the two devices that I had is that this one has a red hard plastic case as opposed to the black mirror look of the EX780. The red plastic will stay cleaner looking a lot longer, as it doesn't pick up fingerprints like the black case does. I would view this one as a "first tablet" for someone who isn't necessarily gentle with their hardware...The rest of the review is the same as the EX780, since they performed just the same. Bottom line, this is a solid device for what it is. Hard to believe that just a few years ago, this would have been state of the art and cost megabucks. :)As with all devices, my first concern was battery life. I found that I can get between 1.5 and 2 hours of battery life when I'm running apps that involve video. The life was longer when I was surfing or reading email, somewhere around 3 hours. Compared to my iPhone 6 Plus, that's definitely on the low side, but coupled with a battery charger it would be OK.Out of the box, it comes with 8 GB of memory, which I can burn through with no problem (for comparison, my iPhone has 128 GB). The advantage here is that the iNOVA will take SD memory cards to add an extra 32 GB. That makes the device flexible enough to load up books or videos for trips if needed. The pre-installed apps (like Google, FB, Twitter, etc) are on the light side, so you don't end up with all your memory gobbled up before you do anything.The wifi connectivity was excellent on my home network. I had no problems streaming videos over Plex without buffering. The fact that the device does not have bluetooth is a drawback, as it makes it hard to use things like external keyboards. That is probably the one thing I miss the most, as it means I also can't use external bluetooth headphones either.The iNOVA comes with a front and rear facing camera, but it's nothing to write home about. The pictures look to be more on the grainy side, and don't measure up to the cameras on the current smart phones. I think it would be fine for Skype calls over wifi, but nothing much more than that.Overall, I enjoyed playing around with this, and it's perfect for getting used to an Android device. Equipped with an SD card, this would make a decent first device for someone who is getting their feet wet with mobile tech. It would also be a good device for a younger kid who wants to be able to watch downloaded videos or play games. This won't be something I pack to take notes at a conference, but it might well be sitting around the house for quick browsing or watching videos.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

It's a weird sensation the first time you use it, but I like how the AccuMed AP109 Portable Electronic TENS Pulse Massager works in relieving muscle pain and discomfort. It did wonders on my stiff neck, and it's also helping a strain in my bicep area.When I think of TENS units, I think of large cases and lots of dials. This is really not much bigger than a TV remote (and just about as easy to operate). There are two electrode lines that plug into the top of the handheld unit. Each line has a Y-split for two electrode pads. The pads themselves have a sticky adhesive that holds the 1" x 1" electrode on the skin. Once you have the lines attached to the unit and the pads on the targeted muscle, it's time to rock and roll.There are five "routines" that are pre-defined for the waist, shoulder, joint, hand-leg, and sole of the foot. My preference was to use the manual controls to get the results I wanted. Each wire has a separate intensity control from Off to 10 (start low... really!), and you can speed up or slow down the pulses. You can also go with a massage, beat, or knead mode that controls how the pulses fire. Those range from a quick hit of electricity to your muscle, or a slow build and release.So how does it work? It's a bit strange when you first turn it on. Having your muscle clench involuntarily (regardless of what you do) takes a bit of getting used to. But the continued application of current to provoke muscle stimulation does a good job in getting it to loosen up and control pain. I'm not a doctor, so I can't spell out the exact reasons as to how/why it works. I only know that it does, and this unit delivers on what it says.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

These scrubbing cloths work much better than I expected. I normally use the plastic scrubbers, but they get scungy pretty quickly. There's not a lot of room for water flow to keep them clean. The cloths have a much wider weave, so they clean up easier after scrubbing dirty dishes.The fabric has a nice level of "coarseness" that cuts through messes on plates and pots, but not so rough that it will scratch glasses or china. I found that they worked well for anything I pre-scrubbed before putting things in the dishwasher.I appreciated the way these clean up in the laundry, too. They clean up completely (no stains to date), and they dry quickly... much better than sponges or normal dishrags.Bottom line... perfect cleaning tools for the kitchen.Disclosure:Obtained From: TurnUPPayment: Free

I hate garden hoses. The ones I buy tend to dry out, kink up, and generally they're a pain to use. I got the chance to try out the Ohuhu 75' expandable garden hose, hoping for a different experience. I'm happy to say that I've been very happy with the results.The hose is exceptionally light, which made it easy to carry around (another thing I hate about regular garden hoses). I hooked it up to our faucet in the back yard, and I had no leakage from the connection between that and the hose (a rarity in my case). I liked the connector for the other end that allowed for turning the flow on and off. That made it a *lot* easier to use with a screw-on bottle of weed and feed. The hose has remained durable over multiple uses, and I ditched the other hoses we had that were too much of a hassle to roll up and store after each use.The spray nozzle that comes with the hose is also very nice, with a number of patterns ranging from a gentle mist to a full-on blast. It's funny, but it almost gets lost attention-wise since I was so focused on the value of the hose. But having the nozzle and hose combined into a single package is an excellent value.I may well end up getting another set for the front yard so that I don't have to move the hose around.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

OK... you want to send someone a great food-based gift box? The Dulcets Gourmet Muffin Sampler Gift Basket is a really good choice. I received the box today, and we (as in the family) has enjoyed the "fruits of my reviewing", so to speak...The variety box is perfect in terms of an assortment of flavors. I personally went for the chocolate chip muffin, while my two sons scarfed down the banana and cranberry flavors. All of the muffins were fresh, just as if they had come out of the oven earlier in the day. The size of the muffins were a surprise, as they had some substance. Granted, they're not Costco-sized, but they're more than what you'd end up with in a regular muffin tin. Given the taste, I have no problems believing that Dulcets uses quality ingredients for their baking.Presentation was exceptional... The outer box is decorative *and* protective, so nothing was crushed or damaged. It came wrapped with ribbon, it had decorative tissue inside, and the muffins are sealed in plastic to make sure they are as fresh as possible. Again, these were very moist and fresh... and delicious!They are definitely priced at a gift-box level, and the packaging is targeted for that purpose. These aren't items that you'd purchase for normal breakfast (unless you have a bigger wallet than mine). But as an impressive gift box, this is perfect.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I've been using the Bolden Lightning to USB 3ft cable of late, and it does exactly what I expect from an Apple MFI Certified cable... and more cheaply than Apple does it.The plugs are sturdy with solid connections to the cord. On the Lightning connector side, the plug is slender enough to fit through my case opening, so I don't have to mess with my case during recharging. Data syncing works as expected, as does the charging capacity and speed.Bottom line, it's a solid cable that comes with a money-back guarantee. When it comes to normal charging cables, I can't ask more than that.Disclosure:Obtained From: Amazon Vine Review ProgramPayment: Free

The Digital Treasures TurtleCell Retractable Headphone Case for iPhone 5/5s was something that my son got highly excited about when he saw it. He is continually trying to take my latest set of headphones because he's lost the last set I gave him. It'd be nice to have a set that remains with the phone no matter what he does.Overall, this combination works well. The two piece case installs easily on the phone, and it adds very little weight and bulk to the phone. The case is sturdy, and it provides plenty of protection to the body of the phone.The earbuds extend and retract from the top of the case. Using the side button will retract the cords when you're done using them... think of it like the retract button on a tape measure. I'd suggest holding and guiding the cords back in to prevent excessive force on the cord if you let it retract on its own.Sound-wise, these earphones are OK. I've had other earbuds and headphones that have higher quality (mostly on the bass side), but there's always the issue of remembering to carry them around. Given that these are always available because of the built-in nature, I'm willing to give up a bit of sound quality for the convenience factor. Besides, my ears aren't that great to notice much of a different for regular listening.This is a unique design that works better than I thought it would. My son loves them, and maybe I'll get to keep my own headphones for a little longer...Disclosure:Obtained From: Amazon Vine Review ProgramPayment: Free

I got this for my wife, and it looks very nice... what can I say? I like lingerie. :)It's a "one size fits most", and it does stretch to cover curvier bodies. The fabric is semi-transparent and very soft, so it covers up the body while also revealing it for a nice tease. The bodice area is unstructured, so it won't provide much in the way of support. Having said that, it showcases that area very nicely. This has a lot of stitching with the lace insets and all, and I'm pleased that they are all finished and lie flat. It's a solid construction and also comfortable to wear.This is definitely worth buying and wearing for that special evening. I'd be happy if that were most evenings. :)Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

This iCooker camera lens thermos travel mug is pretty cool, especially for a camera enthusiast. Aside from looking *exactly* like a coffee mug, it does a good job in keeping your hot drinks hot.The mug holds about 10 ounces of liquid, so it's a bit smaller than some of the other travel mugs I have. I do like the way it tapers, however. It does a good job in fitting solidly into cup holders in cars. The lid is a typical screw-on top with a sliding cap where the fluid comes out.The mug does a good job in retaining heat. I found that my contents were still hot after four hours, which is about the longest I would go before consuming whatever I was drinking. I found no leaking problems at all, even when I tilted the mug at a steep angle.The big draw of this mug is, of course, the fact it looks like a camera lens. On that score, it's *excellent*. Even up close, it looks like it's ready to screw into your camera. It has all the ridged rings and switches that you'd see on a normal lens. In case you're wondering, nothing moves on the outside of the cup. All the features are ornamental and fixed in place, so the person using it will not be able to play with the switches and rings. :)If all you want is a travel mug, you probably would like one that's bigger and holds more liquid. But as a gift for your favorite photographer (or yourself), this is hard to beat.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

When I got the C3 Alize vacuum cleaner, I'll admit I was somewhat sceptical. I know that it's a highly rated machine, but using a canister vacuum instead of an upright seemed to be a step backwards. My scepticism has been removed... this works very well, and I now get the value of a canister vacuum.This works best on short carpets or wood floors (which means it also works well on ceilings). I found the suction was superior than any other vacuum I've owned, and I loved how it auto-adjusts to the surface being cleaned. I've never had a vacuum that adjusts the airflow based on what it's going over, and that's a great feature. It also was much quieter than other vacuums. The cats still don't trust it, but it wasn't quite as traumatic for them.What I liked most is the wand vs. a normal upright where you detach a hose for non-floor work. Having the longer length of the wand made it easy to go from floors to under furniture to cobwebs in the corner without having to reconfigure everything. It led to a much faster vacuuming task than what I'm used to.It's a small thing, but the retractable cord beats trying to wrap the cord around the posts on my upright. As far as bags vs. bagless... that's about the only thing I don't like about the Alize. I understand why they use bags (much cleaner), but it does add more cost over time. However, given the overall quality of the job it does, I'm OK with spending the extra money.The Alize is not a cheap vacuum, but it's one that is built to last and do an excellent job.Disclosure:Obtained From: Amazon Vine Review ProgramPayment: Free

This is a nicely designed headlamp that works for a number of purposes. In fact, there's a good chance it's going to end up on my nightstand for bedtime reading.The lamp portion runs off of three AAA batteries that come included. Side note: one of the batteries has a small cardboard circle between it and the contact so that the batteries don't drain before you start to use the headlamp. Just remove the cardboard before you think that the headlight doesn't work. :) The lamp weighs very little, and I had no discomfort wearing it for longer periods of time. The adjustable elastic band (1" wide) is also comfortable, and it's easy to make it as loose or snug as needed.In terms of light, it performs well. By pressing the orange button on the top, you cycle through a high beam, a low beam, two red beams, and a flashing red beam. The red lights sit on either side of the main white LED, and they work well as a way for people to see you if you're walking or riding in the dark.One other feature that I like about this is the ability to adjust the angle of the headlamp. It's hinged at the base and can tilt forward 45 degrees. So, if I'm lying in bed reading, I can tip the light forward so it hits the pages of the book. Very nice touch...I'm very happy with this headlamp, and I may end up getting another one...Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I've been an Apple guy when it comes to phones and tablets. When I had a chance to try out an Android device, I jumped at it. First up is the iNOVA EX780 7" tablet, a nice sized device which puts it in between my iPhone and my iPad. Given this is my first experience with Android devices, overall I'm impressed.As with all devices, my first concern was battery life. I found that I can get between 1.5 and 2 hours of battery life when I'm running apps that involve video. The life was longer when I was surfing or reading email, somewhere around 3 hours. Compared to my iPhone 6 Plus, that's definitely on the low side, but coupled with a battery charger it would be OK.Out of the box, it comes with 8 GB of memory, which I can burn through with no problem (for comparison, my iPhone has 128 GB). The advantage here is that the iNOVA will take SD memory cards to add an extra 32 GB. That makes the device flexible enough to load up books or videos for trips if needed. The pre-installed apps (like Google, FB, Twitter, etc) are on the light side, so you don't end up with all your memory gobbled up before you do anything.The wifi connectivity was excellent on my home network. I had no problems streaming videos over Plex without buffering. The fact that the device does not have bluetooth is a drawback, as it makes it hard to use things like external keyboards. That is probably the one thing I miss the most, as it means I also can't use external bluetooth headphones either.The iNOVA comes with a front and rear facing camera, but it's nothing to write home about. The pictures look to be more on the grainy side, and don't measure up to the cameras on the current smart phones. I think it would be fine for Skype calls over wifi, but nothing much more than that.Overall, I enjoyed playing around with this, and it's perfect for getting used to an Android device. Equipped with an SD card, this would make a decent first device for someone who is getting their feet wet with mobile tech. It would also be a good device for a younger kid who wants to be able to watch downloaded videos or play games. This won't be something I pack to take notes at a conference, but it might well be sitting around the house for quick browsing or watching videos.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

The pictures look to be more on the grainy side, and don't measure up to the cameras on the current smart phones. I think it would be fine for Skype calls over wifi, but nothing much more than that.Overall, I enjoyed playing around with this, and it's perfect for getting used to an Android device. Equipped with an SD card, this would make a decent first device for someone who is getting their feet wet with mobile tech. It would also be a good device for a younger kid who wants to be able to watch downloaded videos or play games. This won't be something I pack to take notes at a conference, but it might well be sitting around the house for quick browsing or watching videos.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I've been an Apple guy when it comes to phones and tablets. When I had a chance to try out an Android device, I jumped at it. First up is the iNOVA EX780 7" tablet, a nice sized device which puts it in between my iPhone and my iPad. Given this is my first experience with Android devices, overall I'm impressed.As with all devices, my first concern was battery life. I found that I can get between 1.5 and 2 hours of battery life when I'm running apps that involve video. The life was longer when I was surfing or reading email, somewhere around 3 hours. Compared to my iPhone 6 Plus, that's definitely on the low side, but coupled with a battery charger it would be OK.Out of the box, it comes with 8 GB of memory, which I can burn through with no problem (for comparison, my iPhone has 128 GB). The advantage here is that the iNOVA will take SD memory cards to add an extra 32 GB. That makes the device flexible enough to load up books or videos for trips if needed. The pre-installed apps (like Google, FB, Twitter, etc) are on the light side, so you don't end up with all your memory gobbled up before you do anything.The wifi connectivity was excellent on my home network. I had no problems streaming videos over Plex without buffering. The fact that the device does not have bluetooth is a drawback, as it makes it hard to use things like external keyboards. That is probably the one thing I miss the most, as it means I also can't use external bluetooth headphones either.The iNOVA comes with a front and rear facing camera, but it's nothing to write home about. The pictures look to be more on the grainy side, and don't measure up to the cameras on the current smart phones. I think it would be fine for Skype calls over wifi, but nothing much more than that.Overall, I enjoyed playing around with this, and it's perfect for getting used to an Android device. Equipped with an SD card, this would make a decent first device for someone who is getting their feet wet with mobile tech. It would also be a good device for a younger kid who wants to be able to watch downloaded videos or play games. This won't be something I pack to take notes at a conference, but it might well be sitting around the house for quick browsing or watching videos.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

You can never have too many charging cables (at least in my opinion. I tried out these Bolden Design Lightning to USB cables, and the work exactly as expected. They do the job they are designed for, and they do it well.The three foot length is adequate to reach from chargers to desktop (in most situations), and the Apple certification means that you won't get a cable that works once and then won't be compatible to whatever device you're working with. I've been able to use them on a regular basis with no problems.$18 for two is definitely cheaper than buying them directly from Apple, and the two year guarantee gives you the assurance you need to know that you're not taking on any risk.This is definitely a good buy for your lightning cables...

Headphones are great when you find a pair you really like. Unfortunately, the wires will end up getting tangled up on a regular basis, or there's a chance you'll pinch the wire and damage them. I was given a chance to try out a cool product called Cordskinz, and they solve both problems. I really like these...Cordskinz act like a jacket for your headphone cords. They are basically a small rubber tube with a slit the length of the tube. Using a unique splitter device included in the package, you slide the tubing over your headphone cord, trimming off any extra length that you don't need. The tubing gives the cord some structure, and it prevents the cord from wrapping around itself. It also provides a nice layer of protection, and there's much less chance of snagging (and damaging) the wire.I also found that it does a good job on charging cords, too. I like the extra layer of protection that it provides, and I'm finding that I have less damage on the plastic cord casing (due to inadvertent pinching or closing it in a drawer). The USB cable is a bit thicker than a headphone cable, but it still covers enough of the cord for protection.Cordskinz are worth the cost for your favorite set of headphones. The color selection makes a nice fashion statement, and the tangle-free protection they provide is excellent.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I don't mind using my stationary bike for exercise, but it can be painful on the bum. I gave the Adalid Gear cycling shorts a try, and I'm very happy with the result. These are high-quality cycling shorts that keep body parts from going numb.These shorts have very nice construction. The seams lie flat, and they don't cause any irritation against my skin. The fit is perfect, in that they stay put and don't ride up or down during use. The polyester/lycra blend allows enough stretch to be comfortable but still maintain support at the same time. The most important thing (to me, at least) is the padding. These feel great, and I don't feel any pain or discomfort after putting in time on the exercise bike.I would definitely recommend these for people who spend time on the pedals, and want as much comfort as possible.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

Now that I have an iPhone 6 Plus, I need battery packs that put out more than 2800mAh if I want any useful charging options. The Brio LUX 6000mAh battery does a nice job in getting me more than just a partial recharge. This is a battery I'd keep in my travel bag.It's only 4" long, 2" wide, and not quite 1" thick. The micro-USB slot for recharging the battery is located on one side, with the on/off switch on the other. It comes equipped with two charging ports located on the top of the unit, so you can charge more than one item at a time. The front of the charger has four blue LED bars to give you an idea of how much power remains in the battery. Finally, it comes with a carrying bag and a short micro-USB cable. If your device uses something different (like an Apple cord), you have to provide that yourself. I *do* like that the carrying bag is pretty large, and it would fit two cords with no problem.I charged the battery after I opened the box. It took around three hours to get all the bars lit up for a full charge. I then had two charging sessions on my iPhone 6 Plus. I went from 23% to 95% in two hours (three bars still showing lit), and then later I went from 59% to 90% in an hour (two bars still lit). Extrapolating that out, I was able to get one full charge and still have 25 - 50% of the battery remaining. I think it's a safe bet that I could get 1.5 charges out of this unit before I'd need to recharge it.This fits into my "good daily battery" category, in that it will stretch my iPhone to a full day of heavy use. It's light and easy to carry around... hard to beat, especially for the price.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I've been trying out the Slicoo dual-layer cover for my iPhone 6 Plus, and it's pretty good. It has a nice tactile feel, and it provides good protection for the body of the iPhone (but not necessarily for the screen).The case actually has two parts. The hard plastic shell snaps onto the phone easily. All the openings and notches line up well. The bottom portion of the case is a little deep, and it might block cables or headphones with a thicker connector at the base of the plug.The second part of the case snaps onto the plastic portion, and that part has the rubberized feel. That gives a bit more grip than hard plastic, so it's easier to hold with a single hand.While this case gives good protection for the iPhone body, it doesn't give any protection to the glass face. The edges of the case are almost flush with the glass, so if you drop your phone on its face, the case won't be able to absorb any of the impact.Overall, this is a good general purpose case with some nice styling and a very thin profile. If those are your criteria, this will work for you.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

Granted, I don't live on the east coast (where this would have been perfect), but I'm glad I have this EGOZ neck warmer. It's great for keeping my neck warm, and it works great in windy situations.The neck warmer is a tube of micro fleece about 10" long. When laid out flat, it's 10" wide, and it has a nice amount of stretch that allows it to sit on the neck without constriction... very comfortable. The top edge has an elastic cord drawstring that can be used to close off the top part and use it as a hat.The fleece definitely keeps my neck warm. The thing that makes this even better is that the weave doesn't allow wind to pass through. It makes the wind chill factor a moot point, and that's what you really want when the wind kicks up.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I've been trying out the Cable Matters 4-Port SuperSpeed USB 3.0 Octagonal Ultra-Mini Hub in the last couple of weeks, and this is a very nice hub, especially if you are mobile/use a laptop. It's compact and light, and it has all the speed benefits of USB 3.0.The base hub is only two inches wide (3/8" thick), and it weighs less than two ounces. The fact that it can fit four ports into something that size is impressive. I was able to have various items plugged in (flash drives, iPhone cables, external hard drive bays, and I saw the same speeds in data transfers as I saw when connected directly into a USB port on my desktop machine.Since this is powered via the 7" USB cord, there's no need to pack a power cord in a travel bag. If you're tossing this into your travel kit, just plug the cord into one of the ports, and it's a compact package. If you need to travel with a USB hub "just in case", this is a perfect option when you look at weight, size, and speed.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I've been trying out these Symphonized NRG Premium Genuine Wood In-ear Noise-isolating Headphones, and they are very nice. Great sound, comfortable, and no noise bleed-through.These headphones give me a high amount of distance (4.5') from the plug to the earbuds. I've had no issues of them inadvertently being pulled from my ears due to having too short of a cord. Speaking of the cord, I like the fabric covering that they use for it. It makes the cord quite flexible, and it seems to resist tangling better than the normal vinyl cord.In terms of sound, these are really good. The bass is rich, and the whole sound range is as good as I would expect on regular earbuds. The vinyl earpieces are comfortable, and the package comes with three sets to give you a solid fit, whatever your ear size happens to be. Also, there is no sound bleed-through for anyone sitting next to you. Your co-workers and friends will thank you for that.Of course, the cherrywood finish on the earbuds give these a classy look, definitely something distinct and different from what you'd normally see. All things combined, I like these a lot.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free
