I'm pretty sure you can never have too many charging cables, and the Zeskit Lightning to USB cable just recently arrived. This is a well-made cable with the great advantage of being able to reach just about anywhere you need it to go.The cable portion feels much more solid than thinner/cheaper cables. I think this would survive the wear and tear (and occasional chair wheel rollover) better than most of the cables I use. The connectors are sturdy and blend well into the wire itself. Obviously the main advantage of this particular cable is the 10' length. I can have my device plugged into the charger and have a bit of roaming ability. If I'm in a hotel room, this length means I could easily plug it into a wall outlet and still be able to use my iPad or iPhone in bed.If you're looking for a Lightning cord connector that doesn't act like a leash to your charging unit, this is the way to go.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

These non-slip/skid socks are excellent in so many ways... I almost wish all my anklet socks were these.The bottom of the socks have approximately 250 rubber dots (and a rubber infinity symbol) on the sole to help with traction. They cover the area (at least on my foot) from the base of my toes to about 2/3's of my heel. The ankle of the sock isn't just a flat cut. It's higher in the back and front, and lower on the sides, and that gives it a nice fit regardless of whether you're wearing them with shoes or by themselves.The main selling point on these are traction, and they have that covered. It doesn't matter what surface I'm on... these socks don't slip. They feel more padded than my normal socks, so they're much more comfortable.While yoga is one of the primary targets for these socks, they're good for quite a bit more. I would highly recommend them for people who have balance issues, such as elderly individuals. The chance of slipping on a smooth surface is cut dramatically, and they're comfortable to wear.Definitely worth looking into if you'd like to have more grip when walking around the house or doing floor exercises.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I received a set of Noontec ZORO II HD headphones for review, but before I could get to it, my son laid claim to them. He wanted a set of over-the-ear headphones to use when listening to music on his iPhone. In short, he loves them.In his words..."The blue Noontec headphones are amazing. Comfortable, killer sound quality, and they seal out exterior noise really well for not specifically being noise-cancelling headphones. Easily the best headphones I've ever had. Probably about as good as it gets before Beats and Bose."I don't know that I can add much more than he said... :)Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

These T.S. Shure ArchiQuest Architectural Elements Building Blocks have been a lot of fun for the kids of my friend to play with. They're just out of kindergarten, but they've been enjoying the challenges of the set.With the help of an adult, they can follow the included instructions to build the designed structures. OR, if they're in a creative mode, they can let their imagination run wild and build their own structures. As a side note, they are also great for leaving all over the house for parents to trip on... fun for the entire family!Seriously, it's a cool set of blocks that are high quality, and they teach solid architectural concepts.Disclosure:Obtained From: Amazon Vine Review ProgramPayment: Free

If you pick up The World of PostSecret by Frank Warren, it's probably because you're already aware of the PostSecret project that he runs. You probably also read his weekly post where he shares some of the thousands of secrets he receives via postcards from all over the world. If you're a PostSecret addict (like I am), you'll love this book.Contents:Introduction; PostSecret at a Glance; The PostSecret App; Surprises with the Project; Controversial Secrets; My Own Secrets; PostSecret France; PostSecret Germany; My Unforgettable Call on the Suicide Prevention Hotline; A Message from My Mail Carrier, Kathy; A Favorite PostSecret Event Story; Is There a Perfect Secret?; The Perfect SecretThe things that makes the book more than just a republishing of secrets are the short pieces listed above that Frank adds. I especially liked the story about his mail carrier, and how the project affected her over the years. I'm guessing that it was the best part of her job.Like all the secrets, some you'll recognize and relate to, and others you'll wonder how anyone could feel that way. If you're lucky, you'll see yourself in a few, either as the sender or the subject. Either way, The World of PostSecret is an interesting look at the things we all struggle with, but never tell anyone else.Disclosure:Obtained From: LibraryPayment: Borrowed

0:28 Mins Walking/running/biking at night means you should have some way to be seen in the dark. These LED safety lights are a great way to be seen, and I love the flexibility they offer in terms of placement and use.These are very simple in design. The back consists of a clip with ridges on the inside. It opens up about an inch so you can put it on belts, straps, collars, or whatever else suits your needs. They also come with a short (4.5") velcro strap so you can loop it inside the clip and wrap it around an object (like the seat post of a bike).The light has two modes. It can either show a steady or flashing red light that cycles through on the button pushes. It runs off two CR-2032 disk batteries which are easy enough to purchase. To change the batteries, you remove four small screws on the back with a small screwdriver (like you'd use to fix your glasses). The back pops off, you change the batteries, and you screw the back into place. It only takes a couple of minutes, so I don't see that as a negative.The thing I like most about these lights is that I can use them in a number of situations. Since they clip on, they can go from a jacket to a backpack to a dog collar in seconds. It beats having use-specific lights that are stuck fulfilling only one role.This is a perfect item to keep yourself or someone else safe at night.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I like scents in my work area, and this Calily Ultrasonic Essential Oil Diffuser works wonderfully. It's quiet, has multiple settings, and fills my office with great essential oil scents.The diffuser is 6" tall, and fits nicely on the corner of my desk. The plastic outer cover twists off the locking base, revealing the inner workings. You add a cup of water (comes with a measuring cup that properly fills the reservoir), add a few drops of whatever oil you want, and then lock the outer cover back onto the base. Plug it in, and you're ready to go.Holding the mist button down for two seconds starts a low level mist that carries the scent. You can then click through levels 2, 3, and 4 to vary the amount of mist that comes out. I ran it at level 1 and got more than four hours of operation before it automatically shut off for low water level.In addition to the mist, it also has a few lighting options. Holding the light button down for two seconds starts the first setting, which is a slow fade and blend of one color to another, across the spectrum of available colors. Clicking the button after that offers solid color settings of red, blue, green, purple, teal, yellow, and light blue. This can be either a nice addition to the scents, or a stand-alone night light... either one works well.This is a great diffuser, and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants to get into aromatherapy... or just likes the fresh scent of citrus as they work.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I've been trying out a sample of Austrailian Tea Tree Oil that I recently received, and it does a good job in a variety of situations. I've mixed it with my shampoo, and it works well in controlling dandruff. Granted, I don't have a LOT of hair, but this keeps what I do have looking good. I also saw that it's a good disinfectant for cuts and scrapes. I decided to try it out on a couple of scrapes I received, and it shortened the healing time considerably. I found that as I get older, the cuts and scabbing tend to hang around longer than they used to. This seems to speed up the healing and leaves the area looking more like it did before I hurt myself.I'm looking forward to trying this out for other uses that are recommended. I doubt I'll get to the point where I would try it for the more extreme uses like chicken pox or gout, but I like what it does to skin surfaces.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I don't do a lot of camping now, but it's always good to have a sleeping bag (or two) around. I got a chance to try out the Peanut adult sleeping bag by EGOZ. If you understand what you're getting and how it should be used, this is a nice bag.The bag is very light (2 pounds) and stuffs into a drawstring bag for easy carry and transport. Instead of a straight-line top, it comes with a hooded place for your head, and that includes an adjustable cord for making it snug. The zipper is adequate but not heavy-duty... more along the lines of what you'd see in a jacket zipper.Where you have to be careful is in how you intend to use it. The bag is pretty thin in terms of filling, so it's not going to be overly warm in cold weather. If you tend to be cold when you sleep, this is not going to work well for you. In my case, I'd be OK from about 45 degrees on up. I would see this being good from mid-Spring through early-Fall for outdoor use, or year-around if it's for "indoor camping".My plan is to store this with my bug-out bag material so that I'll have some sort of sleeping bag in an emergency. It's light and easy to carry, so it'll work perfect for that.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I was asked if I'd be interested in trying out the Aleratec heavy-duty flat LCD/LED TV 2-tier swivel stand. Given that my current setup had the top of my dresser crowned with too much stuff, I was interested in this solution to the clutter problem. It works great, and things look much better now.The wooden base (the lower tier) is 12" deep and 21" wide. The swivel is set underneath that base, so the whole unit swivels, not just the TV on top. The top tier is 11" deep and 21" wide, and there's a 4" space between the two tiers for putting your cable box/DVR/etc.It only took a couple of minutes to assemble the unit. The four plastic leg blocks slide into the upper tier. There are four screws that connect the base to the leg blocks. When you're done, it's a solid assembly.I now have my flat-screen TV sitting on the top, with my cable box and a network hard drive underneath. That makes room on the top of my dresser for the cable modem and an LED clock.I'm very happy with this item, and it'll be hanging around for a long time.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

I recently finished Johnny McCarthy: A Coal Miner's Son by Dwight Norris, and it's a good story set in a very depressing time and place, one that America has largely ignored and forgotten. The book was hard to put down, as it was a compelling drama with the main character trying to decide between doing what was necessary to survive and doing what was right for the greater good.Johnny McCarthy is a coal miner, one who comes from a long line of miners in his family. He lives in a coal mining town in West Virginia with his wife and son, and their existence is very much hand-to-mouth. Miners are treated as slave laborers by the mining companies, and if they're injured or unable to work, they're tossed aside so that another healthy body can come in and keep up the production.Much of the turmoil in the story relates to the beginning of unionization of the coal minors in the 1920's. McCarthy lives by his father's motto, which is not to bite the hand that feeds you. But he has a hard time reconciling the human abuse and minimal wages against the profits of the mining companies. All he really wants is to provide a living for his family and do his job. However, everyone in his life seems to have an agenda that's less than honorable, and each agenda comes with major risks if wrong choices are made.I know the life of a coal miner is hard, and it was horrific in the early days of American history. Norris has researched his topic well, and creates a set of realistic characters that quickly immerse you in the life that they live. This may not be a "fun" book to read, but it's a good one that leaves you thinking throughout.Disclosure:Obtained From: AuthorPayment: Free

My wife tried out the Ekouaer women's shapewear high waist boyshorts shaper brief, and she was impressed by the fit and wearability. It has boning to control the shaping, and she was expecting more of a "corset" style feel. But in actuality, it was comfortable to wear, and provided a great deal of support. It also didn't roll down from the top, so it maintained the silhouette look that she expected. The overall effect is that the waist, hips, and butt are smoothed out and look nice under clothes that are close-fitting or that are designed to drape close to the body. She would definitely buy these in the future.Disclosure:Obtained From: VendorPayment: Free

Another six months have passed, so it's time for a new In Death novel by J. D. Robb (aka Nora Roberts). This time it's Obsession in Death, and Eve Dallas has to match wits with someone who is obsessed (hence the title) with her, and wants to be her friend who can dispense justice when and where Eve cannot. As you can imagine, that's really not who Eve is and how she works.As with most of the In Death novels, Obsession starts out with Dallas and Peabody catching a homicide shortly before New Years Eve. This wouldn't be an unusual occurrence except for the fact that it was a high-powered defense attorney (that Dallas had gone head-to-head with in the past), and the killer left Eve a personal message on the wall at the scene. The killer tells Eve that they want to be her personal friend, and that they will make sure that those who disrespect her will pay for it in blood.Dallas has to walk a fine line, because the mind of the killer can turn in an instant. If Eve won't be their friend, then perhaps she needs to be taught a lesson in loyalty and respect. Unfortunately, that makes all of Eve's close friends potential targets, and the possibility that they could be in harm's way is making her desperate to catch the killer in any way possible.For some reason I can't quite determine, Obsession started out a bit slow for me. I was wondering if this was going to be a rare case of me not completely enjoying an In Death novel. But once the mind games started between Eve and the killer, I was... obsessed (sorry, had to go there). As usual, I hated when it was over... but I know that six months from now, I'll get my next fix. :)Disclosure:Obtained From: LibraryPayment: Borrowed

After all the Tim Dorsey books I've read, I still have yet to come up with a good way to summarize or explain a Serge Storms novel. I love them, but I can't explain them... at least in any way that would make sense to someone who hasn't read one. Shark Skin Suite follows that same pattern. I couldn't put it down. I laughed, I shook my head, I wondered what Dorsey must be like in real life. :)As with all Storms novels, this takes place in Southern Florida, where the weird and bizarre is just normal life. Serge's latest obsession is to become a lawyer, and the lack of a law degree makes no difference. He figures he can work most effectively as a "fixer", doing the dirty work that skirts the boundaries of the law. No, actually... his form of "fixing" is WAY on the other side of the law. He and his sidekick Coleman (perpetually drunk and/or stoned) get involved in a class action mortgage fraud suit, digging out evidence (or making it up if needed), and tracking down all the movie trivia related to legal movies filmed in Florida. And as per normal with Storms, a few bad guys end up dying in very unique and creative ways.Dorsey takes the normal lunacy that is stereotypical Florida and amps it up by a factor of 10. As his lead character is throwing out trivia left and right (which is part of the appeal of these novels), he manages to drop in real-life "can you believe" incidents that makes you wonder just how far-fetched this might be in reality. I love the fact that you can *never* tell where the story is going next, because anything (really!) is possible. For example, what was the last book you read where a life-or-death showdown was interrupted when it started to rain fish? Waterspouts and Key West... it works.This was a fun read with a lot of entertainment per page. I can't wait for the next one.Disclosure:Obtained From: LibraryPayment: Borrowed

I bought this for a great price. I already have a Vizio M Series 4K TV - so was able to directly compare the two. First off - the most important aspect - picture quality - the Sharp - at least the one I got - is way behind the Vizio. I ran them side by side and after adjustments of every type - the picture on the Vizio was always better. Especially in upscaling - the Sharp upscaling is mediocre to non existent. On 4K content from Netflix and Amazon - the Visio had a noticeably better amount of tiny detail. Sound is about equal on both. The "smart" interface on this Sharp is pretty pitiful. No Amazon at all - but most other popular stuff like Netflix is there. But unlike the Vizio - you cannot make any adjustments to picture or sound in the apps without exiting them - no fooling. Want to up the brightness - well you have to exit Netflix to do so. The interface on the Vizio is XLNT - on the Sharp it is maddening. Others have mentioned this JOKE of a remote with the Sharp, and it is, by far, the worst remote I have ever used. The Vizio remote - so good it has a keyboard on the back side :)  Bottom line is that my Visio M 49 cost $100 more than this Shap and is worth every extra dollar. This is going back to Costco...

UPDATE! Second unit was excellent. Read comparison with Sharp LC below... Purchased 49" version online at store that rhymes with Roscoe. Arrived today looking perfect I set it up, turned on, scrolls thru solid red, green, blue, black and white screens forever. Never get to setup screen. Tried repowering a dozen times. No luck. Dead on arrival. Back to Roscoe and I think I will try another brand.. (UPDATE)  .... Well I tried the Sharp LC and got another Vizio and compared side by side..... I was able to directly compare the two. First off - the most important aspect - picture quality - the Sharp - at least the one I got - is way behind the Vizio. I ran them side by side and after adjustments of every type - the picture on the Vizio was always better. Especially in upscaling - the Sharp upscaling is mediocre to non existent. On 4K content from Netflix and Amazon - the Visio had a noticeably better amount of tiny detail. Sound is about equal on both. The "smart" interface on this Sharp is pretty pitiful. No Amazon at all - but most other popular stuff like Netflix is there. But unlike the Vizio - you cannot make any adjustments to picture or sound in the apps without exiting them - no fooling. Want to up the brightness - well you have to exit Netflix to do so. The interface on the Vizio is XLNT - on the Sharp it is maddening. Others have mentioned this JOKE of a remote with the Sharp, and it is, by far, the worst remote I have ever used. The Vizio remote - so good it has a keyboard on the back side :)  Bottom line is that my Visio M 49 cost $100 more than this Sharp and is worth every extra dollar. This is going back to Costco...

So many leather products look great in pictures - then you open the box and say "What is this crappy thing?" Well, this beautiful piece lives up to the pictures and more. This is one quality piece, from the supple leather to the stitching and the reinforcing belts on the side. I have a few Piel leather bags and this is even nicer. It is not a backpack in size at all and I usually use the shoulder strap. But it is a stunner - you WILL get compliments - and the back pack straps are sure handy when you need to carry it a long way. With all the gizmos and crap we carry these days - I find this bag perfect and use it daily. I know quality leather and this is a rarity in stuff. I am an elder who has been buying leather all my life. I have stuff in  my closet from Wilson's House of Leather that is 30 years old. The quality of those jackets is way beyond what you find in Wilson's these days. This bag approaches the leather of 30 years ago - and the workmanship.

WOW! This phone is sweet - and I have owned an LG G3. Feels great in my large hand, the screen is wonderful. It is actually more colorful than the LG G3 screen. It's not as accurate but more saturated - more like a Samsung screen. Battery life is unreal because the cool running processor combined with the huge battery (3200) means I am at 90% power half way through the day! But sadly I am returning it. This phone is a victim of a stupid design decision. LG made this in only an 8GB version, and it will cause you misery in a short time of ownership because of that. This is crazy to ruin such a great phone - really. By the time Verizon loads all their apps, and the operating system and apps update, your are almost out of memory.  I set mine up with only a few necessary apps - I don't do games - and there is only a puny 1.25 GB remaining. Worse, that was after I removed all the apps Verizon would allow and moving every possible app to the 64 GB memory card I installed. It still runs fine today - but that 1.25 gig will get chewed up a bit more every day with app updates and OS updates and soon - it will run like a slug as it loses more working memory. LG I hope you are reading because with 16 GB this would have been the PERFECT large screen phone for anyone but a gamer. I find the slower processor to be an advantage in many ways, the phone never gets hot and the battery lasts 2 days. But sadly, the 8 GB sticks you in a bad situation that will only get worse. Makes me sad, really. BTW: I bought this with my own money - if you like reviews by folks that don't get the products for free please "like" my review as helpful.

I am not a poetry writer, I write self help and non fiction and satire, yet this book absolutely fascinates me. Adam does something amazing here - this book at first comes across as random pieces in different styles. But there is a common thread here, the madness of which Adam speaks is a collective madness - the reflections of a world and society gone insane. His poem "Bird Song" is my favorite and in a way, sums up this common thread of which I speak. Humanity poking it's head through a mountain of oppression...

I own many waist packs (Mr. Unstylish) and love them. I have severe neck and shoulder pain and tend to carry a lot of things, so I have standardized on waist packs. This is my favorite, as far as looks and style. It is very beautiful leather - but it is not fully lined - some sides are bare leather (see my photos.) - UPDATE - ordered a second one and it IS fully lined - but there is no leather between the front and middle compartment like in my pic - so they make these 2 ways - I prefer the leather divider.  I put up a side view so you can see how it tapers at the bottom - it is nice and deep - but the main pocket gets narrow and the back and main pocket share the same space. I ordered the "saddle" color and must mention that it is both darker and redder than the pics. It is still beautiful - but if you are expecting that exact shade - or hate reddish - you won't like it. The strap in the pic is adjusted to my 42 inch waist - so this should fit almost anyone. Watch the price it goes up and down regularly by as much as $20. I did NOT get this for free or a reduced price nor do I pay much attention to reviews from those who DO get the product for free. I bought the Sunhike version of this pack which is identical and wish someone jhad pointed this out to me. Roomy but very top-heavy - I own many waist packs (Mr. Unstylish here) and I love them. Hate having stuff on my shoulder as I have had extreme neck and shoulder pain for 30 years now. I really liked the looks of this and it is well built, especially considering the price. Not an Eagle Creek in quality, but not priced like one either. My disappointment came when I used it. Most waist packs locate the belt as high as possible towards the top. This is necessary to everything "hangs" from the belt. Look at this pack and you will notice the belt is halfway down. Poor design choice. This means everything inside that is located equal to or higher then the belt will hang down and outward, making for a very unsightly appearance compared to all others I own. I will probably keep it for capacity alone and will most likely use the shoulder strap that comes with it. I did NOT get this for free or a reduced price nor do I pay much attention to reviews from those who DO get the product for free. Perfect fit and not too fat - controls work easily under the skin - fair to good protection - this is a great case in my favorite color....

Don't be fooled - this unit makes great yogurt. I read the bad reviews and don't really get the problems folks are having. I have made 7 batches and all have come out great . Start by using whole milk and a good fresh plain yogurt - follow the easy instructions - heat the milk up slowly - and in about 8 hours you get fresh tasty yogurt that tastes WAY BETTER than what you have been buying.... If you want extra jars - the extra jar sets for the other makers cost as much as this unit. The truth is that most bathtubs do not have a precise 90 degree angle at the edge of the molding. Most are a degree or two off. This great product will not fasten properly unless that angle is EXACTLY 90 degrees! Mine was a few degrees off - most are - no problem - get clear aquarium silicon adhesive and put a nice 1/4 inch bead on all the adhesive surface. It will fill any small angle discrepency and be a better sealant than the original anyway.... even with a perfect fit I would have used silicon for a longer life...  I did NOT get this for free or a reduced price nor do I pay much attention to reviews from those who DO get the product for free. I am writing this from a perspective of being an ex-real estate broker who owned 2 offices. Real estate sales and MLM sales have more in common than most realize. Both require dedication and being ""in sales mode" virtually all the time. I have trained dozens of salespeople and spent countless thousands on sales seminars and, not once in those seminars, were introverts even acknowledged as existing at all!! Truth is that being an introvert was seen as something you simply change in yourself. This was (and is ) totally unrealistic, we are what we are. Jenifer shows you how to use what most in MLM see as a fatal deficency into an asset. This is truly a book for the forgotten masses in sales of all types, definitely long overdue and needed.  Disclosure - Jenifer and I collaborated on writing and publishing "Unstoppable Joy - A Happier You in 12 Simple​ Steps" about 8 years ago.
Most fun and positive movie I have seen in years. Don't even worry about the (typical Marvel) plot - the growth of the relationship between the characters IS the plot.

Did nothing to the fleas but made my cat very ill immediately. Dizzy and lethargic, twitching eyes and vomiting and runs for 4 days afterwards. Never did stop scratching after treatment. Found live fleas on day 6. Did some online research and found out this bad reaction is not that unusual with Frontline Plus. Never again....

I have everything from expensive hard anodized Caphalon to super expensive try ply stainless cookware. Guess what I use 90% of the time? Lodge cast iron. Once you get used to cooking with the the even heat coming not only from the pan bottom - but the sides (and handle - ouch) - it is hard to go back to the so called "superior" modern cookware. Tri Ply ties to do what cast iron does - but doesn't have the heft to duplicate. As far as seasoning - just don't use soaps - let it cool completely before wiping down and re oiling - and NEVER put food in a cold cast iron pan. Always pre heat. I just ordered a second 8 incher because one is not enough at times :)  I did NOT get this for free or a reduced price nor do I pay much attention to reviews from those who DO get the product for free. I use it for making coconut milk with my blender and it works like a charm. Very thick material, great for hand squeezing...

Loved the Macro function - but hated the slow and loud focusing and the soft images at over 200 mm. It really isn't that sharp of a telephoto in my opinion, even tripod mounted. I may buy a used one on eBay some day just for the macro function, which is excellent. So I purchased the Nikon 55-300 f/4.5-5.6G ED VR AFS and LOVE it. The Nikon is more expensive but you can see the difference. It is very sharp through the entire zoom range and has fast, near silent focusing. Plus it has VR which can make a huge difference in hand held shooting. In general I have had poor luck with digital ballasts that I bought several years ago when they were new on the market. Back then it seemed like if you looked at them wrong, they broke. So I went back to reliable magnetic ballasts. But the increased PAR light (10 - 20%) and better efficiency reported in tests after test of magnetic versus digital led me back. Boy it seems the technology has improved tremendously. These run VERY cool compared to magnetic and the bulbs start (and restart) almost instantly. As far as longevity, if one breaks I will update the review but they seem rock solid. The manufacturer has a good reputation for backing up their product, I checked them out before buying. And after looking at over 10 different brands of digital ballasts - it sure looks like the ones $100 more in price come from the same factory. Cases are almost identical on many of these, as are the specs. So I'll go with the low price. One piece of advice not in the manual - - NEVER RUN A DIGITAL BALLAST ON A CIRCUIT WITH GFCI. I have seen them killed in an instant - I believe it is because the digital ballasts fire up by creating a momentary short - which the GFCI kicks in to fix at exactly the wrong moment.

I use vertical lighting exclusively and this is a great tube to lower heat and also keep your backside from getting burned :) The only thing not covered by the other reviews and not apparent from the description is that this can be used for both horizontal and/or vertical lighting setups with 360 degree coverage. The internal reflector is removable to expose glass on all sides and by moving one of the hanging brackets, it can be hung easily in a vertical orientation. Running your ducting with cool tubes on vertical is a challenge but that goes with the territory. This unit is well built and arrived in great shape - packed well.  I did NOT get this for free or a reduced price nor do I pay much attention to reviews from those who DO get the product for free. This movie is scary almost beyond comprehension. There are many reasons it works so well on every level. From mood of dread created by the insane hitchhiker they pick up in the first scenes who explains how "head cheese" is made to the various "animal rooms" that are discovered in the house. I believe one thing that makes this movie work so well is that it almost plays as an analogy. We see how animals are dispatched for food. In this movie, the audience is put in the same position an animal is put into prior to slaughter. This ancient movie is proof positive that digital special effects do not a scary movie make. Carefully directed excruciating tension is what is scary - and this great movie has it in spades. Watch it with your eyes open the whole time - I dare you!

Unbelievable at the price point. I owned a Blendtec - and like this even better. Just as strong - smoothies just as smooth. Folks describe this as loud - not compared to a Blendtec it isn't. Blendtec is so LOUD I would have to leave the room. The other reviews cover most all the good points so I will add a few. The unit comes with a card - follow the link on that card and register and they double the warranty to 2 years! Even better - at the site replacement pitchers are only $30! After paying $100 for a Blendtec replacement - that is a huge change. I am gonna buy an extra for soups with onions and garlic etc - keep one for green drinks and smoothies. This pitcher is built like a tank - I am blown away by the heavy duty gears and bearing on the bottom. BTW: Many complain about the plastic containers on all these high end units. They MUST be plastic for safety reasons. When you are pushing 30,000 RPM - glass would be dangerous and that is why they ALL use plastic. Example from my real life. This morning I made a green drink with all raw vegies from my garden. For dinner I am eating some delicious steaming hot potato and cashew soup. And later for dessert - blueberry sorbet from frozen blueberries. ALL from the Dash!

I bought this based on so many great reviews and my Sable was listed as fully compatible. It arrived without instructions but they were easy to find online. Problem #1 is that on the Sable you cannot attach the bottom straps in the preferred location as there is nothing down there to attach them to. So they offer "alternative #2" in the instructions which is to double the lower straps over the top rack and then attach them to the bottom trunk lip. It worked but did not inspire confidence. I rechecked and had done it exactly like the instructions said, but added 2 bungees to keep the bike more stable.  I only put one 38 pound bike on the rack (no way could I see it holding 3 without damaging a car) and drove a total of 20 miles with my eye nervously on the rear view mirror the whole way. It shook and wiggled and rocked and rolled the whole way so I kept my speed under 55. Once I reached my destination I put this flimsy thing away. Put my bike in the trunk on the way back as the entire trip in I had no confidence the bike would stay in place....

These are very well designed in most ways. The mister works flawlessly, they hold air pressure for days once pumped, the pump is ingeniously easy and the fan is very effective. Much better than my Misty Mates except for one thing. I dropped one of the units, only once, about 4 feet and it shattered to bits. My fault 100%, but I have dropped my Misty Mates dozens of times with no damage. I will treat my other one like glass, but will hang onto the Misty Mates in case I drop it.
Is a very nice teapot. Doesn't drip. Has a lid notch to keep it from falling off. Well made and well packed. A great bargain....

This is a very well made, fully lined fedora. For the money it is an excellent deal. I was afraid the XXL would be too small for my 7 7/8 size head - but it has a bit of extra room and could probably fit a size 8 with ease. I have many expensive hats - but I wear this one with pride as well. Not top end - but way better than $15 had me expecting....

Maybe mine is defective but from reading reviews it seems not. Many reviews mention having to soak the pan afterwards to get off the burnt rice. This is the worst rice cooker I have ever encountered. Burnt rice sticks to the pan on every batch and I have tried many different water to rice ratios, as well as spraying the pan with oil. I can cook rice 100% better on the stovetop with no stuck rice on the bottom. HERE IS WHY THIS FAILS AT RICE COOKING... This thing cooks like if you set your burner on high setting through the whole rice cooking process. If you were crazy enough to try and cook rice that way, you would splatter stuff everywhere (this does) and have a big layer of burnt rice stuck to the bottom (this does that as well)  It cooks on extreme high heat the entire cycle and boils the water off like crazy, sticky rice water can end up all over your counter. You should not have to soak a rice cooker for an hour to be able to clean it - and with this you do. So disappointed because I really wanted a stainless steel pot...

I figured that all the great reviews had to mean something - so I bought one with pretty low expectations. WOW - this is one GREAT machine!  I am familiar with using both Blendtec and Vita-Mix and while this isn't "quite" as good at green drinks, it is 90% there at 10% of the cost. And SO much quieter than my Blendtec, which sounds like hell's own noise when it is on.. Personally I prefer glass containers to the plastic Blendtec and Vita-Mix containers and this one is very nice, thick glass. I use the Frozen Drinks button all the time as the reversing of the gears and spin will almost always pull the frozen fruits down for a smooth drink. And if something breaks or blades wear out - replacements are dirt cheap - 5 stars for sure...

I own many nice Invicta watches and bought this on impulse. I wear it often because it is super comfortable and great looking. . It is much nicer than I expected - even has a screw down crown. Face is very pretty with matching hands and super easy to read. I own the same watch in yellow, I like it that much.

I own many nice Invicta watches and bought this on impulse. I wear it often because it is super comfortable and great looking. . It is much nicer than I expected - even has a screw down crown. Face is very pretty with matching hands and super easy to read. After I owned it a few weeks I ordered the same watch in green, I like it that much.

I was amzed at this case. I bought a few cases - the others were more expensive but didn't protect the phone at all compared to this. This case is VERY HARD to get your phone into. That is a good thing because if you drop it - the phone stays in because it is one solid piece. Drop most cases in this range and it splits in 3 - two halves and then the phone (usually face down on the pavement). 5 Stars for sure...

I have several Vornados as I love fresh circulating air and I hate air conditioning. I just clicked on this and was told "You purchased this item on July 30, 2007. " Well we are now in 2014 and since that day it has run 24/7. Except for the occasional cleaning (great to have compressed air) has had no maintenance. Vornadoes do exactly what they say - they move air in a tight pattern like a big blow dryer. This one is a monster and can move air all the way across my house. I have used it to dry floors and entire rooms out after flooding. They are also the quietest fan you can buy for the amount of air they move. Simply the best and longest lasting "fan" you can get. The only Vornado I have owned that died was 13 years old at time of demise...

I really think this thing is an excellent concept with a major flaw. The very first time I used it - I smelled the engine after a few seconds. I had no greens, just 2 frozen strawberries, a cup of soymilk and some powders. Sop I let it rest and made another smoothie later. Same thing only smelled worse. You can hear the motor struggle even with just liquids in it. Back this goes - if they would put a 400+ watt motor in this thing I would happily pay more because I really wanted this. But it will not last - at least for me....

Well it is big, which I really like. Same size as a large Invicta, of which I have a few. But the quality and fit and finish were not up to what I am used to in this price range. The bracelet didn't seem to me to be a good match. It really isn't all that thick and I felt that in the long run it probably wouldn't hold the huge face. The face is textured but didn't have that detailed and intricate look I am used to. It goes back for a return.  I did NOT get this for free or a reduced price nor do I pay much attention to reviews from those who DO get the product for free. I have a 2000 Sable that doesn't have lighter plugs that shut off when car is off. So this is very handy. I use ir for seat heater - dashcam and phone charger. I LIKE the bright red light - it has saved me from forgetting to turn it off many times :)

This is a very nice watch. Considering the price it is a great bargain. The watch and links feel very solid and high quality. The illumination is very good - better then most Invictas (I have several). The bezel turns smoothly and easily. Watch band is HUGE - I have 8.25 inch wrist and have to remove links. One thing - it does not have a screw down crown so without that feature I would not take it into water...

This is my 5th Invicta and I have been well aware of their quality control issues but never had any problems with their less expensive watches. So I fall in love with this design and Amazon offers it at an unbeatable price so I bite. It arrives today in a major nice presentation box and completely wrapped in plastic. (See pictures) So I admire it through the plastic for a while and pull out my trusty magnifier. Looking at the face my eyes pop out of my head!  OMG - what is THAT!!!! One of the small windows that covers one of the chronograph windows was loose in the watch! It was jammed under one of the tiny chronograph dial hands. A complete disaster. Take a look at the pics I posted - you will not believe your eyes. I thought at a $2000 list price it would be impeccable - no way. What type of adhesives are they using - that is crazy straight out of the box.  I think it is best to stick with their lower end pro divers and grand divers in automatics. Those are very nice watches....

One of the most impressive Pro Divers yet! This watch has a screw down crown although it is not mentioned in the description. Most Invicta "Diver's Watches" do not, and without one you are gambling by taking it into the water. This is massive - unbelievably massive - I have 8.5 inch wrists (most bands stop at 7.5 inches) and it is even VERY large on me. Plus it is very thick - it is NOT going to go under a shirt sleeve. But she is a real beauty. Fit and finish are XLNT and face is stunning. The band is very thick as well, but not quite as long as the bands on my other Invictas. It just fits my 8.5 inch wrist perfectly - rather then having an extra inch to spare and links to be removed like several of my other Invictas came. So if you have a 9 inch wrist this is not going to fit....

These chargers and batteries are so great to have with your cameras. Whenever I pick up a camera (or cell phone) the very first thing I do is I buy a set like this from Amazon. So nice to have a separate charger and the option of 12 volt charging. I take hundreds of shots when I go out - and one battery is never enough. Best investment you can make in my opinion.

This charger and batteries are an excellent accessory.Whenever I pick up a camera (or cell phone) the very first thing I do is I buy a set like this from Amazon. So nice to have a separate charger and the option of 12 volt charging. I take hundreds of shots when I go out - and one battery is never enough. Best investment you can make in my opinion.

Open the door holding this and first, watch their eyes pop out, then see them excuse themselves and leave in a hurry :) Just kidding of course, but it did happen with me by accident one day to me and I couldn't figure out why he left so fast...  Seriously, this is a great garden tool. I have Tramontia cookware (the best affordable cookware in my opinion) and this machete is the same excellent quality. I hardly use my loppers anymore. This thing is SO much faster.

Whenver I pick up a camera (or cell phone) the very first thing I do is I buy a set like this from Amazon. So nice to have a separate charger and the option of 12 volt charging. I take hundreds of shots when I go out - and one battery is never enough. Isn't that why we use digital? Best investment you can make in my opinion.

I bought this on a "Lighting Deal" for a about half the normal price and really was impressed. If I had paid over $100 I would not have been. Armitron is known for cheap watches and this is near their very top of the line. It shows. It is very impressive, especially the stopwatch function. Face is beautiful, but not really easy to read - it could use more contrast in the hour and minute hands. It reminds me of a Victorionox "Swiss Army"watch in look and feel. Nice heft and feels very solid - not like a "show" divers watch but one that you could actually take diving. I have taken $20 Armitrons swimming many times and never had one leak. Armitron has an excellent service record - no complaints filed with the BBB in 3 years last I checked. Compared to hundreds of complaints filed against some watch companies. One disappointment is that the bezel does not rotate, which in this price range is unusual. I would have kept it but unlike most watches that come with metal bands - it was too short for my large wrist. My wrist measures 8.5 inches. Most metal band watches fit me fine. Some I have to remove links from. Without extra links it would have been impossible for me to wear this Armitron and they supplied none.

This remote seems to be getting a lot of hate and after pairing it with my PS4 and getting some time to setup and operate the remote it gets a middle-of-the-road score from me. A lot of complaints surrounding this remote are totally valid but I still found the remote to be fairly decent and it does have some redeeming qualities.►The Bad:(-) Overall I don't particularly like the form factor of the remote. It's much smaller than the PS3 BT remote control that came before it and as a result many of the buttons are tiny. In particular the PS4 face buttons are tiny and poorly positioned making them difficult to use.(-) For a remote with such small keys you'd think there would be a backlighting feature. But no such luck. Finding extra small keys in a darkened room while watching a movie sucks.(-) The remote is missing buttons you'd expect to have. None of the shoulder buttons (L1, R1, etc) get a button.(-) Much like the PS3 BT remote if PS4 is the selected device on this remote any button acts like a power button and turns on the PS4.(-) Batteries (2x AAA) are not included.►The Good:(+) I do like the button click when a button is pressed. It's much more tactile than on the PS3 BT remote.(+) Volume Punch-through is very easy to setup and controls the volume on the TV (a Panasonic plasma in my case) even when another device is selected (e.g. PS4).(+) Setting up the universal control features was pretty easy - either by manually inputting remote codes or using the learning feature (covered in the included instructions).--------------------UPDATE 11/17/2015:--------------------I've had the chance to use the PS4 Universal Remote more and more with my PS4, mainly using Netflix and Amazon VOD, and now I'm understanding the hate this remote gets. So two major issues have cropped up and unless there's a dramatic turnaround I'm probably going to scrap this remote altogether. Also, changing my review from 3 to 1-star.Issue #1: BT Connectivity -After initially working without issues my remote now seemingly cannot stay paired. The remote seems to enter rest-mode but has trouble waking. I end up having to push random buttons in the hopes of finally getting the remote to wake and work.Issue #2: Battery Drain -I'm on my second pair of brand new AAA batteries. The last pair of fresh batteries was put in the remote and less than 24-hrs later the remote (through the PS4) reported that it was low on battery power.

My 2.5 year old son is in the midst of an infatuation with toy cars, trucks and airplanes and loves to take any opportunity to play with his "cool cars" just about anywhere. Lately we've taken to making big road systems out of large thick construction paper that my wife and I draw roads, bridges, railroad tracks and other landscapes for him to zip his cars along. This Melissa & Doug Round the City Rug is perfect for my little guy!►Description:The rug is about 4' x 4' x 40" so big enough to fit a lot of cars (mostly Hot Wheels) but not so big that rolling it up and transporting it is a huge hassle. The rug is colorful and features some cool city center type scenery including a firehouse, hospital, parking lot and a large roundabout. The rug surprised both my wife and I and seems very well built considering the price.The back of the rug features a non-slip pad although I'm not sure of the material. We tested the rug on our hardwood floors and confirmed it stays put. The edging material is woven into the rug to prevent fraying - nice touch!Also included with the rug are four wooden, painted toys - firetruck, police car, ambulance, and helicopter. Each has it's corresponding place to fit on the rug.Overall I'm extremely pleased with this rug. My son loves it and used it immediately out of the box and insisted on parking his cars on it before bedtime. Most definitely recommended!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I've refrained from using car smartphone mounts because I've always thought they were too bulky (clamp style mounts) or looked hideous (suction cup style mounts). This little magnetic smartphone holder works wonderfully and best of all once your phone is mounted it disappears entirely!There are two simple components - the vent mount that features strong plastic grips that slide over your car's AC vents. This component also contains strong magnets that form a strong bond with the metal plat that goes in the back of your smartphone's case or the back of the smartphone itself. Get in your car and simply stick your smartphone near the magnet and that's it!I tested this mount with my Samsung Galaxy S4 using the larger rectangular mount directly on the inside back of my phone's back cover. Unfortunately my phone case is a bit too thick and doesn't allow the magnets to form a strong enough bond to prevent the phone from falling under its own weight.

This is one of those items that I received from Vine that looked so cool on the product page and description but then really failed to impress in person. For the current list price I expected a decently well made clock and mini-weather station setup. I got that in a way but this product just doesn't live up to its price. And to be honest I expected a bit more from the name Frigidaire.If the novelty of having an atomic-clock set desktop clock with some limited weather information appeals to you and getting the time and weather from your phone just isn't cutting it then you may consider this product. But you should be aware that this is an all plastic device. Even the little wireless outdoor sensor is all plastic and flimsy and isn't in any way ruggedized against water as far as I can tell. It might survive just fine if you can find an outdoor spot that doesn't get much exposure to the elements. But even then condensation is going to wreck the sensor sooner than later.The main display is just okay. It definitely photographs really well and looks awesome (even for cheap plastic) until you peel the protective sticker off the screen and discover that the screen is a massive fingerprint magnet.But there is one bit of good news - the atomic clock (WWVB) pairing works! So there's that.►The Bad:(-) Cheap, cheap, cheap. Don't let the name on the device fool you; this is a cheap plastic device. The little kickstand nub that holds the clock upright really had me laughing at the overall lack of any type of quality.(-) No batteries included. For the list price have the decency to throw in a pair of AAA batteries (outdoor sensor) and a CR2032 (battery backup for the desktop clock). Ridiculous.(-) Fingerprints galore. The cool mirrored chrome finish looks good right up until you remove the plastic wrap.(-) Weather information is limited to very simplistic information thanks to the fact that it's conveyed via static LCD icons. Is it cloudy or partly cloudy? Well I guess I'll find out when I step outside! Why is the sun backlit at 9:26 PM in early November?►The Good:Not much here but I did get the atomic clock pairing to work. So I know what time it is. I could've just looked at any of the dozen or so other devices that also display the time in my home but atomic clock.

Note: I'm a pretty hairy guy but the main user of Panasonic's ES-ED50-N Multi-Function Epilator/Shaver in my household is my wife. I did take a crack passing the epilator over a small portion of my leg and confirmed that pulling multiple hairs out by the roots at one time does in fact hurt as much as is sounds.--------------------PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:--------------------I'll make the assumption that anyone reading reviews on this product knows what they're shopping for. My wife is a frequent visitor to a local esthetician and chooses of her own free will to wax her legs and... uh, down there. When I asked if she'd be interested in testing this epilator she immediately said yes (and so did I imagining all the money we'd save).This particular epilator uses a surprisingly and somewhat disconcertingly fast rotating head of 48-tweezers to pluck hairs by roots. The head pivots to move more easily over contours of the body plucking hairs faster than you can flinch. The great thing about this epilator (so I'm told) is that you can use it in conjunction with shower gel/foam to lessen the pain. Trust me dry epilation is not for the weak willed. The head is fully submersible for fast and easy cleaning.Charging the epilator takes about 1-hour and results in about 30-40 minutes of use.--------------------WIFE'S IMPRESSIONS:--------------------My wife is infinitely more pain resilient than I am and that proved to be the case with this epilator. While I flinched and wanted to stop immediately she's used this little device for almost an entire month and loves it. She does continue to use her esthetician for certain areas but her legs are now the territory of the Panasonic epilator.Also she highly recommends reading the instruction manual which does go into a lot of detail about what areas of the body are best suited for epilation, shaving, etc. And which areas you'll risk injury if you use the wrong attachment/head.--------------------IN THE BOX:--------------------1) ES-ED50-N Epilator/Shaver2) Epilation head (legs & arms)3) Gentle Cap4) Shaver Head5) Bikini Comb6) AC-adapter/Charger7) White cloth storage bag8) Instructions

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.Note: My wife is the primary user of this scarf although it is definitely manly enough that I'd have no issue wearing it!This has quickly become one of my wife's favorite pieces to sport on chilly mornings or evening while out with the kids. This scarf is huge and can easily double as a sort of one-person blanket. It's perfect in that use in car rides where I prefer to keep things cooler and my wife gets colder easily. She can simply throw this scarf over her torso and legs and keep warm!The plaid design is terrific and I'd have no issue wearing this scarf. The back is a houndstooth pattern with the same basic color palette as the plaid. The material used is a lightweight and extremely soft acrylic.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.My wife has been the primary user of this bottle although we do often share use of this bottle on walks with our kids. All told we're both extremely happy with this infuser-type water bottle. My wife loves cutting up fruit or fresh vegetables and placing them in the infuser as an invigorating twist on plain water without adding additives like Crystal Light or other flavorings. Our favorite item to add is seedless cucumber. It imparts a refreshing light flavor to water and no calories. Best of all you can refill the water and use the same cucumber for an entire day for an all-day long refreshing way to hydrate.The bottle itself is a glass outer and the infuser is made from clear plastic. The manufacturer claims the plastic is BPA free. The lid is also plastic and the stopper does a great job preventing any leaks. Fit and finish on this water bottle is top-notch.Aesthetically my wife loves this bottle and I agree that it falls a bit toward the feminine side. The colors and bright and really pop and it's quickly become one of my wife's favorite water bottles.

I'm going to approach this review a little different than the standard one-time rating and update this review as I get more experience with the Pivotal Living Band. So this first entry is based on my initial unboxing, setup and use of the Band. More reviews and potential updates to my rating to follow. Also the primary user of this device is my wife although I was present for each step described below.--------------------FIRST IMPRESSION:--------------------So not knowing too much about this device I initially categorized it as a more affordable Fitbit and I think that's pretty much a fair assessment of what Pivotal Living is trying to accomplish - with mixed results. The initial setup process is a bumpy road and I'll state right off the bat that this product (and the accompanying app) could use some more time in the incubator to iron out the kinks.'Setup Issues:You definitely want to very closely follow the instructions on the flap of the box. I looked over the instructions but glazed over the part where the instructions cover Bluetooth pairing. I approached this device like any other BT device and tried to pair it through my phone's (Android) BT menu. Wrong move that lead to unneeded frustration. You need to pair the Band through the Pivotal Living App that can be downloaded via the Play and iTunes stores. I can't hold the device at fault for my inability to follow instructions.'App Issues:The Pivotal Living App is really the central hub of the Band. It allows you to sync your Band and move data from the Band's memory (up to 3 days of data) to your smartphone/device and see a graphical representation of your activity and any goals you may setup (e.g. weight loss goals). You'll have to create an account in the app first. The account creation is pretty straightforward but the app has issues. On my wife's S4 she completed the account creation process and then launched the app. She was prompted for her (newly created) password and when she hit 'Login' nothing happened. This occurred repeatedly and she even reset her password to no avail. Ultimately rebooting her phone and trying the app again proved to fix the issue. This isn't a huge issue but something I'd classify as general lack of polish to the end-user experience.' More App Issues:The next problem my wife encountered was simply entering her physiological data - height and weight. On the app these inputs are sliders; drag the slider right or left to increase and decrease the value. The sliders are extremely inaccurate and frustrating to use. I really have to wonder if anyone at Pivotal has tried using the sliders as and end-user...? Nightmare. On the initial setup the height slider jumps from 4'6" to 5'7". My wife at 5"4" settled on 5'7". I was able to later go into the app and adjust the height more accurately via the 'edit profile' menu. Inexplicably the sliders work better in the edit menu than on the initial setup. But getting the value just right is unnecessarily frustrating. Just allow people to enter values and avoid the sliders altogether. Again, just a general lack of polish.--------------------WHAT IT DOES:--------------------For the uninitiated the Pivotal Band essentially is a little computer that tracks physical activity levels and paired with the app the user can set daily activity goals and be reminded via the Band. The band tracks: steps, total distance covered, calories, % of target goal, sleep, and has a stopwatch feature.Some of the features are a bit hokey. For example to track sleep you have to physically (by interacting with the Band via a button) tell the device that you're going to sleep and then remember to wake the device in the morning. There's no miracle of science and technology here. But having a small portable computer that tracks certain metrics and then represents that onscreen is pretty cool and a valuable tool.'Missing Features:I really expected this device to have a heart rate monitor and think that Pivotal missed a huge opportunity not including that feature. I realize that the price point is considerably lower than devices that include the feature but it is sorely missed.--------------------WHAT'S IN THE BOX:--------------------1) Pivotal Band2) Charger (USB based) must be paired with a USB AC adapter you already own (e.g. smartphone)3) Instructions--------------------CLOSING 10/27/2015:--------------------My initial impression of the Pivotal is a mixed bag. The price point is nice but I definitely feel like I'm using a poor man's Fitbit. The app in particular lacks polish and refinement and leads to a frustrating experience and a terrible first impression. Going with a middle-of-the-road 3-star rating for now. More to come.--------------------UPDATE 11/5/2015:--------------------I changed my rating from 3-stars to 2-stars, here's why.After a bit over a week wearing the Pivotal Band my wife has officially told me to stuff it and that the device isn't worth the trouble. This is after I essentially acted as her 24/7 tech support (which I am anyway) and encouraged her to keep using the band even with her frustration with it.The main issue here is really just a continuation of my initial complaints. Entering basic data (e.g. water intake) into the app sucks. Even when she did enter data into the app directly syncing the band to her smartphone continued to be problematic. The most common error reported through the app was something along the lines of "no compatible band can be found." The syncing issue would essentially mean my wife would either have to remember data or write down her metrics to input into the app later with hopefully better results.Again, Pivotal is coming in at the bargain basement price compared to the major players in the activity tracker segment. I strongly believe that this product isn't quite ready and needs further development.At this point I cannot recommend the Pivotal Living Band.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.Probably like most people I've never heard of the "iLuv" brand but after trying out the "Collision" Portable BT Speaker I'm sold! So I've had this little speaker for about a month and have ported it from my backyard patio, to my garage, and it's been playing my favorite Spotify playlists wonderfully on just about every home improvement project I have worked on in that month.►Sound Quality:Probably the most important aspect of any speaker; the Collision doesn't disappoint. I mean I'm no audiophile and I don't expect super high-fidelity sound form such a small and battery operated speaker but the sound pumping from the Collision is impressive. This little speaker delivers better sound than I expected and better sound than many other BT speakers I own that are more than double the price.►Build:The entire speaker is ruggedized with a thick coat of black silicone. This serves to protect the speaker from the elements and also inadvertent spills. I really like how this speaker was built and even the silicone-coated buttons are well thought out and offer a satisfying tactile "click" when pressed. Another thick silicone flap seals inputs like the 3.5mm auxiliary port and mini-USB charging port.►Battery:Battery life is pretty good. I don't think I'm getting a solid 8-hour playback time on a single charge but it's pretty close - maybe 5hrs of continuous use.►Setup:Getting your music to the Collision is easy; either through an auxiliary cable (3.5mm jack) or Bluetooth. If you've set up a BT device before you know the routine. Press and hold the power button until a blue LED on the Collision starts flashing; search for BT devices on your smartphone/tablet/device and finish the pairing process.►The Good:(+) Sound quality.(+) Overall rugged build.(+) Battery►The Bad:(-) The rugged outer shell, which I think is made from silicone, tends to attract dust and hair. Not a huge deal but just putting that out there.

I've been using Logitech's K380 in my home for about two weeks and in that time I've really grown to like this keyboard. In a nutshell this is a portable keyboard made to work with a huge range of devices in your home. Ideally you'd be able to cut the cord (USB that is) and use the K380 to replace several different older, wired keyboards.►Compatibility:Compatible devices/OS' include Windows (tested on Win 7 & 10), Mac, Chrome OS, Android, & iOS. I tested the K380 on everything except a Mac and can report that the keyboard is super easy to pair and includes an incredibly easy way to pair multiple devices and switch from one to the other  just about instantly.My main reason for using this keyboard is pure, unadulterated laziness which for me means being able to switch from typing on my PlayStation 4 to my Asus Chromebook. With the K380 that's as simple as pressing button. On the K380 the first three function keys store and serve as the mechanism for switching between paired devices quickly.►Keys & General Usage Notes:The tactility of the keys isn't great but I didn't really expect too much from such a compact and lightweight keyboard. I'm also on the fence about the rounded keys; I make more mistakes typing with this keyboard than any other keyboard I own and I think a fair blame lies with the keys rounded shape. The key shape is really the only gripe I have about this keyboard.That said once you do get more accustomed to the layout and rounded keys using the K380 is a cinch and the ability to switch quickly between devices shouldn't be understated.►In the Box:- K380 keyboard- (2) AAA batteries- Instruction manual

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.Simply put this is one of the easiest and best thought out wine bottle openers I've ever used. If you want to look like a pro opening a bottle of wine in front of friends or family or just want an easier way to open your bottles of wine this is the corkscrew to purchase!First time using this opener my wife tested it out and she loved it! You simply use the included foil cutter to cut and remove the foil; position the corkscrew over the neck of the bottle with the arm extended all the way forward (away from the operator) and then gently and smoothly pull the handle back toward you. The corkscrew handles the rest and twists the screw into the cork without any additional operation from the user. You then simply remove the entire corkscrew and cork together and enjoy your wine!Build quality seems really good although I've only had the chance to use this corkscrew on two bottles of wine so far. The corkscrew is heavy if that's any consideration and rather large. So probably not something appropriate for all situations.Very pleased. Recommended!

I'm not the quintessential "watch-guy" but have put together a nice little collection of pieces that I like over the years. There's something distinctly appealing to me about wearing a watch even in the age of the smartphone and connected devices. That said my most expensive watch is distinctly not that pricey - a Citizen Skyhawk AT but I love the piece and all of its quirky features.So my review of this Lucien Piccard piece started with some digging for background information on the company. From what I can find the parent company behind Lucien Piccard is the same company that owns Invicta and Stuhrling/Akribos - SWI Group. If you're a watch person or have previous dealings with this company you likely have strong feelings one way or the other. I've met folks in both camps - some that love Invicta, Stuhrling, Akribos watches and folks that think they're garbage. I've never owned a watch made by SWI aside from this Piccard piece.►Aesthetics:On looks alone this is an attractive piece. The 46mm case diameter means you're getting a large watch face - not massive like some other almost ridiculously sized Invicta watches I've seen - but large enough to be noticed. The tanned black leather strap looks great and feels like the genuine article. The leather is stamped to resemble crocodile skin.On the watch face you're getting a "skeletonized" window at the 9:00 position which simply means the mechanical components of the watch are exposed. One the reverse the a large skeletonized window exposes more of the the watch mechanics.►Materials:Overall I'm pretty happy with the materials used on this watch. Genuine leather calfskin for the band, 316L stainless steel for the bezel and case, and synthetic sapphire crystal for the case window (the face of the watch). The synthetic sapphire is particularly important as it should resist scratches more than other materials like mineral crystal.I'm also a big fan of the quick-release or "deployant-buckle" clasp on this watch. It allows you to set the size of the band once and then simply release a clasp to extend the band to slip it on and off. This ends up saving wear and tear on the leather strap and makes the watch easier to take on and off.►Movement:This is the big "a-ha" for a lot of folks. The movement is Chinese and advertised as such. I really do appreciate that this is clearly advertised on the product page, if not on the watch itself. This is my first Chinese movement watch and only time will really tell if it can measure up to the likes of Swiss of Japanese movement.The watch itself is mechanical hand-wind which means that the watch must be wound by the owner periodically to keep time. Setting the watch time and date is incredibly easy (especially compared to my Skyhawk AT).►Closing:I do plan on updating this review as my time with the watch grows. For now this is my daily M-F watch so I should have some good idea of the lasting quality as the months wear on.

The Stanley Classic Growler is the post-apocalyptic solution to your beverage needs... meaning this thing is built tough! This growler is large, relatively heavy for its size, and uncompromising. But despite those characteristics it excels at keeping hot beverages hot and cold beverages cold!I haven't had the chance to test this growler in extremes but did get the chance to test this out at a local municipal park that was sponsoring an overnight camp for kids. So my son and I pitched up camp and enjoyed hot cocoa on our camping adventure well into the night. The next morning as we were preparing for breakfast the cocoa was still warm! Pretty impressive even if the overnight temps only got into the mid-60s.This November I have a hunting trip in Wyoming that will definitely feature some extreme low temperatures and I plan on having this Stanley Growler right there with me with hot coffee to warm me weary bones.High marks to this growler for doing exactly what it's supposed to do. I did deduct a star because the cumbersome size and fixed position handle mean this growler takes up a lot of room in a pack. Overall, I do recommend this product and definitely something I'd spend my own money on.

My wife and I recently welcomed a baby boy (4-months) and have been using disposable diapers until he gets a bit bigger and we can transition him to the reusable cloth diapers we used on our older boy. Our normal diapering routine usually involves us switching between brands - Huggies, Pampers, GoodNights, etc. - usually just what's on sale or what we have coupons for. However, we do have our favorites. These Huggies Little Snugglers are one such favorite.My wife has done a great job getting our little boy sleeping through the night (10-12hrs at a stretch) and we use the Little Snugglers to get us through. This diaper does an excellent job retaining moisture while keeping it away from the skin. Using this combination we've been extremely successful with no leaks and no diaper rash!We have had a few incidents where, um... things got out the back of the diaper but things do happen. However, overall these diapers are a hit and definitely a part of our diapering routine.

It's been a few years since I purchased my last HDTV, a Panasonic plasma at that, so I was really curious to test this set out for a couple reasons. First, Polaroid and televisions... who knew (certainly not me)? Second, the price for HDTVs has absolutely bottomed out and I was really curious how this stacked up against my 46" Sharp Aquos set that I bought back in 2008 (for many multiple thousands of dollars).--------------------PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:--------------------The 40GSR3000FM is Polaroid's "Full-HD" (FHD) aka 1080p LED-LCD television. The set is on the cheaper side compared to better known models out there including Sony and Samsung. Right off the bat I'll state that if you're first concern is maximum picture quality you're looking at the wrong television. This set strives to offer a "good" picture quality (at 1080p) but isn't going to light the world on fire with cutting edge display technology. You're getting an entry level set.►Setup:This HDTV comes with a glass stand base that has to be assembled. This consists of mounting a plastic component that bolts the glass base to the television using three different sized screws. There are extra screws in the box (1 each). Assembly isn't terrible just not terribly efficient. I've never seen a company piecemeal together such a trivial part of a television before... but again the theme here is budget HDTV so maybe that's why.After you've got the base assembled or TV mounted if you're going with a mount the next step is setting up your sources. Suffice to say that this is as easy as it gets. Polaroid's onscreen menus are easy to navigate and getting the TV setup with cable, HDTV antenna, or whatever your inputs are is a breeze.►First Impressions:Unboxing this set the first thing I noticed is the weight... this TV is just so light! The advertised weight is 21lbs and it felt lighter than that setting up the TV. This isn't necessarily a bad thing just an observation.Once setup with my HDTV antenna and PS3 I tested both over-the-air and Blu-Ray movies with the set. The picture quality is "good" and I don't mean that in a bad way... it's just good enough. No one buying this set is concerned how this picture stacks up to a (former) Panasonic's plasma black level or a Sony XBR for contrast. It's not reasonable to make that comparison so I won't. The picture for everyday performance is fine. One thing I would recommend is turning off the dynamic lighting adjustment; which adjusts the set's LED backlighting depending on the onscreen content. I think it tends to wash the picture out and also can be disorienting/noticeable as the TV is constantly adjusting brightness.►White/Blue Line on the Bottom:I'll note since several other reviewers noted in their reviews a blue or white line along the bottom of their sets that no such line is visible on mine. I tested various channels and sources and have not noticed this or any other type of issue with my set.►Inputs:Definitely the highlight of this TV is the sheer amount and variety of inputs Polaroid has thrown in. The complete list:1) 3x HDMI2) 1x Component Video (Y Pb Pr)3) 1x Composite4) 1x VGA5) 1x RF (75 ohm antenna)6) 1x USB7) 1x Headphone jack8) 1x PC audio jack--------------------WHAT I LIKE ABOUT THIS HDTV:--------------------(+) Price Point. This is an entry level set that lacks the sheer picture quality and refinement of more expensive HDTVs but still delivers a good picture at 1080p.(+) Inputs Galore. Use this HDTV as a television or extra computer monitor... chances are there's an input on this set for what you need.(+) Lightweight. At just 21lbs this set is easy for even one person to handle and set it up on the included stand or even wall mounting!(+) Matte Finish. A low glare matte finish to the screen helps cut out glare.--------------------WHAT COULD BE BETTER:--------------------(-) Speakers. The included speakers are pretty bad and sound muffled.(-) Remote. This is a pretty terrible remote across the board. It feels cheap, looks cheap and is cheap... but at least it gets the job done. Just without any refinement or backlighting.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------I wasn't sure what to expect from a Polaroid HDTV but I'm walking away relatively satisfied given the price point of this set. Sure this isn't a set that'll blow anyone's socks off with astounding picture quality but it does display a nice HD picture on a budget. This set would be perfect for a business, child's room, or for a myriad of other uses where budget trumps performance. For the HDTV shopper on a budget I'd consider this set. Recommended.

I don't travel extensively but enough that I purchased some high quality Victorinox luggage that I've been using for several years mostly when I travel for work. My wife and I do have an older set of luggage for trips we take together that's more than well worn and needed replacement. This Travel Gear Signature 4-piece set is comparable to our old set (purchased from a department store 10+ years ago).So right off the bat I've never heard of the Travel Gear brand or really know anything about it. A quick search on the internet reveals that this luggage set is sold under at least one other name. So "Travel Gear" appears to me to just be one of the many brands for the same manufacturer based in China. The MSRP (and Amazon list price) on this luggage set is a whopping eleven-hundred dollars... right. No one in their right state of mind is going to confuse this luggage set for a $1000+ dollar set of travel bags.All that said I do think this is a nice set of luggage for a decent price (the Amazon price; not MSRP). Each bag is large but still fit within airline bag size regulations. The material (woven jacquard) seems thick and durable. Zippers are large and appear to be heavy-duty and also include loops for luggage locks. The three large rolling bags features "spinner" wheels and can glide almost effortlessly across surfaces and turn on a dime. Aesthetically the bags get a "meh" from me. I'm not a huge fan of the "TG" logo that's across the entire surface of the bags.►Included in this 4-piece Set:1) 28" Spinner: Exterior dimensions: 29 inches high x 18 inches wide x 12 inches deep, 2 inch expansion; Interior dimensions: 28 inches high x 17 inches wide x 11 inches deep, 2 inch expansion2) 25" Spinner: Exterior dimensions: 25.5 inches high x 16 inches wide x 11 inches deep, 2 inch expansion; Interior dimensions: 24.5 inches high x 15 inches wide x 10 inches deep, 2 inch expansion3) 21" Spinner: Exterior dimensions: 22.5 inches high x 14 inches wide x 9.5 inches deep, 1 inch expansion; Interior dimensions: 21.5 inches high x 13 inches wide x 8.5 inches deep, 1 inch expansion4) Tote: Exterior dimensions: 13 inches high x 15.5 inches wide x 6.5 inches deep; Interior dimensions:12 inches high x 14.5 inches wide x 5.5 inches deep►Impressions:Overall the luggage set seems well built and I'm confident that it can hold up to the rigours of travel. The bags are large and heavy so if you're looking for a minimalist approach to luggage this isn't it. I also was a bit disappointed that there's not a scrap of leather to be found anywhere on this luggage. Even the tote handles which appear to be leather in pictures (or maybe I just expected that) are made from cloth.
