Again, the list price is just bonkers.I have not yet spent enough time using this luggage extensively to judge how it performs long-term. I do plan on updating this review as I accumulate more mileage on this set.

My 2.5 year old loves VTech toys; his mother and I are somewhat less enthusiastic about all the bells, lights, songs.... you get the idea. But we agree that the toys are fun and interactive for our son so we do our best to put up with the annoyance factor the toys inevitably bring. This 2-in-1 Learn and Zoom Motorbike is no exception. You're getting a human powered scooter bike with two wheel configurations, tricycle and two-wheel scooter, and the steering wheel holds the usual VTech light-up buttons and speaker.►Assembly:Putting this little scooter together was super-easy. In fact no tools are required (minus a Phillips screwdriver for accessing the battery compartment) and the steering wheel and back wheels just snap into place. The back wheels can be configured into two different riding modes depending on the child's ability by simply snapping the wheels in a different configuration. Two spring-loaded release tabs hold the wheels in place and when pushed back release the wheels so that they can be reconfigured.Additionally you'll get a sticker sheet for some of the decals (four total).►Use:My 2.5 year old loved the toy right away and after using it on both our living room floor and driveway/sidewalk I think the toy is probably best suited for very smooth surfaces. Our neighborhood streets can be a bit less than smooth so probably best to avoid those with the plastic wheels. I'll also note that the steering wheel actually does turn the front wheels.Durability of this toy seems just okay. My son is on the larger side and probably approaching the limit of what this toy was designed for. The materials here are pretty thin plastics. They're colorful and fun but not as rugged as some of his other scooters.Overall he's satisfied and this is a toy his little brother will definitely be getting some mileage out of. Recommended!

I've been using similar Nitrile gloves in my garage for years for messy tasks like changing oil on my car or lawn mowers, mixing oil and gasoline for my 2-cycle weedwacker, and also for tasks like staining furniture. Nitrile is great and doesn't leave my hands smelly or feeling like they're covered in fine powder like latex. Additionally you still retain a good sense of touch while using these gloves; something I definitely don't retain while using my heavy-duty work gloves. The Ammex Gloves seem to match up nicely compared to other brands I've tried.

Turtle Beach's Ear Force PX24 is the "universal" (PS4, Xbone, PC, and mobile) headset solution for anyone looking for an entry to mid-level headset that offers really good quality sound and features but don't want to spend a bundle. I own a myriad of gaming headsets, including TB, and the PX24 most closely resembles the Z22 headset that I own for my PC.--------------------PRODUCT FEATURES:--------------------This headset features stereo sound and a "virtual surround" mode. I think at this price-point most headsets on the market aren't true surround sound enabled and though the real thing is very impressive the PX24 does a great job with audio. Overall audio quality is very good and what I've come to expect from Turtle Beach. Audio is crisp, clear but still features plenty of bass "oomph".This headset is wired to the console/PC/device in what TB calls "tethered". So if you're bent on a true wireless experience you'll have to look elsewhere. I own a few different wireless headsets including the TB Elite 800 and Sony Gold Wireless Headset (GWH) and the freedom of wireless and not having to deal with cords is very nice. I do think TB has done a good job with the "tether" including the in-line amplifier with controls that somewhat offset the hassle of being tethered to the controller.'Inline Amplifier Features & Changes:The inline amplifier has received a nice facelift compared to my Z22. The inline amplifier on the PX24 features an easier to use interface to start with. A large central button toggles between Master Volume, Virtual Surround, Mic Monitor, Variable Bass Boost. A small blue LED under each setting lights up indicating the user selection and a side-mounted turn-dial is used to adjust each of the settings. This definitely beats my Z22 which featured independent dials for each and overall makes the inline amp a bit more efficient to use. Rounding out the feature set is a side-mounted toggle selector for the system you're using (again PS4, Xbone, ...). Independent Superhuman Hearing and Mic Mute buttons are also present on the amp for quick access. The status of each is given by very nice LED backlighting; Superhuman Hearing gets a blue LED and Mic Mute a red LED.One key difference with the PX24 is that the inline amp is not USB powered. So there is a built in rechargeable battery. This is really the make it or break it feature with this headset. One of the key features (at least for me) with wired headsets was that I needn't worry about battery life and plugging it in after use. That's now out the window with the PX24. Something to be aware about.--------------------PRODUCT USE:--------------------Setting up the PX24 is extremely easy and you'll be up and running out-of-the-box in less than a minute. Simply plug the headset to the inline amplifier and then the amp to the controller.Again audio quality is very good. Not audiophile level and certainly not as good as my Elite 800 headset. But I do really enjoy just pure stereo sound and I tested the PX24 on my PS4 and PC and love the stereo audio. Playing my favorite tracks on Spotify or in-game wandering the halls of a chalice dungeon in Bloodborne; the PX24 delivers the goods.'PX24 Compared to Z22:Except for a palette swap and minor changes to the the stitching on the headband the headsets are almost identical. The refresh or major change here is to the inline amplifier. In my humble opinion I do think that the inline amp on the PX24 is far superior. Just having one rotating dial instead of five makes me like the PX24 better. Also I'm a sucker for LED backlit keys and yeah the PX24 gets the nod again. The fact that the PX24 needs to be recharged (amp) is a bummer but something I'll adjust to with usage.--------------------THE GOOD:--------------------(+) Audio. Excellent in-game or music sound without breaking the bank. If you're looking for an economical headset that's not bottom-of-the-barrel then the PX24 is a good starting point.(+) Compatibility. Use the PX24 with your PS4, PC, Xbone, or mobile device. It's great for someone looking for an all-in-one solution.(+) Inline Amplifier. The facelift and changes to the ubiquitous TB inline amplifier is for the best. I love the simple toggle and consolidation down to just one radial dial for adjustments. The addition of LED backlit keys is a nice touch.(+) Build Quality. The PX24 is comfortable, easily adjustable and fits even large noggins (I can attest to that); it seems to be a progression of the Z22 which I've owned for years and still looks new so I take it as a good thing.--------------------SOMEWHAT LESS THAN GOOD:--------------------(~) Tethered Mode. This is a cross between fully wired to the console/PC and wireless. You're wired to the console controller or in the case of mobile and PC to the device itself. Less convenient than full wireless and you do have to deal with wires. But then again you also get the excellent inline amplifier for immediate adjustments. It's a bit of a trade off.(~) Battery. Having to plug in the inline amplifier to charge the headset is a bit of a pain and just one more thing to plug in.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------Overall I'm very pleased with this headset. Turtle Beach has taken one of my favorite, go-to headsets (Z22) and improved upon it with changes to the inline amplifier while retaining excellent build quality and sound and expanded compatibility. Recommended!**Note: In-game chat only tested on the PS4. Chat performed perfectly.

I'm going to echo many of the comments made in other reviews; the Tiger Stainless Steel Travel Mug does a stupendous job at keeping you hot drinks hot but the lid has a major drawback in that it's tough to clean.►Hot Coffee Test:My morning ritual always involves brewing up a hot cup of coffee and enjoying it on my way to work. Most mornings I'm still sipping on my coffee after I get to work. Most of my travel mugs do an okay job at keeping my coffee warm but the Tiger mug is on another level. I tested this mug over the course of several days and even after 3-hours my coffee was hot enough to that I had to carefully sip from the mug.►Design & Appearance:On just sheer looks this is one attractive mug. The white finish looks terrific and feels good too while not getting dirty easily; unlike some of my other mugs that show fingerprints easily the Tiger mug does not. The built-in rubber grip is pretty great too. High marks all around.►The Lid:This is where things start falling apart for this mug. While I have no issue with the centrally located button (depressed with a lime-green ring to show the spout is open) I do have issue with how hard the lid is to clean. First, simply washing the lid is quite hard because water leaks into the inner components. You can literally hear water sloshing around inside the lid. You have to shake the water out while forcefully holding the lid and the bottom of the cap (inner gasket) open. Even then there's water that will certainly still be trapped inside.My wife suggested soaking the lid in the sink overnight in detergent. That technique does work and gets the lid clean and I can simply shake dry the lid and use it immediately rather than having water sit in the lid and it getting skunky. However, the amount of attention this lid needs just makes the whole mug a hassle.►Closing:Above all if you're looking for a travel mug to keep your drinks nuclear-hot then you've found it. The drawback here is the lid is a PITA to clean. Recommended with caveats.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.Lightweight, easy to pair, and good sounding headphones is how I'd describe the Ausdom S03 Bluetooth Headphones. But I'd also add that these headphones are not the most comfortable out there.►Product Description:The Ausdom S03 features a behind the neck/head design where the speaker wire acts as an integral part of the earpiece. Soft silicone earbuds and in-ear pieces hold the S03 securely on the ear. The right earpiece features all three buttons on the S03 including volume and power/call answering/pairing. The volume buttons also serve to skip or restart tracks when held down for 1-second.►In The Box:1) S03 headphones2) Mini-USB to USB cable3) Instruction guide►Product Notes:The manufacturer makes these claims (which I've not verified): 7hrs of talk or 5hrs of music listening on a single charge» Bluetooth profiles: A2DP, AVRCP, HSP, HFP►Product Use:After unboxing this set of headphones I was really skeptical they'd fit my (large) head but surprisingly these headphones not only fit but they stayed in place for 3hrs while I was doing yardwork! I have not had a chance to take the S03 on a jog yet but I'm confident that after standing up to 3hrs in the yard with me it wouldn't be an issue.Pairing the headphones is straightforward - just press the power button and hold it down until you hear a series of chimes, search for Bluetooth devices on your media player or smartphone and complete the pairing process.My only real complaint with the S03 is that after 3hrs these headphones were really starting to get uncomfortable; especially around the top of my ears where the wire wraps over the top.►The Good:(+) Sound. The sound quality is really nice especially for headphones of this weight.(+) Lightweight. The headphones only weigh 17-grams!(+) Fitment. Despite my initial reservations with the S03 they fit my large head surprisingly well!►The Bad:(-) Comfort. My ears were really aching by the end of my initial use with the S03. This is the main issue with this product.(-) Accessories. I've tested a bunch of Bluetooth headphones and the S03 is definitely in the minority that don't come with an assortment of earbuds and earpiece types for different sized ears.►Closing:The Ausdom S03 is a nice pair of lightweight and good sounding headphones and worth checking out. Unfortunately fitment issues and the lack of swappable components means you may end up returning the product. Recommended with caveats.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I'm having a hard time accurately scoring this product. While I really like many of the features of the  Glasstic 16oz Water Bottle there are certain characteristics of this water bottle that I definitively don't like.'Product Description:The "bottle" is really a combination of materials and pieces that fit together to give the end-user the advantages of several different water bottle types. The inner tube of this bottle is made from heavy duty glass. An outer plastic shell (with the Glasstic logo) fits over the glass insert tube. Then plastic caps fit over both the top and bottom of both finishing out the water bottle.The top cap screws on the bottle and a rubber gasket prevents water from leaking. The cap also features a lock preventing the flip-top cap from opening inadvertently. Finishing out the feature list is a nice, large oval plastic handle.'Product Use:I threw this bottle in my backpack on most days and ported it to work and back. After about a week of use it does seem sturdy enough. The cap held tight an absolutely no water leaked out. But there are a few things I didn't care for either; namely this is a bit on the small side for a water bottle at least for me. The other is that condensation can form between the glass inner bottle and the plastic tube. This isn't a major issue but I was sure to wash the bottle and completely let it air dry each night between uses.Also, While having two layers comprise the bottle you're not really gaining much in the way of insulation. Ice added to my chilled water did last a bit long but only a bit.'The Good:(+) Affordable. Some of the prices of water bottles is absurd especially at retail. I really like that this water bottle is priced on the lower-end.(+) Build quality. The components of the bottle seem extremely well made. The glass inner bottle is especially heavy duty.(+) Locking lid. This is a great feature if you plan on throwing the Glasstic bottle in a bag. No leaks either!'The Bad:(-) Ounces. You're only getting 16oz of water per fill up with this bottle. Which may be totally okay for some.(-) Condensation. A bit of condensation between the glass and plastic bottles means you should wash this bottle frequently.'Closing:Buy this bottle if you've limited your search down to glass water bottles and want to avoid plastic and metal varieties. The affordable price means you can try it out without spending a bundle. Recommended!

I guess the first place to start my review is by saying that I do know about the controversy surrounding the G27 and as an owner of the Logitech DFGT, which I used for many years with GT5 & 6 and various other awesome PS3 racing games, I feel the twinge of anger. I do not and will not speculate about the "security chip" claim that Logitech has and continues to make. I am reviewing this wheel, to the best of my ability, as a standalone product.--------------------PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:--------------------Years ago when I wrote my original review for my DFGT I was beaming with happiness; GT5 Prologue had been released (the taste of car-crack that I had grown up with on PS1 and PS2) and my decision to buy the DFGT was validated the very first lap. I felt a lot of that same happiness when I fired up Driveclub (yes, Driveclub) and the G29. This is a beautiful, well-made piece of gaming goodness.Since I do not own (but have used) the G27 I'm going to compare the G29 more to my DFGT. So to start...►Build Quality:From the moment I unboxed the G29 I loved the quality of the materials and how it came together. You're getting a real leather wrapped wheel, high-quality metal pedals and flappy-paddles shifters. Extensive use of plastics are found on the G29 no doubt but again the key is high-quality plastics.►Force Feedback & Turn Radius:I tinkered around with the force feedback setting in Driveclub until I found something that felt good. I'll say that out of the box the configuration is pretty good. However, going from using my DS4 to a full-on racing wheel was a huge gameplay shift so I spent quite a bit of time sliding around the track. The force feedback felt a bit too strong so I dialed it down. One of the things I distinctly remember loving about the FF is the connection it helps the player make with whatever racing game you're playing. That is still very much true with the G29; I immediately felt connected to the road as I drove my M3 and then later Pagani Zonda around Canada, India and various other in-game locations. You feel the road shift, bumps, rumble strips and run-out areas... it's pretty amazing and totally immersive.The steering wheel also features a full 900° turning radius. It's important to note that because not all racing wheels do and you can sometimes find yourself running into the limitations of the hardware when playing a game.►Pedals:The pedals with the G29 are excellent. You're getting real metal pedals here not plastics like with my DFGT. Each pedal has a different amount of pressure required to press the pedal down. The brake distinctly feels like a brake and not like the clutch or accelerator. I will say that I haven't purchased the optional shifter (yes, optional) so my experience with the clutch was pretty limited. I do intend on buying the shifter I just haven't done so yet. So I'll update my review then.--------------------PRODUCT USE:--------------------I'll keep this a bit shorter since I mentioned using the G29 with Driveclub. I will say again that I really do love almost all of the G29. The steering is tight, force feedback is excellent and strong - so much so that I turned the setting down; the pedals are realistic and responsive. If you've never slurged and purchased a driving wheel you simply cannot go wrong with the G29. This is almost the complete package...I will say I have two areas of disappointment with this wheel:1) You have to purchase the shifter separately for the cost of a new PS4 game. Ouch.2) The flappy paddle gearbox (to borrow a favorite term from Top Gear) is not good. Let me describe it this way - it's "squishy". Each paddle shifter has to be squeezed toward the driver and it feels like I'm squishing a stress ball inside the G29 assembly. My own car has paddle shifters and they're so much more better; crisp and responsive with a satisfying "click". Not so much here. Yes, this paddles will have to do if you don't intend on getting the shifter but they're not great.--------------------THE GOOD:--------------------(+) Materials. From a real leather wrapped steering wheel to metal pedals and paddle shifters Logitech did a nice job bringing the G29 together into a premium racing wheel.(+) Force Feedback. I love the power behind the force feedback motor and even had to dial it down in Driveclub.(+) Shift Indicator. Just like your favorite supercar or F1 this wheel features LED indicator lights right on the steering wheel. It's a little gimmicky but cool!(+) Button Arrangement. I love that the L2/R2 and L3/R3 buttons are light blue and a good contrast to the rest of the wheel making them easier to find.(+) PS4 Buttons. The 'Options' & 'Share' buttons are easy to find as is the 'PS' button. Great for quick in-game snaps.(+) Quick Setting. The G29 retains some of the DFGTs button layout including the quick setting buttons and radial toggle.--------------------THE BAD:--------------------(+) Shifter. I have to mention it... the G29 is as much as the PS4 and you still have to buy the shifter separately! That stings!(+) Paddle Shifters. Channeling Jeremy Clarkson here... the flappy paddles aren't great. It feels like I'm squeezing fruit when shifting. I really wish these were more satisfying to use.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------All in all I cannot wait to use the G29 on more games. I've avoided buying Project Cars up to this point because of mixed reviews but will probably jump over after I'm bored with Driveclub. For now the G29 and Driveclub is my gaming nirvana. Aside from a few downsides as mentioned this is a fantastic product and easily one I recommend!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I long ago learned that expensive cables whether HDMI or otherwise is more marketing than picture or sound quality (looking at you Monster Cable) and have been steadfastly buying most of my cables from Monoprice or using AmazonBasics branded cables.I received this 5m cable and had a specific use in mind for my basement where I was intending on doing some rearranging and wanted a long run of HDMI cable. I've had this cable running from an A/V stack in a corner closet to my plasma TV for the better part of two months and it's worked great! I've had no visible impact to picture quality or any other issue of any kind.Comparing this HDMI cable versus Monoprice and AmazonBasics I'd give the nod to AmazonBasics in terms of overall build quality and look and feel. However, if you're looking for a good HDMI cable that gets the job done I'd give these a shot and they're a considerable bargain compared to even AmazonBasics.Recommended!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I really, really wanted to love the Soundpeats Q2 Wireless Bluetooth Headphones; they sound good, look good and are easy to use but I have to echo some of the other reviews - they simply do not fit very well.After receiving these I excitedly opened them, paired them up to my phone, and intended on doing a few hours of yard work. Nope! I spent a good 20 minutes just trying to get the earpieces to stay on my ears. The primary problem (at least initially) is that the cord is wound up in the packaging and tends to want to return to its coiled state. After spending some time coaxing the cord to straighten out I tried the Q2 again... and again the earpieces (one or the other) would pop off my ear with the slightest turn of my head. So ultimately the fitment just isn't right for my head and ears and I gave up using them. No way these would be good on a run... or anywhere where you might need to turn your head.I'll mention that I gave these to my wife to try and she felt the earbuds/earpieces were way to large for her and uncomfortable. So she gave them back. I again gave the headphones away this time to my brother-in-law and he's had better luck with them then my wife and I. Or he's just more patient about resetting the earpieces when they fall out.►The Good:(+) Attractive design.(+) Good sound.(+) Easy to pair.►The Bad:(-) Fitment issues.(-) Cord that wraps behind your head or neck is too short.(-) Earpieces/earbuds are large and uncomfortable.I think Soundpeats makes some good products (check out the excellent Qy7 BT headset) but the Q2 is unfortunately not one of them. Not recommended.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I was particularly keen to try these Mosquito Repellent Bracelets out for two reasons: I'm apparently a succulent steak dinner to mosquitos and I dislike most spray on mosquito repellents. My son also attracts his fair share of bites and has an apparent mild allergy to the bites leaving welts on his skin.So first things first - these bracelets DO work... most of the time. I've had the chance to use these bracelets on the whole family; wife, oldest son (2) and myself in pretty much any outdoor environment we frequent. Those areas would be our backyard/patio, soccer field, neighborhood walks, etc. I should also mention I live in the Midwest and mosquitos are quite bad in my area.'Product Description:Each bracelet comes sealed in a little reusable plastic pouch. The bracelets themselves are coiled plastic and smell relatively strong. I'm not exactly sure what's in each but the overwhelming smell that I perceive is citronella. The bracelets can be worn around the wrist or ankle and are meant to be resealed in the plastic pouch when not in use. The manufacturer claims up to 250 hours of use per bracelet though I've not tested that claim. I'm still using the original bracelet I opened after receiving the product over a month ago and yes, it does still smell of citronella.'Use:As I mentioned before the bracelets are mostly effective at stopping mosquitos. Both my son and I have been bitten while wearing them but then again the same is true when I wear spray-on mosquito repellent. For me the main attraction to this product is the fact that I'm not spraying chemicals on my son or me. Paired with other mosquito repellents, at my home it's citronella candles and tiki torches, these bracelets help form a an excellent layered protection for the family!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I originally imagined using this light on summer camping trips but with a new addition to my family getting out for a weekend overnight camp isn't in the cards. I have, however, used LiteXim's Smart Handheld Light on a few house projects. Most notably I was repairing some undersink plumbing in my wet-bar that had developed a small leak. Using this light under a sink revealed a whole new purpose besides camping - home improvement. Pretty much anywhere you need a light there's a good chance this little light is up to the task. It's bright enough to light small areas relatively well. After using this light I'm considering picking up one more to throw in my wife's vehicle in her emergency roadside kit.The "LiteXim" uses an internal rechargeable battery and can be charged using any mini-USB charger. I've been using my cellphone charger to get the job done. You're getting a few different light modes - high, medium, low, and two strobe modes as well.My only knock against this product is that it's not entirely durable. My two year old son got ahold of the light while I had it sitting under my sink and immediately popped one of the end-caps off. You're getting essentially several pieces of plastics with a rechargeable battery and LEDs. It's fine but I'd be sure to have a backup handy especially for camping.

I've recently been shopping for a rear mount child seat and ordered and eventually returned the Bellelli Pepe Standard Fit and the Thule RideAlong because of fitment issues with my bike. I have a Specialized Rockhopper Mountain Bike that I use for unpaved and paved riding and I was hoping to take my 2 year-old son along on smoother paved surface rides. The Peg Perego doesn't have the fitment issues that both the Bellelli and Thule seats have, however, the Eggy has at least one glaring design flaw that makes it difficult to use this seat and a few other issues that make the seat less than ideal.--------------------PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:--------------------The Eggy is actually very similar to both the Bellelli and Thule seat as far as the mounting system is concerned. You're essentially using a clamp-type mount on the bike's seat tube frame (not on the seatpost, but rather the frame). The mount is securely held in place by four bolts you tighten with an Allen wrench (included).The Peg Perego has an excellent design on the mount allowing for all types of sized frame posts directly addressing the issue I encountered with the other two seats. Included with the Eggy are two different size (lengths) bolts, three different frame post guides, and an articulating frame post mount (metal clamp). These pieces kind of all fit together like a sandwich and the bolts hold everything snug to the frame. It's truly an excellent design and even my wide frame on my bike presented no problem.►Installation:The core of the installation process is really getting the mounting bracket installed securely on the frame of the bike. Once you've identified the correct components to use - the bolts and frame post guides - it's easy to tighten everything down. My only advice here is to tighten each of the four bolts a bit at a time to ensure everything tightens at the same time and you don't misalign the bolts or seat.The Eggy features a bracket with two heavy-duty metal arms that have a plastic mount that slides into the seat bottom. A plastic pin slides through all this and holds the position of the seat. There is plenty of room to slide the seat back and forth on along the seat bottom bracket. The metal arms slip around the frame and slide into the mount and clamp in place. That's the brunt of the installation!I will say that the instructions aren't great but not terrible either. Some of the pictures can be a bit confusing but just spend a few moments going over everything and you should get the hang of it.--------------------PRODUCT USE:--------------------My son weighs approximately 34lbs (this seat is rated to hold 40lbs) and fits in the seat perfectly. We learned a lot on our first short ride around the neighborhood; some of it good and some not so good. So I'll try to capture everything (included my attempts to address the issues)...►First Issue:I initially adjusted the seat further back to give my son a bit more room and so that he could see more than just my back while riding. This however, presented another problem - the seat bottom would touch the top of my rear wheel when encountering any bumps or dips on the ride. This generates a loud grinding sound and more alarmingly the scrape occurs on the plastic locking pin. I was worried that with continued contact the locking pin would disengage allowing the seat to slide on the bracket. So I eventually slid my son closer to me and this seems to take care of the issue for most bumps (although not all) albeit he's very close to my back.►Second Issue:The seat features deep footwells  that protect the child's legs and feet from coming in contact with the bike. The footwells contain foot rests that slide up and down to accommodate children's height and leg differences. The foot rests have plastic straps that fold over the top of the foot again acting to protect the child from mechanical or moving components on the bike. This works well except for one issue - the footwells  are large and the plastic seems to stick out from my bike frame enough that the heel of my feet strikes a portion of it. I can sort of compensate for the issue by adjusting my feet on the pedal; I've tried pedaling with the middle part of my foot, but this obviously isn't ideal and a huge chore on hills. Initially I though I'd set the mount off-center and one foot-well stuck out more than the other. But even after carefully dismounting the entire seat and mounting everything again the footwells just stick out way too far. The only long-term fix I can think of is to drill two small holes along the bottom of each footwell and use zip ties to hold the footwells up against the chainstay arms on my bike. But this of course doesn't make the seat exactly easy or convenient to slip on and off for rides with and without my son.--------------------THE GOOD:--------------------(+) Price. Compared to the Thule especially this is a good quality seat for the price point and a good value.(+) Mount system. The mount system is versatile and included components for many bike types. Once mounted the seat is firmly in place and secure.(+) Safety Features. The seat offers good wrap-around protection for the child, deep footwells to protect little feet, and a nice big red reflector on the back. Two nylon straps and a child-proof seat buckle round out the safety features.(+) One-Click Installation. Once you've got the mount in place the entire Eggy seat is designed to slip on/off the bike with a push of a button on the mount.--------------------THE BAD:--------------------(-) Seat Clearance. Minimal seat clearance (at least on my bike) means that the seat can come in contact with the rear tire.(-) Footwells. The footwells stick out from the bike frame and can lead to a situation where the riders heel/foot strikes the footwell. Idealy there would be an easy way (built-in) to strap the footwell to the bike frame preventing this issue.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------Unfortunately the two issues with the Eggy are pretty serious and prevent easy and repeated use of the seat. I really wanted to like this product a whole lot more especially after trying two other brands that didn't work. This issue may have more to do with my bike and the dimensions of it so it may work better on other bikes. Unfortunately not recommended!

I've had a checkered past with Epson printers but I always try to approach each new item I review from a neutral perspective. For the sake of this review I will be comparing the Epson Expression ET-2550 to an Epson WorkForce WF-4640. This is for two reasons; first, the printers are in the same price range and second I own both and these printers.--------------------PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:--------------------The ET-2550 as best I can tell is Epson's attempt to address the outrageous price for ink. Anyone who's ever purchased a printer knows the routine by now; you buy a printer at a discounted price only to discover with horror that the 4+ ink cartridges inside your printer are not refillable and that ink costs more per ounce than gold. Those shifty printer companies got you again!So I was immediately intrigued by the ET-2550 with its promise of cheap ink that the everyday user can purchase and refill the printer themselves. The good news is that Epson has delivered!Okay so the printer itself is smaller than I was expecting. In fact it sits comfortably on top of my small filing drawer (as pictured). The screen is a disappointing 1.44" color LCD that is decidedly not a touchscreen. The only printer paper tray is a top-loading one with limited capacity (100 pages advertised). There is an included scanner but you're not getting the option to scan from a feeder, just a top loading single sheet scan. I know it sounds like I think this printer is disappointing - and it is in some ways especially considering the price. But then it hit me... Epson isn't using the same loss-leader type of business model with this printer. They're likely charging fair-market value because they're not making it back on ink. When viewed from that perspective I can honestly say that it makes this printer much more attractive.►In the Box:1) ET-2550 printer with scanner2) Four ink bottles (Black, cyan, yellow, Magenta)3) Power cord4) Manuals, installation CD, large plastic bag (used in case the printer needs to be shipped while loaded with ink)--------------------PRODUCTION USE:--------------------The very first thing you should do with this printer is read the instructions and find a good place to fill the ink reservoirs. Unlike most printers you've probably used the ink cartridges are not removable; the printer has empty tanks you'll have to fill yourself with the included ink. So take special care to figure out exactly what you're doing and where you're doing it before you make a huge mess. I managed to fill each of the four reservoirs with very minimal amounts of ink on my fingers. If you have latex gloves that's probably a good idea as each ink bottle has a foil cap that has to be carefully removed.Each ink reservoir features a soft rubbery cap that fits snuggly on top to cap the reservoirs. The printer has an initial setup process that takes approximately 20-minutes. I decided to go ahead and install Epson's printer software (included on CD) so that I'd get the ink monitoring levels on my PC. The software seems very good overall and an improvement over other Epson software I've used in the past.The ET-2550 does feature WiFi and a variety of options (i.e. WiFi Direct) for getting the printer connected to your network. I opted to use the onscreen guide to find my network and add my password and the process really made me miss my WF-4640's touchscreen. The process of entering text on-screen is clumsy at best but doable.The actual printing capability is pretty good albeit a bit slower than what I'm used to with my WF-4640. Black and white printing which is the majority of what I do is rated at 9ppm and color about half that. I'll go ahead and mention that I was impressed with the quality of the overall print jobs and documents I printed with the ET-2550. They're really good and similar in quality to my WF-4640.--------------------WHAT EPSON GOT RIGHT:--------------------(+) Ink! The fact that you can purchase your own ink from just about anywhere makes this printer (and the entire Expression lineup) extremely attractive to price-conscious consumers. This is hands down the single best aspect of this printer.(+) Print Quality. I was dubious about how good the prints could be given the unique approach to ink but I'm glad to say this printer measures up quite nicely to my much more capable WF-4640.(+) Scan. Epson makes some great scanners and though limited to single-sheet scanning the scanner on the ET-2550 does a great job with bright and quality scans. Epson's scan software is also quite capable.--------------------THE COMPROMISE OF THIS PRINTER:--------------------So there are plenty of compromises to be had with the ET-2550. To get similar functionality to my WF-4640 in the Expression lineup you'd need to spend A LOT more money and probably looking at the WF-R4640 which is about three times the price of the ET-2550. You're giving up a lot of features - large 4.4" color touchscreen, feeder scanning, PPM, paper tray capacity - but for the home user the simple fact that ink is so much more affordable makes it all worth the compromise in my opinion.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------I highly recommend this product and again the single best aspect is the user-refillable ink reservoirs and cheap ink! I really commend Epson for making a consumer-friendly printer that addresses the insane prices of ink. Recommended!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I have several reading lamps around my house and particularly my desk area. That's primarily where I tested and used this "LiteXim" 3.5W Lamp. The version that I received is the standard touch base and not the clip-on light. Also my version arrived in a box labled "Fashion Wind"; not that it makes a difference but this lamp is probably sold by many different vendors under differing names.I will say that for anything but a small area the light output from this lamp is pretty disappointing. You get three output settings - low, medium, high -  selected by touching a small area of the lamp base. Even at high output the LEDs in this lamp aren't super bright but enough for a small desk area and maybe for putting directly over a book.The light does make up some ground in that it's extremely versatile. With a built-in battery this lamp doesn't need to be plugged into a wall outlet. An included USB charging cable can connect to a desktop or laptop for charging. And best of all the stem is completely adjustable; you can twist, bend, and contort this light in a multitude of ways. The LEDs mean that the lamp won't generate significant amounts of heat while in operation.Overall I'd pretty happy with this lamp and I do think my house will get some good use of it.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I recently reconfigured my home office in my basement that included moving my Windows 7 based PC to the other side of the room. Not a big deal but my Cat 6e cable wasn't going to reach. Instead of buying more cable I used Etekcity's AC600 Dual-band USB WiFi dongle and it's been great!►Installation:Per the instructions I installed the included software bundle on the mini-CD and followed the onscreen guide to get up and running. The bundled software is pretty lightweight but does run in the system background. I believe that you can get this dongle up and running with the correct drivers (it's plug-and-play ready) without installing the software though I'm not certain you'll get all the features. During installation I was prompted to select the type of WiFi my router supports (AC for me).►Speed:Overall I have no complaints! My machine is pretty lean and I built it myself for quick boot-up times and haven't noticed much of a delay after initially powering on. It does take a few extra moments for the WiFi signal to connect but overall not bad. I do tend to transfer large movie formats to a networked drive connected to my home theater. Transfer speeds testing one >4GB .mkv file were pretty great.Overall very pleased with this unit and it's saved me from having to buy additional cabling for my desktop. Recommended!

The Dyson V6 Mattress (just V6 here on) is my first Dyson appliance that I've owned though I have previously used the Dyson Animal mostly to see what the fuss was about surrounding Dyson's products. I'll also preface by saying that I was hesitant to order this product (from Vine) mostly because it's marketed as a mattress vacuum only... which unless you're a housekeeper who really needs such an expensive single-purpose vacuum?--------------------PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:--------------------The most surprising aspect of the V6 that may not be readily apparent from the photos is that the power is activated by a trigger-button (red; inside the handguard) which makes this vac unlike any other handheld vacuum I've used before. At first this seemed so strange but after a few cleanings I've actually grown to like the trigger activation a lot. Why? Well for starters the V6 is powered by a rechargeable lithium-ion battery; by making the vacuum shutoff whenever the trigger isn't pressed you're saving battery. Second, the trigger is extremely easy to depress and kind of perfectly positioned on your index finger when using the vacuum. It's almost like it's not even there.The second most surprising aspect is that the V6 is lightweight! From the product pictures (before receiving the vac) the V6 looked heavy and well, sort of awkward. In practice the V6 just surprised me with its weight and how easy it is to port around and clean without inducing strain on my arms or wrist.►Battery:The V6 is powered by a lithium-ion battery good for about 20-minutes of cleaning time. Which honestly isn't a whole lot but then again considering this is a product meant to clean up mattresses it's probably adequate. An included AC adapter connects to the V6 on the lower-rear section of the handguard. Charging is indicated by two small LEDs on each side of the V6's bottom mounted battery pack. As far as I can tell the battery pack is not easily user removable/replaceable.►Canister:The debris canister is oversized considering the intended purpose but I found that advantageous... more on this in a bit. A spring-loaded, downward sliding toggle opens the bottom of the debris trap for easy emptying.►Filters:You get two user-washable filters with the V6. A rear mounted HEPA filter and a top-mounted filter that fits on top of the cyclones. The filters are a snap to remove and can be cleaned under the tap.►Rotating Brush Head:The main attachment is an adjustable rotating brush head that does a terrific job picking up debris.►Max Power Mode:As if lifted from the pages of Tool Time the V6 features a "max power mode" that's activated by pressing a small button on the back of the unit's HEPA filter housing. This revs up the vacuum's motor and gives you up to 6 minutes of higher suction power for tough jobs.►Cleaning Tools:Besides the V6 and the main cleaning head (rotating brush head) you're also getting:1) Mini soft dusting brush (oblong brush head)2) Combination accessory tool (oval brush head)3) Crevice tool--------------------USING THE V6:--------------------After receiving the V6 I had a chance to try it out almost immediately on a mattress and box spring in my guest room. I figured this would be a good test as the mattress is several years old and one of my dogs occasionally sneaks a nap on that bed. After firing up the V6 I have to say that it convinced a skeptic... it simply did a fantastic job vacuuming up debris I never knew (or could see) was on the mattress. But what really sold me on the V6...►More than Mattress Cleaning:After using the V6 the next thought I had was the machine was perfect for other jobs too. So I got to work on my downstairs sectional couch (which again my dogs love) and W-O-W the amount of animal dander and hair the V6 picked up was astounding!Shortly after that cleaning excursion I visited Dyson's website to get more information on the V6 and here's the thing - this machine is way more capable than just cleaning mattresses. For whatever reason Amazon's product page seems extremely focused on the mattress cleaning portion; okay the word 'mattress' is in the product's name. But visiting Dyson it's apparent this machine is meant for a lot more. So I put it to the test cleaning everything from my Rosewill mechanical keyboard, baseboards around my house, sofas and ottomans and generally anywhere my pets visit.--------------------THE GOOD:--------------------(+) Versatility. Despite being seemingly singularly focused on the mattress cleaning portion the V6 is really much more versatile. Folks with pets take notice!(+) Power. Plenty of suction power even for those touch animal hair/fur jobs!(+) Trigger-activation. The trigger activation vice the standard on/off toggle is a great idea and helps extend that 20-minute battery life.(+) Lightweight. Despite looking bulky and heavy the V6 is anything but. I've used this in all manner of jobs and found the machine extremely easy to port around and use.(+) Filters. I love that the filters are user-washable and the inclusion of a HEPA filter in such a small machine is terrific.--------------------THE BAD:--------------------(+) Filter exhaust. The rear HEPA filter is the main exhaust point for the V6 and incredibly it exhaust directly into the operator's face! Even with two filters I did not enjoy having hot vacuum air blasted in my face while using the V6. This is the main reason I'm deducting a star.(+) Limited battery. The lithium-ion battery is very good and gives its all right up until all the juice is gone but being limited to 20-minutes of cleaning time and 3.5-hours of charging time is a bummer.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------All in all the Dyson V6 has been a surprisingly good addition to my home's cleaning arsenal. I can honestly say that for the money I'd buy this machine. It does a terrific job cleaning and especially if you own pets consider this machine! Recommended.

My son is probably a bit too young at two years old to get a full appreciation for these Nature Bound Toy Binoculars. Right now he mostly uses them around his neck and occasionally we'll try to get them to work in our backyard playground to spy on birds, squirrels and the wildlife in the neighborhood.Well I'm not sure what I expected, the word 'toy' is in the title and these are most definitely a toy set. As soon as we unpacked them I tried to get the lenses to focus and it's very difficult to do even for an adult. There's no chance my son will be able to focus the binos any time soon.The body of these binoculars is all rigid plastic. My son has dropped these several time on our concrete patio and the binos are starting to show plenty of wear and tear in a few short weeks.My recommendation is to purchase these only for playtime. Anyone interested in introducing kids to even a minor amount of nature watching with binoculars should look elsewhere. Not recommended!

I've used the Arm & Hammer toothpaste with my electric toothbrush for several years and figured I'd give this electric toothbrush + toothpaste pack a try. I'll say right off the bat that if you're already using an electric toothbrush there's very little reason to switch to this kit unless you're looking for a cheaper replacement.►Toothbrushes:The toothbrushes in this kit use two AA batteries (included) that fit in the handle. The common theme with these types of electric brushes are that they're generally a bit larger and more noisy than the more refined (and expensive) brands like Oral B and Sonicare. That is very much the case here with the brushes in this kit. The other negative for me is that I felt the brushes were a bit too stiff; I already have a bad habit of brushing too hard so paired with these stiffer brushes I'm not doing my teeth any favors.Each brush is considerably larger than both my Oral B and Sonicare brushes and features a multi-action head. I think they do a good enough job cleaning but again are considerably louder and offer a more jarring brushing experience.►Truly Radiant Toothpaste:If you're familiar with Arm & Hammer toothpaste then you'll probably like the Truly Radiant formula. If you're not familiar with brushing with Arm & Hammer products then just be aware that these pastes feature baking soda as a primary ingredient. So your brushing experience will tend to be grittier than with other non-baking soda formulas. Personally the combination of baking soda and peroxide just leaves my teeth and mouth feeling cleaner than many of the other brands I've used in the past.My everyday brand is Arm & Hammer Complete Care Plus Whitening and honestly I'm not able to tell a difference in the whiteness of my teeth after using the Truly Radiant brand. I may consider ordering more but that will likely mostly be determined by price.►Included in the Kit:1) 2 Spinbrush toothbrushes2) 4 AA batteries3) 4 Toothbrush heads4) 1 Truly Radiant toothpaste tube►Closing Comments:I think this product is targeting two types of people: those that do not already own and electric toothbrush and those that are looking for a non-strip based whitening product. If you find yourself in either group this is probably not a bad purchase. Amazon's product page currently doesn't have a price (item is unavailable) but looking at other retailers this does seem to fit within the budget conscious market of electric toothbrushes. Overall a good experience. Recommended if your needs align to what the product does.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I have been using these SoundOriginal wired earbuds for a bit over a month and I still have the exact same reaction today after using them on a 3-mile walk that I had when I first unboxed them - these are really good for seven-dollar earbuds!I've used these earbuds mostly with my smartphone, a Galaxy S4, and mostly when out walking. Sound is good but I wouldn't say excellent. If anything I think the sound through these earbuds is a bit on the bass-heavy side and some sounds and voices tend to get a little muddled. I've discovered that is mostly due to the position of the earbuds in my ears. It's sort of a peculiar problem I don't or haven't encountered with other earbuds.Another item of note is that when adjusting these earbuds while I'm listening to music produces some static feedback. It's temporary and passes as soon as I stop touching the earbuds but worth noting.So for someone looking at a cheap pair of really good sounding earbuds I may have already lost you with those two comments. However, I do think this is a pretty good deal for nicely built, metal earbuds with inline audio controls. The inline controls include a volume slider, microphone (for phone calls) and on/off toggle that when pressed quickly skips the audio-track.►In the Box:1) Earbuds with extra long cord and inline audio controls/mic2) Three-sets of different sized earbuds (2x white/opaque, 1x light blue)3) Plastic alligator clampIf you're looking for a decent and cheaply priced set of earbuds that look much more expensive and feature good sound this is a great set. Perfect for vacations or the beach or anywhere you're afraid to port along more expensive sets. Recommended!

I have a solid background using SteelSeries PC products and jumped at the chance to try out their Stratus XL Wireless Gaming Controller for iOS and MAC.If you're a gamer and prefer Apple hardware then you may have looked with some envy at the plethora of gaming peripherals available on PC/Windows machines. Particularly Microsoft's own XBox 360 controller for PC. The Stratus XL seems to take quite a few design choices directly from the X360 controller - and I mean that in a good way.►CONTROLLER LAYOUT:The controller layout is very similar to the X360 controller for PC with the exception of the analog sticks which are evenly mounted similar to Sony's DualShock controllers. Personally I've got no problem with this layout. I own both PlayStation and XBox consoles so I've long ago adapted to the differing controllers. One item of note is that the analog sticks do not depress so there's no L3/R3 function on this controller.Again similar to the X360 controller you're getting L2/R2 trigger-style buttons; the shoulder buttons L1/R1 are bumper style too quick presses. The controller buttons get a palette swap and aren't convex like on the X360 pad but otherwise very similar. Button presses are crisp and register immediately. The d-pad on the Stratus is actually a bit better than that on the X360 pad - a huge feature for anyone playing emulators and older games that are better with a d-pad.Additional features on the XL include a series of four-LEDs that display the status of the controller from battery life to connection to a device. Top mounted buttons can be pressed to quickly display the battery life or connect or disconnect to a device. A toggle switch located on the back of the controller turns the unit on/off.►BUILD QUALITY:SteelSeries makes some great peripherals and the Stratus XL is no exception. This is a nice, heavy-duty controller with a bit of weight to it. Every analog stick and button feels extremely well made - all things you'd expect from a top-of-the-line peripheral and one certainly priced at the top of the heap.The one area that I think SteelSeries could've done a bit better is with the analog sticks or rather the coating on the sticks. Each stick features a concave thumb-pocket, however, I still found that my thumbs would slip on the sticks when playing games. The finish on each is a bit too smooth and in intense gaming can be a liability. This is easy enough to mod but something I felt worth mentioning.►DEVICE SUPPORT:Okay so this device is clearly targeting folks who own Apple devices and I think that's terrific as it tends to be underserved when it comes to gaming. However, the as someone whose household includes Apple and Android and Windows devices I really, really wish SteelSeries had made this controller universally functional with each. I realize that a different Stratus controller is in the works for Android/PC but for the price this controller commands I really think it should support all three.►CLOSING:No doubt if you're a series Apple-oriented gaming enthusiast looking for the perfect controller you cannot go wrong with the Stratus XL. One gripe with the slipperiness of the thumbsticks shouldn't keep anyone away from this awesome controller! Recommended!

My two year old son is a bit too young to attempt putting a toy like this Bloco T-Rex and Triceratops foam models set together. So I along with help from my 10 year old nephew took a crack. We built both models and the end result surprised us both; the models are really neat looking and better than I think we both expected.►CONSTRUCTION & INSTRUCTIONS:Instructions included in this kit are similar to Lego or Ikea instructions; simply meaning you get a lot of pictures and no words. The instructions in this set are full-color and that's important as there are two shades of green that both dino's use and a lot of pieces that are different in color only. The high-density foam comes in large pre-cut sheets of foam material. You'll have to punch out each piece as you build your dino. I'll go ahead and state that you'll have a lot of little foam extras from punching out each of the pieces.The instructions are about as good as you can expect. The color, glossy insert is very good but there were moments where even I was confused as to how exactly everything came together. The other issue is that it can be difficult to discern exactly what shade of green the instructions are referencing. So while the age range is advertised at 6-12 years I think it best to have an adult handy to help unless your child has a lot of experience with these types of sets.Pieces fit together surprisingly well and consists of high-density foam and brightly colored ball joints made of plastic. A few of the pieces such as the triceratops horns don't fit as neatly together as they should. Also, you'll be using a lot of square sections that fit into rounded holes (e.g. the tail of each dino) which can be a bit challenging to get together.►PLAY & USE:The end result is a really neat looking foam dinosaur with articulating limbs and heads. The toys are surprisingly sturdy and something kids can actually play with. Minor adjustments are probably going to be a norm so I definitely suggest holding on to those instructions. One complaint I heard immediately from my nephew is that the T-Rex doesn't stand up easily on his own. You can adjust the legs but the dino is just too top heavy and tips over.Another neat aspect is that the T-Rex model has two options during the built process. You can build a T-Rex or modify halfway in the construction process to build another dinosaur - a Therizinosaurus. Which is sort of a razor clawed Velociraptor looking dino. So there definitely is replay value here. Of course your more creative kids can go off the instruction sheet and let their imaginations go with the foam pieces and build whatever kind of dino they want.For my nephew and I this was a fun afternoon and the dino's are now proudly displayed next to his Lego creations in his room. Fun toy and definitely something different for the little builders in your family, recommended!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.Orico's 7-Port Powered USB Hub is a cool combination of excellent style - seemingly lifted from the Apple school of design philosophy - and performance delivered at a competitive price-point.--------------------►PRODUCT DESCRIPTION:--------------------The very first thing I noticed about this USB hub is that it's one attractive piece of kit. The anodized aluminum finish is just superb. My hub is in the silver finish and it just looks and feels terrific. In silver the hub hides fingerprints and dust. The hub is sturdy with a bit of weight to it. Each of the seven (7) USB 3.0 ports is spaced perfectly to allow a multitude of devices to connect.The second thing I realized after unboxing the hub is that it's powered. Which is terrific and a necessity if you're planning on connecting high-draw devices such as smartphones, tablets or external HDDs. The power supply (12-volt, 2.5A) does have a large brick-style connector so be prepared for that if you're plugging into a powerstrip with limited real estate.--------------------►USE:--------------------I used this hub with two machines - one running Windows 7 and the other recently upgraded to Windows 10. Both machines recognized the drive immediately, downloaded the proper drivers and I was ready to go in a matter of seconds.I have not specifically tested transfer speeds. Though I did have to move a significant amount of data from my desktops storage and onto my tablet for a recent trip that included business documents and some music and movies for entertainment. The sustained transfer speeds were blazing fast even for large .mkv movies.I've also tested the hub with the following devices connected simultaneously:Samsung Galaxy S4»Samsung Galaxy Note Tablet 10.1 2014 ed.»USB thumbdrive»Kingston external media reader--------------------►THE HIGHS:--------------------(+) Fit and Finish. ORICO has built a seriously good product with features and finish reminiscent of much better known technology companies. The hub is both attractive and built well.(+) USB 3.0. Transfer speeds are blazing fast - just be sure your PC/Mac has a USB 3.0 input to realize those crazy fast transfer speeds.(+) Powered. This hub is powered and can support and charge several connected devices without issue. A huge bonus for the home or office.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------ORICO'S powered USB hub is a terrific combination of style and performance. Great product. Recommended!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I've been enjoying my summer spending a good bit of time biking and like a lot of folks I fully take advantage of the technology packed into my smartphone to track and analyze my outings. I've used a few different bike mounts over the years and Bike2Power's U-TAG Universal Mounting Adapter is ranked at the top of the list in terms of functionality and usability.The U-TAG is two simple components - the sticky sided mount-adapter that I glued directly to the back of my smartphone case and the bike mount kit that clamps directly to the bike's handlebar.►INSTALLATION:Truthfully installation was a bit more difficult than I anticipated. First, the instructions include only pictures and a ton of numbers that aren't referencing any text. There's a thin rubber liner that goes between the plastic zip-tie like band that secures the bike mount. It's awkward to place the rubber liner then the mounts band over that and then use a (included) Allen wrench to secure the entire thing to the bike's handlebars... sound awkward? Well it is but the entire thing works so well once you realize how it fits together that I'm overlooking the slightly confusing installation.The other major plus that might not be readily apparent from the photos is that an Allen wrench is used to spin a hex-nut that feeds the band through the mount. What you end up getting is an incredible snug fit that doesn't slip around the bike's handlebars. Every other bike mount I've used has eventually needed tightening and adjustment. I've used this mount since mid-July 2-4 time per week and I haven't needed to adjust the mount!►USE:The single best feature of the U-TAG is how well it all comes together to form an incredibly secure mount  that let's you use your smartphone on rides. With the U-TAG mounting and then removing the phone is incredibly easy.»Mounting phone: Simply line up the mounting adapter plate on the back of the phone and give it a quarter-twist clockwise and you're set!»Dismounting phone: Depress the two quick release tabs and twist the phone counter-clockwise and your phone is free!►THE HIGHS:(+) Quick-on/Quick-off. The quick mount and dismounting system is superb compared my old awkward spring-loaded bike smartphone mounts(+) Secure. This mount hasn't moved an centimeter since I installed it on my bike's handlebars!(+) Profile. One frequent complaint about some other mounts I've used is how much the mount interferes with the phone. Not so here; you get the full phone presented to you without any additional "stuff" from the mount.►THE LOWS:(-) Packaging. I think the manufacturer/vendor has a great product and the presentation of this product (the package) is impressive with clear plastic containers for each component and bright, colorful inserts. But it's honestly complete overkill. There's so much waste material that it felt a shame to toss the container in my recycle bin.►CLOSING:This is a seriously good bike mount and one of those rare items I review that just comes together so well and functions perfectly. I'm planning on getting another mount for the wife. Recommended!

I've used hair cremes in various formats - forming cream, styling paste, pomade - and from differing manufacturers for about ten years. This is my first experience with Dove Men+Care styling paste and though it is a decidedly good product on its own, comparing it to leading brands or simply higher-end hair products makes the Dove product less desirable.First, let me mirror what's been stated in several other reviews - the price per ounce (at the time of this review) of the Dove Styling Paste is crazy. This stuff is priced higher by a wide margin than American Crew Forming Cream which I use regularly and consider a better product. Second, the Dove product suspiciously resembles (right down to the packaging) the bargain priced Suave Styling Paste with the addition of two ingredients: caffeine and cera alba.After using Dove's Styling Paste twice I can safely say that I do like the product. It holds my hair well throughout the day albeit with a bit more stiffness than the American Crew Forming Cream I regularly use. The Dove product isn't greasy and seems to hold up well under the intense heat and humidity of a Midwest summer. The Dove paste does smell a bit floral but wasn't noticeable after a few minutes.All in all I'm having a hard time recommending this product. If you're a diehard Dove Men+Care user then the higher price point may be acceptable. Personally if I were looking at something cheaper than the American Crew product I'd try out the cheaper Suave Styling Paste first to see if I could live without the (apparently pricey) caffeine and cera alba ingredients.Recommended with caveats - also check out American Crew or Suave Styling Paste.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.Kootek's 2.4Ghz Wireless Game Controller for PC is a terrific, budget-oriented gaming peripheral that does a great job and compares favorably against other leading products in its class.--------------------►DESCRIPTION:--------------------The Kootek controller consists of two major components: the controller itself and a small factor USB receiver. Installation is quick and easy and fully supports plug-and-play functionality. On my Windows 7 machine the controller drivers were installed in about a minute and I was pretty much ready to go.The layout of the controller is very similar to Sony's Dualshock controllers even down to the color scheme of the buttons. There are some notable exceptions that I'll get to in a minute. The controller uses two (2) AA batteries (not included) and does feature a rear mounted on/off toggle to save the battery in addition to a built-in sleep timer function.Build quality is pretty good but just be aware that you're not getting the same level of quality that you'd get out of a first party peripheral like the Dualshock or the Microsoft Xbox 360 for PC controller. I would say that the Kootek falls somewhat short of Logitech's 2nd party controllers and probably more in line with device manufacturers like Mad Katz. Functionality is spot-on but some buttons do feel a bit flimsy or on the cheap side.--------------------►USE:--------------------I tested the Kootek with a few different emulators without any issue whatsoever. No special middleware management software like the DS3 (on PC) is required. I can confirm that the Kootek works perfectly with both Nestopia and ZSNES. I have not tested the controller with Steam but would expect no issues with the appropriately compatible game software.--------------------►THE GOOD:--------------------(+) Inexpensive. You're getting a good little controller for the money that includes a very similar layout to Sony's Dualshock with plenty of buttons for assignment.(+) Wireless. Again for the money involved it's surprising that wireless is offered at all much less that it works perfectly without any hiccups.(+) Android compatible. Need I say more? With the appropriate adapter you can get this running on your Android device!--------------------►WHAT COULD BE BETTER:--------------------(-) D-Pad. The directional-pad is not very good on this controller and harkens back to old-school mash-pads. I'm not a fan but thankfully the joysticks work much better.(-) Pressure sensitivity. Although the controller may look like a Dualshock you're definitely not getting pressure sensitive buttons here.--------------------►CLOSING:--------------------Overall if you're looking at a budget oriented game controller and don't want to shell out for the MS Xbox 360 Wireless Controller give the Kootek a shot! Recommended.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.When it comes to jewelry or rings more specifically I'm not incredibly picky and definitely prefer simpler, cleaner designs over the bling look. When my wife selected my wedding band I asked her to pick a non-precious metal without any stones. She chose a simple titanium ring and I love it!The King Will 8mm Tungsten Carbide ring is along the same lines as my wedding band; simple, clean and uncluttered. Personally if you're even remotely considering this ring on the product pictures I strongly recommend at least ordering it; the ring looks better in person than in the photos! I wasn't sure I'd like the polished look (compared to my titanium ring which has a matte finish) but it does look sharp; very similar in appearance to highly polished chrome.This is a beefy ring and feels equally heavy; again especially compared against my titanium ring. The weight is noticeable but not in a bad way. I've used this ring daily for two weeks and it's indeed heavy duty with not a scratch on it. For my money I'd much rather have a simple, good looking ring like this one than a much more expensive store bought, precious metal ring. Recommended!

I'm using this 64GB Micro-SDXC card in my Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 2014 Ed. tablet as expandable memory mostly for holding multimedia and it's been working great so far! This is my first experience with the Gigastone brand as I typically use SanDisk, Transcend, or Sony memory products. So far my experience has been great with no performance or data loss issues with the Gigastone card.In my tablet the total available memory after formating was 58.42GB. I'm using the card to port around a few movies; mostly shows my son likes to watch over and over again and where WiFi or 4G coverage can be spotty (the park or playground for example). Playback has been terrific and again no complaints with performance. I also threw on an emulator for an old-school game system and a bunch of games and play them directly off the SD card without any issue.The adapter works great too. I mainly use the adapter with my Kingston media bridge to dump files from my Windows 7 PC onto the card. No issues at all there.The Gigastone brand is definitely one I'll consider in the future. Recommended!

* While I've got no problem wearing pink I opted to give these shoes to my wife so I'm ghostwriting this for her as she's the person actually wearing the shoesMy wife recently gave birth to our second child and received the all clear from her doctor to resume her exercising routine that includes walking, running, yoga, etc. In terms of shoes my wife isn't particularly brand loyal; she's run the gamut of athletic shoe brands from Mizuno, Nike, Puma, Saucony, New Balance and probably some others I'm forgetting. She has used these NB Vazee Pace Running Shoes for about a week and loves them!► Fit & Support:In simple terms these shoes are pretty much true to size. My wife is typically an 8.5 normal width size and these NBs were spot on. Arch support is equally terrific with no problems during some tune up runs (typically 3 miles). My wife usually likes shoes with good thick soles and plenty of ankle support (no minimus shoes for her) and the Vazee's checked those boxes as well.► Comfort:Again, she is super impressed with the Vazee shoes. She loved them so much after taking them to yoga she kept them on while running errands. My wife really loves how lightweight the shoes are while still offering lots of support and plenty of cushion on runs. The mesh upper is breathable and helps keep her feet cool.► First Week Impression:Both my wife and I have positive experiences with New Balance shoes. This pair of Vazee shoes is no exception. My wife has used the shoes for runs, walking, yoga, everyday errand running and loves them. The Vazee line is definitely a brand she would purchase. Recommended!

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.I recently wrapped up a complete renovation of a guest bathroom in my home that included a new tub/shower and of course the requisite fixtures. I was appalled at the price of fixtures; the Moen tub/shower combo I chose was close to $200 (not including the valve which added another $200) and that is for a "cheaper" chrome finish!When I was offered the chance to try AKDYs 8" Round Rainfall Shower-head I initially passed; after all how good can a $15 shower head really be if all the leading brands are ten times the price? I ended up deciding to give the showerhead a shot since I needed a new shower head in my master bathroom anyway. My old master bathroom shower head had an annoying habit of no longer staying in position and would tilt down constantly.► Contents in the box:1) 8" Round Rainfall Shower Head2) Small roll of white teflon pipe tape► Installation:Installation was incredibly easy and I did it in a few minutes. You'll need a few tools on hand, probably most notably channel locks to remove the old shower head and to also securely tighten the new one. I think it's great that Teflon pipe tape is included in the packaging. You'll want to clean the pipe after your old shower head is removed with steel wool or a specialized pipe-cleaning tool before applying the teflon pipe tape to the threads. Then simply screw on the new shower head, tighten, and test to make sure you have no leaks. That's it!► Performance:So I'll say straight away that I'm not a fan of the "waterfall" feature of this showerhead. The idea is that by twisting the middle portion of the head water is diverted through the narrow central slit to create a "waterfall" effect. It's a novelty and not really all that great. However, performance out of the oval, shower portion is terrific! Consider me pleasantly surprised to really like this shower head! My wife loved it too!► Closing:If you're looking for a cheap alternative to the insane prices that new shower fixtures go for then consider the AKDY. This shower head really cannot compare to better known brands like Moen, Delta, etc. in terms of build quality but for a cheap plastic alternative in a pinch, for a basement bathroom, or just as a replacement to an ageing shower head this is very good!

I purchased this grill brush to replace my worn out Weber grill brush. I have a Weber S-310 grill with stainless steel grates (the "Flavorizor" bars type) and my old brush just wasn't getting the job done any longer.The Alpha Grillers Heavy Duty BBQ brush is pretty good with one exception - it lacks any type of scraper tool. So for really tough burnt on chunks of stuff on your grill this brush likely won't get the entire job done. For regular cleaning of the grill grates and for things not super charred-on the surface of the grates this brush is excellent.The overall construction seems good and I'm hoping to get quite a few seasons out of this brush. High marks for the extra long and strong plastic handle. The braided steel neck is up to the rigors of cleaning the BBQ as well. Personally I do like the brush but do recommend having a scraper handy. I kept my old Weber brush solely for the scraper.

Notice: I received a free product sample in exchange for writing an unbiased review. The manufacturer has no influence on my review or score.Many years ago I served in the US military and used tactical gloves that are similar to the Vorosy Full Finger Tactical Gloves. I've left the military but still occasionally use my old gear for paintball or hunting and that's exactly where I used these gloves.Compared to my military issued gloves the Vorosy are quite a bit more lightweight and softer. The gloves seem well built and feature good stitching, heavy-duty nylon wrist straps with a metal buckle and a thick strip of Velcro to keep the gloves on. The knuckle protection offered here is quite good too with a lightweight plastic coating. I opted for the gloves in green and these appear to match US woodland green pretty closely; similar to the green found on US equipment prior to the move to digital patterns.Performance after an afternoon of paintballing was great. The gloves got filthy with sweat and dirt and cleaned up better than expected in a slop sink with Oxyclean.Sizing is pretty spot-on too. I opted for the medium size and they fit my hands almost perfectly (5'10" 175lbs). Dexterity sacrifice is small with the gloves on and you'll definitely have no issue using these with a paintball gun or hunting rifle.Overall excellent tactical gloves. Recommended!

For this novice DIY'er the Kraus KEF-15600ORB was about the easiest upgrade to a wet-bar sink that's imaginable. This faucet is advertised as a bathroom fixture but as my bathroom is entirely chrome this wouldn't be a good fit so I decided to replace my aging Delta faucet with the Kraus and it was a simple but dramatic improvement!--------------------DESCRIPTION:--------------------The first thing anyone is likely to notice is just how friggin' big (to use a technical term) this faucet is. It stands almost 15-inches tall (14.48" x 2.36")! So if subtlety is your thing keep looking. The entire package as it arrived from Kraus is top-notch including the box the faucet came packed in. The faucet is heavy duty with a beautiful antique rubbed-bronze finish and white (ceramic looking) handle that gives this faucet a farmhouse feel.The Delta faucet this replaced was aging; at least 10 years old but not dripping yet. I'm very happy that the Kraus has a ceramic cartridge which should provide many, many years of drip-free performance.In the box you'll get:► KEF-15600 ORB faucet► Reusable cloth bag (the faucet comes wrapped in)► Cleaning cloth► Hot/cold metal water lines (2ft.)► Instruction manual--------------------INSTALLATION & PERFORMANCE:--------------------Even if you've never replaced a faucet this is completely approachable to anyone! You need some basic tools including a wrench, Phillips screwdriver, pipe tape (I use teflon tape), and silicone sealant (I use the dry clear variety).
