If you're planning on also updating the sink accessories to match the faucet you'll likely need a pipe wrench and sealing compound (plumbers putty).My install was simple and just involved removing the old faucet and water lines and installing the Kraus faucet to the sink and the new water lines to my under-sink valves.For the novice Kraus has provided very good instructions complete with diagrams to get the job done. But there's nothing here that will present a challenge.Performance post installation has been superb. The single-lever water valve works smoothly and easily makes minute adjustments to water temperature and flow.One word of caution, I installed this faucet in my basement wet-bar and not in a standard flushmount sink and not in a bathroom style vessel sink (on top of the cabinet surface). With the height of the faucet and the depth of my sink water is falling out the faucet and traveling over 2ft before hitting the sink bottom. This can, at maximum flow rate, cause a bit of a mess from the slash. So just something to consider if using this faucet.--------------------CLOSING:--------------------This is my first experience with Kraus and an overwhelmingly positive one at that. Kraus is most definitely a brand I would hold up with the likes of Moen, Delta and Kohler and a brand I will consider for future purchases. Very highly recommended!

I received this product for free as part of the Vine program and per usual I glance at reviews to see what others thought of the same product before I submit my own review. I am a bit surprised to find that this hair gel has received so many negative reviews - overwhelmingly 1 or 2-star reviews (as of the writing of this review). That has not been my experience using this product for a few days, however, I do not have the history with Jack Black Hair Gel that some other reviewers do.My "go-to" hair styling product for the last several years has been American Crew Forming Cream. That product strikes a good compromise between styling hold and control and avoids hard, stiff hair a.k.a. helmet head. It is, however, a bit pricey so I am always on the lookout for other products with similar performance at a cheaper price. I think Jack Black Building Hair Gel is that product even if the savings are marginal.I've worn this product two days; both days work days where I keep my hair neat and tidy. The product has performed great! The gel is clear, definitely fruity smelling (no surprise there), and holds my hair while not giving me hard, stiff hair. The Jack Black definitely is stiffer than my American Crew forming cream but nothing like the cheap drugstore gel of my youth. Honestly any stiffer and you might as well buy a tub-o-gel (in neon blue) from the drugstore.I found that styling my (short) hair was as easy as the forming cream I use. The Jack Black product held my hair throughout the day without issue. So for me this is definitely a product that I would purchase and use again.I did deduct one star for the following reasons:► Stiffness: Simply compared to the American Crew product I regularly use.► Smell: I'm not a fan of the fruity smell of the product when first putting it on. It's not noticeable after a few minutes but definitely perceptible at first.

Well worth the money because it comes with eight bars and the packaging is weighty, substantial, and classy.  If you choose to give this as a gift, there is no doubt the recipient will be very happy.  I bake with Scharffen Berger frequently, so I was very pleased to receive this.  The eight bars go a long way (well, not so long with me) and the flavor profiles are excellent.  The soy lecithin is at least of the non-GMO quality.  Around 400+ calories per bar, so I recommend eating conservatively...if you can!

Wasn't familiar with the brand, but pleasantly surprised.  As others have noted the eye shadow material is a little powdery.  The neutral colors looked very good.  The glittery colors are a bit *too* glittery and only a very slight application of it is needed to achieve a full effect.  Would consider this brand again.

PROS:- Incredible number of supported inputs- Many different control options- Picture quality as bright and vivid as advertised- Black levels ok!CONS:- Barebones packaging, e.g. no HDMI cord included (although this may be a plus to some)- Average bulb lifetimeI connected the Epson 1440 to a Macbook while streaming "Days of Thunder" off Netflix.  The movie was projected onto a blank wall.  The picture quality was impressive, with excellent contrast and vivid colors.  Black levels seemed very good.  Definitely the best projector I've used to date.
Meowed loudly, then pigged out for 5 minutes while ignoring me.  I think it's safe to assume he liked it.

I've been using Hefty Zipper bags for forever.  I like the sturdier zipper mechanism on these new bags, but I don't hear the "click" that is promised when the zipper locks.The Quart size is a little small (would prefer half gallon ideally) but it's great for storing small snacks and such.  Great update to an awesome product.

These are great!  I wonder what took them so long to come up with this.  Each cup is sturdy, opaque, and holds a large quantity of fluid.  Only downside I can think of is that more schools aren't represented.

I came across this movie as a big Scott Adkins and Wu Jing fan.  Sure the nationalistic overtones were ham-fisted and groan-inducing at times, but no different from your typical Michael Bay movie.  On the other hand, the action scenes were very well done, with generally realistic tactical movements, reloading, accurate gear (check imfdb) and fingers off triggers.  This movie should appeal to anyone who likes believable cinematic gunplay.This movie may be a disappointment to Scott Adkins and Wu Jing fans such as myself.  I was expecting a big climactic kung-fu showdown since both actors are exceptionally physically talented.  Instead, we have a more subdued concluding fight scene, but understandable given that they were going for a more 'realistic' fight.  Wolf Warriors had high production values and was quite entertaining.  Let's just hope they make a sequel that's all kung-fu.

Long time watcher of Strike Back ("SB").  SB is to guns what Spartacus was to swords.  Pure wall-to-wall action with multiple gunfights every episode.  Although sometimes the action is improbable, i.e. Scott and Stonebridge wear "hero armor" while poorly trained henchmen rush headlong into their gunfire, it's generally very well choreographed and far superior to anything else on TV and most Hollywood films.  Scott and Stonebridge have an affable, sarcastic and easy chemistry while demonstrating believable tactical sense.  I can't think of another show where two characters clear rooms, cover each other, call out mag changes and actually reload.  Not to mention the ladies of SB are just as good.Kudos to Phillip Winchester for doing such an authentic sounding British accent.  I didn't realize he *wasn't* British until I checked IMDB.  I think SB Season 3 (or Season 4 if you count the prequel) is one of the strongest in terms of plot, action, and global filming locations.  It's better balanced than the plodding Season 3 (although I loved Tywin Lannister) and more action heavy than Season 2.

Really impressed by the value of these earbuds.  For just a shade over $10, you get different size cushions and a nice fit.  Sound quality was pretty well balanced, bass did not seem overpowering.Can't go wrong with these if you need a cheap backup pair.

Very satisfied with the Philips L2BO.  They're my first experience with the Fidelio line of headsets, but I'm very impressed. The sound is very well balanced and the bass is developed without being too punchy.  They're supremely comfortable to wear for hours; moreover, the orange contrast stitching is stylish.  Two drawbacks keep me from giving it 5 stars.  No volume control and sound tends to leak from the ear-cups making them ill-suited to quiet environments like libraries.PROS:- Fantastic balanced sound- Stylish, orange stitching- Comfortable, good build qualityCONS:- Noise leakage- No volume control

I purchased the Rhodium/blue tinted version of these TF 144s, popularized by Daniel Craig in the James Bond movies "Quantum of Solace" and "Skyfall".  I had some doubts about the authenticity of the item, but Sunglass Express shipped these quickly via Prime, and with all Tom Ford branded accessories included.  Additionally, Tom Ford identification was etched into the arms.  A far better deal than ordering direct from Tom Ford.Construction was solid, and these TF 144s are much sturdier than my Ray Ban Aviators.  The TF144s are known for being narrow; they fit more snugly than my RB Aviators, but not to the point of being too tight.  I would say the fit was perfect and sat evenly on my nose bridge.  If you notice in press pictures, the TF 144s are a touch too small for Mr. Craig.The biggest drawback of the TF144s is their lack of polarization.  Note that a lack of polarization does NOT mean these particular TF144s are not authentic; if you check the Tom Ford manufacturer's website, the TF144s advertised there also lack polarization.  While the lack of polarization has the advantage of enabling viewing of cell phones and other LCD displays, it also causes considerable eye strain on a sunny day.I hope Tom Ford releases a polarized version of the Rhodium TF144s in the future.

It seems that other reviewers were initially confused, but this set is stainless steel, NOT non-stick.  I prefer stainless and find it superior to non-stick cooking.  The pans do have a tendency to tarnish over time and will lose their magnificent luster, but Barkeeper's Friend will help maintain some of that original sheen.I have mixed thoughts on this Viking set and give it a 3.5 star rating, rounded up to 4 stars on Amazon's ranking system.  On one hand, it is a beautiful starter set with thoughtful touches, e.g. transparent glass lids and internal volume markings, but you're also paying extra for the brand name.  Furthermore, the Contemporary line is one of their cheaper sets.  I think the brand markup is therefore unreasonable.I prefer the Calphalon Tri Ply line, which performs no worse on my induction range and also offers similar Tri Ply construction at a more competitive cost.  Furthermore, I find the Calphalon Tri Ply comparable 3 quart saucepan more comfortable to hold because it offers an additional, smaller handle.PROS:- Viking brand name- Solid construction and hefty weight- Internal volume markings- Taller sides on fry pan prevent spillage- Mirrored exteriorCONS:- Unreasonable price markup given cheaper line- Saucepan and frypan uncomfortable to hold one-handed due to high arcing handle design and considerable weight- Saucepan, as compared to comparable Calphalon Tri Ply saucepan, difficult to hold one handed due to weight and lacks additional smaller handle

I was thinking about using a neutral polish on my Walnut McAllisters, but I'm glad I went with Walnut.  It's a beautiful polish that's well worth the price premium, and help me maintain the luster on my beautiful AE shoes.  Definitely worth spending a little extra to keep your AE shoes in top top condition!I applied using an old shoe mitt.  Noticed immediate improvement in leather shine, color, and helped conceal minor scuffs.  Works considerably better than the old Kiwi brand of polish products I used to buy at CVS.

The critics really trashed this movie, but I enjoyed it.  Better than the average VoD movie.  Sure it was a plot we've seen rehashed hundreds of times, but it was nice seeing Milla Jovovich play a character outside of her usual Resident Evil persona.  Dylan McDermott plays the same character here as he does in every single show.  Pierce Brosnan was a nice addition, even though he seemingly plays the world's most incompetent assassin.  A heavy dosage of willing suspension of disbelief is required, but it was an entertaining popcorn flick.

Absolution was pretty entertaining.  Predictable plot involving nameless Eastern Europeans trafficking girls?  Check.  Steven Seagal wearing his trademark tinted glasses and getting doubled in action sequences?  Check.  Menacing boss getting beaten down by Seagal in five seconds?  Check.  Willing suspension of disbelief?  Check.While Absolution is no Under Siege, it was an entertaining action flick.  Adding Byron Mann as Seagal's sidekick was a good idea, since not only did Mann provide a light-hearted athletic counterpoint to Seagal, but he performed his own stunts as well.  Note that Mann appeared as the villain in Seagal's "A Dangerous Man".  Vinnie Jones had limited screentime as the over-the-top one-dimensional villain.Absolution is good for some mindless fun.

I was pleasantly surprised by Infini; it's a pretty slick low-budget film.  Although it borrows heavily from existing sci fi movies, e.g. Aliens, The Thing, Event Horizon, etc.., the storyline is engaging.  Some minor quibbles; a) I had trouble understanding some of the characters due to their thick Aussie accents, and b) the middle section drags a bit.When I first watched Infini, I was greatly confused by the beginning sequence.  I'll explain it below (**NOTE, SPOILERS FOLLOW**).  Key to understanding the beginning is paying attention when a few background characters talk about time dilation.1) Captain Johanson's squad slipstreams back to the East Coast Command HQ.  They're held under quarantine while being questioned about outbreak exposure.  This same scene is repeated at the end of the movie, after we follow the squad's linear adventures on Infini.  The storyline is like one giant flashback.2) Whit on his first day of work at the West Coast Division.  Stuff starts to hit the fan when a random squad slipstreams into Infini, spends some time there (recall time dilation), and returns infected.  The West Coast Division Captain orders a random jump "dirty jump" which happens to be to Infini.  Whit and his buddy, Pontner, dirty jump, but the Captain is left behind because Pontner is unable to reprogram his APEX unit due to insufficient security clearance.3) At East Coast Division HQ, they learn of the demise of the West Coast Division.  The chief briefs Captain Johanson's squad and sends them to Infini.  Then the rest of the movie unfolds in linear fashion on Infini.

Having read several of the other reviews prior to trying mine, I was a little apprehensive about the usefulness and quality of the machine.  I'm happy to say that I'm very pleased, after having successfully made a batch of sweet potato fries in just 20 minutes.I took 1 medium sized sweet potato, sliced it up into fairly non-uniform wedges, and mixed the wedges in about 3/4 to 1 Tbsp of olive oil.  I decided to increase the amount of oil over what was recommended after seeing that the wedges were insufficiently coated.  I also skipped the washing step, since sweet potatoes already have quite a bit of moisture, and further washing seemed unnecessary.  I turned the dial to 400 degrees F, turned the timer to 25 minutes, then loaded the basket at the 20 min mark and waited.  Didn't even have to turn the wedges midway through.  At the 20 minute mark, they came out pretty crispy!  Slightly burned, slightly soft.  A lot better than what I'd expect to make at home in the oven, but not quite as good deep fried restaurant ones, obviously.  I might try adding an egg white wash to the olive oil mixture next time, to further increase crispiness.PROS:- Looks like Eve from Wall-E- Non-stick basket very easy to clean, although I worry about grease sliding underneath the basket.- I didn't find it noisy at all; more like a hushed fan.- Made semi-professional tasting sweet potato fries with minimal effort- Heats up very quickly- Simple, no-fuss operationCONS:- Non-stick basket can't be removed, making it difficult to clean underneath- Tiny font on machine is difficult to read- Probably can't make deep-fried OreosNow that I can make semi-decent fries, I'm looking forward to hosting a few more BBQs this summer!

I previously purchased some no name no-slip socks from Target, but wasn't entirely pleased with them.These Mabuas are stylish, competitively priced, and fit great!  No complaints thus far.  Will update my review after a few washings.**May 20, 2015 Update**Now that I've worn the Mabuas for a couple weeks, I can comment further.  And my opinion of them has only improved!- 1st wearing was a little too tight; the Mabuas dug into my skin making them slightly painful to wear.- 2nd-4th wearings; Mabuas just right.- After 1st washing, no change to elasticity or tightness.  Non-slip heel works as advertised.Would buy again!  Excellent durability despite washing.  Plus I love the bright stylish colors.

I recall seeing the trailers for Blackhat and Michael Mann's named attached to the directing credits, but never had a chance to watch it in theaters.  I was excited to check it out on Amazon.  Poor decision.The first half of the movie was interesting enough, as the team tracks down the trail of a mysterious hacker.  Leehom Wang was more entertaining to watch than Chris Hemsworth.  However, pacing suffers in the second half and many plot points, e.g. the romance between Chris Hemsworth and Tang Wei, felt forced.  Minor characters are poorly introduced; was I supposed to care when the barely mentioned HK police inspector is gunned down?Furthermore, Mann's reliance on long shutter speeds was terribly annoying.  I never liked the B-roll-esque footage it produces.  Its application in Black Hat made me think I was watching a home video.  Moreover, the combination of long shutter speeds using HD cameras and regular film cameras was distracting.  I realize it might be "avant-garde" but I wished that Mann had ditched this technique in Public Enemies.It's a film that tries too hard to be stylish and forgets its foundation.  I think that part of the reason it's not as stylish as say Collateral, which employed many of the same filming techniques, is that its characters weren't nearly as exciting and fleshed out.The action scenes were decent.

I have to echo what some of my colleagues have already written.For $150, the Nesco FS-10 presents a reasonable and introductory level food slicer.  It's a bit of a niche tool since I imagine most people buy their meats pre-sliced.  However, the Nesco may be perfect for people who turn out large roasts or buy in bulk.  At the least, the Nesco presents a better option than hand slicing.I was a little surprised at the construction.  Given the pictures, I was expecting a sturdier built slicer.  Most of the parts seemed to be made of plastic or cheap aluminum.  Additionally, the footprint was quite large.  This is my first food slicer, and I was surprised at how loud and noisy it was while operating.As for cleaning the blades, I had some difficulty loosening the locking screw, since the suggested quarter didn't quite do the trick.  It's really quite tightly locked in.  Once you loosen it though, cleanup is quite easy.The Nesco does the job, but I would have preferred stronger construction.  At least I'll be better prepared this Thanksgiving!

Cat food reviews tend to be very subjective, so I'll just say the cat loved it.  When I opened the can, he started meowing loudly, then quickly devoured the entire can and licked it clean.  I smelled it before serving the cat, and it was quite pleasant; not much different from the canned tuna fish I had for lunch.  The fact that it is real fish and grain free is a big plus.  The price is not unreasonable for fairly large portions in a 24-count box.
Love LOVE the show, Justified.  Felt I had to do it justice and get the original headlining song by Darrell Scott.  If you like the show, you won't regret the purchase.

Admittedly, I was never much a fan of the last generation of Alienware laptops.  They were too industrial in appearance, and had all the aesthetics of a giant brick.  I can happily say that the new Alienware 15 is now much better looking, without sacrificing any performance.  While it's no Dell XPS 13 or MacBook Pro, it does look better than its nearest crosstown rival, the ASUS ROG.APPEARANCE:  I really like the exterior look of the new Alienware 15.  The corners now sport angled indentations which lend a slimming effect.  The entire top shell of the Alienware is covered in lightly brushed aluminum (no plastic here!) that thankfully resists fingerprints.  A distinctive and trademark alien head rests on the center of the top shell.  The main body and lower shell of the Alienware is formed from a matte plastic material that feels very durable, but does have the tendency to collect oily fingerprints.  The Alienware feels very solidly constructed.  It also sports considerable heft with its 7 lb weight.Surprisingly, there isn't an optical drive available, despite the laptop's vast real estate.  I would've thought they could fit at least a slot loading drive.  The lack of an optical drive is a minor quibble on my part since I can't recall the last time I actually used a CD/DVD/Bluray, but for those of you which actually still use that type of media, this may be an issue.  Otherwise, input options abound on the Alienware.  There are no less than 4 x USB 3.0 ports, a mini-display port, HDMI out 1.4 port, Alienware Graphics Amplifier port, and 9-in-1 Media Card reader to name a few.SPECS/COMPETITION:  The Alienware 15 is pretty much loaded for bear.  The Amazon configuration is a bit cheaper than the retail price on the Alienware website, although I would've liked to see Amazon offer a Windows 7 alternative configuration.The closest 15.6" gaming competitor to the Alienware 15 seems to be the ASUS ROG GL551JW-DS74 15.6-Inch IPS FHD Gaming Laptop, NVIDIA GTX960M, sold on Amazon for about $300 less.  The ASUS has a slightly higher clock speed processor, faster hard drive, optical drive, lighter weight, but a weaker 960M graphics card with 1GB less video memory, and in my opinion, a less attractive exterior design as well.  The 970M on the Alienware 15 as compared to the 960M has 1280 vs. 1024 CUDA cores, 1038 MHz vs. 950 MHz core clock Turbo, and a 192 bit vs. 128 bit memory interface.  The 970M reportedly has about a 40% higher 3DMark score than the 960M.  For Battlefield 4, the performance difference between a 970M equipped notebook and a 960M equipped one is considerable.  At 1920 x 1080 AA 4x MS settings, a 970M can hit about 55 fps while the 960M manages 33 fps.The 960M's bottleneck lies in its limited memory interface and 2GB of memory.  The 960M is more of a mid-level gaming card for the price conscious.  If gaming is your pleasure, then you may do better paying the $300 to get the much faster 970M on the Alienware 15.  The only other alternative I can think of is the Sager NP8652, but Sager isn't as mainstream a brand as Alienware or Asus.  In essence, I think the Alienware is competitively equipped and priced.OPERATION: Boot times are fast with the 128 GB SSD.  I had some initial concerns about the Alienware 15 only being equipped with a 5400 RPM drive, but performance seemed fine.The Klipsch branded speakers are surprisingly good for a laptop.  Mids and highs sound crystal clear, and there is even a fair bit of bass.  I appreciate that Alienware is using Creative SoundBlaster X-Fi, rather than the Realtek on-motherboard solution that most manufacturers tend to use.  Also the use of Killer NIC is an added premium touch.The keyboard has a set of programmable macro keys on the left.  Interesting, but I'm unlikely to use them.  The keyboard itself has a very good tactile feel and typing feels natural.  With its fully customizable AlienFX light displays, the Alienware 15 looks gorgeous in a dimly lit room.  I appreciated the touchpad itself having a backlight.The IPS screen looks excellent when displaying 1080P content.  No dead pixels as far as I could discern, and backlight bleeding is minimal to nonexistent.  Colors are vibrant and saturated.  Thankfully, bloatware is quite minimal.Battery life is about as decent as one can expect for this behemoth.  I averaged about 5-6 hours with light usage, 4 hours with heavy video/multimedia usage, and 1-2 hours in gaming mode.FINAL THOUGHTS:  I like what Alienware has done with its new generation of gaming laptops.  The Alienware 15 presents a lot of performance in a stylish package.

Not sure who or what Pocky is, but these little biscuit sticks were AMAZING.  Think chocolate pirouettes but smaller.  Difficult to believe that such a small pack contains half my daily allotment of saturated fats.Yes, some of the Pejoys arrived broken, but this in no way detracted from their deliciousness.

Here's what I like about the Skinny Cow drinks:- Uses sugar instead of stevia- Low number of calories- Good mocha flavorHere's what I didn't care for:- Strange aftertasteThe strange aftertaste is enough to subtract 2 stars for me because it tasted chemical-ly and left a bad flavor on my tongue.  I do appreciate that they used real sugar instead of stevia (which I also dislike the aftertaste of), but ultimately, flavor is everything for this type of drink.I don't see myself reaching for another.

I'm a big fan of Belvita biscuits, so I was curious to try these alternates from competitor Nature Valley.Upon opening the package, there was a strong and pleasing blueberry fragrance.  There are 4 biscuits to each self-contained package.  Each biscuit was slightly brittle, although the brittleness is probably not from fiber, as there is only 1g of fiber per biscuit.  The shape of each biscuit was remarkably reminiscent of Belvita's; surely Nature Valley could have come up with a more original design?  Taste-wise, I thought they were sweeter than Belvita, and too sweet for my preferences.  They did, however, pair nicely with my plain Greek yogurt.

I've purchased all of my shower liner replacements from Amazon, but this one is the best so far.PROS:- **NO PLASTIC ODORS**- Plastic material has substantial feeling constructionThe first bullet point is the most important.  Absolutely zero nauseous plastic odors of any kind!  Which is huge since it's an issue that plagues many of these low cost liners.  It looks good and can be ordered in different levels of opaqueness (although mine was transparent).  Will definitely be re-buying in the future!

Happy to add this Baker's decorating kit to my growing collection of OXO items.  I like the easily washable silicone tubes, which beat the messiness and environmental unfriendliness of a pastry bag.  The individual pieces fit together well for a solid connection.  For a starter kit and very competitive price, it comes with six very handy, commonly used tips.  I furthermore appreciated the pictorials included in both the instruction manual and side of the box that demonstrated what types of designs each tip creates.Only complaint I can think of is that the volume of the silicone tubes is quite small, limiting application to small decorations for cookies and cakes.  I cannot for instance, use these to pipe macaron shells.  Perhaps OXO will release a larger volume tube in the future?

The OXO Good Grips can opener are unfortunately not the best that we've come to associate with the usual OXO quality.  The can opener itself is decent, but the grips are plasticky, hard and uncomfortable.  Additionally, I found the bottle opener part difficult to position.  Fortunately at this low cost price point, you can afford to purchase several additional can openers as replacements, should the original one fail.The red color is ok, but the brighter blue/green colors might be more preferable for kitchens.

Firstly, I appreciate the heavy glass bottle which the shea butter comes stored in.  It feels like high quality.  The aerosol spray tip dispenses the moisturizer in a fine dispersion.  Secondly, the moisturizing properties are exactly as described.  I love the fact that the liquid doesn't leave a greasy feeling, and is in fact very smooth and silky upon application.  The scent is pleasant, but not overpowering.  Thirdly, 3.5 fl oz is plenty to go around.

My first time using stainless steep soap.  Looks great, but isn't quite as foolproof as claimed.  After cutting lemons, I used the soap as directed.  It mitigated, but didn't entirely eliminate the lemony fragrance from my hands.It might work better after cutting more foul-stenched foods such as garlic/onions though.

First of all, I love the selection of chocolates offered (milk, semi-sweet, bitter-sweet, and dark).  Furthermore, the small sizes of the chocolates is conducive to both snacking and wine-pairing, although I did more of the former.  The included wine-pairing guide was also helpful.As others have noted, i wasn't such a fan of the packaging, which had the appearance of a giant thermal plastic cup, e.g. the brown plastic cups with white/black tops for holding coffee.  Scharffen Berger is a premium brand and therefore should have a more premium packaging, especially for a wine pairing application.Excuse me while I go sample some more chocolates.

I'm primarily interested in the storyline differences between unrated cuts and their theatrical counterparts, so here are the differences between the two (NOTE: some SPOILERS FOLLOW).1) The unrated cut is still a bloodless affair.  No digital blood either.2) Most of the action scenes are longer by a few seconds.  Christmas, in particular, receives two significantly extended action scenes towards the end.  Doc/Galgo/Luna/Yin Yang also benefit from slightly longer action scenes.3) There is some extra dialogue between Barney and Stonebanks at the end of their climactic fight.4) Language is slightly stronger in the unrated cut, with one or two more uses of "MF-er".

I have to agree with the other reviews about the setup issues.  The iP110's largest asset, e.g. its portability, is also its greatest Achilles heel.  The small footprint means there's no LCD screen, which makes setup an infinitely more confusing and frustrating process.I consider myself pretty tech savvy, but I had great difficulty trying to get the Pixma to work with my wireless network.  So much so that I just gave up and paired it with my phone; a slightly easier process.  I would suggest just going the route of smartphone setup since the Pixma seems to be giving everyone headaches when attempting setup over wireless.For its size, the print quality and speed are impressive, as is the low noise.  I plan on throwing this into my backpack and printing documents from my phone while on the go.

As other reviewers have noted, these NutriGrain bars are similar to Fig Newtons in taste and texture.  I found them much sweeter than Fig Newtons however, much to my disliking.Size wise, their dimensions suggest the NutriGrains are best for a small snack.  They're small enough to fit several in your pocket or purse.  I liked the apple cinnamon/blueberry flavors the best, and the strawberry flavor the least.  I'm not so hot on the use of artificial flavoring.  I give it 3.5 stars, which rounds up to 4 stars.PROS:- Good value for the money- Convenient size- Brings back childhood memories- Kids probably like itCONS:- Much too sweet- Artificial ingredients- Unpopular strawberry flavor- Very little protein

Glad I found these.  They're like the Balance Bar equivalents of Kind Bars.  While the Balance Bar Bares have slightly higher amounts of sugar and lower amounts of protein than Kind Bars, they also have a lower unit cost.PROS:- Not too sweet- Bar has perfect consistency, not too gooey, and nuts aren't jaw-breakingly hard- All natural ingredients- Excellent and unique flavor; really liked the subtle heat from the chile powder and paprika- Cheaper than Kind BarsCONS:- Not very much protein- Deceptively small to tempt you into eating more than oneI'll definitely be getting more of these in the future.  Good job Balance!

I'm very pleased with the Taylor 7583, but will probably be less so around Thanksgiving once I've weighed myself post-meal.PROS:- Auto off- Fingerprint resistant glass- Sturdy construction- Batteries are included with packaging- Digital readout/blue display- Textured designCONS:- Can't think of any; the price seems about average for glass digital scales.- I didn't observe any problems with the digital readout.I like that the scale feels sturdy when stepping thereon.  There's no sense of tilting or off-balance-ness.  Moreover, the scale seems accurate, as it reflects numbers similar to those given by my gym scale.

The BIC Atlantis is a handsome looking pen, and certainly a lot more elegant looking than the plain BIC pens that we've come to know and love.  The ink writes well, without bleeding.  However, it's missing some premium features, such as a finger cushion, which separates it from higher end products from Pilot or Uni-ball.  It's a positive direction for BIC, and I hope they continue along these lines to make a higher end product (if they don't already do so).

The VA2455sm is a wallet friendly, good looking monitor.UNBOXING: The bezel is 3/4 glossy black plastic, and the lower bezel portion has a textured, faux metallic surface.  Standard menu buttons line the bottom, and DVI/VGA/power inputs lie in the back.  The monitor has a single blue LED power light mounted in the center, which looks great at night.INITIAL USE:  I have a Digital Storm PC (Geforce GTX 680 with 4GB RAM) running Windows 7, and Windows automatically installed the drivers for the monitor.  There were ZERO dead or stuck pixels.  Colors look very vibrant on this monitor, and blacks were very good.  Also, no backlight bleeding that I could discern.  I watched a couple 1080P movies which looked excellent on the new monitor.  I turned down the brightness and contrast.  So far text looks excellent, and no headaches from using the monitor.  Perhaps the integrated blue filter works as intended.CONS:  There is NO height adjustment on this monitor, TILT only.  I guess I'll have to find some old books to increase the height.  Furthermore, the base stand doesn't seem well suited to the monitor as the monitor mounting is slightly rickety.  The integrated speakers (Viewsonic really seems to like adding speakers onto its monitors) are pretty much useless, and I disabled these the first opportunity I had through the on-screen menu.  I wish that Viewsonic had deleted the unnecessary speakers and instead added a height adjustment function.  Lastly, Viewsonic only included a VGA-VGA cable in the packaging when I was expecting at least a DVI cable.These complaints aside, the VA 2455sm is a gorgeous looking LED monitor that is as easy on the wallet as it is on the eyes.

I'm primarily interested in the storyline differences between extended cuts and their theatrical counterparts, so here are the differences between the two (NOTE: SPOILERS FOLLOW).The extended cut runs approximately 3 minutes longer longer than the theatrical cut.  The new scenes are pretty minor, although there is significantly more CGI blood in the first battle.1) The first battle against the Bessi is a lot bloodier in the Extended Cut.  Throats are slit, combatants are impaled, and people are stabbed in bloody manners by various bladed weapons.2) General Sitacles makes unwanted romantic advances towards Atalanta.3) General Sitacles threatens to execute Phineas for failing to detect the Bessi ambush, but Phineas is saved by Autolycus's intervention.4) Hercules has a flashback to King Eurystheus condemning him for the alleged murder of his family.Sure Hercules isn't going to win any Oscars anytime soon, but I found it an entertaining popcorn flick.  The Rock was fun to watch and I liked the script's tongue-in-cheek approach to general Greek mythology.  Definitely better than the Kellan Lutz version!

I wish I had the Eton on my last international trip!  I recall several instances when I didn't have the right power converter, and my phone was almost out of battery and needed a quick charge.I like the Eton's ruggedized and grippable exterior.  The availability of dual USB output and charging light indicators is helpful.  Furthermore, the Eton's miniature LED flashlight is a thoughtful touch and has a decent throw despite being small in size- sure beats using my smartphone as a flashlight.  Smartphone charging time is fast and my Galaxy S4 was fully charged in less than an hour.However, my Eton-charged smartphone drained just as quickly as it had charged.  Despite being fully charged with the Eton, my S4 drained to just 25% battery in 4 hours with little to no activity.  Additionally, the flashlight/charging indicator button is too small and well-camouflaged that I still have trouble locating it along the spine of the cover.The Eton is helpful if you need a quick charge and don't have access to a plug.  Just don't expect the charge to last.

For $30, this Paderno is a quality salad spinner.I like its;- sturdy construction- color palette- smooth spinning action- dishwasher safe parts- tight fitting partsI can't find much, if anything, to fault the Paderno with.  Guess I'll be eating a lot more salad from now on!

There's a lot to like about the Farberware New Traditions, with its low price point being foremost.  I imagine this set will appeal greatly to college students and young professionals.Amazon's description oddly doesn't contain the exact pots/pans, but here's what's included in the package:1-quart covered saucepan2-quart covered saucepan3-quart saute pan5-quart covered dutch oven8-inch nonstick skillet9 3/4-inch nonstick skilletNon-stick Slotted Turner, Slotted & Solid SpoonPROS:- Low price- Stainless steel elegance- Transparent lids- Generally good build quality- Bonus utensils- Non-riveted, thermally cool handlesCONS:- Lid tolerances could be better- High arc-ing handles a little uncomfortableI wasn't expecting the addition of the slotted turner, slotted spoon and solid spoon, so these were an added bonus!  I find that all the pot/pan sizes are very practical.  Ideally a larger dutch oven on the order of 8-quarts would have been more preferable, but the 5-quart one is of a decent size for one-two persons.  The lid of the 5-quart dutch oven can be used interchangeably with the 3-quart saute pan and 9 3/4-inch non-stick skillet.The Farberware New Traditions performed well in the kitchen and their stainless steel finish looked elegant.  My main cookware comprises Calphalon Tri-Ply which have considerably thicker sidewalls and heftier construction, but the Farberware still felt solidly built.  I like Farberware's glass, transparent lids which enabled me to look inside while cooking.  Unlike my Calphalons which have handles riveted to the bases, the Farberware has a completely smooth finish in the interior, which means no excess food particles getting stuck in the rivet joints.My dislikes were minor.  I didn't like the loose fitting lids, and I think there could have been tighter tolerances.  This may not bother everyone and the lids didn't roll around while cooking, but it's just a pet peeve of mine.  I found the handles a little uncomfortable to grip due to their high arc-ing angle, but it's not like you're constantly gripping the handles while cooking.In conclusion, it's an excellent and comprehensive starter set at a very attractive price point.

This OXO colander arrived at just the right moment.  My other colander was starting to collect mold in the holes and I instantly appreciated this OXO.  It's sturdily constructed, and the good grips handles provide thermal insulation as well.  I like the fact that it has 3 feet, which will likely prevent the colander holes from collecting mold due to its elevation above my counter surface.I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars because the 3 feet were attached in such a way that they block some of the holes.  This could easily have been avoided by using some extra care during the manufacturing process.If you're in need of a colander, this is a tough one to beat for the price.

Don't let the MSRP fool you.  For $70, this is an excellent bread machine.I've always wanted to try a bread machine, but never wanted to fork over the money for an expensive Pansonic or Zojirushi.  Enter the West Bend with its *very* competitively priced 41413.  I think this price point is perfect.  Sure, the functions might be a bit more basic than its competitors, but it gets the job done.  Deliciously so, if I might add.  The 2-lb loaf size is perfect for individual consumption, and a single loaf lasted me approximately over one week.  So far I've baked 3 different loaves; country white, oatmeal, and whole grain.  All three turned out and easily.PROS:- Very easy to program.  Delayed start is handy.- Baking pan cleans off easily- Takes the complexity out of baking- Apartment smells amazing- Cheap price point- Convenient 2 lb loaves- Small counter space footprintCONS:- Bread loaf tops are non-uniformly formed (see discussion on this below)I haven't yet tried the gluten-free recipe, but I'm happy to know that West Bend at least offers it as an option.  The baking pan cleans off easily, even if it must be hand-washed.  My only gripe about the West Bend is that the tops of my loaves were not formed consistently.  Sometimes the tops were completely even post kneading; other times they were misshapen.  Granted they all tasted the same, but I would've liked them a little more evenly formed.

I ordered these thinking that they were dish towels, but upon receipt, discovered that it was not so. These are more like non-functional decorative towels. Do not order these thinking that you can dry your hands on them, because they lack water absorbency powers. I've relegated them to picnic basket duties, where they've done well. Although you get two towels in the package, it's still expensively priced at just over $40 for two. I'd rate them 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4.

My main vacuum cleaner was a Hoover, but like all traditional vacuum cleaners it's heavy and requires taking out the cord and stowing it after usage.Enter this Air Cordless Hoover.  Excellent build quality.  The low-mounted battery pack provides a stable center of gravity.  It took a few hours to charge each battery pack, and an extra pack (as is an extra filter) are thoughtfully provided.Sucking power was very good on both carpet and bare floor.  The Air Cordless was exceptionally easy to maneuver and swivel, and the vacuum mounted light was very bright, providing good illumination of the general vicinity.  My biggest complaint about the Air Cordless is that the vacuum wand isn't very long.  Additionally, vacuum suction when using the wand wasn't quite as strong, it seemed, as when the main unit was engaged.In conclusion, it's a very well equipped cordless vacuum cleaner that offers all the capabilities of a traditional vacuum cleaner, minus the inconvenience of a cord.  It's definitely replacing my former Hoover corded vacuum as my goto choice.

PROS:- Relatively inexpensive price- Slim form factor- Alienware name- Generous amount of inputsCONS:- Limited upgradability- Graphics card bottle neck- No option for Windows 7 when ordering from Amazon- No SSD or option for oneThe X51 R2 is an entry-level gaming machine; the primary bottleneck lies in the Nvidia GTX 745.  The GTX 745 is a crippled version of the GTX 750 Ti, the latter using the same GPU but having all 640 shaders unlocked.  It's a low profile card that Nvidia specifically builds for Dell.  I wouldn't expect to do any intensive gaming; maybe BF4 at low-medium resolutions but that's pushing it.  It's on par with the Radeon HD 6850 (a 4-year old card) and the Geforce GTX 555.Those who spring for the R9 270 will find a card that effectively doubles the performance of the GTX 745.  The 240W power supply on this particular X51 configuration severely limits the video card upgradeability.The X51 is very competitively priced.  The other small form factor (SFF) machine I'd consider would be the Digital Storm Bolt II (since my regular desktop is also a Digital Storm machine).  Although more capable than the X51 R2, it's also twice as expensive and most people may not be willing to pay that amount.Construction looks solid.  The X51 R2 is built primarily of non-glossy, fingerprint proof plastic.  The miniature alien head on the front bezel can be rotated to match the chassis orientation.  The use of an external power supply is a neat trick.  It allows a smaller chassis and much quieter operation.  The X51 R2 fortunately comes largely free of bloatware.  The only pre-installed software I could find were just Steam, McAfee and Cyberlink Bluray software.The one disadvantage of ordering this machine off of Amazon rather than the Alienware site is that you cannot customize your machine on Amazon and must accept a pre-built configuration.  This in turn means going with Windows 8.1 (ugh)!  On the other hand, the Alienware site allows you to swap our Windows 8.1 for Windows 7.Given that the X51 isn't best suited for high benchmark games, I plan on instead using my X51 for home entertainment since it has a Bluray drive, SPDIF and coax connections, 6-analog outputs for up to 7.1 speakers, and Bluetooth/wireless connectivity.

I used to use the Canon 50mm 1.4, which was a good deal for its price, but it lacked the "pop" that I was looking for.  After renting a 50mm Sigma Art from LensRentals and demoing it over the weekend, I just knew I had to get one.  The sharpness was unbelievably good.  Even my photographer buddy who owns a 50L was very impressed.I placed my order on Amazon, but after a month of being on the queue with no progress, managed to find a discounted copy from Amazon Warehouse.  I was initially hesitant to buy it, but it looked brand new and I did not notice any AF issues.  It pairs nicely with my 6D and the initial results are already very impressive.  I can't wait to take it overseas on my next trip.  I guess the biggest downside is that the Sigma 50mm isn't weatherproof, so I'll just have to avoid rainstorms.Build quality is excellent.  It's slightly heaver than my Canon 35L and with a comparable length.Looking forward to taking more portrait shots!

Was looking for a set of replacement pens, happy to have stumbled across these Acroball Pros.  They indeed write smoothly with zero smudging.  My only complaint is that the index finger rest gel pad is too hard, and could use more cushioning.  The medium point is perfect, and not too thin or wide.

This Thermos is great!  Well constructed, certified Tritan, so no BPA worries here.  It's also lightweight and easy to carry around.  The filtration is very fast and takes at most 10 seconds to filter the bottom portion.  The filtered water tastes excellent, like bottled water.  After the first use, the water had a slightly sweet aftertaste, but improved significantly after repeated use.  It only filters potable water, so don't bring this on your camping trip thinking that it can filter out microbes.There are only two downsides I can think of.  First, the volume is quite small at just half a liter.  However, I find this amount perfect for use at work/home, where I don't need a giant bottle of water.  Additionally, it's good for drinking on the go.  Second, filter longevity at just 20 gallons seems on the low end.  Also, I'm not yet sure where to purchase replacement filters and how much they would cost.On the whole, I'm very happy.  Now I can freely drink at work without having to bring bottled water from home.**07/01/14 UPDATE** I've been heavily using the Thermos over the past week, and have encountered a few problems that have caused me to lower the rating by one star.  First, charcoal particles leak from the filter into the filtered water.  Second, sometimes the filter is clogged, requiring me to empty out the container and refill.  Minor inconveniences perhaps, but they shouldn't be happening.

My initial impressions of the BlueAntPump were very favorable.  I liked the device packaging which neatly arrayed and labeled the different ear plug tips and stabilizers.  I liked the possibility of the BlueAnt being fully waterproof, provided the battery charging cover is closed.  (**Note, the battery charging cover appeared to have a somewhat flimsy construction, so take note! of this potential longevity issue.)  Battery life was impressive and a full charge took just 2 hours.  Sound quality, while not spectacular, was fine for my workouts.  Charging via micro-usb (cable provided) was helpful.  The wireless bluetooth connection was very convenient, and took just a few seconds to complete.I unfortunately found the sportbuds uncomfortable to wear.  They constantly pinched my earlobes, despite attempts to adjust them, and were painful after just a few minutes of usage.  I suspect that individual comfort will very subjective, so YMMV.  Controls were ok, but slightly awkward to use and adjust.Based on the other reviews which speak highly of the BlueAntPump comfort, I suspect my experiences may be in the minority.  I'd rate these 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4.

The Margaritaville is the ultimate in margarita making convenience.  The operation is almost fully automated, save for a few switches that need to be toggled for margarita creation.CONSTRUCTION: This contraption is massive, so make sure you have enough storage and counter space for it.  Despite its size, it's not too heavy.  Nor is it so light that it would suggest poor build quality either.  Everything seems well assembled.  A heavy duty carrying bag is provided and I was impressed at its sturdiness.  It was more than strong enough to carrying around the Margaritaville from one location to another.OPERATION: Fill the top reservoir with ice and the bottom container with your margarita mix, and you're good to go.  I was particularly impressed by the thoroughness with which the Margaritaville shredded the ice cubes.  The ice was ground so thoroughly that it achieved a fine, slushy consistency.  I was not very impressed by the automatic mode however, which gave my margarita an overly liquid-like consistency.  Operating it in manual mode with occasional bursts of ice shredding seemed to do the trick.  Cleanup was a breeze.  Excess melted ice water is deposited in a reservoir which can be emptied out.  Genius!MISC: I wish Margaritaville had included a recipe book in the package.  I saw a few recipes online, but then the website froze.  Also, the instruction sheet was terribly difficult to read because it was printed on dark colored paper.  I guess they were going for the whole tropical motif, but it was just impractical.CONCLUSION: For the ultimate in margarita making, you can't go wrong with the Margaritaville.  My presence has already been requested at certain upcoming parties...

The Denons are a stylish looking, entry-level pair of earbuds.  As others have noted, no carrying case is provided, but this wasn't a big drawback for me considering that I almost never use the carrying case for my earbuds.Fit was comfortable; although the default pair of ear cushions felt too small, I was able to find a more comfortable size from the extras provided with the package.Sound quality was decent.  Clear and crisp to be sure, but bass was average to below average.  However considering the sub-$50 entry level pricing, I think the sound quality is more than adequate for its price range.In conclusion, it's a crisp sounding, bare-bones but competitively priced earbud set.

Tasted about the same as other bottled waters, except for a slight aftertaste, presumably from the calcium carbonate.  The aftertaste was very subtle, and fairly neutral in flavor.  The bottles are conveniently sized for grabbing on the go.

I LOVE my iLuv.  It's a good looking speaker that sounds excellent.1)  Everything about the iLuv is stylish, down to the packaging materials and manual.  It is tall and has a substantial footprint, so make sure you have enough space for it.  It is sturdily constructed and made of fingerprint proof white plastic that is easy to clean.  A convenient hand-hold is provided as well.  It can be paired with another iLuv SYRENPROWH to provide left/right stereo options.2)  Pairing via Bluetooth could not have been easier.  Voice controls indicate when a successful pairing has been made.3)  The sound quality is excellent.  I tested it against a rectangular Jabra Solemate MAX, and the iLuv had superior sound.  The vertical design projects sounds more effectively than the Jabra's squat rectangular design.  Bass is surprisingly good as well.4)  I've used it at several parties already and my guests complimented me on the stylish Bluetooth speaker.  Fortunately I've not had to test its water resistant (note, not water proof) claims, but I can more confidently use it at outdoor parties knowing it is weather resistant.Overall, I'm very pleased.

Computer wouldn't recognize it as a USB 3.0 drive, but had no problems recognizing it as a USB 2.0 drive.  Defeats the purpose of paying a higher premium for a allegedly USB 3.0 device.  Disappointing to say the least, especially since Kingston is a large namebrand.

The Hamilton Beach is my first French press.  Its 1 liter volume occupies a niche between single serve coffee machines and larger full brew machines.  Obviously it's not as convenient as conventional brew or single serve machines since you have to boil the water separately, but the taste was stronger and more pronounced.  It seemed well built, with a glass (albeit very lightweight) container and sturdy plastic handles.  The metallic coffee filters seemed cheaply constructed because one of them arrived bent, but considering the press only costs $20, it's not a big deal.  Bent yes, but still functional.It cleaned up easily as well.  My biggest complaint is that the manual didn't explain what all the different parts were for, like the circular spring.

I pretty much only use Tide Detergent for my clothes, and this HE Detergent is no exception.  Cleans great, smells great, and works fine in my regular washer (doesn't sud as much).  Highly recommended.

The Unrated Cut runs about 12 minutes longer than the Theatrical Cut, and contains several new scenes including a much expanded ninja action scene.  Wolverine drops a few more choice curse words and there is now CG-gore.  I'd say it's more like a hard PG-13 rather than an R-rated cut.The UNRATED Cut is much better than the theatrical cut.**Note, SPOILERS follow, so read at your own risk**.1) There is more gore, but primarily CGI blood sprays.  Some shots of Wolverine's claws going through people's limbs, but nothing explicit.  No graphic dismemberments.2) Wolverine drops a few more f-bombs.3) Some of the opening scenes depicting Wolverine at the POW camp are a little longer.4) The scene involving Wolverine, an arrow, and the hunter is slightly longer and more brutal.5) Slightly longer dialogue with Yukio on the way to the plane.6) Relationship between Mariko and Yashida and Shingen and  Yashida is better fleshed out in the unrated cut.7) A new scene where Yashida asks Logan his age.8) A new scene with Yashida talking to Shingen on his deathbed, telling him, "You are not the man to lead Yashida".9) A new scene at the love hotel where the Yakuza show up and get into a fight with Wolverine.  Mariko intervenes and demonstrates some fighting skill as well.10) Wolverine's operation on himself is bloodier.11) The fight scene between Shingen and Wolverine is slightly longer and now depicts Shingen rather graphically cutting into Wolverine's shoulder blade (no blood though).12) A new scene where Viper gives Hadana poison for his arrows, which he later uses to bring down Wolverine at the ninja fight.13) The ninja fight scene is now much longer.  Wolverine gets dragged away in nets and hit by ninjas on bikes.  Yukio shows up to assist Wolverine and drives around in a snow plow chopping up hapless ninjas (some hearty blood spraying).  Wolverine lights his familiar cigar midway through the battle.I'm actually glad the extra action scenes were removed from the theatrical cut.  Some of the action seemed a bit silly (e.g. ninjas hitting Wolverine with their motorbikes, although Wolverine lighting his trademark cigar was nifty).  Furthermore, Yukio's appearance detracted from Wolverine's thematic solo search for Mariko.  Didn't think Yukio added much to the scene.14) The Silver Samurai battle is the same length as previously.Overall, the unrated cut is much better dimensioned than the theatrical cut.  This is the one to get!!

Preface: I'm not a home theater aficionado.PROS:- Good out-of-the-box, pre-calibration performance (contrast ratios, black colors, skin tones)- Dual HDMI inputs- Allegedly long MTBR (mean time between replacement)- No rainbow effect- Decent sounding built-in speakerCONS:- No 3-D- No lens-shifting- Menu navigation awkward compared to Epsons- Negligible zoomThe Viewsonic PRO 9000 is advertised as having a Laser-LED hybrid light engine.  What does this technological mumbo jumbo mean exactly?  It means that the Viewsonic is using a blue LED, a red LED, and a blue laser striking a green phosphor to create its light output.  There's no traditional mechanically rotating color wheel (long associated with DLP technology) so there's no rainbow effect.  The use of LEDs affords near instantly available light and lower power consumption.  I don't have a Kill-a-Watt meter so I was unable to test the power consumption claims.  However, startup time was indeed very fast.  Best of all, there's no expensive lamp to replace.  For comparison, the highly rated Epson 8350 1080p projector has $300 replacement lamps.Viewsonic says the PRO 9000 is rated for 20,000 hours.  That's roughly equivalent to running the projector 24 hours a day for 2.5 years continuously.  Not too shabby.The PRO 9000 felt solidly made, and had an attractive blue-gray exterior.  A carrying case is provided, as are various cables (including a ~ 6 foot HDMI cable), remote control and provided batteries.I was pleased with its out-of-the-box performance.  I connected the PRO 9000 to a BluRay player running The Hulk.  Black levels and skintones were good, and contrast levels were excellent.  Brightness levels seemed fine, since I primarily used it in a dark room to watch movies and/or tv.  I found the menu operation a little awkward to navigate, in comparison to an Epson I recently used.  Zoom was almost non-existent.  The dinky built-in speakers are adequate stop-gap measures until a more permanent solution can be found.I've dinged the PRO 9000 half a star (4.5 stars rounds up to 5 stars) because at this price-point, it's missing a few features which I think it ought to have.  Its main selling point is the hybrid LED engine, but I think that it should've been equipped at least with a better zoom, if not lens-shift or 3D capability.  For those not familiar with "lens-shift" technology, it enables some flexibility in projector placement by allowing one to steer the lens vertically or horizontally for an ideal picture.  I placed my projector on-center, so not having this capability wasn't a big problem.  However, it is a feature that is increasingly more common on higher end projectors.  3D images give me a headache, so again not having this capability didn't bother me, but this may be a disappointment to some.As the other Vine reviewer mentioned, the higher price you pay for the PRO 9000 is due in part to the early adopter tax.  If the PRO 9000 were lowered $100-$200 more, then I think it would be a much more competitive purchase give its lack of premium features other than the increased lifetime.

I give the Whitening Kit four stars because it worked as advertised- my teeth were noticeably whiter after application.  The MSRP of the kit value is also less than the sum of the retail values of the individual parts.  I've deducted one star because it caused tooth pain during usage.  Additionally, only a few elements of the kit are actually needed for whitened teeth.First, a few thoughts.- The Oral-B 4000 took somewhere between 24-48 hours to get a full charge!  * I liked the brushing feature wherein the toothbrush stops during operation to remind you to switch quadrants.  * Nice of them to include two extra brushing tips in the kit.- The white strips worked noticeably better than the ones I last used.  They're a neater affair these days.  * I no longer foamed at the mouth and took on the appearance of a rabid dog.- You can probably achieve just as good (and cheaper!) results using only the white strips and the toothpaste.***************************USAGE LOG:Day 1: I'm not a heavy coffee or tea drinker, but I did have some yellow stains on the lower portions of my teeth.  Started the kit in earnest, although I decided not to use the white rinse because I didn't like the after-taste.Day 2: My teeth were already one shade whiter!  However, the Oral-B 4000 was causing tooth-root-pain so I switched to manual brushing with the whitening toothpaste.Days 3 - 12: Used the white strips/manual brushing + whitening toothpaste.  Very pleased with the results.  Mild, but tolerable tooth pain.Took a break for Halloween and consumed candy which may have set back some of my whitening progress.Days 13 - 14: Teeth look much whiter.  Even the hard-to-reach-side-teeth look brighter as well, due wholly to the whitening toothpaste.CONCLUSION: I think the entire kit is unnecessary.  It certainly worked as advertised, but you can achieve the same results with just the whitening strips + whitening toothpaste, without the whitening rinse and electric toothbrush.

I used to own a Mad Catz G.L.I.D.E.7 Gaming Surface for PC which had a similar gaming surface but occupied too much real estate and was too thick.The Logitech G240 comparatively is much thinner and slightly larger than a piece of 8x11 paper.  It fits perfectly on my averaged sized desk without occupying too much surface area.  The gaming surface is suitably matched to my Logitech G700s Rechargeable Gaming Mouse.  Tracking in FPS like Battlefield 4 is more precise, and photoediting in Lightroom 4 has also improved.  It's another Logitech hit!

Preface: I am not a home theater aficionado, but I do appreciate good quality electronics.The Epson Home Cinema 707 is an excellent entry level HD projector at an affordable price range, and it displayed very strong out-of-the-box performance.  It utilizes Epson's trademark 3LCD technology, an alternative to the DLP technology used by competing projectors.  3LCD theoretically offers advantages over DLP, including no rainbow effects, lower power consumption, and lower pricing.  However, higher priced DLP projectors are less likely to exhibit the aforementioned characteristics.PROS:- Built-in speaker audio quality- Legacy video input support- Carrying bag- Video quality- Horizontal/vertical keystoningCONS:- Only 1 HDMI port- Mono, not stereo, speaker- Low contrast ratioBUILD QUALITY:  The Epson was solidly constructed upon removal from the packaging.  The plastic had a nice glossy feel which resisted fingerprints.  A carrying bag, remote control + batteries, and assorted cables were also provided.  I appreciated that legacy inputs are supported, including analog audio and composite video.  There is one significant downside in that only one HDMI input is provided.  I don't have an HDMI switcher, so I had to manually unplug my bluray player and swap it with the FIOS/Cable TV connection each time I wanted to change the source.VIDEO QUALITY:  Video quality out of the box was fantastic.  There is NO lens shift capability, but there is horizontal/vertical keystoning.  Keystoning was adjustable via physical buttons, and these buttons helped optimize the placement and positioning of the projector image.  Only 2D/720p is supported, so 3D/1080p fans will have to look elsewhere.  Black levels were very good and skin tones looked natural at default settings.  Brightness was excellent, and I had to turn down the brightness from the initial settings.  There did not seem to be an appreciable difference between the different pre-programmed visual settings.  The contrast ratio seemed a little low when I played the same Bluray disc in a higher end 1080p DLP projector for comparison.SOUND QUALITY:  The Epson is equipped with a built-in speaker which was surprisingly full-bodied and loud.  The speaker only outputs from one side of the projector unfortunately, but the projector is sufficiently compact that a stereo configuration wouldn't make much sense.  If you don't have a sound bar/home theater receiver yet, then the built-in speaker can serve as an interim solution until procurement of a more permanent audio setup.The Epson 707 was positioned at a distance of about six feet from the projector screen and it created a 60-inch diagonal picture.  Sure beats watching the World Series on a 42-inch TV!

The hard part was figuring out how to load the dang stapler.  There weren't any instructions either.  I literally spent 15 minutes finagling the stapler before I figured out that pushing down on the rear "button" caused the front loading tray to pop-out.  The loading tray itself also does not accommodate many staples either, so count on refilling more frequently than usual.  Minus one star for not including better instructions, but kudos to Swingline for including sample premium staples in the package.Once loaded with staples, I found the Swingline true to its description.  Very little effort was needed to staple sheets together.  I don't think I'll be replacing my conventional Swingline anytime soon, but I do have to give Swingline credit for trying to innovate a new stapler design.

There are a lot of things to like about the Braun Cruzer 5.  Sleek looking package, cordless operation, decent battery life, name brand manufacturer to name a few.  However as others have noted and I myself experienced, there is one very poorly thought out design flaw that detracts from the Braun.  The guards do not lock into place and it's all too easy to cut off more hair than expected, even if another person is doing the cutting for you.  Who wants an uneven cut?  It should be a very simple fix for Braun, but until they address it, pass on this model.

The Jabra Motion UC is easy to setup for even the tech un-savvy.  After opening the packaging (an attractive transparent plastic casing), I was up and running within a few minutes.Comfort was generally good.  I have smallish ears, and there is a smaller ear piece included which I prefer.  It slips over the ear fairly comfortably, and is easy to switch to the other ear, and changing that configuration can be done within seconds.The range is excellent.  I can leave my phone anywhere in my apartment and roam with the bluetooth with no change in signal.  In addition, there is a small chip that is included to enable the bluetooth to be used with a laptop.  I haven't tried it yet, but that would be great to be able to skype more clearly, and not have to stay in front of the monitor talking right into the speaker.The bluetooth is charged with an included plug.  I did notice that the bluetooth begins to flash red (low battery) after just 40 min conversation or so, or if you leave it "on" (open).  However, I've yet to run out of power even after a 1 hr conversation.I also like the included case which is conveniently sized for travel.Excellent Bluetooth device.

I was disappointed after trying out the SteelSeries 3Hv2.  The packaging looked very promising!  While I liked the convenient and collapsible storage capability, these were the sole advantages.  The ear cups were tiny and not at all comfortable for adult ears.  The sound quality was poor, with weak bass, and muddy sounding indistinctness.  $50 isn't cheap either and I was certainly expecting better audio quality.PROS:- Onboard volume/mic control- Bright orange tangle-free cording- Collapsible convenient storageCONS:- Tinny, muddy sounds- Weak bass- Tiny ear cups- Discomfort over extended usePASS on these.

The Unrated Cut runs about 7 minutes longer than the Theatrical Cut, and primarily contains additional action shots (nothing major).  Director Marc Forster has said that the Theatrical Cut IS the Director's Cut, which also unfortunately means that we will not be seeing any footage from the discarded Battle of Moscow (except for a few quick scenes in the closing montage) and the Matthew Fox subplot.The UNRATED Cut is the one to get!  It contains slightly more gore (but not gratuitously so) than the Theatrical Cut, and the action scenes are more fluid and less choppy.I've listed the primary differences between the Unrated Cut and the Theatrical Cut below.  Note, SPOILERS follow below, so read at your own risk.1) When zombies are shot/stabbed/curb stomped/etc.., they spew CG black blood.  When people are bitten, there's more CG red blood.2) During the opening scene in Philadelphia, there are more scenes of pandemonium and zombies getting shot and/or biting humans.  The segment with the red T-shirted male ("Here comes the Number 12 Train...") being bitten and transformed into a zeke is longer and more violent.3) At the NJ Mart, when Gerry is looking for albuterol for his daughter, the camera pans down to show a dead body lying in a pool of blood, suggesting that the pharmacy employee shot him.4) The chase scene from the alleyway to the apartment is longer and more harrowing.  Gerry headshots a zombie and shoots a few others, also crushing a security guard zombie with a filing cabinet.  In the theatrical cut, this zombie chase scene is instead used during the Lanes' early morning escape to the apartment's rooftop.5) The escape scene to the apartment rooftop is now longer and more violent.  Gerry bayonets, shoots, or rifle butts many more zombies.  In a surprising twist, Tomas saves Gerry from a zeke, rather than Gerry himself shooting the zeke in the theatrical cut.  Matthew Fox's parajumper character also shoots a few more zombies and there's more zombie blood when they're shot.6) When Dr. Fassbach trips and accidentally shoots himself in the head, the wound is more graphic.  Chunks of his back skull are blown into the air and gore covers the exit ramp of the C-130.  Although this description sounds graphic, the camera cuts away quickly so that only brief glimpses of gore are seen by the audience.7) David Morse's character graphically pulls out his last remaining tooth in the Unrated Cut.  This is not shown in the Theatrical Cut.8) The Battle for Jerusalem has additional action shots.  It's now a thrilling and intense sequence in the Unrated Cut!  More IDF soldiers shooting zekes, more zekes biting people, grenades blowing up zekes, etc..9) When Gerry cuts off Segen's hand in the Unrated Cut, we see the bloody stump as well as geysers of CG blood.  This is definitely graphic and not for the faint of heart.10) The zombie attack on Belarus Airways is now more intense with passengers getting bitten left and right.  There is more CG blood too, but nothing too explicit since most of the shots are very quick.11) Gerry takes down a few zekes in the WHO facility more graphically.  He clotheslines one zeke with a crowbar and stomps on the face of another.  More CG black blood.Prior to watching World War Z, I had mixed feelings about the movie based on the trailers I had seen.  Fast zombies?  Blasphemy.I ended up enjoying the movie, even with Damon Lindelof's rewritten third act.  The ending on a quiet, but hopeful note was a better conclusion than the rumored Battle of Moscow.  The idea of using a temporary, but curable disease as camouflage was a unique plot point.  Can't wait for the sequel, even if it has very little to do with Max Brooks' original books.

I usually wear an 8.5 wide, but Teva doesn't make wide widths so I've avoided the brand until now. With Amazon's shoe selector system, I ordered the 9.5 as recommended and the shoes are comfortably roomy everywhere, but because of the adjustable strap design they still stay snug at the back of my heel.I purchased these just before we went on vacation and planned to use them for a pool shoe, but then had some issues with my feet aching and swelling in my regular walking shoes so I figured I'd try these for one morning walk. Wow, they were so comfortable I wore them every day and walked at least 10 miles a day on pavement.Extremely comfortable, good looks, tons of adjustment, you can't go wrong with this shoes!

** I received this item for free in exchange for testing and review **I'll admit it, I have a thing for LED flashlights. We own maybe 5 or 6 small ones, and 3 or 4 larger units. Whenever a new design comes along, I'm excited to see if it's brighter or lasts longer than the last one.I was happy to test this Wasing because it uses regular AAA batteries and also has an adjustable beam.Overall this is a well-made and sturdy light. The only thing I would be worried about for really rugged use is the front plastic housing which is large and seems like it could break if the light were dropped on cement. We have other metal cased LED flashlights that are extremely rugged and have withstood lots of "drop tests" without any issues, but they don't have the plastic housing like this one does.On the plus side, it's the plastic housing that make the wide beam of this flashlight work so much better than any other pocket-sized LED light we have. The beam is wide and even with no annoying dark circle around a brighter center. This makes it perfect to use for walking in the dark and also for jobs that require a wider view than a focused beam provides.The only issue I have with this light is the "Lantern Function" which puts off a very diffuse and inefficient glow. If you were stuck in a pitch-dark cave, the lantern would give you enough light to help avoid tripping over a boulder or something, but it's not nearly enough light to work by when you're out camping.

** I received this item for free in exchange for testing and review **I'm really loving all these new solar-powered LED light options that have been popping up over the past year or two. We live on a large property so adding Christmas lights to a few trees out by our front gate was pretty much impossible before solar-powered units came along. I love the soft warm white tone of these lights over some bright white ones I bought last year, I think these look more like incandescent bulbs than the brilliant white ones.These are relatively bright and will stay lit until at least midnight as long as they've received an hour or more of full sun during the day, if it's been heavily overcast all day then the charge runs out after a few hours. My one complaint is that the lights towards the end of the strand are maybe 20% dimmer than those closest to the solar panel.Placement of the solar panel is important - it works much better if you can find a spot facing east/west that is never shaded.I'm very happy with these and plan to buy another 3 strands to decorate a larger tree out in front of our house.

** I received these knives for free in exchange for testing and review **This is my first experience with coated knives, and I didn't really know what to expect, I honestly wasn't expecting much given the low price point.I was pleasantly surprised by their quality and cutting abilities.These feel nice in the hand, they are weighted properly to sit level without feeling too blade-heavy. I enjoy using these most with soft fruits and vegetables like tomatoes and strawberries, cutting crunchy things like carrots requires more effort with these knives than it does with my heavier blades.I really love the sheaths, this allows me to store safely anywhere. I actually added the small paring knife to my travel cooking kit that I carry with us when we're doing motorcycle trips. It's much better than the cheap serrated knife with its makeshift cardboard sheath that I had been using!The coating seems to allow some foods to more easily separate from the blade, but I found that mushrooms seem to stick more to these blades than my regular Henckels stainless.Overall they're a great addition to your regular set of expensive knives. They're quick and easy for small jobs and wash up with hardly any effort.

This is so much better than Unity! My family almost wanted to boycott the series after that one, but I’m really glad we gave Assassins Creed another try.Good:+ Voice acting is great and the character’s personalities are intriguing and engaging.+ Safehouse is so cool, what an innovative idea!+ Funny. I rarely laugh out loud when I’m in the middle of a game, but there were a few things that really cracked me up.+ Upgrades, there are tons of them, and most are extremely useful. Love the train!+ The gameplay world is massive.+ The ability to take people hostage almost makes up for not being able to hide behind bushes anymore.+ They really got the Victorian-era feel right. I love it, but my husband was disappointed it wasn’t more steampunk.Still not Great:- Free running and climbing are still awkward and take a lot of getting used to.- Audio is lackluster. Music seems mostly flat, wish it had more bass and drums to match the feel of the game.- No more stealth behind bushes – this took a lot of getting used to for me. I probably used it too much before though.- Lots more fist fighting, less swordplay.Overall this is a great game, it’s easy to lose a few hours inside the world and not get frustrated about glitches or anachronisms. It’s smooth and everything just works. It’s fun, challenging, and ramps up difficulty at a good rate. I'd like to give it 4.5 stars, it's darned fun and definitely worth playing even though it has a few minor flaws so it's not really a 5-star production, however, I didn't feel like it was fair knocking off a full star for the few small issues we had.

The tough thing about reviewing headphones is that sound is nearly as subjective as taste. I've had headphones that I thought sounded tinny and other reviewers raved about their booming bass, conversely, I have a set of headphones that I've always used as a gold standard to compare against all others (Etymotic ER6), and these also have their detractors.That said, I am very impressed with the full-room sound and extremely crisp tones I get with these headphones. Another plus is that although they do offer some noise canceling, they still allow enough ambient sound in so I don't feel totally isolated from my environment.There are two issues for me that keep these from being a 5-star product, first is if you wear glasses, the over-the-ear design is somewhat uncomfortable. Without my glasses on I could easily wear these a few hours without pressure or fatigue, with my glasses on I was limited to about a half hour before the back of my head started aching.The second issue is call quality. There's no way to position the microphone which hangs behind the ear. Because of this location, my voice is somewhat muffled, although the system does a decent job of canceling wind noise (something I expect from Jabra). While this is fine for a quick "I'm heading home, be there in 15 minutes" type of call, if you try for any deep discussions the person on the other end of the line is going to get frustrated.Overall, I'm very impressed with the quality of these headphones. They're head and shoulders better than the $30 pair I own, I just wish they were more comfortable with my glasses!

** I received this item for free in exchange for testing and review **Overall this is a nice mouse with good control and little to no lag, but I can't deal with the problems of it dropping out every so often and the hassle of trying to get it to re-connect. This seems to happen when I have other Bluetooth devices in range, and maybe the mouse is trying to connect with them? I don't know, it's frustrating and not worth the hassle unless you are short on USB slots.
