For all I know, my dog could've been going back to the dish that smelled more familiar to him as "his".That said, the Petsafe Current Fountain isn't too bad - just not what I expected.  The large bowl holds 15 cups of water (3.5 liters), takes up about a square foot in space, and has nonsplashing continuous running water.  The water moves just barely, so if you have pets who like the splashing movements like my dog, you may want to look for something else.  The bowl is very lightweight, and can be easily tipped by curious pets.  The cord isn't too long, which can be both a good or bad thing, depending on where you're placing the bowl.  To refill the bowl, you can simply pour in more water, and the filters are easy to change and readily available.Overall, while this bowl wasn't for us, this may be good for other pets.  The deduction of star is based primarily on color and how lightweight the bowl is - it really is easy to tip this bowl in comparison to his current fountain bowl, and frankly, the color is hideous.  That aside, it works as advertised.

The Omgar Insulated Lunch Bags are a great value set of lunch bags.  The bags are thick, durable, and hold a good sized lunch inside of them.  In all honesty, they're not the most attractive looking bags, but my kids don't really care, and they LOVED the fact that these can keep their lunches hot or cold - depending on what's being served.The bags hold a good amount inside of them.  I'm able to put a 2 or 4 cup round Pyrex container, a full 16 ounce bottle of water, and a gala apple in the bag with plenty of room to spare.  For those who own a Ms. Bento 2 tiered container (Zojirushi Ms.Bento Stainless Lunch Jar, Aqua Blue), this also fits in there.  A six pack of sodas can fit in a single bag.  If you wanted, you could fit a 24 ounce container of yogurt in one with some room to spare - yes, these bags are fairly roomy and you can pack a good sized lunch in them!  There are some side pockets on the bag which I found to be perfect for holding utensils.  The bags are lightweight, easy to wipe the insides to clean, and can be zippered shut.  Because the zipper is on the top, kids will also not turn their food contents sideways, like most insulated lunch boxes.Overall, my two kids really liked their lunch bags. They're lightweight, durable, and hold a good amount of food inside while keeping the food hot/cold.  These would be great bags for day trips, holding road trip snacks, and definitely for every day school/work lunches.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Suzuki Piano School Volume 1 is a great starter book in teaching your kid classical music.  This book focuses on "tonalization" - the search for ways of producing beautiful sound from instruments in the same way that singers use vocalization to developing their singing voices.  When first starting this book, the music looks (and is) very simple.  The first quarter of the book focuses on multiple variations of "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star".  While it seemed redundant to the kid initially, it really helped him hear the differences between the different tempos and dynamics.  Being able to count accurately really matters in the beginning - if you don't have a teacher helping you, there is also a CD that helps you hear the song and understand what exactly is going on.  The CD is very helpful, and will be much more helpful down the line once you get into the second and third volumes.  Also, if you have a teacher who understands and can teach the Suzuki Method, it will help speed things greatly.This particular volume is an international version, so there are four translations inside - English, German, French, and Spanish.  This doesn't hinder nor clutter the book at all.  Overall, this is a great book to have in your kid's piano lessons.

The Rumio Makeup Coutour Kit is a good kit for the beginner makeup and contour artist.  The makeup goes on lightly, which is great for everyday use, and blends well.  I had no issues with skin irritation, and the color palette included can be blended to match any skin tone.  The cakes are really quite large - with that much product, it's not hard to convince myself to practice layering on, and I don't feel bad using more product.  The one drawback - which can also be seen as a strength - is that the makeup goes on quite sheer.  For those who are trying to get a really pronounced effect, you will need to layer on quite a lot to get the desired effect.  Unfortunately, that also makes the makeup very powdery and noticeable.  For those who like a soft and less defined look, this works well enough.The palette is thin for easy storage, and features 6 different contouring powders.  It has everything you'll need to get started in learning how to contour.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

I've been using my Keurig 117644 2.0 K200 Brewer, Black for some time now, and while I love my machine, I hate that I have to keep paying at minimum $0.30 per cup for fairly mediocre coffee/tea blends that Keurig puts out. To add insult to injury, the carafe packs are at least $1.88 per pod, and the flavors are not nearly as abundant as the k-pod blends.  To be honest, even finding generic k-carafe pods can be difficult, and while my friends enjoyed that I made each of them a separate k-cup coffee, sometimes it would be nice to just make one carafe of coffee that everyone likes instead of four single cups.The Fanor Reusable K-Cup and K-Carafe Filters are a great solution to my problem. The reusable cups come in a convenient pack of two, so you can make either a single K-Cup or one large carafe of coffee or tea. The overall feel of the cups are durable, and the K-Cups are completely compatible with my Keurig 2.0 Machine so I don't have to have hack the machine with a piece of genuine k-carafe foil and a piece of tape. FYI - the cups are these hideous colors because the color overrides the Keurig's reader so they will work with your machine.  I would've liked these in a less bright color, but it doesn't work that way.To use the carafe cup, simply fill the cup up 2/3 full, place the pod in the Keurig so you can read the text on it (hinge is facing downwards), then use your Keurig as normal.  For the single cups, you'll need to align the arrows so the striped looking arrow faces downward and the hinge of the cup is facing upwards.  I've tested out these cups with both coffee and tea with good results. One disclaimer noted on the package is that you must make sure that if you're using coffee is neither very finely nor coarsely ground. I grind my own coffee and the results have been favorable.  I don't buy preground, so I can't give feedback regarding that.  The cups are also very easy to clean.Overall, the K-Cup and K-Carafe filters work as advertised.  They work well with my machine, can hold a decent amount of coffee/tea, and are easy to clean. I would definitely recommend these to Keurig users.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Curtzy Silicone Rubber Chocolate Molds are easily washed, very pliable for easy chocolate release, smooth textured, and really very cute.  This set includes six different trays in which to mold chocolates and other candies.  These molds work particularly well with chocolate as they create a flawless shiny surface.  There were no bubbles, pits, or scratches on the interior of the molds.  Be sure when you wash the molds to use non abrasive cleansers or sponges so you don't scratch the insides of the molds - if there are any scratches, your chocolates will look dull.One thing to note is that you should definitely wash these out carefully when you first receive them.  There is a slight plasticky scent to these molds that do go away once washed.The molds included are all five pictured, as well as an additional mold with four rocking horses, three small cars, four Lego-esque bricks, and three whole body bears.  The molds are really adorable, particularly the animal set, and in some cases very detailed such as the flower set.  My favorite set is the chocolate spoon set - the spoon bowl is even slightly concave, so you can pipe a bit of mousse in there for a cute, but elegant dessert.Overall, this is a really great chocolate mold set.  They work very well, and the chocolates comes out smoothly and easily.  I've included some tips on tempering chocolate below for these molds.To get really glossy chocolate, you should temper the chocolate over indirect heat (in a double boiler).  Melt three-fourths of the chocolate needed using small chopped pieces of chocolate and stir constantly as it melts, heating it to about 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Once the chocolate is smooth, remove it from the heat and add the remaining chocolate, stirring it in until it's melted and the temperature has dropped to about 80 degrees. To finish the temper, heat the chocolate again in the double boiler to between 88 and 91 degrees for dark chocolate, or 86 and 88 degrees for milk chocolate.  Place the silicone molds on a baking sheet or tray, and pour the melted chocolate into the molds. For smooth chocolates, the molds must be filled to the rim. You may need to smooth the chocolate into small details using the tip of a toothpick. Air bubbles can become trapped inside the poured chocolate. Lightly tapping the mold on the counter dislodges the bubbles. You can also prevent air bubbles by brushing a thin coat of the tempered chocolate onto the inside of each mold before pouring.  Place the molds in the fridge for 20 minutes to cure the chocolate, then turn the molds upside down and tap or press lightly on the underside to remove the finished candy.  Completed candies will fall from the mold very easily.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Winomo Organizer works very well at keeping cleaning supplies in check in the garage.  It was easy to mount on the wall, and I use it to store my brooms, small trimmers, and other sundry items.  You can store four poled items, and there are five hooks to hang items from.  It's easy to hang and remove items such as brooms and mops on this unit.  Any bit of organization in the garage is helpful and this holder does a good job at reining in the mess.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

I purchased my first Pure Komachi by Kai 6-1/2-Inch Stainless-Steel Chef’s Meat Knife in 2004, and now 11 years later, I still have and use the knife.  When given the opportunity to try out the Kai Pure Komachi Knives HD, I was really interested.  First off, the most noticeable difference is that the knives are no longer made in Japan by the Kai Corporation in Seki City.  These knives are now made in China as indicated on the handle.  I'm unsure if the knives are full tang as their handles are no longer translucent.The Komachi HD knives are fairly similar to the first generation Komachi knives.  The knives are very lightweight and very sharp.  I tried out all the knives on various food items including meats, vegetables, and fruits of various hardnesses with great success.  The handles fit my hand very well, and the overall look of the knives are playful and fun.  Each knife comes with a blade sheath so accidentally getting a cut while getting a knife from a drawer in minimized.  Because these knives are stainless steel (albeit coated), they can be sharpened if needed (with exception of the serrated knife).While I like these knives for casual "small meals cooking" use, I can say that if your budget allows, definite invest in a heavier weight knife.  Because these knives are so lightweight, if you're doing a large load of prep, your hand and wrist may get tired.  In comparison to my Henkels blade, I find that I can do larger amounts of prep with less effort with the Henkels - but that said, the Henkels is much more expensive.If the current Komachi knives are anything like my previous Komachi knife, I will say this knife will last a long time without having to sharpen much.  I'm not sure about the longer term quality as of yet, but I can say that my 11 year old Komachi knife does have some rusting in the handle and discoloration due to lot of use, but still can cut through chicken and vegetables with great ease.  This is with near daily use and a rare sharpening.  The long term Komachi quality (at least the Japan version) seems fantastic.  I'm hoping the China version lasts as long.Overall, these are a great option for a budget set of knives.  These are certainly worth recommending to college students or casual cooks on a budget.  They are sharp and cut well.  Definitely worth a look at as a gift or for your own kitchen.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Herbalosophy Nourish Masque is a good deep conditioning hair masque.  Instead of a small tub, the product comes in an easy to squeeze out tube.  The masque deeply conditioned my hair, although I left it in for about 15 minutes instead of 5 (not intentional, just started doing something else and forgot).  The masque made my hair feel soft and very manageable after use.  It is very thick, and the tube holds about 2-3 applications for people with slightly longer than shoulder length hair. The conditioner rinses out easily, despite being a very thick product, and has a mild herbal scent.  The only gripe I have is that this masque needs to be applied to damp, not wet, hair and left on for at least five minutes to work.  Unless you're shaving your legs or something, that's a long time to be standing around in the shower with partially dry hair.  This holds particularly true for those who are on major water restrictions due to drought (welcome to California).  That aside, the masque did work well, although because of the hassle, I would lean back in favor of other conditioners.  Overall, not a bad product, but just a little extra work to get it working well.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The NockNock Solar Fairy Lights are a fun set of lights to put in your yard.  The lights are completely solar powered, can run in either a steady or blinking mode, and come on a black string so it blends seamlessly into any foliage/item it's hung on.  I put our lights on a small bush in our front yard with good results.  As long as the small panel is situated directly in the sun, the lights will charge well and automatically turn on once the sun sets.  The lights stayed on for quite a while - in fact, I've gone to bed and the lights would still be on.  By the morning, the lights would be off and start charging again.  On days of overcast, the lights don't charge nearly as much, and I noticed them off before the 8 hour mark.  The lights really are dependent on how much sunlight it gets during the day.  Despite being called "warm white", the lights do not have an overtly yellow tinge to them - our set didn't have the "cool white" blue tinge either - the coloring of the lights is really quite white and looks great outdoors.The lights work very well on "steady mode", but I can't say it works as well on "blinking mode".  For whatever reason, the company decided to make all the lights blink on and off at the same time.  Because none of the lights alternate in blinking, the entire string will be off, then on - it's really kind of bizarre looking, so I never use that function.  That aside, the lights work very well and are easy to install.  These lights are a great "set and forget" decorative touch for your garden.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Fuloon Foldable Pet Swimming Pool/Bath Tub works fantastically as a foldaway tub.  First off, when you first receive this, I would highly suggest airing this tub out - it smells terribly of chemically plastic when you initially receive it!  My biggest gripe out this pool really stems to that smell - to be safe, I  scrubbed out the interior of the pool to make sure any residual chemical coating was washed off.  I also aired it out for a couple of days, just to be safe.  Once the plastic smell is gone, the pool works great.  I was able to fill it with water without it leaking, and it it held up fine while giving the dog a bath.  In addition, the pool was easy to fold back up and put back into the accompanying plastic carrying bag.  This is great because the pool itself doesn't take up much room, and I can store it on a shelf without much effort.Overall, this is a good sized pool to bath dogs, or to use as a wading pool for a smaller dog.  It's durable, easy to clean, easy to empty out, and stores very well.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The CAILLER L'Art Du Brut Dark Chocolate Cocoa Bar is a delicious bar for any dark chocolate lover.  This bar of chocolate is much thicker than your standard Hershey's bar, and so full of nuts and blueberries that the chocolate can't completely cover everything.  The chocolate is definitely not very sweet - if you've eaten Ghirardelli semi sweet chocolate chips, the Caillier chocolate bar is even less sweet than that.  While not very sweet, the chocolate is naturally sweetened by the nuts and blueberries.  I love how this chocolate is minimal in ingredients, and does not contain filler oils that would make it taste waxy.The bar is decadent and makes a lovely treat.  The ingredients include chocolate, sugar, almonds, hazelnuts, candied blueberries (blueberries, apple juice concentrate), milk fat, sunflower lecithin, cocoa butter, and vanilla extract.  This is a great quality chocolate bar from Switzerland - I would definitely buy this chocolate again!

I ordered the Sztrokia Tempered Glass Screen Protector on October 13 and received it almost 2 weeks later on October 26, even despite the estimated Nov. 25 arrival date.  That said, if you order this screen protector, it's definitely not going to show up in 2 days (unless it's offered via Prime at this time) and since it's shipping from China, will likely take its sweet time getting here.The Sztrokia screen protector is very simple to apply, can be repositioned if you place it on incorrectly the first time, and does a fine job of protecting my iPhone screen.  The protector was much simpler to apply than those bendable plastic screens - the air bubbles come out very quickly and easily, and you really just need to drop this protector on and it sticks nicely.While I haven't dropped my phone to breaking point again, the Sztrokia screen protector is much thicker than my previous plastic protector.  Despite being thicker, I'm able to use my phone as normal, and can access the home button just fine (although there is a little ridge there that takes getting used to).  I've had a few minor drops with the Sztrokia in place, and it seems to be holding up just fine.  When dropped, it didn't scratch easily and seemed to do it's job.Overall, I'm very pleased with this screen protector.  It's easy to install, feels thick and durable, and once applied you can barely tell it's there.  Definitely a good way to protect your iPhone screen.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

I love having my house scented, but I don't like having to use chemical laced air fresheners, nor do I like having to worry about the residual smoke or potential fire hazard a candle may have should I leave it alone for too long.  The Vividay Aroma Ultrasonic Diffuser is a great compromise - I can have a lovely scented house without having to worry about chemicals or accidentally torching my house down.The Diffuser is one of the largest I've seen.  It holds 500 ml (about 2.25 cups) of water and can run continuously for quite a long time before running out of water.  There are three preset amounts of time - 1, 2, and 3 hours - as well as a general "on" switch where you can leave it on until you decide it to turn it off or when the machine runs out of water, whatever comes first.  The diffuser also has a built in lamp with two light setting - bright or dim light.  The light is definitely not bright enough to read to, but works well as a soft mood light or night light.  I found when paired with some soft ambient music, this light and diffuser worked well to create a very calming environment.The Vividay diffuser has a very large opening to allow a fine vapor smoke to be released.  The vapor can come out as either a light or heavy mist.  It is recommended to put 2-3 drops of essential oil per 100 ml of water.  I tested this unit out with a "breathe" blend essential oil as both the husband and kid suffer from seasonal allergies.  This unit worked very well in helping them breathe a little easier.  The "smoke" comes out very cleanly and quietly, and the scent is distributed very well.  The unit operates using a standard two pronged outlet, and can be refilled easily by simply lifting off the top lid and adding more water/oil.The one issue I had with this machine is with the settings.  First, when you make any selection that requires pushing a button, the unit will beep very loudly.  Any button you push will result in either a loud single or double beep.  In addition, when using the machine, it was initially difficult to figure out which was the high/low setting.  I found that when you push the high/low button that the high setting is indicated by a single beep and the low setting is indicated by a double beep.  I couldn't figure this out until the lights were out and I utilized the lamp feature where I could clearly see the smoke.  While this issue wasn't great enough for me to dock a star, let it be known that the beeping can be annoying at times.Overall, the unit really worked well, and I love how well the diffuser worked and how it could hold a large store of water.  While no one has gotten sick yet, I can imagine this will be an incredibly useful machine once someone gets their first cold and when winter comes into full swing and when we have our house heater on.  The diffuser definitely helps moisturize the air, works very quietly, and is simple but lovely looking.  This along with a good set of essential oils would be a great gift for anyone.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

As a long time fan of Harry Potter, I was thrilled to see the series finally being produced as a colorful illustrated version.  My kids are on the younger end of the elementary school, and while they can enjoy chapter books devoid of pictures, having illustrations included are a big plus, and it helps them understand a little more of what's going on/what certain characters and scenes could look like.  The story is included in its entirety, and the illustrations are absolutely gorgeous.  This is definitely a great book to include on the bookshelf of any Harry Potter fan.

My 15 lb Papillon is a very selective chewer. For a long time now, I've been giving him pressed vegetarian bones such as Greenies or Whimzees. When he was smaller, I gave him a rawhide bone to find out that they're not nearly as digestible as claimed - rawhide caused him to get upset stomach and the runs.  While he liks the veggie bones, he could quickly go through one in less in than five minutes.  In addition, I noticed his breath was not improving because his teeth were not getting a good workout.  Bully Sticks are a great option for him because they're easily digestible, it takes him some time to chew through them, and they help clean his teeth through all the chewing action.My dog totally loves these Bully Sticks. Initially I was worried that he would have difficulty chewing through these sticks because these are much larger than most treats he gets, but the worry was unwarranted.  My dog was able to chew through these without any issues.  These sticks are all at least 12" in length, and a little thicker than your average Sharpie, but thinner than a Mr. Sketch marker.  As a warning, the bag that the sticks come in will not seal after you open it because the sticks are so long .  You may need to put them in a gallon ziploc bag, or cut the sticks in half in order to close the bag.  Because my dog is smaller, it's advised to only give him half a stick.  I was able to cut all the sticks in half using my pruning shears and ended up storing them in a ziploc bag in the freezer.  Storing in the freezer was not necessary - most people freeze them to keep the odor down, but these have little to no odor - I stored these in the freezer because my dog enjoys the harder and cold texture.  The Best Bully Stick website also suggests storing these in the freezer as it keeps the sticks fresher longer.My dog didn't have any stomach issues and was able to digest the pieces he swallowed just fine. The sticks are not greasy like a bone, but is smooth and dry like a pig ear.  While my dog chewed, I didn't notice any scent and he didn't have bad breath afterwards.  In comparison to the vegetable sticks, the Bully Sticks are much better at keeping my dog busy while cleaning his teeth. The veggie sticks were too easy for him to chew through, and I've noticed since giving him the Bully Sticks, his breath and teeth health have improved vastly. It's great that my dog can chew for longer than five minutes - I love how it's keeping him extra busy in the afternoon! The cost is reasonable, if not better than our local pet store.  I'll definitely be buying this treat for him once he finishes the bag!FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Luseta Coconut Milk Shampoo and Conditioner Set is great for dry hair. I have medium length Asian hair which tends to lean on the drier and more porous side. I often wear my hair tied back, and get plenty of sunshine on my hair throughout the day. The shampoo and conditioner set really helped make my hair feel soft and manageable. It has a lovely coconut scent that's fairly strong when using in the shower, but fades to a soft and pleasant scent when dry.  If you love coconut scent as much as I do, you're going to love using this set - the scent is simply divine!The Luseta Coconut Milk formula was great for my dry hair - the white shampoo lathered up well, rinsed out easily and didn't make my hair feel overly "clean" to the point of squeaking. I used the matching conditioner afterwards and its scent matched the shampoo. It also rinsed out easily and didn't leave my hair feeling heavy or greasy.  The shampoo is gentle and moisturizing enough to use by itself, but works much better when using in conjunction with the conditioner.Overall, this is a really wonderful quality shampoo. It works perfectly as a daily conditioning shampoo set, and left my hair looking and feeling very healthy. I would certainly purchase this set again.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Cupider Waterproof vibrator just didn't cut it for me, in more ways than one.  In comparison to the Cupider Rabbit (Freeker Masturbation Female G Spot Clitoral Multi Speed Bunny Rabbit Vibrator (Rose)) this vibrator really fell short.  First off, this particular unit uses an uncommon battery.  I'm guessing it's one of those shorter AA looking photo batteries, but I couldn't get the battery to come out of the unit.  I shook it, got out some tweezers, and basically spent 15 minutes trying to unsuccessfully remove the battery to examine it.  One this battery is out, playtime is literally going to be over.The vibrations on this unit is really great - there are three vibration modes (one low, one high, and one alternating from vaginal to clitoral stimulation), and powerwise, this unit is on the mark.  The operation is strong, the sound on this is really minimal, and the silicone outside is silky smooth.  However, the overall unit is fairly small - not much larger than your average hot dog - and without a handle of sorts, it's difficult to hold and use.For a buck more, I would get the larger "upgraded" rabbit vibrator by Cupider.  It has 30 vibration modes, a handle for better handling, and uses standard AAA batteries.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

The Famili Digital Food Scale is a fantastic small item scale.  The scale is 8"x6.5"x0.75" in size and weighs 534 g (18.8 oz).  It's weighable surface is about 6.5"x6.5", if you don't want to block the readout screen at all.  The scale looks and functions almost identically to a body scale - the surface is all glass and smooth and the weight is calculated by the feet of the scale.  You will need to have a good flat surface for this scale to work accurately.The Famili Scale is very accurate and is able to detect and accurately weigh items as low as 3 grams to up to 11 pounds.  It's a little disappointing the scale doesn't weight down to 1 gram like my other kitchen scale, but it's exceptionally rare when I have to weigh out a single gram of anything.  The scale can tare a mixing bowl, so you don't have to make any calculations to subtract container weight, and the scale is able to measure items in fluid ounces.  The fluid ounce measurements were accurate, although there is a warning regarding measuring oil.  If you choose to measure oil, it will result in a volume reading of +10%.  You will need to adjust accordingly.The scale operates on two AAA batteries, and has a very bright LED readout screen so it makes seeing the numbers much easier.  One thing I didn't particularly care for is that the numbers on the readout screen are small - about 0.5" in size.  I like having larger numbers so when I'm baking I can see what I put in from afar, so this was a little bothersome to me.  Having the numbers in red also didn't help the case.  That aside, the scale is easy to operate, a breeze to clean, and works very accurately.  The scale works silently, has a good surface area to weigh items, and is attractive looking.  Overall, this is a great scale to have to weigh your smaller items.FYI - I was selected for this opportunity to review this item free of charge. The content and opinions expressed here are all my own.

Head and Shoulders Refresh Dandruff Shampoo not only will make your hair feel very clean, but it also cleans very gently and should not irritate your skin or scalp. The shampoo did a fine job of getting my hair clean, but not so clean that it get tangly and "squeaky" feeling.  My son who occasionally gets dandruff flaking about had the best result from using this shampoo - the flakes were reduced dramatically.  There was a little tingling when using this shampoo, but not as much as using a shampoo with something like tea tree oil in it.  The scent is pleasant and not overbearing, and fades nicely as it dries.  The scent is not overly feminine nor masculine, and was well received by all who used it.  This is a good shampoo to get hair soft, manageable, clean, and flake free.

I recently purchased the Chesapeake Bay Candle Blood Orange scent from my local bulls eye store.  Of all the many candles I've tried over the years, this is my favorite scent.  The blood orange scent is not too sweet, not too citrusy, and is just a very lovely calming scent.  This candle comes with two wicks to light, and once lit is very bright and emits the most wonderful scent.  The candle burns slowly and seems to last a good amount of time.I've seen this particular scent put in various types of containers and renamed for the corresponding container collection (Heritage Collection, The Collection, etc), however I've found the scent hasn't changed despite the various collection names.  If you're curious about the scent, I would check our your local red bulls eye store prior to purchase - I don't think you'll be disappointed!

The Up & Up Anti-Itch Cream works wonders on insect bites.  The mosquitoes were out and about this summer as usual, and the family and I didn't escape our backyard without a few bites.  This cream worked as well as any other brand name 1% hydrocortisone cream.  The inactive ingredients had some other good skin soothing ingredients such as aloe and oat extract, and the itches would subside shortly after use.  I would definitely purchase at your local bulls eye store for the best value though - shipping here kills the deal!  Overall, good product though.

My husband recently received the Lumio Book Lamp as a gift, and I have to say that this is an absolutely beautiful lamp.  The cover is one continuous piece of wood that has been carefully cut on specific spots where the spine is, so the book can actually close seamlessly, and yet not be two separate pieces with hinges or glue to keep it together.  The pages are accordion folded "Tyvek" - apparently that's a waterproof and 100% recycled material.  The LED lights are inside the pages so that you can't see the light directly and all the wires and such are housed internally - when the book is open, it really looks just like an open book with all the pages flared out.The light is charged via USB on the cover edge of the book.  When you open the book, even just a crack, the light will turn on.  The light is exceptionally bright and is bright enough where you could read easily with it on.  There are magnets in the book cover and book comes with several attachments you can use to hold it open.  The magnets in the book serve several functions.  First, it helps keep the book shut when not in use, can be used to hold the book open in a cylinder shape, and can be used in conjunction with a small magnetic "wheel" set.  This wheel allows you to hang the book on the wall like a sconce, or can be used with the included leather strap to hang the book from a ceiling - this is surprisingly a very versatile lamp!  It has a nice weighted feel to it, and is very durable.  We've opened and closed the lamp many times without wearing out the pages at all.Overall, this is a very beautiful book lamp.  It would be a wonderful gift for any book lover - it definitely makes an interesting conversation starter!

It was right during the time I was just getting into Level 42 that a series of four twofer import CD's came out-all representing their 80's album output. This was the ideal way to really dive into their music in it's original format. Especially as each one presented a series of demos,unreleased numbers and special mixes that enhanced the original content. These two albums from the end of the decade represented music from the band which I'd never even heard of up to this point. And was the most difficult volume to find,and turned out to be the last one I picked up as a result. Still it perhaps represents the most significant musical culmination of their career so far.  The first album is 1987's Running In The Family. My two favorite numbers on it are the throbbing,melodically probing dance/funk of "Lessons In Love",the apparent big radio hit here and the title song-a synth and lead guitar fueled example of thick,uptempo rock 'n soul. "Children Say" features layers of harmonically complex keyboards and similarly rhythmic drums while "It's Over" and "Two Solitudes" are both more musically atmospheric art pop style ballads. "To Be With You Again" and "Fashion Fever" are both frenetic uptempo synth funk while the slow crawling reggae tinged groove of "The Sleepwalkers" and the shuffling funk/pop groove of "Freedom Someday" conclude this particular album.  1988's Staring At The Sun is a whole different animal from it's predecessor. With new drummer Gary Husband and guitarist Steve Topping? we have the driving fast uptempo dance rocker "Heaven In My Hand"-with it's staccato clavinet and lead guitar providing a sea of rhythmic interplay that extends into "I Don't Know Why". "Take A Look" meanwhile is a Caribbean inflected mid tempo number while "Over There" embraces a progressive,complex electro jazz/fusion drum solo with a dynamic melody. "Silence" and "Man" are both rhythmically and melodically heady numbers in a similar genre while the shuffling groove of "Tracie",the cinematically heady title song,the AOR pop sound of "Two Hearts Collide" and the hugely dynamic live band interplay of "Gresham Blues" conclude the album.  These two albums both extend from the other in terms of a band coping with two vital factors. First off was the massive commercial breakthrough of their 1985 release World Machine. This informed the first of these albums in the sense that the music really began to reflect the bands funk,soul and pop craftsmanship more than instrumental soloing. By the time of that albums follow up? The Gould brothers had departed the band. And they began really upping the ante in terms of flexing the harder,more guitar oriented jazz/rock strains of their sound-finding a new way to expand on their classic early to mid 80's sound. It would essentially go from here in their sound after these albums musically. So these represent Level 42 at a very important musical crossroads.

At this point? It really doesn't matter that Wynton Marsalis has been the head of Jazz At Lincoln Center and all his accompanying prestige-and occasional controversy within the musicians community. What is important is that he and his very musical family sprung from the same soil as his respective musical genre. So he's had a close up view as it progressed for his own generation. In 1991 Wynton bought together a sextet-including such musical luminaries as pianist Marcus Roberts and drummer Jeff "Tain" Watts for a series of fairly elongated songs that celebrated his core creative roots.  "Harriet Tubman" begins the album with a moody swing that has a lot of conversational sax and trumpet melodic interaction going on about it. "Elveen" takes the same mood down a notch in tempo while the title track takes the tempo and overall atmosphere up in mood a notch.  "So This Is Jazz,Huh?" and "L.C. On The Cut" are both slower bluesy numbers with prominent drum solos. This is a very good musical idea-basically a mixture of soulful hard bop dissonances mixed with a chunkier flavor as well. Harmonically it probes but doesn't seem to come to any musical resolutions. In as much as that seems to be the story of black America so far? This album is as telling on what it symbolizes as any jazz has ever been.

When I first began exploring (and eventually reviewing) the albums of the Grateful Dead? Ended up starting with their 70's and 80's albums. And for the most part don't feel that was a bad choice because they made some of their most broad stylistic strides during that time period. But these kings of the San Francisco psychedelic music scene made this debut recording in the summer of love. Have been perhaps more excited to listen to and review this album than anything else they've ever made. Just the idea of this band first getting it's feet wet in the recording studio after already being such established live icons already. And what a journey it is!  "The Golden Road (To Unlimited Devotion)" begins with an electric piano led mix of driving,melodic power blues rock that continues on "Cold Rain And Snow" as well as the more surf oriented "Beat It On Down The Line"-while "Good Mornin' Little School Girl" and the extended "Viola Lee Blues" really work the 12 bar electric sound into the technicolor stratosphere. "Sitting On Top Of The World" is a fast paced country/western oriented number while "Morning Dew","New New Minglewood Blues","Alice D.Millionare","Overseas Stomp" and "Death Have No Mercy" are all thick,grooving pop rockers. ""Tastebud" and especially a 22 minute live take on "Viola Lee Blues" really kick out some of their trademark jams.  One thing that this album really showcases is Bob Weir and Jerry Garcia's ability to mix strong melodic craft with extended instrumental looseness. Playing even on the short songs with a strong sense of collective improvisation? The Grateful Dead come off here as rock players who think like jazz ones. All trying to have a musical conversation with the intent of working everything out-rather than just making a lot of loud and noisy solos to show up the other members. It's probably that very quality that made the band mean so much to the psychedelic music scene. They were able to bring their music on record to the people without commercializing their own intent out of it. And that's the intent that made them the icons they are today.

One of my core memories is of continually going to sleep as an older toddler whenever the title song of this album came on the radio. The song was not boring to me ever,but somehow soulfully comforting. In my early adulthood as I was exploring the funk/soul spectrum of music? It came to my attention that Spandau Ballet were major players on the UK post disco/dance/soul/new wave scene along with groups such as Incognito. They had many wonderful early albums especially to chose from. Of course this is the first of their's I ended up with-their big international breakthrough as I understand. And couldn't be more happier about it.  "Pleasure" begins the album a percussive,rhythm guitar led boogie groove with some light synthesized touches. "Communication" adds a sparkly Motown styled shuffle and falsetto choruses to the mix while "Code Of Love" is a stripped down number just bubbling under the surface as it builds. "Gold" goes up in tempo with an epic,danceable sense of drama whereas "Lifeline","Heaven Is A Secret" and "Foundation" find the melodic nature of the songs supporting the strong rhythmic interplay of the band. The title song concludes the album,a longer version than I've heard with it's popping guitar,yearning sax solo and mid tempo soulful romance.  Having understood their earlier albums to be looser in their overall approach? This 1983 release find the band very successfully adapting their sound to pop radio considerations. Their strong emphasis on percussive,chugging guitars and strong rhythmic elements in general have not disappeared in the least bit here. But the songs are generally shorter,and the focus is more on crafting choruses and refrains than solely building on a good groove. As the particular music scene Spandau were involved in developed? Most of their contemporaries faced similar musical considerations. But albums like this really helped to show that it could all work very well if done well.

Somehow in these last two years? The topic and music of Fela Kuti has come up a great deal. Watched a wonderful documentary on the man,based on a biographical Broadway show. Plus he's been the topic of many conversations between myself and friend Henrique regarding strong Afrocentrism in music. Still this managed to be one of only three CD's by the man that I've picked up. And he has many more in and out of print as of this review. Somehow today on what would've been his birthday? It seemed right to listening to his music in celebration of the revived understanding of that Afrocentric creative approach he always encouraged.  The title song opens with a huge busy percussion sound-with the rhythm guitar chugging away at lightening speed while unison and solo horns all manage to make themselves noticed with great melodic clarity. "Mister Follow Follow" is set at a much slower tempo-with the horn charts and guitars playing  very succinct Arabic type tones. "Observation Is No Crime" has a slow,bluesy funk shuffle where Fela himself plays a wonderful sax solo as the cherry on the type. "Mistake"-a live track recorded in Berlin the same year this album came out is another percussive horn based musical conversation pinned down by a strong bass line.  From beginning to end this album is wonderfully funky. And in the manner of James Brown,with whom Fela shared a complex and mutual admiration, he continually emphasized the rhythmic and harmonic power of the live band as one pulsing unit. Because I have personal difficulty listening through Fela's heavy Yoruba dialect? Some of the lyrics on this album don't come through that easily to my ears. But being able to pick up consistent references to "black power"? The man's radical activism comes across without having to go into any great verbal detail about it. As a matter of fact? The best way to receive Fela's music is moving to it in some way. Really allows it's spirit to be received well.

First time I ever heard of Fela "Ransome" Kuti was when he was referenced by Paul McCartney when he was recording with Wings in Lagos. It had to do with him feeling that Paul and his band were their to steal African music to to claim as their own. Over the years I've come to learn some about the complex socio-musical ethic that Fela had-going right along with his political awakening. This two albums,the latter of the two produced by Ginger Baker and were both recorded in 1975 after a trumped up drug conviction. This being the first album I purchased from the Africa 70? I was very excited by the prospect of what I was about to hear.  "Expensive ***t" is a is set to ringing,fast paced percussion,a light touch on the rhythm guitar and the main melody on the piano. "Water Got No Enemy" is a rhythmically full number-filled with thick melodic horn charts,as well as massive vocal leads and choruses. "He Miss Road" is an intensely funky number with the guitar and bass lines in heavy vocal interplay with the peppy organ getting in on the musical conversation. "Monday Morning In Lagos" has a very unusual time signature (to me anyway) with big horn accents and equally off kilter organ while the whole thing ends with the 17 minute plus poly rhythmic explosion of "It's No Possible"-with it's spacey organ based melody.  In my long history with music? I've only really ever listened to African music/Afropop in a rather peripheral way. And even then generally as an element in funk,soul and rock music. Something about Fela's sound is extremely appealing to me as a huge funk fan. When playing it in the car with my other driving? I wondered how she'd receive it. Her reaction to the first song was a strong identification-actually wishing to choreograph a dance of her own to it. Since the Africa 70's music was intent on projecting the Afrocentrism of rhythm and movement as a key aspect of life and the aural tradition? Well this album will very likely make a similar impression on almost anyone who hears it.

It was through yet another session of grate digging that I first came across this album-on vinyl of course. It came to me seeing the title that it had been slighted as one of the bands lesser albums-snidely using the reference point of it's 1983 release date as a main reason for it's lack of quality. This presentation of it having actually encouraged me to pick up that vinyl. Even though doing something just to be a contrarian isn't the best way to go generally? This was so much of a pleasant surprise? Actually ended up getting a CD copy of it that I could listen to on the go. And after several listens? Still glad I made that leap of musical faith to pick this up to start with.  "Blue World" is a mid tempo,bluesy dance number with some bubbling synth and live percussion mixed with some clever internal rhyme in the lyrics. "Meet Me Halfway" takes the tempo up a notch-maintaining the same flavor with a bigger guitar solo as does the even faster "Sitting At The Wheel" right after it. "Going Nowhere","Under My Feet","Under My Feet" and "Running Water" are again more acoustically tinged ballads while "It's Cold Outside Of Your Heart" has a somewhat electronic country rock flavor. The marching instrumental "Hole In The World" and the requisite spoke word lyrical poetry of "I Am" provide the operatic element of the album musically.  This is actually one of the Moody Blue's strongest albums of the 1980's far as I'm personally concerned. Pretty subjective I know. That viewpoint comes from the facts that this album basically integrates the synthesizer approach of some of the previous album totally into the bands sound. And also allows the presence of more rhythmic uptempo tunes. The dance/rock power of the music is still full of their trademark symphonic sound. And this progression from one particular element of their new sound allowed for this to be an excellent follow up that,while perhaps not succeeding commercially,lived up to it's creative intent.

Growing up I was pretty aware of the long musical history of the Moody Blues,while all the same having heard precious little of it. Later on? It became clear that this was a 60's psychedelic era group that had a fairly long hiatus from the early to late 70's before making a comeback later in the decade. Still it wasn't until this one from several years after that where my first entry point into their music came from. And even longer before I went deeper and discovered the album-rather than the song I first heard from it. Tonight is actually the second time I've given the album a thorough listen all the way through. And as much as I enjoyed it the first time? Hearing it again did enhance my views.  "The Voice" begins the album with a pumping melody built on acoustic/electric guitar interplay-along with synthesized orchestration. "Talking Out Of Turn" has a more percussive  mid tempo soul/folk flavor with very grand strings and bleeping synth bass. That latter instrumental quality is the defining element of "Gemini Dream",an strong new wave production update of the bands melodic sound that represents the first music I ever heard from them. "In My World" and "Nervous" are both pretty acoustic ballads-with "Meanwhile" being an uptempo shuffling variant of that approach. "In My World","22,000 Days","Painted Smile" and "Veteran Cosmic Rocker" are all super singable progressive pop swells.  From the first song to the tenth? This really is a wonderful album. The craftsmanship of these songs is every bit as wonderful as the symphonic/baroque pop-rock the band pioneered in the late 60's and early 70's. There's also a great juxtaposition of orchestral elements as well. Some of the songs actually use real strings and horns for this purpose-while former Yes member Patrick Moraz essentially replaces the bands trademark Melletron with a variety of differently pitched synthesizers. For a band that pioneered much of the symphonic rock movement that is especially big in the 2010's? This album was high quality as well as being forward thinking as to how their music was now being presented.

From my understanding? Hall & Oates 1977 album Beauty On A Back Street didn't do much to please the music listening public or either member of the duo themselves. The pair had the melodic pop smarts,the strong instrumental ability and lots of soul to boot. It just needed a tad bit more of a push to bring it up and keep it out more. This is an album that I always had a huge interest in by them-even when my first copy on vinyl skipped too much to enjoy. And it was a worthwhile effort to pick this up on CD because the pairs introductory record with the production of David Foster really showcases them getting their musical ball rolling along very nicely.  "It's A Laugh",with it's slogging echoed rhythms,sax intro and falsetto harmony choruses basically opens the door fully to the sound most people know from their 80's classics. "Melody For A Memory" and "Have I Been Away Too Long" have foreboding,marching rhythms with a thick late night arena rock ballad flavor. "The Last Time" has a full on wall of sound wallop to it while "I Don't Want To Lose You" is a bouncy "Motownphilly" type soul pop number.  "Alley Katz" and "Don't Blame It On Love" are two riff heavy,punky styled street rockers that adds a sunny melody with the more surf flavored "Pleasure Beach". "August Day" is a beautifully harmonized ballad built around some beautifully processed piano.  It's really hard to describe this album in terms that are all that simplistic. But if I could it would be as one which was half soulful pop and half heavy guitar rockers. And say that loosely because both elements show up throughout all aspects of it.  Foster's production has a glittery,cinematic aspect about it that really works wonderfully with what Daryl and John do musically here. On every level? It basically does that rockier sound from the previous album in a way that functions better. That's because rock used more as an instrumental style here,where the primarily foundation is a jazzier soul and pop one. Definitely a key album in this iconic duos musical development.

For quite a few years now? I saw this album and it's cute pun of a front jacket on both vinyl and CD every so often. Avoided it because,as with many recordings I've listened to? It was never represented as being among their strongest musical accomplishments. It was after all made after Daryl and John had been playing with each other in different bands and recording demos. So this was their 1972 debut on Atlantic,featuring the late and iconic Arif Mardin helping out with some production and arrangement. Found the vinyl crate digging earlier this, and decided it was time to give this album the chance I should have some time ago.  "I'm Sorry", "Fall In Philadelphia" and the orchestrated closer "Lily Are You Happy" are bouncing mid-uptempo soul rockers-the former two with pronounced country and western  inflections . A similar flavor with the wheepy pedal steel guitar shows up on the more acoustically inclined "All Our Love","Goodnight And Goodmorning" and "Southeast City Window". The ballads are actually separated into two different types. "Georgie" and "Waterwheel" are of the stark,piano based variety while "They Needed Eachother" and "Thank You For" are both primarily acoustic guitar based ones with some electric piano accents to top off on.  Have to agree with what I first heard about it. This is very much a duo finding their sound. In the early 70's groups such as The Eagles,America and C,S&N were all basically throwing off different viewpoints on the country rock/singer-songwriter vibe. And this album certainly seems to be mining hard in that musical quarry. Perhaps it was bucking for a hit,maybe it wasn't. And Daryl and John both due a lot of close vocal harmonies and trade off more than the shared leads they are more known for. Still on many of the songs,their elaborate and soul oriented melodies shine through strongly. And it's not too bad a place to go to discover their beginning together after dealing with their more iconic music to come.

Whenever I am in a record store and looking at the Thelonious Monk CD's an vinyl they have? It becomes clear how right the liner notes on the back of this album really are. 1957 truly was the year the man broke out as an artist. Especially when we're talking about recording full length album statements in the studio. He had two iconic albums during this year that are a staple of my father's record collection and he played for me on and off. This was actually the first album I ever had by him-purchased it about twelve years ago this year. Listened to it several times and,in the context of what I've heard from him since? It suddenly reveals a lot more of itself to my ears.  This solo piano record finds Monk harmonizing with his own distinctive style of melody on many original numbers and standards long associated with him such as "April In Paris" and "Monk's Mood". Some of the long form numbers such as "Functional" showcase much of his style of playing as much as his instrumental technique. One of my favorite parts here is a 21 minute recording session-complete with several different takes of "Round Midnight"-really showing how he developed this as a solo piano number. This is an odd place to start for this artist,I'll have to admit. But in a way? It's perfect because it gives you the feel of hearing the man playing and growing musically right before your ears. So it's probably one of his most telling albums.

Sometimes I very easily take it for granted that the album length format in music was not yet half a century old before I came into the world. It probably has a lot to do with why I've generally steered away from compilations over the years. Yet it would seem in the case of Thelonious Sphere Monk. In the late 1940's while be-bop was still very much a live,musician's musicians based music? It was individual sides that were still driving recorded music. So these autumn 1947 sessions necessitated a set of this sort. Still when organized in this way? These tunes do tell a very full length type of musical story.  "Humph" opens the album with a fast paced sax solo oriented number with Monk's piano building up harmony just behind the main rhythms. There are many alternate takes here. "Evonce" presents two versions-the former a lot instrumentally fuller than the later while "Suburban Eyes" only changes the arrangement a bit. "Thelonious" has an airier atmosphere with it's brush style drumming while "Off Minor" deals with a distinctively chorded mid tempo blues. "Well You Needn't","April In Paris" and "Introspection" take a similar rhythmic vibe and focus right in the melody of the piano. "In Walked Bud" is a very lyrical,horn conversation based number that swings and bounces along wonderfully.  A fast take on Gershwin's "Nice Work If You Can Get It" and the ballads "Ruby My Dear" and signature pieces "Monks Mood" and "Round Midnight" round out the compositions here. After talking more to people such as my father and friend Henrique about this man's playing style? Monk has a fantastic and nimble technical ability that he is presenting idiosyncratically. That really comes out in this collection. By presenting two takes of almost every song here? It really gives you an insight into the jazz icon's creative process as you'll here him,Art Blakey and every other musician on here developing ever more complete versions as they go. An excellent place to understand....well what made Monk the kind of musician he was.

Cannot tell you how many times I've located vinyl copies of this album crate digging in the discount bins over the years. Not being all that familiar with her recorded catalog? It was a record I continually avoided picking up. That is until earlier this year. Of course this was the third in what turned out to be a quintet of ever evolving albums that Nona Hendryx released in the 1980's. For this particular occasion? She came out with hard dance music pioneer Arthur Baker and Chic's bassist Bernard Edwards as two producers for this 1985 set. In this era of huge commercial blockbuster albums? Nona ended up doing so in the more creative end of the spectrum.  "Revolutionary Dance" is a rhythmically full,uptempo electro funk jam where each chorus is punctuated by melodically  horn charts. "A Girl Like That" is a pounding synth based dance rocker while the first part of the title track follows right in line with it musically-the second part later in the album being a more polyrhythmic funk oriented workout for a double sided attitude of the same musical coin. "I Need Love" is more of a mid tempo arena rocker along with the similar if somewhat more groovecentric "If Looks Could Kill (D.O.A)". "Rock This House" is a Stonsey rocker,appropriately featuring the lead guitar of Keith Richards while while the sleek and bright dance rocker of "Time" concludes the album.  In a lot of ways? This album embraces the dance/funk/rock hybrids that were becoming common with black female artists after the huge success of Tina Turner during this period. What this particular album possessed was an extremely strong rhythmic power as well as Nona's knockout musical personality. Basically everything amounts to the most Afrocentric and funky end of the freestyle dance movement that was becoming a major player in the mid to late 80's. Also this album helped to emphasize many elements of the upcoming "black rock" movement that was already beginning to gain some heat. So this album got it's musical juices flowing at warp speed from the get-go.

Throughout my adolescence? I continually heard the name of Nona Hendryx dropped in reference to being one of the most important and unsung female artists of the early 80's. It wasn't until sometime later did her history get present in the important context of groups-from her time as part of Labelle in the mid 70's to her membership in the expanded Talking Heads half a decade later. Managed to locate this album on vinyl a year or so again-with the CD reissue in and out of print faster than I could grab it. Produced by Bill Laswell and his band Material? This represents an important milestone in Nona's recorded career.  "I Sweat (Going Through The Motions)" mixes a brittle new wave dance beat with warm,round synthesizers and gospel/soul choral vocals. "Soft Targets" mixes live drums with various percussion effects and a bubbling,liquid bass and/or melodic rhythm guitar line. And this feeling continues on the life with call and response vocal exchanges and a deeply chugging guitar. That flavor extends into the more strident and rocking "To The Bone" while "Electricity" slows the same attitude down in tempo with a hard electro rock vibe. "Ghost Love" evokes a melodic digital dub type vibe with spacey backup vocals while "I Want You" closes with a strident post disco styled number.  One of the first things I really appreciate about this album is how instrumentally juxtaposed it is. The combination of synthesizers and drum machines with their live equivalents creates a potent blend of analog and digital musical elements. As for Nona herself? She was one of the most powerful vocalists in the soul/funk community of her era-bringing her hard,throaty pipes with immense passion on every one of these songs. All of these songs are based in funk-emphasizing country rhythms/percussive effects very heavily with a generally stripped down air about it all. In many ways? It's one of the best presented  and realized new wave funk styled albums of this particular year.

While researching the Commodores discography early on? This 1983 album was basically described as their very worse release. Looking back on it having heard the rest of their catalog? I can sort of understand why that might've been. The band were dealing with the departure of Lionel Richie. And following this album their bassist/second composer Thomas McClary would himself embark on a solo career. The witty back cover portrait showcases the band visually playing up common "Friday the 13th" type superstitions-playing up that many might consider this album unlucky and creatively cursed. Luckily? It's anything but,to me anyway.  "I'm In Love" opens the album with a new wave/West Coast style uptempo groove which continues with the almost Doobie Brothers like "Turn Off The Lights"-both superb opening pieces. "Nothing Like A Woman" is a mid tempo funk groove built around strong electric and synth bass forming a superb,creamy foundation. "Captured" is a (then) contemporary country pop ballad while "Touchdown" has a strong electro/boogie funk air about it. "Welcome Home" merges the heavy funk while at the same time continuing the West Coast vibe as "Ooo,Woman You" is a tough,guitar oriented rocker. The piano based quiet storm soul ballad of "Only You" concludes the album.  To tell the truth? This album is about as far away from the type of funk the Commodores were doing a decade or so prior to this as the human being is biologically to...the amoeba. Of course there'd already been a strong evolution in their sound since then as well. A good deal of this album is in fact more uptempo based than anything the latter day Richie era ones had been. Walter Orange and newcomer Harold Hudson trade off lead vocals here as well. Newer elements such as the already funk/soul based WC pop sound,the rockier sides of new wave and the electro sound are strong elements of this as well. So it's actually an excellent transitional album from one era of there's to another.

It was when I first started getting interested in the funk genre that I discovered the enormous contributions the Commodores made to it's salad days. Often referred to as Motown's kings of "Southern Funk"? They had a spectacular mid 70's period in that regard. Their first two albums were pretty much undisputed classics of the genre. By the end of 1975? The band were still very much in that framework,but were on the verge of a gradual change of direction that would bring them big commercial success,but divide some of their audience in time. The important thing about this album is just how much it established them as a strong instrumental powerhouse.  "Hold On",the shuffling "Free","Mary Mary","(Can I) Get A Witness" and "Gimme My Mule" are all squarely in the chunky bass/ guitar/Clavinet heavy uptempo funk that the band had already made their trademark sound at this particular point. "Sweet Love" is an interesting ballad as it bridges the soul oriented style of their earlier slow songs with the more pop flavored ones of their later years-this one with a jazzier twist about it. "Time" is a very melodic uptempo groove that has more of a Caribbean soul flavor with it's high pitched synthesizers trade offs leading the way. "Cebu" ends the album with a spacey,reverbed psychedelic type funk instruments with a great reverbed bass line.  Some years ago? I managed to pick up a cassette reissue of this album. And fast fell in love with it. That is,until it started to ware down with age. Even though it was recently issued on CD? Ended up picking up the original vinyl at a flea market recently,and must say the type of direct "united funk" the Commodores are throwing down here comes across beautifully in it's original format.  As it stands musically? This album is a superb companion piece to their first two albums. And also stands with what I consider to be a vital quartet of heavily funkified albums they put out between 1974 and 1976.

A decade and a half ago when I first moved in with my family where I am today? Was at a local salvage store where they had cassette tapes they were trying to unload. One of them was this 1983 album by the Temptations,of which I recognized the cover from a few years of crate digging. Much to my surprise? It became a favorite of mine during the early 2000's when I was still playing cassettes a lot. For years? There was not a sign of a CD issue for it. Until a European company,apparently famous for mastering from high quality vinyl finally put it back out earlier this year. Didn't even think-just ordered the copy and am happy to be able to review it after years of listening.  The title song opens the album-a brittle drum machine and synth bass led funk rocker that actually has a strong period Rolling Stones flavor in some of it's riffs-one of my favorite 80's songs by the Tempts actually. "Love On My Mind" is a post disco update of the classic style four part harmony mid tempo ballad they were so famous for while "One Man Woman" has a sleek Gap Band type groove about it. "Show Me Your Love" is an urban contemporary ballads while "The Seeker","Bring Your Body Here (Exercise Chant)" and the closing "Made In America" are all creamy boogie funk numbers. "What A Why To Put It" meanwhile is an intense,bass heavy groove ballad.  One of the chief complaints I've heard about this album over the years was that the producer Dennis Lambert was obsessed with the lead singer Dennis Edwards,and essentially turned this into a solo album for him. From where I'm siting? This album is actually no different than any other Temptations record recorded from the 70's onward: the focus is more on one lead voice and the harmonies of it's members. Another thing it really brings out is how successful it brings the group into the new wave/electro/boogie era-with hefty funk grooves and dance rockers being the order of the day on this album. Even though it doesn't get much notoriety? I highly recommend Temptations admirers give this a listen.

In terms of music and the groups own lineup? The Temptations have always been defined by peaks and valleys. This was particularly prominent in the 70's-when members and hit songs were coming and going so fast it was hard to tell what was happening. Even with such a chaotic period? The Tempts were always able to carry on with incredibly high creative standards. For this very early 1975 release? Producers Jeffrey Bowen and James Anthony Carmichael bought in both The Commodores and P-Funk's Eddie Hazel And Billy Bass Nelson to really thicken up the stew of the by this point already iconic Motown group's evolving sound.  "Happy People" starts out the album with intensely powerful dance funk-powered by round bass synthesizers and chugging rhythm guitars. "Glasshouse" has a similar element though with a straighter gospel/soul dance approach led by some stomping piano.  "Shaky Ground" really allowed for a major united funk era hit for them-with it's tough,slippery bass line,horn accents and slow crawling rhythms. "The Prophet" and "I'm A Bachelor" are both sumptuously orchestrated cinematic funk-the former dealing with the more positive aspects of Christian philosophy. Of the ballads the title song and the closing "Firefly" find their beauty in subtlety while "Memories" deals with grander arrangements.  Have to really agree with everything I've ever read and heard about this album. It really was their finest album length moments of the mid 70's. Even though many of the members might not have themselves agreed with this? But by sticking primarily to uptempo funk based songs,this album really allowed for each of it's members vocal ranges to cross paths in so many rhythmically and melodically powerful ways. Now before I picked up this CD? Already had three of it's songs on their big box set. Even so? Anyone whose heard the hits from this should still seek this album out as a whole because it's only that really matters in a very funky sort of way!

Forty five years ago today? Janis Joplin sadly joined the 27 club. At the time it was probably tragic-especially with also losing Jimi Hendrix the same year. Looking back on it from today? Well every raspy blues oriented female rock singer whose come along has basically siphoned Janis's own vocal cross marriage of Bessie Smith,Etta James and Tina Turner. This album was so iconic that when I first of it? Never actually occurred to me that it was a totally posthumous release. Happily it seemed that a lot of great musicians,producers and engineers got this together so well? Turns out she didn't quite make it to reap the success of what turned out to likely be her definitive album.  "Move Over" opens the album with a pounding,uptempo mixture of rock 'n soul with a melody straight out from the most gut bucket of 12 bar blues. "Cry Baby" is probably one of the most musically and vocally theatrical ballads she ever made while  "My Baby","Trust Me","Get It While You Can" and more so "A Woman Left Lonely" tone down the same musical impulse- with more soulful organ on the latter. "Half Moon" is driving,percussive guitar and piano funk/rock while whereas "Buried Alive With The Blues" really brings the busy uptempo psychedelic soul right back home "Me And Bobby McGee" throws down a country soul classic from Kris Kristofferson. "Mercedes Benz" is a particually acapella melody that rounds out the original album.  For bonuses we get live,fast and furious takes on Etta James' "Tell Mama","Try Just A Little Bit Harder" along with "Cry Baby" and "Little Girl Blue" just bringing down the house with it's eternal choruses. All that included? This really is an amazing album. One of the best parts of it is,while her screaming intensity is what made her as a singer? Janis Joplin sings a good deal of this music pretty dead straight for the type of artist she was. That's matched with material that is far fuller realized in the soul/rock/country vein than anything she'd ever done in the psychedelic era. While it was an end as opposed to the new beginning it was meant to be? I can see how inspirational this album could be in all this time for sure.

When I very first heard Janis Joplin singing on a clip from the Ed Sullivan Show? She came at me within the context of a soul/blues shouter right out of the box. Since then? I heard her music discussed in more of a rock context as the lead singer of Big Brother & The Holding Company. First time I heard of this album,her final release of the 60's? It was described in a music review book as being a messy soul album. It was the second of those three words that instantly caught my attention. It wasn't until several years after that I finally got a chance to hear it on this CD (well another copy of someone else at the time) to form my own opinion about it.  With it's mid-tempo percussive groove and countrified rhythm guitar,"Try (Just A Little Bit Harder)" brings the slick yet stomping Southern funkiness into the mix right away. "Maybe" is in a similar vein-only in a ballad mode with climactic choruses and hot horn charts that reveals itself yet again on a version of Nina Simone's "Little Girl Blue","Work Me Lord" and the somewhat rockier title song. "One Good Man" and "To Love Somebody" are both pretty straight up power blues workouts. "As Good As You've Been To The World" is a uptempo gospel/soul raveup whereas the bonus track "Dear Landlord" adds more blues to that same framework.  Two live versions-first a Woodstock version of "Summertime" and another version of "Piece Of My Heart" with an improvised spoken intro complete this set. Because of Joplin's ability to cross between a scaling interpreter to craggy throated squaker at a moments notice? The only thing I could personally wish from the original album is more uptempo tunes because the ones that are hear are...frankly pretty incomparable in her catalog. The ballads are all excellent of course. Basically it all comes out sounding like a Stax production with the Kozmic Blues Band's much more raggedy rhythm section playing along with her. It's combines rawness and sweetness with a heavy dose of funk. And is very likable to me.

It's been seven years since Michael Jackson passed away. During those years? His youngest and (by the end closest) sibling Janet has been totally silent in terms of new studio material. Being a longtime Jackson family admirer? It did all seem to me like an ending. Wasn't hearing a peep out of anyone in the family. My own observations of her post 1990's music is similar to my friend Henriques. They all had excellent music. But sometimes contemporary ideas from newer producers just gave her a lot of blander material. The most exciting thing about this album isn't actually the happy comeback-that's second. First off is her reuniting fully with Jam & Lewis. And I would think that sent her off and running for this one!  "Unbreakable" begins the album with a sample heavy mid tempo new funk style while Missy Elliot,also returning herself for this album,brings her classic Afrocentric EDM style uptempo sound into the mix. "Dammn Baby" a bassy electro funk jam while "The Great Forever" brings in a brittle shuffle into the mix. "Shoulda Known Better" is a contemporary orchestral pop number whereas "After The Fall" is a more ambient ballad. "Broken Hearts Heal" is a stripped down post disco/boogie style number whereas "Night" embraces the chill house style-with a full on Minneapolis style synth horn funk breakdown on the finale. "No Sleep" is a sticky,mid tempo steppin groove with rapper J.Cole.  "Dream Maker/Europhia" is a more electro/hip-hop styled number while "2-B Loved" deals with a melodically/rhythmically thick twin city funk yet again whereas "Take Me Away" has a folk/rock/drum n bass hybrid. "Promise" is a sweet and slow Brazilian bossa while "Lessons Learned" and "Well Traveled" both have more pronounced modern country flavors. "Black Eagle" raises in tempo with it's jingling,light percussive sound reflects the pleas for love and peace in the lyrics. "Gon' Be Alright" is a fantastic way to end the album-with a thick and live rock 'n soul styled uptempo jam out of the late 60's Sly & The Family Stone school-complete with lead and bass vocal trade offs.  One of the qualities I've enjoyed of Janet's vocals in the last decade or so is how she's dropped into her lower range. It has actually grown to expand on her tonal vocabulary as well as the general power of her voice. With only a few nods to sounding at all modern in the pop sense? This album finds the artist in just the right place to realize who she is,and what her sound is. Since the 80's synth/electro/boogie funk sound has become a staple of modern grooves again? The sound Janet and her producers coined almost 30 years ago is finally being realized for it's vitality. In many ways? This is possibly Janet's strongest album since the turn of the millennium. And for me anyway,a very welcomed comeback.

Always personally felt that Joe Jackson was excellent at exercising his ability to create music rather uniquely. Of course being that he's recorded and toured fairly consistently since the beginning of his career? There's no way that I could explore every single album and musical period  of his. And that counts his salad days in the 1980's as well. After his wonderful tribute to Duke Ellington last time out? Seems that Jackson recorded his latest studio set across four different locations: New York,Amsterdam,Berlin And New Orleans. Not to mention bringing in local musicians,most unknown to me for the sessions-including Bill Frissell and Regina Carter. So this is all set to draw his listeners right in from the get go.  The album begins with the NYC sessions-starting with the classic jazzy pop piano ballad title song that extends very nicely into the more uptempo and upbeat "If It Wasn't For You". "See No Evil",one of two covers,has a dense modern rock flavor while "King Of The City" has a lightly percussive electric piano driven sound. The horn and violin pop/rock of "A Little Smile",the modern classical opera approach of "Far Away",the slow jazz bossa of "So Far Away" and the almost African high life/British pop hybrid of "Poor Thing" round out the Amsterdam sessions. The glam rock of "Junkie Diva",the hard prog of "If I Could See Your Face",the more ambient "Blue Time" and the albums next cover in 1938's Cabaret styled "Good Bye Jonny" round out the Berlin sessions.  The shuffling pub power blues of "Neon Rain",the Caribbean jazz-pop styled "Satellite",the lightly funky "Keep On Dreaming" and the West Indies percussion styled "Ode To Joy" close out the album's part made in the Crescent City. While I always like the idea of recording an album in different locations? Jackson not only selected already very musical cities to record in,but it goes with the lyrical themes. These songs basically express the yearnings,uncertainties and self observations of an artist whose done and seen much-and seems to feel much regret in the end. The majority of the lyrics are rather depressing as a result. It's why I personally deducted one star off the review. But being a Joe Jackson album?
