It's filled with his signature sound and loads of celebrating musical diversity.

Technically speaking? I've already given a partial review to this album as part of an older CD twofer with it's own followup. What I didn't know until later was that as with many double record collections of that sort? Tracks were omitted in order to fit them both on one CD. And this had the fullest of the missing songs-the other being a reprise from the next one. About a year ago? I located the complete album on the original gatefold vinyl. Especially now with the sad passing of founding Crusader Wilton Felder? I wanted to actually give this entire album it's own separate review. Every album this group ever did deserves at least that from it's listeners from where I sit anyway.  The album opens with "Soul Shadows"-one of those songs that feels as if I've listened to it for years with it's slow Caribbean jazz shuffle ,bluesy rhythm guitar/bass and always wonderful lead vocals from Bill Withers. "Honky Tonk Struttin'" is squonking sax based funk delight-set even more on fire by the clanking percussion of Sheila E. "Elegant Evening" and the title song are both excellent examples of the liquid slow ballad flow that the Crusaders do so consistently well. "Last Call" is a very melodic mid-tempo,lightly Brazilian inflected jazzy pop number again led by sax. "Sweet Gentle Love" is that missing track-a gentle acoustically textured ballad with a strong bluesy flavor.  Recently my friend Henrique was explaining to me the advantages of bands like The Crusaders having three composers in the band. Each of them could switch off so,if one was lacking in inspiration another could chime in with one of their songs. Again it's that iconic sense of musical chemistry that really makes this album work. By the time 1980 here rolled around? Each of these three members and coalesced into that "fine wine" type of creative aesthetic where they all new how to make their sound work every time. There's great music here for cruising,late night romance and funky stuff for getting down. It's one of their classics and superb way to begin the 1980's for them.

It would be difficult for me how many times I'd heard the name of Phil Woods name dropped by various jazz lovers over the years. When the news reached me a couple days ago that he'd passed away? The name was interestingly more recognizable to me than the music-of which I'd actually heard none. My friend Henrique and I have been having a lot of talks about the importance of celebrating iconic musicians while they are still alive. Sadly that's a chance I never had with Mister Woods here. But while people die? Their different arts of course create a sort of immortality for them. It was my father who took this out of his collection and recommended I hear it. It was time worth spent.  The first side of the album includes two extended pieces in "Chromatic Banana" and "Ultimate Choice". These are both very rhythmically and melodically abstract numbers. Some of the instrumentation veers off into off kilter,almost raggedy harmonic solos now and then. "The Last Page Sans Melodie" is my favorite here as it structurally veers from hyper-melodic saxophone with an funky electric piano twist into a swinging be-bop rhythm. After the percussive,flute led Afro-Brazilian romp of "A Look Back" the album concludes with "The Day When The World" is another  great example of improvised jazz/funk with a strong melodic phrase.  Nothing on this album lacks vigor and excitement. And as many people have already written? Woods' instrumental resemblance to Charlie Parker is very prominent-especially his abstract improvising on the chords of the song. And on that level? That's the only thing that makes this album just a tad less than what it could be. With the wonderful Gordon Beck on keys,announced humorously by the bands children at the end of the album? It all really works better on the second side when the rhythm section is in clearer focus. The more avant garde musical touches on the first two songs won't hold every listeners attention very well. But still not a bad place for me to first hear this man's music at all.

About a couple decades ago? I was readying an illustrated record of Michael Jackson. It mentioned this album specifically,and his participation in it. Up until that time? I never thought of Johnny Mathis as someone still making music up through the mid 1980's. How wrong I was. The man had never stopped going from his beginning up to the point. Just the notoriety of the music itself seemed to vary. This came from a period that seemed pretty successful for the man. Over the years? Probably passed it by on vinyl a number of times. Finally located a cassette of it that was in excellent shape. And from then on was very excited to hear what it had to offer.  "Simple" beings the album with a piano,horn and vocal choir heavy R&B/jazz-pop shuffle groove while the creamily orchestrated ballad "Love Won't Let Me Wait" again pairs him with Deniece Williams. Similar musical ideas show up on "Lead Me To Your Love". "The Best Is Yet To Come" again has that bouncing rhythm guitar heavy jazzy pop uptempo sound. The melodically complex mid tempo duet with Angela Bofill on "You're A Special Part Of Me" is tempered by the thickly rhythmic funky pop of the MJ composed "Love Never Felt So Good. "Priceless" and "One Love" are both climactic ballads with "Right Here Right Now" builds from slower refrains into stomping choruses.  Overall Johnny Mathis is in tremendous form here vocally? Musically,the album has a very strong Al Jarreau flavor. Which makes perfect sense since he has apparently cited Mathis as a huge influence on his singing style. Again having not followed the man's career before this consistently? It's interesting for me to here him singing songs with this particular type of production and in this particular sort of genre. But doing so is teaching me not only more about this artist. But also about how someone with as distinctive a style as him can keep the flow with what's going on the given time and still sound totally like himself. Superb album from a vocal icon.

For as long as I can remember? I've always had the utmost respect and admiration for the musical career of Johnny Mathis. He's always proven himself professional,adaptable and extremely consistent with the ever changing nature of the popular song. Over the years? Seen this album during my many vinyl digging sessions at the local Goodwill. Since so many people wanted to get rid of it? Avoided picking it up for sometime. That is until one day I realized what could be so wrong with singular vocal talents like Johnny and Niecy together in the late 1970's?  It's a wonderful example of how sometimes a second guess can lead you in the right direction.  There are three big Motown numbers here-two of which that were famoud duets to begin with starting with a slightly faster version of "You're All I Need To Get By" and a heavily orchestrated "Heaven Must Have Sent You". Stevie Wonder's "Until You Come Back To Me" is given a strong,liquidy mid tempo groove with some chiming electric pianos. "You're A Special Part Of My Life","I Just Can't Get Over You",'Touching Me With Love" and "Me For You,You For Me" are in a similar rhythmic and melodic vein-only with a more percussive flavor-perfect for Johnny's vocal approach. "Ready Or Not" is a bouncing disco friendly number with a pronounced Caribbean uptempo shuffle to it.  "That's What Friends Are For" has a similar upbeat tempo but more soulful air while a version of "Just The Way You Are" is pretty instrumentally faithful to the original. In terms of the album as a whole? These are an excellent mix of original and interpretations. Being that I listen to a lot of music? I haven't had the fortune to be able to explore the breadth and progression of Johnny Mathis's music over the years. But this album seems to find him squarely in the area of a soul/R&B crooner. Along with a lady whose understanding of that idiom,coming out of gospel is pretty renowned. It's an excellent pairing filled with quality material. Especially for those who enjoy Johnny's soul/pop period.

Here's a wonderful example of how one particular discovery led directly into others. After my discovery of this artist? I ended up ordering this albums predecessor and picking up this then new release right along with it. Of course looking at it tonight? It really showcased how music continues to be the key thread connecting myself and Henrique  as friends. And what a great thing that is because a band he also introduced me to,the excellent jazz/funk quartet of Butcher Brown,are Mister Payton's accompanists on these dozen individually number-titled compositions. Honestly didn't know exactly what to expect. And very glad I just went right into this expecting quality,expressive musical talent.  "Two" beings the album with a drum/electric piano based groove that builds in intensity throughout while "Three",my favorite song on the album is a stripped down jazz/funk/pop with that great low,brittle rhythm guitar and classic urban early morning flavor I love. "Four" brings in a heavy wah wah,deep Rhodes and clavinet oriented sound to a more bubbly groove while "Five" goes for more of a straight ahead fusion/funk samba shuffle-which shows up without the Latin flavor on the slower tempo "Eight"."Six" goes for the intense,James Brown sounding jazz/funk jam whereas "Seven" is another spare piece-this time built on a mid tempo ballad with subtle bass/guitar interaction. That continues on the slower paced "Nine" and "Ten" as well.  "Eleven" and "Twelve" both go more for the JB shuffle yet again whereas the delayed jazzy pop rhythm of "Thirteen" concludes the album. Odd thing I noticed with this album is that many online reviews seem to give it the same sort of flack the major writers/critics gave to Miles Davis and his many proteges when the jazz/funk fusion genre was first starting. In this case focusing more on Payton neglecting his horn. From what I'm hearing? This is an artist who is extremely functional both as a DIY type multi instrumentalist as well as a bandleader as he is here. Focusing on playing the Rhodes piano allows him to lay a superb rhythmic foundation for the very live sounding funk and jazz/rock fusion instrumentals that populate this album. So from where I sit? Nicholas Payton is really going to some fantastically funky places musically.

One of the things I've come to learn over the years is despite the modern ethic that seems to only reduce society down to the individual? Their are actually very few multi instrumentalists in the music world-who aren't just playing a lot of keyboards. And there are even fewer such musicians yet who have a horn as part of their repertoire. The Crescent City's own Nicholas Payton is among the latter. His music was introduced to me through my friend Henrique-a key inspiration for many of my recent musical discoveries. It was actually not easy to track this fairly new album down less than a year ago. Now that I have and listened to it? I'm finding words are inadequate to describe what happens here musically.  "By My Side" is a mixture of powerful Clavinet/bass synthesizer and otherworldly processed lead vocals with a rolling old school electro/hip-hop beat-something that shows up in a similar fashion on the shuttering "The Second Show (Adam's Plea","Flip The Script" later in the album, whereas "Freesia" has a breezy Brazilian rhythm and electric piano for a cosmically jazzy number. "Shades Of Hue" takes a similar idea into a melodically powerful ballad area whereas "Truth Or Dare" combines an extremely phat mix of electronics with Payton's trumpet and vocals. "Togetherness,Foreverness" has a loping,delayed neo soul rhythmic flavor where "Indigo" has a straight up,brittle beat jazz/funk swing to it. "Love And Faith" has a clean jazz pop shuffle about it  while "Flip Thee Script"" Don't I Love You Good" and "iStole Your IPhone" are just plain rhythmically unique.  "You Take Me Places I've Never Been Before" is an electronic blues delight with Cassandra Wilson on board while the organ fueled gospel/soul ballad "Give Live,Live Life,Love" and the digitized swing of the title song end off the album. With many albums in the funk genre? Some are diverse,others stay firmly on their variation of the one. This album is definitely in the former category. If such a term could apply to this. If I had to give this album any sort of a musical label at all? It would be as if Stevie Wonder and Omar Lye Fook came together to record with Lonnie Liston Smith & The Cosmic Echoes. The rhythms are full of a hard groove,the melodies are soaring and the electronic keyboards create many unique sounds. It's among the most beautifully funky albums I've ever heard in my life actually!

One main reason that I've been hesitant in purchasing that much new music this year,in addition to space issues in my living area,has a lot to do with a seeming lack of quality control. Specifically a lot of artists who have spent the last half decade being more rhythmically exploratory have retreated and basically given up on the funk. When viewing new releases here? This reminded me that it was just about time for a new release by Jeff Lorber. In terms of commitment to that strong groove? This man and his band(s) always deliver. So considering my recent (and unfortunate) extended musical lag? Felt this would provide just the aural vibes I'd want flowing through my ear holes right now.  "Get Up" sets off the album in a straight forward bass/horn led groove with a bluesy rhythm guitar lick. "Up On This" is a more percussive number where the entire instrumentation stutters along into sassy and melodic refrains. "Mustang" and the fast paced "Right On Time" bring in a piano/Rhodes based shuffle while "Fire Spirit" really gets some more jazzy scaling harmonics into the mix. "Arecibo" brings in Robben Ford to really turn up the funkiness to it's maximum proportions and the band itself and this idea basically extends itself into "Starfish","Deep Green","Soul Party" and the hefty groove of the closing title track. "Tenth Victim" meanwhile takes a slower crawling ballad outlook on this sound.  Every album I've heard Jeff Lorber,with or without the Fusion,make in the past decade or so have all been excellent. One thing this particular release brings out is that he has officially joined Steely Dan,Boz Scaggs and The Crusaders as among the "fine wine" style jazz/funkers. Their grooves have reached a level of fluidity and strength that allow it to work on many levels: whether it be casual at home listening,driving music or just dancing away the blues all night. And as far as my own personal intent with this album? With every ounce of it's instrumentation jamming very heavily on the one? This one truly reaches out to lick the listeners funkiest emotions.

For two years in a row? Herb Alpert made what was for me a very happy comeback-basically recording originals and standards in a modern setting that's still true to his classic melodic and rhythmic ideas. The two albums released up to that point both had musically sunny dispositions and enormous revelation in the groove. So it was much to my delight when,a few weeks ago I discovered that he was releasing a third album in this series. Seems to be somewhat of an artist of runs and pauses over the many decades-in terms of full length releases that is. After listening to this one? Can only hope there will at least be a couple more like this to follow up on.  The title song that opens the album is an uptempo Brazilian groove that's both featherweight in melody but thick in rhythm that continues on "Sweet And Lovely" and "Night Ride" later in the album. "Blue Skies" has a folksy ska flavor while "Got A Lot Of Livin' To Do" really goes for the ethereal end of Cuban jazz. "Cheeky" brings in the steel drums and flute to extend on this carnivalesque musical vibration while the tempo of "Take The "A" Train is bought down to a slow swinging attitude-the same treatment "Something" gets as well. "Love Affair" is orchestrally heady modern classic piece whereas "Windy City" has a gentle pop jazz flavor. "Walkin' Tall" is a straight up reggae number while the dixieland stomp of "On The Sunny Side Of The Street" and the torchy "Danny Boy" conclude the album.  Overall this album completes a triad of excellent 2010's releases from Herb Alpert. It does have it's own uniqueness about it however. Of these albums,this one is by far the most live band oriented and really embraces Alpert's strong Latin musical influences on many different levels. One famous jazz quotes that stays in my head was Jelly Roll Morton having said that without the "Spanish tinge",one didn't have the right seasoning for jazz. Therefore this album takes a bit of a journey through all of the different tributaries on that level of America's improvisational music form. While this may be the last we hear from the man for awhile? Hoping this particular musical winning streak of his continues for a little bit longer anyway.

While I have several of the 1990's big soul/R&B/funk box sets in my music collection? I've found them very daunting to review here because of the breadth of what they are presenting. The story with this started a couple of years ago when my father purchased the complete Atlantic sessions of Ray Charles pre-owned at a time when I just couldn't swing it. Now just about a month ago? I was at a second hand store in nearby Old Town and notice this career spanning set-all shrink wrapped and never opened for $10. It was simply too much to resist. And almost too much music to comprehend. But glad I did because it's still having a profound effect as I'm writing this.  The first two songs on disc 1 of these are direct from vinyl-both jump blues style numbers before the man really found it his voice. Then we get into his classics such as the gospel/blues drenched "I Got A Woman","Hallelujah I Love Her So",instrumentals such as "Rockhouse" and the ultra groove "What'd I Say". Disc two keeps it right on going with "Let The Good Times Roll","Georgia On My Mind",the stomping rendition of "Hard Hearted Hannah","Hit The Road Jack" as well as his two famous songs recorded with Betty Carter. Disc 3 concentrates on his country excursions and orchestral ballad projects on his own Tanger.ine Label-along with cinematic grooves such as "The Cincinnati Kid" and the deeply soulful "Let's Go Get Stoned".  Disc 4 is probably the most interesting to me as it contains a lot of heavily funky soul numbers such as "In The Heat Of The Night","Look What They've Done To My Song,Ma","I Don't Know What Time It Was" and in particular "If It Wasn't For Bad Luck" with Jimmy Lewis. After his famous rendition of "America The Beautiful" there is a hidden track of his first early 70's Coke commercial. Disc 5 begins the same way with a thick electric piano driven funk rendition of Stevie Wonder's "Living For The City" and eventually takes jump cuts to his country duets with Willie Nelson,George Jones and Hank Williams Jr. all the way to the soulful  "Shake Your Tail Feather" done for the Blues Brothers movie. Of course there's his new jack duet with Chaka Khan on "I'll Be Good To You" as well as versions of "A Song For You" and "Still Crazy After All These Years".  There are dozens of excellent songs presented here I just didn't have time to mention in this review. But it still ranks high in presentation and song selection what the best box sets should do. It features all the hits,in their full length versions and presents everything in chronological order. It feels like the listener is musically progressing with the man as he goes right along.  Even though it's always been made clear to me that Ray Charles had a vastly diverse musical palette he worked with? This really emphasize how much he allowed his own connective thread of soul to show so brightly down very other stylistic tributary he explored. You know it's him from the start,and by the end. And therefore if anyone wants to get a thorough dose of what made this artist what he was and to soul music? This is an easily recommended place to go for that!

As with a lot of people with only a casual awareness of his career? I basically had it in mind that by the late 70's,Ray Charles was a country/pop balladeer who had long left anything closely related to soul/R&B behind him. Not only is that not the case. But kept me from understanding something very important about this period of his. His career on Atlantic in the late 50's is music history. Seldom is it acknowledged about his return to the label that mad him famous with this 1977 release. It's something I wanted in my vinyl collection for awhile now. And about a year or so ago finally picked it up. It was a musical investment that I'm growing more happy with over time.  "I Can See Clearly Now" starts out the album-taking the pop/reggae of the original into a more uptempo funky soul direction. "The Jealous Kind" and "Heavenly Music" both have jazzy electric piano mid tempo references while "Anonymous Love" is a horn,percussion and organ fueled cinematic soul groove. My personal favorite number here is "Game Number Nine"-a straight up bluesy synth funk number in the vein of Billy Preston's "Wide Stride" of the same vintage and full of Ray's renowned storytelling. "Oh What A Beautiful Morning","How Long Has This Been Going On" and "Let It Be" zero in on his swinging bluesy soul balladry while "Be My Love" brings the big orchestras into play for a similar tempo.  Because of the vast amount of albums he tended to make? It's not hard to understand why so many of Ray Charles' studio sets remain out of print today. Yet with some such as this,it's hard to imagine how they specifically got overlooked in that regard. In this case? We have nine songs that just about perfectly tie together everything the man had done musically for the past decade or so before. Especially in terms of his complete melodic and rhythmic re-invention of standards. Also there's some serious late 70's jazz and/or funk elements here that work wonderfully at modernizing Ray's particular approach to music. So it's a very strong late 70's offering from the man.

Sometimes it's difficult for me,of a specific generation to imagine a time when it was very common for some popular artists to record upwards of two or three albums a year. Seems that's basically how Ray Charles spent the mid to late 60's when looking at his discography. He was actually recording on his own label. That was something very few black artists in particular were doing in his day,and along with Sam Cooke they were leading the way in that regard. This album was recorded by an artist who was about to transition into yet another of his many stylistic periods. And as something of a conclusion to this one? It's not too bad.  On this particular album the strings and more easy listening rhythmic elements are in place from song to song. Especially from most of what I've heard of him of this period. Ray's singing here is also a bit more by rote than I'm personally used to hearing from him. "Love Is Here To Stay" is another one of his trademark bluesy soul piano shuffles sung with his equally renowned distinctive power. From some on and offline reading I've done? There are mixed feelings about whether this period was musically healthy for Ray Charles. What really matters is how he felt since he was in complete control of these albums. It was an important stage of development for him. And a nice listen,especially if one's in the right mood for it.

Looking back from a time remembering Ray Charles being very much alive and active? It really fascinates me not just how prolific the man was in his prime,but also how much he innovated in terms of being an album artist. Following the formation of his own Tangerine Records? He released a long series of album length sets of standards-many of them following a loose conceptual thread. Being the great storyteller that he was? He had the creative energy to make unrelated songs seemed like they always belong together when putting them together in this way. And that even goes for album such as this without any obvious connective elements to them.  The majority of this album consists slow ballads that are heavily orchestrated with strings and horns. The songs that stand out musically in this setting are the big band uptempo romp of "You Made Me Love You (I Didn't Wanna Do It" and "Gee Baby,Ain't I Good To You"-a slow swinging piano blues/soul number. There's also the shuffling country soul of "Here I Go Again". Vocally what gets me most about this album is on songs like "Love Walked In",Ray sang in a breathy high falsetto voice. It's something he does quite a lot here,and a vocal style I seldom heard him sustain as much as he does on this album. It's the genius at his most vulnerable sounding. The fact there's still a strength behind it says numbers for his creative sensibilities.

For most of my teens? This particular album was part of my internal "discount special" list. It was always a cutout CD everywhere I went during the mid/late 90's. Which usually meant it was a comeback album for a veteran act of middling to decent success. At least,that's what I was expected to think at the time. Have learned since it's a far more complex situation than that. In actuality? This album was a reunion between Nile Rodgers and Bernard Edwards-reforming Chic with new instrumentalists and singers to accompany them about a decade after they originally split apart. The only thing I'd even read about it was that it was a good place to get new disco songs. Again,time has offered a new perspective.  "Chic Mystique","Your Love" and "Something You Can Feel" all add an early 90's production sheen to the classic funkified disco groove that the band pioneered. On the other hand songs such as "Jusagroove","One And Only One",the wah wah fueled "In It To Win It" and the fast,live oriented title song are all much more in the heavier boogie funk style primary-with thicker drumming and rhythm in general. "Doin' That Thing To Me" and "Take My Love" are both in their classic ballad style in every sense of the word. "My Love's For Real" and "High" both add a more brittle hip-hop/funk beat to the sound while "M.M.F.T.C.F" concludes the album with the phattest funk here.  Cannot say why exactly? But I seem to remember this album for exactly what it wasn't: a very programmed pop/house style album. That has nothing to do with the rhythms here,which are mostly live drum oriented. It has to do with that production update I talked about earlier. By the time this album dropped? Music was being fully digitally recorded and mixed. The punchiness that analog recordings had were replaced by often thinner sonic's audible to even non audiophiles. That is the case with this album. Musically? It not only updates their sound but also showcases how much their original music lived on in the many tributaries of acid jazz and dance-pop this album embraced. And it doesn't hurt they really turned up the funk here either.

It's really funny to me now how growing up? I somehow managed to totally separate Nile Rodgers as an artist and a producer. Grew to understand him thoroughly as both. Yet it wasn't until adulthood that I began to see him musically outside of his role within the Chic Organization. This was his first solo album from 1983. The same year that his original band ended their seven year run. For a long time? It was extremely difficult to locate on vinyl. And a CD format was unheard of. That all changed about six years ago when two different labels reissued it right around the same time. I feel extremely luck to have gotten a hold of it now,and be able to give it a thorough listen.  The title song and "Yum Yum"-with it's slamming synth bass,digital bells and call & response vocal leads are both ultra thick grooves on the funkiest side of the post disco dance sound. "Beet" is a stripped down new wave rocker while "Get Her Crazy" and "Rock Bottom"  really focus right on hard on the phat rhythm guitar sound that Rodgers had made his trademark long before this. "It's All In Your Hands" has more of an electro funk style drum pattern while "My Love Song Is For You" is the lone ballad-essentially a slow burning funk groove. "Most Down" ends the album with a JB style shuffle that again adds that slippery synth bass.  Coming into this? I expected this to be a very strong album. And it lived up to that expectation in more than one way. Disco music could be a number of things at it's core. For Nile Rodgers? It was funk. In this case very conceptualized too. The nautical map on the cover is an excellent expression of what the album title has to say. The album still has the man's signature instrumental style and framework of rhythm. On the other hand? This is also where his more elastic style as a producer-embracing pop and rock styles meshes right together with the dance based approach he'd pioneered in the previous decade. So on that level? It's probably Nile's most important album thus far. And one I'd highly recommend for those looking for a healthy perspective on dance/funk of the early 80's.

Just taking a listen to the major breakthrough album that was Dare! was a year and a half before this? It was clear that a major part of the Human League's basic sound,outside their instrumental approach,was going to be soulful dance and funk music with a lot of strong melody. Honestly not a bad way to go when electronic pop music and what was used to create it was still in it's infantile state of development. While the band were recording their next full length album? They elected to extend on their new approach by releasing this six song EP during 1983. And it proved to be a major continual step in the right direction far as they were concerned.  "(Keep Feeling) Fascination" is my favorite song by this band-starting the album out in it's extended version and ending it on a re-edited and sampled improvisational mix. It's essentially a Sly & The Family Stone style vocal trade off between the groups male and female voices-right down to the bass singers part and instrumental breakdown. "Mirror Man" gets the uptempo percussion flavor of mid 60's Motown down perfectly for an equally strong number while the danceable "I Love You Too Much" and the dramatic mid tempo rocker "You Remind Me Of Gold" are more about electronic orchestrations. "Hard Times" is a brittle,funky dance number to round this out.  This EP is a superb extension on it's predecessor. The funk/soul influences on that album are actually the definition of most of this one. To talk a bit about my personal experience and having already reviewed the 45 for the title song? This really does remind me of my very first exposure to this band. And really got me to understand just what the UK new wave/synth pop movement really meant set against the post disco black music freeze out of early 80's America.  Seems that overseas? Groups like this were actually innovating on those ideas in new and technologically advanced ways. And that in a word describes the music found here.

Having been born when I was and seeing what pop music is based in today? It's sometimes hard for me to believe that the synth pop/new wave genre of music was completely unknown to the vast majority of people in the world. It's been a part of my life as long as I can remember. Yet to speak objectively? It seemed to be in England and Australia of 1981 that this entire movement really began to emerge from the underground. The Human League were a superb example of this. Having lost two key members after releasing a couple of more experimental electronic albums? The refashioned group decided to move onward's and more towards the people.  "The Things That Dreams Are Made Of" opens the album with a disco beat-accentuated by thumping synth bass. "Love Action (I Believe In Love" has a similar vibe,this time focusing on wonderfully played electronic string charts. "Open Your Heart",the abrasive "The Sound Of The Crowd" and the brittle "Seconds" all focus more on a pop/rock approach while "Darkness" comes out with a strong blue eyed soul attitude that continues on the very catchy hit "Don't You Want Me". "Do Or Die" has a percussive Brazilian funk flavor about it as "Get Carter" and "I Am The Law" are darker/more ambient ballads.  Included in this set is an EP by the "League Unlimited Orchestra" called Love & Dancing. It features mostly instrumental versions of the songs off the main album-in particular a version of "Don't You Want Me" that's pitched quite a bit higher. Not to mention "Hard Times"-essentially a bluesy soul/funk number. Taken as a whole all of these songs are excellent. And the synthesized instrumentation a popular revelation at the time-whereas a cult of people were familiar with the likes of Kraftwerk and such before,especially stateside. The fun part for me was being able to easily discern the other known genres of music amid the electronic musical approach. Funk,soul and disco were (as with most new wave) a huge part of this. And that would set the stage for what the Human League would become as they continued to evolve.

One of the things I noticed about Earl Klugh from the 1980's onward is that every other album or two? He'd tend to release a solo acoustic album. If I recall? That was the case before this release. Somehow assumed that this was another such recording. But it isn't by any means. It was recorded with Greg Phillinganes and a small group of musicians in tow for each song. I discovered this CD completely by accident-stopping at a Goodwill for a bathroom break and afterward briefly browsing the used CD's. Came across a number of them and this turned out to be one of them. Really had no clue what to expect. And am very happy I found out.  The gentle Brazilian pop/funk of "The Traveler",with it's shiny keys and thumping bass bookends the album with Part II being the closing track. Of course there's a great deal of musical progression between them as well. "Just For Your Love" is a slow shuffle R&B ballad featuring female choral vocals and the processed Rhodes piano sound I always love. "Second Chances" is a spare and melodically simple electro pop number with a nice round synth bass whereas "For The Love Of You" is a melodic mid tempo,orchestrated disco-pop groove. "Debra Anne","Santiago Sunset" and the albums sole acoustic number "Moon And The Stars" are all ballads concentrating on Klugh's guitar solos.  "Sandman" again returns to the percussive vibe of Rio in a very gentle way while "Return Of The Rainmaker" is my favorite here-a vast orchestral movement that veers some Latin guitar solos to huge string and horn filled swells for a heavy Spanish folk vibe overall. In many ways? This album is one of the most musically adventurous I've ever heard from this artist. The basic rhythm section is kept even more spare than usual for an Earl Klugh album. And the presence of the Chamber Ensemble adds an enormous and successful musical contrast to that. It has just about every element done in the best possible way for Klugh and is an album I'd recommend for anyone looking to get into one of his full length albums.

It was a cassette copy of the 1981 album Crazy for You that first got me listening to the music of Earl Klugh. At that particular time? Just about any album from that time frame that involved musicians such as Greg Phillinganes and Louis Johnson had my instant attention. Came to my attention shortly after that Mr. Klugh recorded quite a few albums in the company of these personnel. And this album is actually the follow up to the aforementioned one as well. It was difficult to locate on CD for years. And that was the format I wished to hear it in due to the sonically clean sounds of the musicians involved. Late last year I found it! And it's a happy musical event for me all around.  "Back In Central Park" opens the album with a breezy,uptempo Brazilian jazz-pop featuring the title song using choral vocalists. "If You Want To Be My Love" is an extremely powerful funk number-full of solo and ascending electric/synth bass tones interacting with the sauntering rhythms. The title song has a similar vibe to it-only with a smoother pop and R&B flavor about it with a hand clap and rhythm guitar fueled outro. "Just Like Yesterday" has the melody based,electric keyboard oriented mid tempo shuffle of a Ray Parker Jr. composition (though he didn't write it) while "If Your Still In Love With Me","I Never Thought I'd Leave You and "Christina" are all creamily orchestrated ballads.  'Night Drive" ends the album with  a slap bass heavily Brazilian jazz/funk attitude yet again-this time on the phatter end of the genre. As far as I'm concerned? This particular album is every bit the equal of it's predecessor. It even goes for blending some synthesizers into the production as more orchestral elements. Yet the core of the album remains very much on the clean end of that keeping it live instrumental spirit. And to quote Stevie Wonder? There's no way this band could lose? While I haven't heard all this man's music from the period? I would go as far as saying that the early 80's were surely some golden period for Earl Klugh.

Almost two decades ago now? My father purchased a CD celebrating a musical style referred to in it's title as Nuyerican Soul. One of the songs on that collection was an updated acid jazz version of the title song of this album,and along with other songs there it featured Roy Ayers. Had absolutely no idea who the man was until hearing that. And this began a voracious time of crate digging searching for music by the man that,during the mid/late 90's wasn't particularly easy to come by in my neck of the woods. It was actually earlier this year that I got a CD copy of this album-featuring the tune that started it all for me with this artist.  "Hey Uh-What You Say Come On","The Golden Rod","People And The World" and "It' Ain't Your Sign,It's Your Mind" are all intensely percussive Afro-Cuban jazz-funk jams full of beautiful harmonic passages,exciting compositional changes and otherworldly electronic melodies. "Keep On Walking",the mid tempo Salsa kjazzof "The Third Eye" and of course the dynamic title song are superb examples of funkiness taken it's slowest possible ballad tempos. "You And Me My Love","Tongue Power" and the comically romantic  closer "Lonesome Cowboy",dealing with the "urban cowboy gets married" theme are all thick,bassy hard funk-filled with horns and stomping drum breaks that  keep down the strongest groove possible.  Something about the mid 70's during which this was recorded just seemed to allow funkiness to be it's own lovely reward. Hearing this particular album now helps me understand the acid jazz/funk movement really pumping out of Europe during my teen years. The songs here have the funk and Afro Cuban rhythmic underpinnings that were always central to Roy Ayers sound. Yet he also bought in both lead and orchestral string synthesizers to add great melodic/harmonic color to the music. The way he uses them on this album? The do in fact have the aural impression of bright cosmic rays shinning through from the skies above into these grooves. This all combines to make this a very special 70's Roy Ayers album.

Years of listening have really helped me to appreciate how jazz,blues,soul,rock and Afrocentric world music's joined together in,so many combinations, under the banner of funk. Having been listening to Roy Ayers for a long time now? I see him as a major figure in showcasing this particular musical unification. Known about and seen this soundtrack for years. Finally decided to pick it up inexpensively on a reprinted,very high quality vinyl because...it just seemed like the right format sonically to enjoy what this particular album had to offer. Even though this is my second attempt at reviewing this? That little bit of time has added greatly to my original perspective.  "Coffee Is The Color" begins the album with a percussion and wah wah based uptempo groove with the vibes providing that jazzy melody. "Pricilla's Theme" starts out in a flute led bossa nova before going back to that same faster rhythm while "King George" is thick,Rhodes piano led hard funk that gurgles and churns. This extends itself throughout the album in different ways such as on the heavily melodic,stripped down "Brawling Broads" and the bluesy guitar drenched "Exotic Dance" as well as "King's Last Ride" with it's rocking wah wah. "Coffee Sauna","Shinning Symbol" and "Making Love" are all beautifully atmospheric ballads. That along with the beautifully arranged "Coffey Baby",featuring a talented young singer named Dee Dee Bridgewater.  "Aragon" and "Escape" return to the same uptempo,percussive flavor of the opener with the looser,more avante gard "End Of Sugarman" closes the album. Probably the most significant elements of these soundtrack that stands out for me (having not yet seen the film itself) is the juxtaposition of genres really catches onto the mood of the score itself. The softer,more melodic themes generally catch right onto the harmonic depth of jazz while the uptempo songs expressing actions tend to go for more rhythmic and uptempo styles. It's overall embrace of Afrocentrism to express the idea of the liberated black female action hero of Pam Grier make this a musical standout of the blacksploitation era.

With their previous album All In The Name Of Love.Atlantic Starr made the full transition into a band who were known for popular adult contemporary ballads than dance music. Of course that didn't mean they didn't stop making uptempo songs of the highest quality. Over the many years of CD browsing and vinyl crate digging? The 80's era Atlantic Starr albums have come up on this occasions again and again. This one showing up quite a lot more often than I expected for what I recently learned to be a relatively uncommon album. Turns out it's their final release of the decade. So thought it would literally follow up that predecessor as a good listen very well.  "Under Your Spell" opens the album with a heavy AC ballad which extends through "My First Love","My Sugar",the closer "You Deserve The Best" and the sentimental humanitarianism of "Friends". "I'm In Love With You","Woman's Touch" and "I Can't Wait" are more rhythmically climactic mid tempo numbers that emphasize heavy song craft and melodic progressions. "Love Ain't Fair" adds a chugging reggae flavor with a like minded Jamaican accent to the lead vocals. "Don't Star The Fire" and the title track meanwhile are very sleek,electronic and lightly funkified dance tracks which round off this album.  In many ways,this album is the exact opposite of what came before it. While it's two predecessors were basically heavy electro funk albums with a few pop ballads added to the mix? This album is primarily about slick quiet storm urban contemporary material. There isn't any kind of heavy grooves and stomps to deal with here. At the same time? The bands vocal,instrumental and composing abilities are so strong and well oiled by that this ended up being a culmination of their pop savvy rather than a mere end to it. Their hit period would come to an end after this album so it would seem. Yet they continued to put out new albums once and awhile. And this is a great way to conclude this period for them.

It feels wonderful to have already acknowledged Atlantic Starr as being the seriously strong album makers that they were quite awhile ago. It actually helped me to go back and finally pick up this album,which I did today. It's the most common one I've seen. And contains that song that introduced me to them in childhood. Because this did represent the culmination of a musical change in priorities for the band? Was a bit concerned if the entire content of this was going to be boring and bland. Yet already being aware of this albums fantastic predecessor As The Band Turns? Already had in mind to expect the happily unexpected. Turned out to be a good instinct to truth.  "One Lover At A Time","You Belong With Me","Females",the Maurice White produced "Armed And Dangerous" and "Let The Sun Shine In" are all beautifully crafted melodies with grooves that feature pumping synth/synth bass and rhythm guitar based stomps. With the addition of both real and electronic horns on occasion. "Don't Take Me For Granted" and the title song are themselves rhythmically climactic ballads that extends into the more cinematically flavored "Thankful and "My Mistake". "Always" of course finds that lovely middle ground between those two slow jam styles-that creamily orchestrated number that represents the first time I heard them. "I'm In Love" is a slinky mid tempo groove with the dynamic acapella of "Interlude" closes it all out.  Much in the same spirit of the Commodores a decade prior to this? These people started out as a larger band playing the harder and most danceable funk of the period. And in their later period became better known for their ballads. But in both cases? It really fascinates me how well both updated their more uptempo tunes. And this particular album is literally split right down the middle in terms of both musical styles. It really helped to showcase how much slow,singable romantic pop ballads had the potential to pull the listener towards the equally well crafted uptempo and symphonic soul to be found on the rest of this album.

Very recently,I congratulated my friend Henrique for a blog he did based on a constant conversation he and I have had about music. And it applies to this is well. Having come into my preteen years during the last half of the 80's? Both he and myself noticed that the dance music of that time began to tie period technology very well back into the fabric of heavy funkiness. I am very happy that I was able to experience the late Jermaine Stewart's major hit period as it was happening. Still only knew him wrongly as a one hit wonder. Having recently heard about this album? I located the used CD of this for under $5 earlier this year. And tonight decided to give it a listen.  "We Don't Have To Take Our Clothes Off" is the song that introduced me to this artist. And it's a great opener with it's well crafted melody,chugging rhythm guitar and singing horn accents. "Dance Floor" is built around several brittle bass synth accents and deep,sexual backup vocals while "Jody" has an extremely chunky,metallic rhythm and bluesy melody-some of the hardest funk I've heard from this era outside Minneapolis while "Versitile" and the title song both take the same musical idea and smooths it out just a bit more. "Out To Punish" is again based in JB style rhythm guitars while "Moonlight Carnival" adds a Afro Caribbean flavor to a fast electro/funk dance number. "Don't Ever Leave Me" and the closer "Give Your Love To Me" are both jazzy,soulful ballads.  A lot of people I know tend to look at this particular of dance music as being based more on "12 inch singles and extended club play. Yet listening to this? It's an wonderful album. Of course it's full on danceable-thematically reviving the sensitive masculinity somewhere between Thom Bell and Prince. With a help from Jermaine's own songwriting and the always able production of Narada Michael Walden? This album finds it's sense of rhythm through heavy funk-full of phat bottoms and often very fiery electronic elements. If one is looking for a superb example of how vital stomping funkiness was to 80's freestyle dance music? This is an excellent place to find that hybrid in great form!

What major factor that's helped me to realize just how much I've actually appreciated the disco era of the late 70's more than I thought I did? That would be the understanding that it was gay and/or black DJ's-people who really loved funky,danceable music who really pushed that particular period forward. As a vocalist and a performer? Sylvester here was in fact both of those things. Though he passed away when I was still a child? It was during that transition in life from my adolescence to adulthood that helped me understand just how significant this man was on a purely musical level as having been such a big personality.  "Dance (Disco Heat)","You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)","Stars","Body Strong" and "Can't Stop Dancing" are all gospel/soul four on the floor rave-up's filled with infectious,percussive energy and often very abstract Eurodisco bass synthesizer orchestrations. "I Need You" and the faster paced "Sell My Soul" are both more sleek early 80's boogie funk-both with strong melodies and somewhat phatter bottoms. "Cry Me A River" is an amazing,uptempo blues shuffle featuring the likes of John Tropea whereas a version of "Ooh Baby Baby" and the live clover "You Are My Friend",featuring the always outstanding Martha Wash represent the slow ballad end of the mans work.  With the strong production help from Motown alumni Harvey Fuqua? These eleven songs bring up a very interesting points about myself and greatest hits collections. Especially in the late 70's and early 80's? These sorts of collections,especially when focused on a single artist,can have the effect of making their sound come off as very one dimensional. To a certain extent? This one has the potential to do this as well. Where it overcomes this is where it shows just how during the 1977-1980 period in which these were recorded? Sylvester was actually showcasing the rhythmic linkages between black American gospel and African poly rhythms in his popular dance songs. Not only that but it even brings out his range and diversity. So where I'd normally go with a full length original album? This collection actually works quite well.

For the past five years? Something very unique has happened to me with this musical artist. I was reading about Dam Funk on and offline,discussing him with my friend Henrique,hearing his songs and having collaborations with him. And all without having even one of the man's many albums recorded under his own name. One of the factors of this year for me is that while the new music is not only hitting me the wrong way? But there seems to be a decided absence of funk behind it all. I have my theories why this is happening. But thankfully,looks like I'm not the only one because thematically this album actually addresses that very situation head on.  It starts out with a CB radio style transition from veteran P-Funker Junie Morrison about how music's future depends on our awareness of the funk. Such an incredibly profound statement,than on with the show. "We Continue","Somewhere,Someday","The Hunt Of Meat & Lucifer","It Didn't Have 2 End This Way","Acting" and "Virtuous Progression" blends the man's grand synthesizer orchestrations with percussive,stomping rhythms. "I'm Just Tryna Survive" with Q-Tip","Just Ease Your Mind From All Negativity" with Snoop Dogg as well as "Gldye 2nyte" with two generations of Leon Sylvers' are given the same treatment. "Floating On Air" is a more electronica/rock hybrid. Whereas "howugonfu*karoundandchoosebusta"  is a synth bass heavy funk stomp.  The police brutality/music industry metaphor of "Surveillance Escape" and the amazing,jazzy funk jam of "O.B.E" (perhaps my favorite here) round out the album. Overall this is just a flat out wonderful collection of songs. It points to something very important that I've been mulling over a lot lately. Dam Funk here is one of the few younger people to come out and choose heavy funk as their musical base over funk or commercial hip-hop. Boogie and P-Funk are of course his main influences,and he really lets them shine brightly. Also musically and thematically? He really knows how to stay right on the one-driving often topical points as well as humor into his music! Highly recommended nu funk classic to be!

Around a decade ago? My musical ears were all a buzz about a multifarious new artist named Lizz Wright. That's all it was to me though. Somehow never bothered to check out any of her music,and moved on to other things. It was less than a week ago that I learned that she was coming out with a brand new album. Considering that this year hasn't really produced any interest in people I'm more familiar with? I thought that this one,who is making her label debut on Concord, would be an excellent place to start with her music. And am honestly surprised with the actual content that emanated from this album.  "Freedom" begins the album with a rhythm guitar heavy funk groove with a strong Afro-Brazilian jazzy back beat while "Surrender" ends it with a slowed down retro southern soul ballad-book ending the album with a title song in two separate halves as it were. That same slow soul ballad feel extends into "Lean In" and a version of the Bee Gee's "To Love Somebody". "Somewhere Down In The Mystic","Real Life Painting" and "Blessed The Brave" integrate more acoustically driven singer/songwriter elements into them. "The Game","You","Riverman" and "Right Where You Are",sung as a duet with Gregory Porter are all slow swinging jazzier numbers while "The New Game" is a stomping,organ fueled rhythm & blues number.  All and all? This is a very balladic album. The vast majority of these songs are slow and meditative. What's interesting to me is that while all of these songs are very strong? Wright counter balances them with uptempo numbers that are some of the most thickest,vital,bluesy and often full on funky music that's around at the moment. While it's true I can see this albums sweet and poetic nature as reaching out more to the female members her audience than the male ones? It's a very good mixture of folk/jazz,neo soul and R&B and is probably one of the best kinds of label debuts that an artist such as herself could possibly imagine.

If I had been in a girl group about a decade ago from this point? Must say that Destiny's Child would not have been the group I'd have wanted to be a part of. As musically and culturally significant as they were at that point? 2004 showcased a time when members had been coming and going right and left. Not only that but Beyonce had already launched a solo career that...well,most people know how that turned out. Because for many years many music writers don't always celebrate groups as much as individual artists? It was wonderful that this group managed to get another trio version of themselves back together to make what's so far been their last album.  "Lose My Breath" is a stellar intro-perhaps one of their finest songs with their call and response vocal leads sung rhythmically enormous Brazilian marching band style live drumming. "Solider" is a pretty by the numbers contemporary pop/hip-hop number with Lil Wayne while "Cater 2 You","Through With Love","T-Shirt",'Bad Habit" and "Free" are sensuous funky soul style ballads. "Girl" has a sweet mid 70's Memphis soul/pop danceability about it while the flavor of that era also continues onward into the reverbed,muted horn fueled groove of "Is She The Reason" and the cinematic soul ballad of "Love" which closed out this album.  One of the big things this group did during their heyday in the early aughts was to reintroduce world music's rhythmic and melodic ideas into the black American popular consciousness of the day-via contemporary hip-hop/R&B music. And with a very strong Afrocentric focus no less. For their finale? The group seemed to be in something of a more nostalgic mood as it got underway-with far more retro and neo soul style sounds than what they'd been previously associated with. In terms of the vocals,material and production by Rodney Jerkins? This was a rather subdued but still often fiery finale for Destiny's Child.

Probably the most important lessons I learned from Destiny's Child during their time was that to some people? The musical attributes of a group can be neglected by the listener if their songs are essentially saturating your everyday life. Radio,television,at the store,there didn't seem to be any escape from them in 1999-2000. To this day? There are still a lot of elements I grapple with about turn of the millennium contemporary soul/R&B music. Happily for me now? I've already reviewed a couple other Destiny's Child albums,including their first. Since this release represented my initial knowledge of them? Seems overdue to put some serious writing behind it on my own part.  The introducing title track finds the quartet doing a tongue in cheek impersonation of a Godfather type dialog about the main theme of the album before it all kicks off with the stop/start electro funk "So Good"-with it's popping drum machines and brittle guitar like keyboards. That style shows up here again intact on "Confessions" with Missy Elliot and on "Bug-A-Boo","Where'd You Go","Hey Ladies","If You Leave" with Next and the blockbuster hits "Jumpin Jumpin" and "Say My Name" with a more pronounced Egyptian/Arabic melodic and vocal framework. "Temptation","Now That She's Gone","Stay" and "Sweet Sixteen" are all acoustic guitar driven ballads while the album is rounded out by the mid tempo groove of "She Can't Leave You" and the beautiful acapella rendition of "Amazing Grace" that closes it all out.  All of the songs of this album are introduced by a brief spoken series of biblical style commandments on this albums concept,which revolves around the cycles of romance at this point in time. It's about men cheating on women,those same women expecting men to cheat and then feeling a sense of regret about the ensuing insecurities. This introduces an idea that is central to what contemporary R&B still explores really. Musically however? This album brings out another important element that Beyonce,Kelly and company may not have been aware of. Recently heard comments about how the major religions of the world all derive from the middle east essentially. By blending Arabic harmonies and melodic exchanges with the Christian gospel soul flavor? Destiny's Child transformed that religious concept into a musical reality.

As difficult as it is to imagine now? There was a time not too long ago where I basically purchased used vinyl based on my knowledge of the artists existence,and if it was something I'd never heard of. That was surely the case with this particular album. At this point? I had no idea of Billy Preston's late 70's/early 80's period recording for Motown. It was certainly a very key time to be there-especially they were then celebrating it's 20th anniversary and beginning to sign what probably amounted to it's last group of artists as an independent label. Of course this artist was already a musical icon quite sometime before this point. So interesting these this creative meeting happened when it did.  "Give It Up,Hot" and "All I Wanted Was You" are two high octane disco-funk numbers-filled with a busy interaction of percussion,bass and guitar along with Billy's keyboard soloing. The title song and is a more straight up vocal funk number whereas "You" is a sleek West Coast pop sounding number with an extremely strong melody. "I Come To Rest In You" is another gospel infused ballad in his classic style. Syreeta Wright makes her debut as his duet partner on both the bouncy pop of "It Will Come In Time" and the slow piano ballad of "With You I'm Born Again". "Lovely Lady" is another of his uptempo honky tonk soul style songs while the album ends with the instrumental "Sock It,Rocket"-a fiery combination of percussive fast paced funk and thick,otherworldly synthesizers.  For the first couple of times I heard this album? Only felt it was decent to very good in quality. Only the final cut on it really blew me away,and it still does. Again in the context of the music I've listened to since? I realized just how important this album was to Billy's career as a whole. His sound beforehand had generally been stripped down and focused on his orchestrations and melodies with many different keyboard instruments.  This album on the other hand finds him as a composer,producer and soloist surrounded by the Motown musicians of the time-all of whom provide very different flavors than what he might've previously provided for himself. It actually showcases him in a more workable team setting that way. And becomes more powerful with each listen.

Exploring the music of Billy Preston in album,rather than single, terms within the last several years has given me some important insights into the man's particular musical bent. His previous offerings to this particular album found him working with TONTO in 1975,than moving on to a Philly soul type sound on his follow up the next year. Interestingly enough? I found out about and purchased this album quite awhile before even knowing about the other two just mentioned. So when dealing with what seemed to be his final album for A&M,and completely a very successful run of hits for them? This release was something I really wanted to hear.  The title song starts off the album with some furious funk that blends bass/guitar with the internal interactions of Billy's many different keyboard solos between them. This also goes equally for "Complicated Sayings","You Got Me Buzzin'" and "Touch Me Love". My favorite song,one I share a mutual affection for with friend Henrique is "Wide Stride"-an instrumental that includes a very early use of polyphonic synthesizers playing the horn charts matched to a stripped down bluesy funk rhythm.  "Disco Dancin" blends the dance floor sounds of that era with an organ fueled gospel rave up while "Attitudes" is a bouncy rock 'n soul boogie instrumental in his then classic style.  "Happy" is another instrumental that really goes for the thick,grooving synth funk and is another favorite of mine here while "I'm Really Gonna Miss You" and "Sweet Marie" are both late 50's style rhythm & blues mid tempo ballads. The album ends with the wah wah heavy rhythm box funk of "You Don't Have To Go". In many ways? This is my favorite Billy Preston album of his 70's period. One of the reasons is that the album is extremely thick with raw,stomping funk and soul. Sometimes he was a musician who lost a bit of focus trying to showcase his eclecticism. But in this case? He merely stuck to doing what he did best,and making the highest quality music in that vein to boot.

I truly feel great regret at not taking the time to explore Gloria Estefan's music from my teenage years when it was new. One of the reasons for that is looking back from today? It was a steady stream that led up to the massive Latin pop influx in the US during 1997-2000. How this particular album came into my personal collection had to do with revisiting the transitional albums from Miami Sound Machine up through her solo career. Luckily for me? Her albums are extremely easy to find in my area on CD used for well under $4 much of the time. So all I really had to do was pick this up,pop it in my CD changer and let the music to it's thing.  The title song begins the album with a stripped down percussive slow salsa-melodically built around flowing Spanish guitar. "I'm Not Giving You Up" takes similar elements and adds small bursts of strings and phase filter effects in just the right places. "The Heart Never Learns","Show Me The Way Back to Your Heart","Along Came You (Song For Emily)" and "I Know You Too Well" are on a similar musical path. "Steal Your Heart" starts as a solo acoustic guitar number and burst into a full blown uptempo salsa that blows up to full power on "You'll Be Mine (Party Time" and "Higher". "As for "Path Of The Right Love" and the closer "Reach",featured during the 1996 Olympic games bring out a vastly important element of this album.  And that element is deep musical Afrocentrism. Both of the aforementioned songs focus right in deeply on the most tribal elements of African folk forms and American gospel. One important conversational point bought up with myself and friend Henrique lately is that many of the South American and equatorial countries of the world,including Gloria's native Cuba,have a far richer African cultural flavor than an overt European one. With lyrical themes dealing with the complex emotional spirituality of romance and self improvement? This album picks up philosophically on that impulse as well. It's always pleased me to hear that Gloria and Emilio Estefan have continually emphasized that beautiful sense of rhythmic tribalism in both their slow and fast songs. Really helps to give it all that distinctive flavor.

One of the things I've noticed in listening to a lot of 90's era Gloria Estefan is how much from the albums of that era I actually recognize. Frankly? There aren't too many cover albums in my collection because,quite frankly,they've been extremely overdone in the past decade and a half or so. In this case? Part of the many qualities that makes her artistry so special is how she approaches her music in an entirely creative rather than solely performance based angle.. Since the focus of the Miami Sound Machine was usually rhythmic and instrumental? Her solo career focused on her voice. And in such a case? An album such as this really helps bring that out.There are a good number of doo wop era numbers here such as the title song,"Breaking Up Is Hard To Do" and "Goodnight My Love,Pleasant Dreams". These are lushly arranged songs that go very well alongside numbers such as "Traces","Don't Let The Sun Catch You Crying",merged here with the intro of Erik Satie's Trios Gymnopedies and "Love On A Two Way Street"-all of which have a slow Calypso samba about them. "Turn The Beat Around" I recognized instantly and like "Everlasting Love" and an excellent retake of Dr.Buzzard's Original Savannah Band's "Cherchez La Femme" basically add contemporary digital electronics while maintaining the strong disco era rhythms of the originals. "You've Made Me So Very Happy" and "It's Too late" find her dealing with her jazzy side-taking full advantage of her vocal range in the process.After hearing this? It's probably going to be one of my favorite cover albums. There are many things I appreciate about Gloria and Emilio's musical and vocal arrangements on this album. The songs that require a lot of that receive it,the ones that are more about subtle shadings don't. Have the impression that she probably sang these to herself over and over again for years before doing this album. One of the other qualities that make this appealing for this sort of album is that many of the song selections showcase just how much Afro Cuban percussion was actually present in a good deal of the 60's pop that's on here,and that man Americans grew up on. I really appreciate the fact this album bought that out in this particular manner. And it's a major source of it's appeal for me.

Ever since I first heard anything about this 1973 release? It was always understood to be the Van Morrison album that was the most difficult to find. Especially on CD. For years it was something I would be searching for during many a grate digging session and come up with nothing. Finally managed to locate the vinyl at Dr. Records near where I live. A couple of weeks later? My main record haunt Bull Moose got a used copy in on CD. This is one of things that totally shocked and surprised me. Over the years,I've heard nothing but positive things about this album. Even from people who were not ardent "Van fans" as it were. So was very excited about the musical treasures to be found within.  "Snow In San Anselmo" is a ballad with a gentle rhythm,some tasty rhythm guitar and piano improvisations along with Van vocalizing in his fragile higher range he uses for the majority of this album. "Warm Love" is a flute led mid tempo soul oriented number while the title has some of the horn based country soul balladry flavor of his previous couple of albums. "Wild Children" is a gently swinging bop jazz influenced number while the singer/songwriter pop-rock of "The Great Deception" with a surprisingly cynical outlook on the 60's counterculture. "Bein' Green" is interpreted in a bluesy manner similar to Ray Charles' version while "Autumn Song" paints a beautiful lyrical picture with an upbeat jazzy swing while "Purple Heather" extends lyrically on that theme with another country soul ballad.  What really separates this album musically from what came before it is that Van Morrison completely abandoned any idea of creating radio hits. He began to concentrate on jazzier forms-the Miles Davis-type idea that melody and the general hummability of a song could actually come from elongated songs with strong choral improvisations. These eight songs have the effect of all being very strongly crafted and singable without being confined to the 3-4 minute pop song format. The classical touch of strings and female vocal choirs courtesy of the Oakland Symphony Orchestra add heavily to this wonderfully composed and arranged album. One which I feel might be one of Van Morrison's very best of his 70's period.

Having listened to and actually reviewed a great deal of Van Morrison over the past couple of decades now? Somehow feel that I haven't really given enough attention to the man's solo recordings of the early to mid 70's. This was basically where he honed and developed the sound that has made him famous for so many years. Interestingly enough? I found a lot of this music came in and out of print in almost too fast a state for me to really make a move on picking any of them up on physical media. Ended up finding this one used at Bull Moose,even though my father already had the exact same CD copy. It still feels like something more than worth having two copies of.  "Jackie Wilson Said (I'm In Heaven When You Smile)" is a bright,beautiful example of a shuffling horn based R&B/soul number and one of my very favorite Van Morrison numbers-mainly because I love his uptempo soul numbers most of all. "Gypsy" and "Redwood Tree" are both more rocking soul oriented numbers built around both 12-6 string and rhythm guitars. "I Will Be There" is a sweetly swinging mid tempo blues while "Almost Independence Day" and the title song both focus on more elongated country/soul-folk style ballads built around the acoustic guitar and Morrison's renowned improvised vocal licks. "Listen To The Lion" takes this to the next level-adding a mild Calypso rhythm with a bridge featuring Van literally braying in the manner of an actual lion.  Musically this album seems to emanate from the same types of musical sources that had been at the very core of Van Morrison's creative ethic that had spawned his iconic Astral Weeks five years prior to this. By combining a selection of shorter,catchier and therefore more radio friendly songs with longer and more surreal musical selections? Van was able to provide a two sided window into his own creative process. It was one that could allow casual music lovers,as well as serious musicians and writers/scholars to be able to appreciate what he had to offer. And it's an album that even people with only a casual curiosity about Van Morrison's music should definitely seek out.

Having seen and heard songs from It's Better To Travel over the years,along with used copies of the album in every format almost everywhere I went? There was a part of me that thought of Swing Out Sister as something of a one hit wonder who only had a small handful of albums. Not only isn't that the case. But it has nothing to do with what they represent musically,and creatively in general. This was an album that I only learned about after purchasing their first. It was their second release-and their last for the 1980's. Considering the technological changes in the rhythms of dance music between 1987 and 1989 when this came out? Wasn't sure what to expect of it. And came out extremely surprised on that end.  "You On My Mind" "Heart For Hire" and "Precious Time" are very basic pop/rock uptempo numbers with heavy orchestration on the choruses while "Where In The World" and the propulsive "Waiting Game" are both funkified dance numbers. "Tainted" and "Between Strangers" bring in the programmed shuffle rhythms of the new jack swing sound into their melodic dance grooves while "Forever Blue" is a piano and round drum beat based ballad with some beautifully crafted choruses. "Masquerade" brings in a very tribal Afro-Brazilian rhythm with acoustic sounding electronics and vast dynamics while "The Kaleidoscope Affair" and the epic jazziness of "Cony Island Man" go for elaborately arranged instrumental soundscapes. Instrumental versions of "Precious Words","Masquerade" and a string mix of "Forever Blue" all emphasize the same spirit.  While sharing many things in common melodically with their first album? Swing Out Sister elected to go for a very different musical approach for this album. The arrangements here are,for the most part,far more dramatically arranged and orchestrated. While there are a couple elements where the drum programming of the period did show up rhythmically in the songs? The overall sound has a lot more to do with the song craft and general approach of 60's easy listening jazz pop/soul/bossa nova that one might hear from the likes of Burt Bacharach,Quincy Jones,Herb Alpert and Henry Mancini. The presence of the thick,punchy analog recording style helped to bring their growing musical sound even further into focus for a creatively powerful sophomore album.

Despite only knowing a couple of their songs from the radio? I always had a strong affinity for this particular group. That isn't surprising considering my interest at the time in Sade,Level 42 and later discoveries of Basia and Lisa Stansfield from this era as well. The UK jazz/funk/soul scene of the mid to late 80's added strong melodic pop-craft sensibilities and different elements of contemporary instrumentation into the mix. This particular approach to has stuck with that particular scene to the present day-with different eras adding less or more retro styles depending on the reception from the people. This album hit the first decade of that scene about smack dab in it's center.  "Breakout" is the song I know best from this album-filled with disco friendly bass synths along with jazzy funk,horn and string fueled choruses and refrains. "Twilight World" has an even more sophisticated orchestral mix,but's it's the accenting percussion that really brings the spark of life up from it's bottom. "After Hours" has a minimal rhythm with a jazz suite like melody and spacey synths while "Blue Mood" is a thick,uptempo 80's funk number while "Surrender" again turns the percussion and orchestration for a slower groove. "Fooled By A Smile" and "It's Not Enough are a direct cross between both of those songs while "Communion" is a Brazilian electronic jazz mid tempo ballad while "Theme From It's Better To Travel" is one of the best uses of MIDI themes to recreate late 60's cinematic soul.  This CD edition of the album contains four bonus tracks with extended vocal/instrumental renditions of "Breakout",a version of "Surrender" with a full mock American accent monologue. It ends with a haunting instrumental of "Communion". Of the movement this album was a part of? This brings in two important elements of it's own into it. One is the 80's Euro Dance touch,with the pulsing disco beats and bass synthesizers along with the arrangements. And as for them? The album is given a strong contemporary jazz orchestra flavor about it. Something like what a Duke Ellington or a Gill Evans might've done with digital instrumentation of this period. In addition of having superb pop smarts and a great funkified dance ethic? This album looked to accomplish a lot musically,and really succeeded at doing so.

Over the past five or six years? I spent so much time re-exploring the 80's era Spyro Gyra that I had missed completely the first time around...that I flat out neglected to dig into the 1990's era output. During these years there was a wonderful CD/DVD/video game resale shop in my area called Edge. They aren't in operation any longer. But I managed to find several of this bands CD's for that latter decade there. Still don't have them all,and doubt if I ever will of course. And what little gaps there were I filled in at Bull Moose. This was one of those cases. One where reviews from right here helped guide me to. As it turns out? This was an all around good decision.  "Pipo's Song" is a gentle uptempo salsa built around the sax and still drums-giving both the Spanish and more rock oriented guitar each a chance to solo on two separate refrains. "Breathless" is a anfaring  fusion/funk groove introduced by a melodic piano solo. The swinging bossa of "Real Time",with it's bluesy horn voicings begins in a similar fashion-only with the marimba. "Jennifer's Lullaby" is a gentle Spanish guitar/piano based ballad dedicated to the late Stan Getz. "Whitewater",,the title song,"Gliding","Cabana Carioca" and Rollercoaster are all multi sectioned Latin jazz/rock fusion numbers with bursts of horns while the smooth ballad "Inside Your Love" and the slap bass heavy funk of "Nothing To Lose" round out the album.  From about the early 90's to the early years of the millennium? Electric jazz/pop/funk/fusion somehow ended up becoming mired in the "smooth jazz" style-really a studio production method rather than a specific genre that became musically stifling and,to some gave the instrumental electric jazz spectrum of music a controversial reputation. This album is extremely melodic,well played on and rhythmically propulsive as any Spyro Gyra album. Yet it is completely devoid of any such production values. The album has a pronounced Brazilian jazz/rock fusion air about it all that's very live instrumental oriented-sounding like a band playing together all the way in a similar manner to their Breakout album seven years prior to this. An excellent early 90's release from this already iconic contemporary jazz band!

Somehow or other I ended up getting this CD pre owned-during a time where in which I was totally obsessed by anything they happened to be musically involved with. Always finding out new things I appreciate about them in that regard. On it's own terms? Gladys and the Pips started the 80's decade very strong with their Columbia debut in About Love,an album I have on vinyl and consider to be one of their very finest releases actually. Interestingly enough? I learned of that and got it sometime after picking up this album. So am lucky to have a somewhat broader context with which to listen to this now.  "I Will Fight" and "Baby,Baby Don't Waste Your Time" are swinging,uptempo soulful shuffles full of rhythmic bass/guitar interactions and spacey synthesizer accents. "If That'll Make You Happy" and the string filled "Changed" are both rich,harmonic ballads with  "A Friend Of Mine" being a richly orchestrated mid tempo number with the jazzier "Love Was Made For Two" is a highlight for me. And that strength continues onward with the organ drenched contemporary gospel of "God Is",the boogie dance number "Reach High" and a version of "I Will Survive" that concentrates on being more of a piano ballad before briefly going into a Broadway style of gospel drenched disco.  One of the most significant things to be said about this album is that it set the group up with fellow Motown alumni Ashford & Simpson for the majority of the production. They understood Gladys and the Pips' strong Southern gospel/soul funkiness. And how to bring that into the new 80's decade and it's electronic instrumental interests without destroying any of the qualities that made the group what they were. The end result is another album the strikes an optimum balance of slickness,soul and musical eyes that never take sight off of the groove.
