And the fact that this ethic would essentially be the one this group would follow until their late in the decade breakup says a lot for the understanding they have of their talents.

While always having an enormous appreciation for the unique flavors that Spyro Gyra bought to their type of melodic jazz fusion music? There are still many albums from their "classic" period which I do not have. And up until today? This 1982 album topped that list. Of course as with many such cases? There have been ample opportunities for me to pick this album in many formats,seeing as it's such a commonplace used item in my particular neck of the woods. Today I actually picked up the CD...in Dr. Records where I found the exact same copy there over a decade ago. And at this point? Am more than thankful that I at last had the opportunity to give this album a chance.  "Last Exit" is a bouncy pop/funk jam full of hot horn choruses,solos and strong rhythmic changes with grooving bass/guitar interactions on the bridge. "Old San Juan" is built upon gentle guitar and whistling before going into a spirited,Spanish tinged horn fanfare. "Harbor Lights" and "Sueno" are slow ballads built around glistening electric piano and sax while "Stripes" is a stomping,soulful uptempo number built around bluesy guitar and harmonica. "Oasis" is a pulsing  funky number built around some of the most thoroughly jazzy instrumental solos from all ends as the title song builds that impulse forward to it's heaviest Afro Brazilian ends. "Soho Mojo" ends the album with another sprightly and melodic uptempo theme.  One thing I'll say for this album right away? It thoroughly explores live instrumentation on every type of song featured on it. A good number of these songs really showcase the bands jazziest chops-with the big band Caribbean flavored choral horns blend with the pulsing bass/guitar and keyboards for some truly spirited musical conversations. At the same time? Their renowned concentration on melody and general build is present in every song. Very much like it's predecessor? This album has it's share of unexpected turns. Which proves something I've always held about this band: that Spyro Gyra come across very very differently as an album oriented group as opposed to a singles oriented one. And this album really captures that spirit.

As it turns out? Bobby Caldwell here is an artist who first came to my attention in a music matching online search I was doing. And it's been largely via the web that I've been exposed to his music thus far. During the last several years? The albums from his prime period in the late 70's and early 80's have become more and more scarce to come by. Luckily earlier this year? I managed to locate a used copy here at an inexpensive price. And this was the album that I most wanted to hear from him because it's his first,and contained the song most associated with him. All told,no disappoints at all!  "Special To Me" and the faster, jazzier guitar oriented "Love Won't Wait" are both Philly style uptempo dance numbers that are orchestrated with sweeping disco strings and percussion. "My Flame" is a gentle mid tempo ballad while "Can't Say Goodbye" has a stronger funk stomp about it with Caldwell's powerful vocal croon heavily reverbed for the occasion. "Come To Me" is a melodic piano ballad in a Stevie Wonder/Elton John vein whereas the title song,his signature song is as great example of slower jazz/funk/pop as I've ever heard. "Kalimba Song" is a gurgling bass and...kalimba driven funk instrumental whereas the West Coast friendly pop/soul ballad of "Take Me Back To Then" and the liquid jazz/pop of "Down For The Third Time" round off the album.  From what I've been hearing listening to this album a few times already? It is likely going to end up among my very favorites. A crack multi instrumentalist,singer and songwriter? Caldwell excels at being able to balance his talents as a rhythm king and song constructivist in a very appealing way. Musically he picks up on some of the most vital soulful oriented sounds being innovated at the time. Everything from uptown disco/soul to heavy Afrocentric funk-especially with his use of Kalimba which outside Earth Wind & Fire's Maurice White was not at all common at the time. The entire album just has a unique instrumental sound and is matched to a talented and passionate vocalist who is still happily makng wonderful music to this very day.

First time I ever saw this album,or this artist was when a DJ who had a jazz and funk based radio show at a local college station showed me this on vinyl. He frankly pointed out the only reason he actually had the copy was because of the presence of musicians such as Stanley Clarke and Jan Hammer-both of whom we had a mutual admiration for. A little under a year ago,I located this album on CD at the local record store Bull Moose. And was very excited by the opportunity to be able to hear this album. Even though it came to me with some significant gaps in Buchanan's catalog in my personal collection. Still happy to hear it nonetheless  "The Heat Of The Battle" begins the album with a fast paced shuffle with blends a strong bass/guitar jazz-rock fusion sound. "Hidden" meanwhile is a yearning melody filled with rich orchestration featuring classic strings. "The Circle" is a very direct early 70's style Stonesy rocker which makes use of huge female vocal choirs on each chorus. "The Adventures Of Brer Rabbit And Tar Baby" is a bluegrass duet between Buchanan's guitar and Clarke's electric bass. "Ramon's Blues" is another slow crawling...well just what it says it is while "Green Onions" gets a significantly more rocked up interpretation than the original.  "Judy" is a thick,dense mid tempo jazzy piece while "Done Your Daddy Dirty" is a shuffling,hard edged number. The album ends with the fusion vocal ballad "Your Love". One of the first things I noticed about this album is how different the playing is from Roy himself. He comes at his guitar with much more of a loud,hard rocking attack here. The cleanliness of his general tone is still apparent however. Not sure if the intensity of his playing here had to do with the influence of arena and punk rock of the late 70's. But the presence of jazz oriented musicians-including also Narada Michael Walden,give the overall production a slick veneer to the crisper instrumentation. A very unique and potent album again representing this artist at the peak of his powers.

It was probably about eight years or so ago that I first picked up Roy Buchanan's debut album on cassette tape at the local Goodwill. It was a very enjoyable album,one which I fully intend to pick up on CD in the near future. However browsing the internet on recommendations for good albums from Buchanan's catalog? This one actually came into mention. Turns out it's his second solo album (and actually titled as such) from 1973. Was lucky enough to pick it up on CD. And was hoping it would live up to it's reputation. In short order,it did-and then some!  "Filthy Teddy" opens the album with a piano fueled groove while "After Hours",Five String Blues" and the jazzier groove of "I Won't Tell No Lies" (probably my favorite hear with it's early Steely Dan-like attitude) are all generally slowed down blues shuffles. "Treat Her Right" adds a surf rock attitude and a vocal from the man himself on this classic interpretation. "Tribute to Elmore James" goes for a gritty uptempo shuffle while the closer "She Once Lived Hear" is a moaning,bouncing slow country & western ballad to close out the album.  Overall this is a fantastic album-easily equal to,perhaps even stronger than his debut. It emphasizes instrumentals primarily. And one of the most important elements of his guitar playing technique. Roy Buchanan plays with an enormous level of feeling-making a lot of use out of tension and crying sustains. But the quality of his tone means that he is also one of the cleanest players in what I'd refer to as the blues-rock/power blues genre of music. It was something that seemed to have peaked during the early 70's. And this album is a key part of the more instrumental end of that movement by one of it's strongest musicians.

As I've said before? Dan Fogelberg is musically pretty new to me in terms of his albums. Especially when it comes to his earlier work. Somehow or other from what I was hearing of him? Seemed better to not necessarily follow his album in chronological order. And just go for the ones that sounded strongest through the miracle of online/in record store digital song previewing. This came to me through such a situation. And as with every album I've heard by the man thus far? It has it's own kind of musical flavors.  "Aspen/These Days" opens the album with a string intro that goes into a slide/acoustic guitar led mid tempo pop/rocker with a steady,marching beat. "Comes And Goes" is a gentle,acoustic calypso while the title song is a wonderfully crafted pop number-with multiple Beatle like sections to it. "Old Tennessee","Next Time" and the closing "The Last Nail" are all sweetly melodic,acoustically derived ballads while "Man In The Mirror/Below The Surface" and the uniquely chorded "Crow" are two more multi-faceted pop rockers.  One of the things I notice about Dan Fogelberg's lyrical concerns is that he's very analytical about his explorations of...what would seem to amount to baby boomers in their adult romantic relationships. And on this album? The music really fits that sense of emotional built. Many of these songs have very orchestrated movements to them. And while not exactly a concept album? There is a wonderful flow to it all. With everything fitting together so well? I would not recommend this as anyone's first album by him. But it's not a bad one at all to take a listen to shortly after discovering him at least.

For many years of my life? I knew only of Dan Fogelberg as an artist who had a few pop hits when I was a little boy whose names don't quite come to mind. But probably know them well upon hearing them. Then he died about eight years ago. One of the things about me,when I'm not greatly familiar with their musical catalog? Seems best to start from the beginning. Unless of course such a debut is not recommended from a huge number of different sources. This 1972 album seemed by such standards to be an ideal place to start. Though it's actually the second album by him that I'll be reviewing however.  "To The Morning" is an entrancing melody led by acoustic piano,strings and Dan's ethereally high vocal harmonies. "Stars","Be On My Way","Hickory Grove","Looking For A Lady" and "Wysteria" are all similar types of songs-only built around the acoustic guitar. "More Than Ever","Long Way Home (Live In The Country" and "Anyway I Love You" are all pedal steel guitar fueled country-rock numbers that again emphasize strong song construction. "Hickory Groove" and in particular the closer "The River" both emphasize swelling musical arrangements that go right along with these epic ballad melodies.  While there are some songs here that work better than others for me personally? I think this was a wonderful debut album for Dan Fogelberg. He's surely in the singer/songwriter mode of focusing squarely on his compositions. But for the most part he places them in gentle settings,where even the strings create something elegant and beautiful. Some of the drum tracks on the uptempo numbers give me to wonder if this CD edition wasn't remixed slightly. Whether that's the case or not? And despite it's lack of commercial success at the time of release? The material and instrumental performances make this a must have album for the it's era and sub-genre

During the time I was first becoming aware of Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band? One of the things I came to understand is that it's band leader August Darnell eventually decided to shift the priorities towards actually having a trio of female backup vocalists rather than a female lead singer. The results were the Coconuts. And Darnell apparently re-christened himself Kid Creole. This 1980 album was discussed in the reading I was doing as being an important transitional album. Al the same? Took awhile to locate it in a used vinyl bin. And today am very happy I did.  "Mister Softee" starts off the album with an upbeat pop/funk number led by tingly percussion and a low rhythm guitar. "Maladie D'Amour" is a finely orchestrated disco friendly mid tempo soul stomp-with some rhythm guitar and clavinet riffing on the refrains. "Yolanda" and "Darrio" are deeply grooving boogie numbers with some wonderfully processed bass/guitar on the former while the title song is a stripped down calypso with a distant,echoed vocal lead. "Lil Marlene" combines the boogie and calypso influences together while "Bogota Affair" has a strong salsa pop flavor. "Calypso Pan American" ends the album with a vibraphone charged boogie rhythm yet again.  One thing about this album I noticed immediately is that,for the most part it goes right for the jugular of the Afro-Latin,percussive pop/funk sound,with a harder rhythmic stomp than the more sweetly orchestrated music of Darnell's original group. It was as I'd read a transitional album. There are some disco era elements of this album. But for the most part? This album has a more mic'd and raw production style than the extremely slick studio sound that it very easily could have very well with. In terms of the songwriting? It's definitely leaning towards shorter pop structures as well. So it comes down to being an excellent introduction for them.

It was on the same disco compilation where I first heard Imagination and Teena Marie that this group came to my attention. Found a compilation which merged their first two albums on the BMG Music Service in the late 90's. But it was a few years later that I discovered they had a third and final album out,which was released in 1979. August Darnell,Andy Hernandez and company always had one of the most telling and witty storytelling content in the lyrics to their music. With their second album being a bit more musically experimental in nature? They decided to adapt from where they'd started just as they were about to come to an end.  The entirety of the first side consists of "Didn't I Love You Girl?","Call Me","New York At Dawn" and "R.S.V.P". All four of these songs hold together as something of an extended musical sweet consisting of a percussive,danceable stomp as well as the horns (both muted and otherwise) and both solo/choir vocals wavering in and out of the basic mix throughout. "The Seven Year Itch" is an extended number which is quite a lot more on the funk side-with it's churning rhythm guitar and bass interaction. "Once There Was A Colored Girl" returns to that hurdy gurdy organ grinder approach of some of the songs from their last album while the closer "Italiano" blends the big band and funkier musical flavors.  From the way I hear this? The album does musically what it apparently set out to do. That is successfully merging the big band jazz flavors of their debut with the more pan ethnic influences of it's follow up. What comes out of it is the idea that the members of this group basically understand how many strands of American popular music-whether deriving from Latin countries or within the disco sound itself,all have an enormous degree of Afrocentric origin points to them. Because of the heavy reverb and awkward mixing of some of the lead and backup vocals on this album? The lyrics are not always particularly easy to make out. But from what I can here? There are references to racially troubled romances and culturally biased musical appropriation on this album. All I can say is I am glad this wasn't the end for Mister August Darnell!

When growing up? Songs such as "Stepping Out" and "Breaking Us Into" were 45's in constant rotation on my family's turntable. Many years later a friend of mine explained to me that a local gay men's choir he was a part of actually performed the entirety of this albums predecessor  'Night And Day' one time. Had no idea the scope with which that 1982 album reached people so personally-both in the musical and thematic sense. On this follow up two years later? Jackson upped the ante by paying tribute to classic Blue Note album art for the famous Sonny Rollins collection Vol 2 and bringing in many new members to his big band for the album as well.  "The Verdict" opens the album with a big one/two drum wallop with the trumpets and flugelhorns accenting each beat before the piano based main melody kicks into gear. "Cha Cha Loco" is an elaborately arranged slow crawling salsa while "Not Here,Not Now" and "Be My Number Two" are a stripped down piano and percussion based melody with liquid bass accents. "You Can't Get What You Want (Till You Know What You Want)" is a horn packed and wonderfully crafted funk/jazz jam with a thick,busy bass/guitar and horn chorus interaction. "Go For It" has a bouncy 60's Motown beat with call and responses blending punk and gospel approaches.  "Happy Ending" is a Brill Building style pop duet with Elaine Caswell while "Loisaida" and the closing "Heart Of Ice" are both enormously cinematic instrumentals built around fanfares of keyboards and horns. This album definatly expands on the melodic live band flavor introduced so strongly on it's predecessor. The difference on this album is the the horns take on a far higher priority. Not only that,but little of the music here has anything even remotely radio/commercial friendly by mid 80's pop standards. Joe Jackson was seeming to be re-writing the music books-creating music for the listeners and the live show that followed this release more than anything. Even though that tour exhausted the man into a brief hiatus musically? This is still a prime example of his musical talents.

Ever since my days as a member of the BMG Music Service? I've been seeing one write up after another about this classic rock album from 1971.  Often popular songs from it were referred to over and over again. Yet I'd personally never heard any of them before. As I later became aware of the AOR sub genre of music? It started to make sense why that might've been the case. In the end? I never actually purchased this album in any format. It came my way via a grad bag of old loose CD's our local record store were selling at one time. Surprised to find such an album that way. And even more surprised when I actually took the time to listen to it.  What really makes this album stand out for me is Ian Anderson's use of flute. Especially on songs such as "Hymn 43". Musically and lyrically? It does a good job of bridging the psychedelic and progressive rock era. Not to mention the themes of religious institutions in England overshadowing the actual word of god itself,plus the poverty and crime that eventually comes out of class systems. Musically however? I had a hard time understanding how this could be a classic album. The bluesy electric guitar and folksy acoustic ones are of a playing and melodic style I've heard in rock over and over again. And in all due honesty outside the opening title song? The song craft is not particularly strong for me either. Still in terms of story songs and in terms of transition? I can sort of see why this is important.

Personally have my own outlook on the cultural transitions of the late 80's into the early 90's. Expressed it in many different ways. Yet at the same time? It was certainly an interesting convergence for those involved. The original and even post punk artists were now 30 somethings. And life would go on. That being said? 1987 was one of those big years for now classic albums from that decade. Prince had his Sign O The Times,Springsteen his Tunnel Of Love,Michael Jackson his Bad,Fleetwood Mac's Tango In The Night and..the list goes on. So it would seem U2 made their own contribution to this. Generally whenever I heard of the band? It was this album and the hits contained within that are mentioned. Yet tonight is the first time I've heard it.  The opening three songs on this album ended up being a lot more familiar to me than I could've imagined. "Where The Streets Have No Name","I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For" and "With Or Without You" all take that stripped town ringing,rhythmic guitar melodicism really bought out in their last two albums to their highest level of well crafted musical beauty. "Bullet The Blue Sky" has a very confrontational,bluesy style guitar and drum thudding stomp about it while "Running To Stand Still" is one of the bands most eerily quiet melodies. "Red Hill Mining Town" takes that same approach to a somewhat more high key approach while "In God's Country" continues in the direction the album started off in as does "One Tree Hill".  "Trip Through Your Wires" has a hard power blues shuffle while "Exit" and the closer "Mothers Of The Disappeared" are both rhythmically and melodically discordant songs where instruments and samples alternate to sound like found sounds at a moments notice. Both lyrically and musically? This album picked right up where it's predecessor's left off. Interestingly enough? It also has two very distinct moods about it. It starts off with it's most listener (would not necessarily say immediately radio) friendly songs-with their strong choruses and melodies. While later on in the album? As the lyrical content grows less certain and more probing? The instrumentation and arrangements split apart into near incoherence. In some ways? I personally prefer it's two predecessors. Yet this album reveals itself to have more to it with each listen. And that is usually the mark of what makes a classic pop album,

Even before I was really aware of their music? A neighbor who was a close friend of the family was a major U2 fan. So heard more about them than actually HEARD them to be honest. Somehow their hits probably zoomed right past me with radio listening at the time. During the late 90's/early 2000's however? I was also becoming very aware of Daniel Lanois and his work with Bob Dylan. Not to mention Brian Eno's understanding of how to harmoniously combine melody and harmony. Through the now defunct BMG? I found this 1984 album in which both artists were involved in assembling it. It was one of the first U2 studio albums I ever purchased. And in many ways a personal favorite of mine today.  "A Sort Of Homecoming" opens the album with a massive swell of tribal percussive rhythm matched by the Edge's like minded sheets of high pitched guitar strumming. "Pride (In The Name Of Love)" takes this song into a much slower and pop song craft based approach while the funky groove of "The Wire" and the title track have a strong,sleek and heavily reverbed new wave danceability. "Promenade" strips things down to bare bone guitars and feather like drumming. Same goes for "4th Of July","Bad","Elvis Presley & America" and the meditative closer "MLK". Meanwhile "Indian Summer Sky" adds a strong rocking snarl to the basic rhythmic sound the album provides.  One thing I appreciate about U2,especially during the early/mid 80's,is how much they embraced what amounted to highly tribal ideas into their sound. Bono's vocals and songwriting are of course very poetic. Being something of a instrumental fan? Especially in terms of how it builds a song in general? It's the Edge's...well really Afrocentric use of guitar as a massive rhythmic element that really creates the bands signature sound for me. And this album is probably one of the very best examples of this sound-operating at about the full peak of it's power. For whose of you unfamiliar with U2's album? I recommend this and it's predecessor as good examples of their basic sound in terms of how it projected in the studio.

Just realized while listening to this album for...I believe the fourth full time tonight? I don't actually have a good chunk of Rick James's original studio albums. Even a few of his classic ones. It's all a matter of relative rarity than anything of course. All the same? This actually came to me via a lot of his vinyl ordered off ebay about a decade ago now. During that time? This was understood from most of my reading to represent Rick's musical and personal nadir in the mid 80's. So honestly wasn't exactly expecting anything special. Several run through's and a bit more experience on the artist later? This comes through with more clarity.  "Can't Stop" begins the album with a stripped down,straight up bass/high synth and lead guitar oriented new wave dance style number. "Spend The Night With You" has a thumping dance-pop vibe about it-with it's simple rhythm guitar and dinging keyboards. "Melody makes Me Dance" has a funky hand clap powered rhythm,again built around the bass synth and an almost folksy blues guitar riff. "Somebody (The Girls Got)" is a powerful naked funk number filled with Vocoder refrains. The title song is basically a mid 80's update of Rick's 70's era Stone City Band sound-with period electronics while "Moonchild" is a shuffling,somewhat jazzy funky soul number.  "Sha La La La La (Come Back Home" is a sax and slap bass fueled ballad as the ultra funky,live band style "Rock N Roll Control" ends the album followed by a brief reprise of the title song. Overall? This album presents some of Rick's most thoroughly dance/rock oriented music. The electronic keyboards and drum machines give this album a cooler feel than the usually steely live band "punk funk" sound he pioneered only a few years before this. But still this is album is chocked full of beautifully arranged funk/soul numbers as well. Not to mention some of the mans finest compositions and performances. True it's not as flamboyant a performance in general as one would expect from him-concentrating more on song than presentation. Still it's an album more than worth exploring.

First time I ever saw this album was in a record shop in the city of Portland called Strange Maine. The front art depicted the artist in a scene from a specific episode of the original Star Trek series...whose title is actually also one of the songs on this album. So it was a buy it for the cover moment. When I heard the vinyl? And realized the great musical talent of Allan Holdsworth-former member of the New Tony Williams Lifetime? Well just had to find a way to get this on CD. And another local record haunt in Dr. Records helped me with that a couple years later. This is one of the more tough albums I have to review. But it's sooo worth giving a try at.  "Non Brewed Condiment" features a series of swirling and cascading electronic harmonies surrounded by deeply phrased melodic statement. "Funnels" seems to continue the them of downward motion with more of a swinging rhythm and a softly wailing guitar solo. "The Dominant Plague" is one of my favorites on this album. It has a stomping,tribal beat and a series of complex,intertwining melodies that make it one of the most ethereal and aggressive synth jazz/rockers I've ever heard.  The title song is a melodic fan fare with a higher pitched main theme while "Looking Glass" and "Mr. Berwell" both showcase Holdsworth's amazing soloing-with the latter going up in tempo from a slow,almost folkish beginning. Whereas the closing "All Our Yesterdays" (that Trek episode I mentioned earlier) is a cinematic ballad movement that has an uptempo fusion style conclusion.  While each song features a trio of different drummers and bass players? Holdsworth himself holds down as a guitar player and by introducing the Synthaxe,a unique and rarely produced type of MIDI synthesizer controller that allowed him to realize a certain quality in his playing that I could hear even on this album-without knowing anything else by him. His basic instrumental technique has a vocal,horn like phrase about it all. And with his know synth controller? He was able to realize that aspect of his sound with a new,exciting and often extremely beautiful tonal pallet. Sometimes the atmosphere and almost antispectic,other times flamboyantly futurist. Allowing instrumental experimentation to guide his compositions here allowed for great musical adventure and memorability. So I highly recommend this album. Especially to other musicians.

Somehow it hit me listening to this...just how much of my adult musical understanding comes out of the artistry of the late George Duke. Painted his portrait several times. Made a friend because of him,who had me speak to Duke himself on a radio show and later taught me how to play chords on the keyboard to the man's song "Capricorn". Obviously this is not the first time I've heard this particular album. It was the first record by him I ever heard of. And the first of his I ever saw sitting in the record store CD racks. It was a major album for the man career wise. So many jazz/funk lovers and fellow musicians have aurally eaten this album whole over the decades. So hear is what I hear when listening to it.  Opening up with the cinematic bass synthesizer of "The Beginning",the album goes right into the powerful guitar/bass interaction based jazz/rock fusion of "Lemme At It". Opening with a fanfare on the electric piano,"Hot Fire" deals with some heavy duty Afro Cuban rhythms and melodies. The title track of course finds the classic half rapped/half sung slow bass synth funk stomp holding down what amounts to a "P-Jazzfunk" masterpiece. "Just For You" is a melodically complex pop/soul ballad with an electronically symphonic instrumental chorus. "Omi (Fresh Water)" and "Diamonds" are both kinetic,uptempo Brazilian fusion jams while "Searchin' My Mind" is an EWF like uptempo pop/funk number sung by singers Dee Henrichs,Deborah and Sybil Thomas.  "Watch Out Baby!" is a grinding hard funk stomp with the bass/guitar rhythmic chunkiness of Stanley Clarke and Michael Sembello leading the way. "The End" concludes the album similarly to how it began,while the additional unreleased bonus selection "Bring It On Home" deals with a down home bluesy soul instrumental. What George Duke and his extremely talented band of players does here is really quite amazing. For the last several years before this? He'd musically sought to locate and lock down the unifying rhythmic/melodic threads between jazz,soul,rock,blues and the music of Brazil. The unifying factor he discovered was a strong sense of musical Afrocentrism. And that's the quality that this album,across it's oozing mix of musical genres,possesses in abundance. Exciting,joyous and adventurous jazz/funk that I feel is among the most essential of it's particular spectrum

While I am far from versed in the full intricicies of even old school hip-hop? It seems relatively rare for a rapper or group of rappers to have a debut album that is also a major musical game changer. But if happens in other genres,why not? Ever since I was a teenager? I kept hearing about the controversy surround Def Jam's first white hip-hoppers here. Yet continued to hear about their first album. For some reason as with many albums? I avoided it time after time. Ended up picking up a brand new copy at a local dollar store-sadly right around the time Adam "MCA" Yauch's passing. Having just listened to it? Feel like something was terribly missing in my understanding on my generation of hip-hop for not listening to it.  "Rhymin & Stealin" begins the album with a slow crawling,heavily reverbed beat leading the way. "The New Style","She's Crafty",with it's bluesy riff and "Posse In Effect" with it's laser beam type percussive sounds are all classic,stripped down early rap/hip-hop tracks of the mid 80's. "Slow Ride" features horns and Afro-Latin percussion replicating the instrumental chorus of "Lowrider" while "Girls" has a ringing,children's carnival style bounce. "Fight For Your Right" and "No Sleep Till Brooklyn" are both fierce guitar rockers showcasing the groups punk roots while "Paul Revere","Hold It Now,Hit It","Brass Monkey","Slow And Low" and "Time To Get Ill" blend their mix of rock,rap, funk/soul and TV snippets together into the beginning of it's own brew.  As a major production triumph for Rick Rubin? This album seems to represent the moment when the freedom expressed in the hip-hop genre began to take hold. In all truth? The trio's vocal delivery and lyrics are straight up frat boy juvenile at this point. So they don't possess the spacious topical word play of the Furious Five or even the poetic artfulness of De La Soul-for example. But the sonically heady musical mix is essentially the beginning of the journey that would culminate in a couple of years after this-with major iconic hip-hop releases featuring the Bomb Squad for Public Enemy and NWA. And in those cases with some of the genres most powerful lyrical assertions. So this album impresses me anyway by contrasting it's simplistic lyrics with music moving toward a stronger and complex instrumental mix.

As a newcomer to the music of John Klemmer? I seem to find myself with an usually large variety of albums to choose from in used record bins of all sorts. The album and song titles of this CD,which I've never personally encountered before,indicated that this was a Brazilian oriented project. Between albums by Earth Wind & Fire,Lee Ritenour and George Duke during the late 70's? The Latin bug seemed to be getting to many musicians in the most positive of way-expanding their rhythmic possibilities further into deep musical Afrocentrism.  As it turns out? This album is still a very powerful contribution to that particular ethic.  The title song begins the album with an upbeat melody based around the percussion,bouncing bass line,electric piano and flutes in addition to Klemmer's sax. "Tropical Snowflakes" is a gentle guitar based bossa while "Heartbreak" extends on that theme and is built around some spirited piano,string and accordion accompaniment. The Gershwin standard "Summertime" maintains that rhythmic idea as well-with easing transitions in tempo and mood. Same goes for "Tender Storm" and "Copacabana". "Bahia" slows the mood down just a bit. It's the closer "My Love Has Butterfly Wings" that really flies with it spirited Latin jazz/funk,uptempo majesty and Klemmer's intense improvisations that do indeed seem to take musical flight.  Overall this album is a bit different in flavor than many of the other Brazilian based jazz/fusion/pop projects I've heard from this era. While there's generally a tendency towards the slower melodic bossa nova throughout the album? On the occasions where the tempo goes up? Klemmer really showcases his talents as a jazz improviser. And is musically excited by the Afro-Latin percussive settings provided so ably by Alex Acuna,Airto Moreira and Paulinho Da Costa. Not to mention the bass of Abraham Laboriel and Lenny White providing some adventurous territory. While this is one only of two John Klemmer albums I've actually listened to all the way through? It's a very welcomed presence in my music collection,a favorite and highly recommended.

It's difficult for me to calculate exactly how many times I've seen this and other 70's era John Klemmer albums in vinyl and cassette budget bins over the years. Reason I didn't pick up any of them is because I simply didn't know anything about him. He was also recording in an era when there were at least two other major pop jazz sax superstars coming into their own. Managed to recently pick this on up an original cassette. A bright sky blue colored one no less. Am both surprised and impressed with what I've heard.  One of the things about this album that's the most interesting for me is seven of it's eight songs all carry such a flowing structure from song to song. Much in the manner of John Coltranes acoustic (and far far far more musically iconic) 'A Love Supreme'? There's a strong melodic sax them that runs throughout this album. And variating into different ones with each song. Rhythmically it's a light drum brushing tone-along with a heavily reverbed and processed Rhodes electric piano. "Tone Row Weaver" stands out as more unique-with it's upbeat reggae lilt.  With guests such as Larry Carlton,Dave Grusin and Jeff Porcoro? This album takes a very interesting turn for albums of that era. It's slow and ballad paced. Stripped down. Yet not overtly funky or abstract. Some people refer to it as the beginnings of the "smooth jazz" genre. Yet it has that rawer analog era production which gives it a gentle snap overall. Normally an album with such strong repetition wouldn't excite me. But essentially extending on the mellowest side of the Grover Washington Jr. school of smooth,sleek and soulfully melodic sax? This is part of a wonderful era for the pop jazz genre.

Truthfully,I've experienced the musical legacy of Traffic almost completely out of order. That may be a good thing. Since it allows the albums to stand out on their own merits,as opposed to solely on continuity from one to the other. This turns out to be their last,from 1974. For many years? I personally thought they were long over by the time. And pursuing solo careers as well. Of course this followed up it's excellent predecessor Shoot Out At The Fantasy Factory. Have heard and reviewed that,and with all due objectivity? This album actually expands on and even betters that accomplishment on every level to these ears.  "Something New" begins the album with a gospel inflected country soul melody while the 11 minute "Dream Gerrard" goes from a slow,stomping piano based jazzy groove into a full on soul rave up in the second half of the song. "Graveyard People" is my favorite song on the album-a beautifully fluid jazz-funk number filled with spacey synthesizers,layers of rhythmic electric piano and pumping bass lines. "Walking In Wind" is a gentle piano/bass oriented funky soul stomp while "Memories Of A Rock 'N Rolla" is a slower churning psychedelic style number.  "Love" is a percussive,shuffling jazz/funk fusion number filled with melodic flute while the title song is a strong organ based soul ballad to conclude the album.  All of the elements I've ever heard in Traffic's music were leading in my mind towards clean funk grooves. And this farewell studio album offered that. Some of the members of this group would go on to work with Winwood on his solo debut at the end of the 70's. And considering the direction he'd pursue on that and after? This provides an excellent midway period in that way. Even though many of these songs represent a period when Traffic's music was getting longer in length? Everything has an extremely strong structure to it all that really allows the band members to stretch without losing sight of the groove and song craft. And that makes this a highly fitting finale to their legacy.

As it turns out? The most interesting this about this album is that it's the very first CD by Traffic that I ever bought. Recommended to me by my father,after years of experiencing it on the original vinyl. And it's actually a comeback for the band-apparently following Steve Winwood's one off super-group Blind Faith. When I first heard this? I had no idea about the different transitions that the band,and music in general was fast taking during the years 1968-1971. Still found it a wonderful album during a period where my musical understanding was growing by leaps and bounds. Looking back on it now? Makes it even more wonderful for me to hear.  "Glad" starts the album with a spirited and percussive melody that slips through jazz,gospel/soul and Afro-Brazilian instrumentation-especially Winwood's sustained organ. "Freedom Rider" is a flute fueled psychedelic fusion number with some unexpected arrangements bringing it even more to life. "Empty Pages" is an electric piano fueled soul/funk inflected piece while "I Just Want You To Know" is an interlude that holds to that style. "Stranger To Himself" is a "blues in technicolor" example of psychedelic rock while the title song is an elongated acoustically oriented folk interpretation of the English standard.  "Every Mothers Son" is the slowest number on the album that essentially ties all the themes explored by the album together while "Sittin' Here Thinkin' Of My Love" is a slow piano pop/rocker. Both with and without the addition of the two excellent bonus tracks? Well it's hard for me not to be a bit partial to this album. That's because with this power trios talents from Winwood,Chris Wood and Jim Capaldi? They are able to bring the same strong level of instrumental and compositional ability and adventure that the jazz,soul and blues masters they admired had already innovated. This is probably both representative of their transition from the more psychedelic soul styles of their earlier music to their more jazz/rock based works of the new decade this originally premiered in. A true masterwork for everyone involved. And very highly recommended to anyone who appreciates strong musicality in rock 'n roll.

If you have kids, they will absolutely LOVE this thing! I earned mega bonus points when it showed up and my kids figured out what it was and what it could do! In a darkened room, it turns the ceiling or whatever you point it at into this awesome light show (and I mean kids showing "Wow! That is cool! Oh wow! Watch that!" kind of awesome!)It's touted as an LED night light lamp. I'd call it more like a totally awesome, turns you into the coolest dad in the world if you buy it and let your kids use it night light! This is seriously one of the coolest "night lights " I've ever seenWhat it does:It has a rotating plastic lens in the top of it with different colored lights inside. Turn it on and the lens slowly rotates, which turns the lights shining through the lens into a kaleidoscope effect on a ceiling or wall. And wow does it do cool stuff! Somehow they've figured out how to literally make it look like a laser light show with these red squiggly lights (reminds me of that laser looking windows screen saver) along with several other multi-colored lights moving around on the ceiling at the same time.It has 8 light modes. Each one turns on the different colored lights in different sequences. Sometimes it's all of the lights, sometimes it's just red or just green or just blue. Sometimes they flash, sometimes they rotate through the lights. To activate the different light modes you just press the big button on the front. Keep pushing it until you get to your favorite mode.The head itself rotates about 45 degrees so it can shine the lights directly straight up or at a wall at about a 45 degree angle.The light comes with an opaque lens cover as well that "mutes" the light show effect if you want to "tone it down a bit", but my kids like to leave it off in favor of getting the full grandeur of this thing. They like it so much that we've gone to rotating it between their rooms at night because they all want to use it. "It's MY turn tonight for the light!" they say with excitement! They seriously love this thing!Brightness:In a completely darkened room it shines pretty darn bright. Much brighter than a standard nightlight, so if you're looking for something more muted, this isn't it. It'll shine the lights on a ceiling in a room at day time with the blinds drawn (yeah, it's pretty bright). But my kids don't care one bit. They love looking at the light show it gives off. If you stick the opaque lens cover on it, it does help to tone down the brightness, but it's still pretty bright.It has a speaker!It comes with a headphone jack and an included headphone wire to plug into anything with a stereo plug. My kids always love to listen to music at night. We usually use a blue tooth speaker connected to one of our cell phones or just leave a cell phone in their room, but with this you can plug it right into your phone and pump music right through the light. There's two buttons on the unit to turn the volume up or down too. It's not the highest quality speaker, but it's not all that shabby either and can get pretty loud. There's a bit of distortion at the top end, but for putting a kid to bed, it's perfect!It turns itself off after a while.This feature rocks! While I think having a lightshow in my kids room is cool and all, I also don't want it going all night long. When I first plugged this in and tried it out the first night I found out Soaiy figured that out. It just turns itself off after so long (not sure how long, haven't bothered to time it yet). I love it! When it turns off it also turns off the speaker too. So your kids can go to bed with some nice soothing music along with a lightshow and then after so long it kicks off so your kid can fall asleep. I know it stays on longer than my kids stay awake because they've never complained about it "going off" and believe me, if it did while they were awake, I'd hear about it...."DAAAAAAAAAHHHHDDDDD!!!!" Yep. None of that so far. Love it!Accessories:It comes with a USB charger style plug (reminds me of the one they send with kindles), a headphone jack, and a USB cable.I've used all of them and they all work great. One cool thing about this. Because it's powered by USB, you can even power it with one of those portable battery packs (ie. think outdoor camping or something). We used a small portable battery with it in the middle of a room one night and it was really nice to have that option. I can see using it at lots of events or parties and with a portable battery pack it'll go wherever you want. The cord on it is pretty long too. I'd say about 5-6 feet.Overall:I can't say enough good about this thing. My kids think it's the coolest light they've ever seen and that helps dad earn mega bonus points cause I'm the one that got it. It also has helped two of my kids who have a TERRIBLE time going to sleep, drift off to sleep much easier. So, if you've got a youngster that you'd like to soothe at night with a light show plus some music, grab this thing and hook it up and watch the grins! Or, if you have kids at all, I'm betting they'll love this thing! My kids are 12, 10, 7, and 5 and all 4 of them absolutely love it. Five full, well deserved stars across the board. I love it!* I received this item from the manufacturer in exchange for a review *(but I'd still buy one at full price. My kids love it THAT much!)

This bluetooth speaker has really nice, rich, deep sound, but getting your device to connect to it can be somewhat tricky. Once you do get connected though, the sound is great. If you're willing to deal with the quirky interface, you'll be rewarded with some of the best sound in a speaker this size in this price range.Sound Quality:The REAL reason you buy a bluetooth speaker, right? It is for me. After owning and reviewing several bluetooth speakers I've come to realize that the driver size and box it's contained in make a world of difference on how well a speaker will sound. This one is in a fairly large box (4" wide x 4" deep x 2.5" tall) and the sound driver fires out the front. I have to say I was honestly surprised at how rich the sound is out of this speaker. The bass is really nice, mids are well balanced, and highs are fairly well represented. Sound wise, it's a great speaker. It can also get really nice & loud too with very little distortion. As a speaker playing sound, it's really great. It's one of the bright spots on this unitBattery Life:Not really all that hot. On a full charge you can expect about 5-6 hours of music. However, it doesn't turn itself off like other bluetooth speakers do when it's not connected, so standby time is significantly less than other bluetooth speakers that I've used. It'll probably make it through about 10 to 12 hours on standby but not much past that at all. However, if you turn it off when it's not in use it'll last much longer. But I do wish it would just put itself to sleep.Interface:Buttons:|<< - goes back a song or starts a song over>|| - play or pause (also mutes the radio and mutes the line in)>>| - goes to the next song- - turns down the volume+ - turns up the volume (32 is as high as it goes)M - stands for Mode. You touch it to cycle through the different modes (Bluetooth Speaker/FM Mode/Aux Mode (if somethings plugged in)/MP3 mode (if you have a card plugged in on it)Ok. Let's get this out of the way. It's a "touch sensitive" interface, and no bones about it, it's terrible. It's slow to react and it's EXTREMELY finicky. I rarely use this word in my reviews, but I HATED the interface. Touch it once, nothing happens. Touch it again, then it reacts but it also executes what you previously touched too. ie. if you hit the M (which is for Mode), and nothing happens and you hit it again, then it finally reacts and now it's like you hit the button three times in a row and it cycles through all the modes, really fast. Changing channels on the radio, changing between Blue tooth mode & FM mode, increasing or decreasing volume, all of it just was super, super finicky. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't, sometimes it took on a life of it's own and went berserk. I REALLY didn't like the interface at all. Just give me solid buttons that click or something, but this "touch sensitive" interface is for the birds.FM Mode:This speaker features an FM radio built into it. It works, but if you don't have a USB cable plugged into it, it won't get any reception. The instructions really don't say much about using the radio either, so it's somewhat of a guessing game. When it's on, you can use the |< and the >| buttons to go from channel to channel, but without the USB cable plugged into it, you won't get any reception. I also pressed some buttons in a certain sequence and now it has a bunch of presets on it, but I couldn't tell you how I did it or what caused it and the instructions really don't tell you much about operating it. It's there. It works. Bring a USB cable though if you want to use it.AUX Mode:They supply a headphone wire to plug the speaker directly into a headphone jack. By far, this was the most reliable way to get sound to the speaker because it overrides all the other modes when the wire is plugged in. It worked well in this mode, but it kind of defeats the whole reason you buy a bluetooth speaker. But it worked greatConnecting via Bluetooth/NFC:This was a royal pain in the rear. I tried multiple devices too (LG G3, MacBook Pro, Nexus 7). The devices would see it, you'd attempt to connect and it'd just sit there. After about the 4th or 5th try it would finally connect. Only to disconnect a few seconds later. When I FINALLY got it to connect and STAY connected, the sound is awesome! But man, getting it to connect the first time is a beast with this thing! Also, if it drops the connection, it switches over to FM mode. Then you're back to messing with the super sensitive touch screen to try & put it back into Bluetooth mode again so you can re-try & connect. Yeah. Wasn't fun. But again, once you DO connect and if you're only connecting it to one device, it will usually stay connected, but that first couple of tries are a real duzy.NFC:I gave this a try. It works, but because you set your phone on top of it to get it to do it, the phone actually pushes the touch sensitive buttons and sends the thing into a tizzy. So, yep, it does connect via NFC mode, but don't touch your phone to the other buttons or else you'll be off in FM mode or some other thing.Language:This thing speaks in both English and Chinese. How do I know this? Because I accidentally kicked it into chinese mode while trying to get it to connect or get into the right mode. I THINK if you hold your finger down on M long enough it switches languages. After some fiddling with it I finally got it to speak in English again. It says stuff like "Blue toos mode", "FM Mode" "Power is low, please charge" and a few other things. (it's funny. It say's Blue tooth with a chinese accent. Kind of cute really). So if yours goes into Chinese mode, just hold the M down long enough and it'll switch back.Battery Charging:If you plug the big end of a USB cable into it, you can use it to charge up another USB device. I tried this out on my cell phone (LG G3). It worked, but it charges in "slow charging mode" (my phone even told me it was slow charging), so you can use it in a pinch, although the battery in the speaker is pretty small by itself (it's removable though. You install it in the bottom).Size/Appearance:It's about 4" x 4" x 2.5" and weighs just under a pound. There are rubber pads on the bottom to keep it from sliding around too. I really liked the weight. Heavy enough to stay where you put it but not too heavy to move around. It's also pretty classy looking too!Included Cables:A USB to micro USB cable - worked great (use this as an antennae too)A line in cable - worked great, pretty long too. About the length of an average set of headphones.Overall:If you can get past the really quirky interface, the sound and volume level on this speaker is awesome! The FM radio isn't anything to write home about but it works. The battery life is less than other bluetooth speakers I've tested in this price/size/range. I really like the sound that this kicks out (it's up there with the best I've tried in this price range), but man, that interface drove me nuts. If you're planning to use it as your ONLY bluetooth speaker, it'd probably rock as once you've connected it, the next time you turn it on and the device you're connecting it to, it'll stay connected. But man can it be tricky getting it there. So overall I give it 3 stars. Sounds great, kind of a pain to get setup & use and I wish the battery life was longer.* I purchased this item at a discount in exchange for a review *

I've tested quite a few of these over the last while and I've gotta say this one's my favorite. Here's why.Compact Design:- Not overly bulky & easy to insert into the cig lighter. I've used and seen a lot of other ones that are just way too big for my liking or they're just really difficult to fit into tight spots on my power ports. This one is really small, really sleek, and just has a nice, simple designColor :- I know, that's preferential, but I really like the dark black color. They didn't load it up with cheesy graphics or color it orange or some stupid color, but instead left it classy black. It really blends in well in the van and doesn't make itself overly obvious. I really like that! Granted, maybe you're up for screaming, "Hey look, I have a USB Car Charger in my cig lighter!" with bright neon colors. I prefer the subdued route. Love it!Blue Light:- It has a blue light that comes on when it's running. I love that its there because it lets you know that it's powered. I have mine in a minivan with lots of kids and stuff up front. All of that "stuff" gets moved around a lot and bumps stuff I plug into the power ports. The fact that this thing lights up so I know that it's on when I need it is just a really nice feature that I loved having. It's a nice, subdued blue light too. Very classy! Again, loved it!It Works Really Well!- This is really why you buy these things, right? This one doses out a whopper of charge for my phones, tablets, bluetooth speakers, etc... I've been using it for almost a month now and have charged pretty much everything I own with a USB Charger cord on it and love how fast it works! I can stick my LG G3 phone on it and in about a half hour of driving I've juiced the phone up quite a bit. I've used it with an LG G3, a Moto G (1st Gen), a Nexus 7 tablet, a blue tooth speaker, and an iPod 7th Gen. All of them worked great on it.I Love The 4 Ports!When my kids are all in the car we definitely have more than 2 devices on going down the road. The fact that this thing can charge up to 4 of them all at once rocks! I get the extra long USB cables (love the braided 6 foot ones by the way!), run two to the middle seat with kids with electronics running and run the other two cords to my cell phone and the wifes. It powers them all and charges them up pretty quickly. It delivers 2.4 amps to each port too! I've used a few that have some ports at 2.4 and others at slower speed, but everything I own can handle the 2.4 amps going to it--so having that extra juice rocks!It Just Works!I love that there's no switches to mess with, no guessing which ports to plug the cables into (ok, now which one charges fast?), and no headache. It just charges like it should and it does a really good job of staying put in the power port.Overall:If you're looking for a nice, classy little car charger that doesn't draw attention to itself, isn't bulky, actually works, and delivers a full 2.4 amps to all 4 ports, then you'll love this one! However, if you're really into that neon green look that screams "I'm cheap & made in china!" by all means keep looking, this one's too classy for that. I absolutely love mine!* I purchased this item at a discount in exchange for a review

These are by far the most comfortable set of Bluetooth headphones I've tried to date. They also have extremely good sound to them too!Connecting to my LG G3 phone was a breeze (Man I love Bluetooth 4.1! It connects soooo much faster than bluetooth 3.0 and the battery life is way better!) and they actually have surprisingly good range (I set my cell phone down and walked into the other room about 30 ft away and they were still going strong). By far my favorite set out of all the ones I've tried.Connecting:This is by far the easiest set of blue tooth headphones I've ever used as far as connecting to my phone (LG G3) goes. Turned them on, turned bluetooth on on my phone, put it in search mode and BAM! There they were! They show up as Smart i8 with a headphone logo. Tap the logo and connecting is fast and easy. The headphones have a pleasant ladies voice that speaks IN CLEAR ENGLISH "Connected". (I can't tell you the number of headphones that either just "beep" to indicate they're connected or a broken chinese accented english voice attempts to tell me they're connected). The nice lady also says, "Power On" and "Power off" and "Disconnected" when you turn off bluetooth. If you go out of range she says, "Out of range". Ok. Back to connecting the headphones. Absolutely breeze! Also, when you power them down & power them up the next time they use them, they're really good at finding your phone again--and fast! I don't know what Bluetooth 4.1 is, but I know I REALLY like it!Battery Indicator:Apparently, Bluetooth 4.0 (and beyond) allows the headphones to display a battery indicator for the headphones on my phone. I love it! It's accurate too! Worked great!Buttons:MFC Button (Multi-function)Praise the Lord & sing Hallelujah! Someone FINALLY made the MFC button BIG! The whole side of the right headphone is one big honking button--and man do I love it! Push it to turn the headphones on, off, answer a call, pause a song, or go into connect mode. With the headphones on my head I could easily use the button, could reach for it, and could easily use it. Man, I can't say enough good about how NICE it is to finally have the button big enough to realistically use without fumbling aroundVolume Buttons:Located on the right hand side, they're somewhat on the smaller side, but they're still pretty easy to operate. I was able to easily turn the volume up or down with the headphones attached to my head. They don't "beep" when you push them, so you don't get any audible feedback like other sets I've used, however, they do beep when you hit the maximum or minimum volume levels; which I really like having.Range:This is one area these seem to excel over other bluetooth headphones I've tried. They actually STAY connected. You'd think with your cell phone in your pocket that a set of bluetooth headphones would stay connected, but I've had several disconnect. These, however, have been rock solid. Just for kicks I even set my phone down and walked about 30 feet away and still got a signal loud and strong. Pretty impressive!Sound:Probably one of the main reasons you buy a set of headphones. These things absolutely rock! The bass is nice, deep, and full, the mids come out really well, and the highs are crystal clear. I've been hearing instruments in songs with these that I haven't heard in other speakers or headphones in quite some time. Also, they get nice & loud! Loud enough that I easily need to knock them back a couple notches from max volume level. I really like that feature because if I get in a really crowded area where I need the extra volume I know it's there. Really, really impressive immersive sound though. The best I've heard in a set of blue tooth headphones; especially in this price range too.Comfort:Outside of how they sound, comfort is one of my biggest things I go for in a set of in ear headphones. If they aren't comfortable, I'm just going to wear them, regardless of how well they sound. These, however, are the absolute most comfortable set I've ever tried. I can literally wear them for hours on end without my ears hurting. Kudo's to whoever designed them to fit in the ear! Just really, really comfortable!Overall:I've reviewed several sets of bluetooth headphones. Most are ok, some are even a little nice, but none of them have sounded this good, felt this great, were this easy to operate, or worked this well. Hands down the best set of bluetooth headphones I've ever used. Granted, I don't go for the super premium ultra expensive ones--just not in my ballpark--but man, these things just flat out knock it out of the park. I really, really enjoy them and they're by far the first set I grab when I want to use blue tooth headphones. Highly recommended!* I received this set of headphones in exchange for an honest review *

My mother absolutely LOVES these! She's already come up with several uses for them and has many more planned. They're much better than the others she's tried and loves how easy they are to write on, erase, apply, and remove from items. Just a great set of chalk labels! They totally deserve the "Premium" title in their name!Applying To Surfaces:She said they went on like a breeze. Just peel them off the cards, clean the surface, and stick these in place. We tried them on glass, plastic, and metal containers and they all went on easily and stayed on. Bonus points!Pen Use:The pen that comes with these works extremely well. It's a nice pointed tipped pen and writes on the labels really easily and very legibly. It's a nice, bright white too; which makes them easier to read.Erasing:These clean off extremely well and leave nothing behind. We cleaned them with a damp cloth and unlike others we used, these actually CAME CLEAN! In the past, others that we've tried leave a residue behind (think overly used chalk board) or they would smear. Not these ones. They cleaned off all the way to a nice, dark, clean slate every time. Writing back on them was a breeze too. We were really impressed!Removal:This is one area where these really do well. Others we've tried leave a really nasty, sticky residue behind or they tear when you pull them off, but these were really easy to remove and were easy to reapply to other surfaces. They did leave a hint of stickyness, but it was easy to wipe it off with a towel and it was completely gone. Unlike others that just leave a nasty residue, these come off really clean.Overall:My mom absolutely loves them! She's already started coming up with new uses for all of them and has had a lot of fun applying them to all sorts of containers. She's excited to use them for holidays too! You stick them on a little wooden stick and can set them next to food items to indicate what they are. It gives a little "old fashioned charm" to the meal and just looks cool. Value wise, these are great! They're inexpensive, they actually work and actually come clean when you want to reuse them, and can be easily removed and applied to other things. Plus, my mom, who's a doting grandma, is thrilled to be able to use them in all the crafts she does! Five stars all the way!* I received these items in exchange for a review *

My wife & daughter really like this shampoo. It's leaving their hair extremely soft and shiny. I've known of the benefits of coconut oil for several years using it for cooking and soap making so I was excited to try out Luseta's shampoo.I'm really glad I did too. The fragrance of this shampoo is incredible! It reminds me of coconut tanning lotion in a way, I really like it and so do my wife & daughters. The shampoo itself has a nice, thick texture to it as does the conditioner. This makes it go on nice and thick and because of the coconut oil in it, it lathers up extremely well.As far as it's effect on hair, my daughter absolutely loves what it does to her hair; making it nice & soft. Her hair is naturally on the oily side and being a teenager convincing her to wash it all the time can be a challenge, but with how nice it makes her hair feel, she's happy to wash it daily.Overall, it's a great shampoo and conditioner. If you enjoy the fragrance of coconut oil, you'll love this shampoo too!* I received this item in exchange for a review *

These work really well! We got them to prune an out of control raspberry bush with and really, really were impressed with how well they did.Our raspberry bush had gotten really out of control and I knew I'd need a pretty good set of pruning shears to attack the plant. So, I gave these a whirl. Wow! Really, really nice! The ratcheting action on them is really cool. It ratchets down until it hits some resistance (big raspberry branch) and then it grabs and clips with as much force as you want to give it. When it snaps the twig in half it gives this very satisfying "click" too. Kind of an affirmation that you've clipped the thing all the way. Very cool!The clippers themselves are very comfortable to use and the grip works really well. We used it on various sized raspberry branches and it easily cut through all of them with ease. My wife said that they were really easy for even her to use.The clippers have a lock on them too to lock the blade shut for storing. It moves really easily into place & locks them tight.Overall we were really impressed with how well they worked and we now have a much more controllable raspberry patch now too!* I received this item in exchange for a review *

These headphones have fairly good sound but they sound a bit bright to my ears. I listened to several different kinds of music on them and compared them to a set of MAXROCK (TM) Slim Flat Cable 3.5mm Metal Headphones with Mic In-ear Noise Isolating Headsets (Gray) as well as a 10 year set of inexpensive Sony MDR-CD180 CD Series Headphones with 30 mm Drive Units (Discontinued by Manufacturer) that I own.Sound Quality:The real reason for buying headphones, right?On a scale of 1 to 10 with 10 being extremely good and 1 being terrible, these are about a 7 to 8.Highs and mids are well represented, but seem to be lacking any depth of sound.Bass was there but not very rich or strong. Especially in comparison to the Maxrock's & Sony's; which both have much better bass response, richer sound, and immersive sound to them. The sound of the Sentey's on the other hand seemed to be coming from somewhat undersized drivers making the sound seem almost distant by comparison to the others. I didn't get the "immersed in the music" feel like the Sony's and the Maxrock's give me. Overall, they seem like a great set of bargain headphones, but if you're an audiophile, I'd opt for a higher quality headphone.Microphone:I placed a phone call with these connected to my LG G3 and the caller sounded extremely clear through the headphones and the caller said they could hear me extremely well as well.Cord:Seems to be a very well made cord with braided fabric surrounding it. The jacks to plug into both the headphones and the device you're listening to are also very robust. The plugs are also thin enough to plug into my LG G3 cell phone with a bulky case on it too. Bonus points on that front!The cord also has a button, a manual volume control, and a mic on it. The button pauses or continues a song or if you push it long enough it triggers the siri like program on an android. I tested the manual volume control and it worked really well. If you need to silence your music--and fast--nothing beats a manual control!Comfort:These don't feel overly bulky on my head and with the included case, they're a cinch to haul around. They were extremely comfortable to wear too--even more so than my older Sony's. Also, with the headband adjusted they stayed on my head really well too. I'm not sure I'd ride a bike with them or do something active with them on (in fact it even recommends against that in the included owners manual), but for casual listening or walking around with them on I think they'd stay on quite well.Build Quality:These things look darn near bulletproof. Really, really nice build quality The plastic on them feels nice & sturdy and feels like they could easily last for quite some time. The cushioning on the ears also looks to be high quality too. They don't feel too thin and have a nice, thick rich feel to them.Overall:I'd say they're definitely a 4 star set of headphones. They sound pretty good, they're comfortable to wear, they look to be build for the long haul and I love the foldability of them. I also really liked the case they came with. I wish the sound was a little richer sounding and better balanced and definitely wish there was more bass to them, but for an inexpensive set of over the ear headphones, they're still pretty nice.* I received these headphones from the manufacturer in exchange for a review *

This is an awesome little battery powered lamp. We've been using it in our bedroom at night on it's lowest setting as an ambient light after all the other lights are off and it's absolutely perfect! Not too bright, but bright enough that you can see in a dark bedroom well enough where you're walking & going so you don't run into something.We placed it on our headboard and turn it on once all the other lights are out. We run it for about 3-5 hours at a stint on low and have been able to get about 3-5 days out of it before the battery needs to be charged back up.The light has 3 brightness settings.- Nice, low ambient light- Middle is a bit brighter (easy for one person to read a book by)- High beam is really bright. It easily lights up our bedroom about as much as our nightstand lamp doesSee my pictures. I took several of it on the different light settings.The light is a white light (I'd say about a daylight brightness, not soft-white). It weighs just over 6 ounces (180 grams), The base is 3 3/4" wide x 2.5" deep x 1 3/4" tall. The neck with the light bar includes is just over 16" long. The neck itself is extremely flexible and is easy to move into any position you'd like. However, if you stick the neck too far out towards the back, it'll fall backwards on you, so it does take a little adjusting if you want the neck to sit very far back. I found that I was able to easily adjust it to fit against the wall on our headboard just fine.The light bar itself has 7 LED lights in it that all come on when it's on.Controls:Pretty simple operation. Touch the round circle on top one for low, tap again for medium, tap again for high beam, and tap again to shut it off. It's extremely easy to use and reacts with the slightest touch. My kids had an absolute ball playing with it ("I wanna touch it next!").Charging:It comes with a USB charging cable with an adapter plug on the other end. Kind of odd to have a round adapter plug vs a micro USB port like so many other USB chargable electronics, so don't lose the cable or else you won't be able to charge it up again. Charging seems to take about 2-3 hours from completely dead, but there's no indicator other than the brightness of the light once you unplug it to let you know if it has a full charge.One bonus is that when it is plugged in, the light works at full strength, so if you had a USB Charger and wanted to leave it plugged in all the time, it'll always be powered.Performance:It's extremely simple to use (touch to turn it on or off), easy to charge, gets nice & bright, the battery lasts a long time, and the neck is infinitely adjustable. You can even twist the lightbar itself almost 360 degrees to point it in whichever direction you'd like (think Mr Gumpy with a light in it--infinitely adjustable). It also stays where you adjust it too as well.Uses:We used it primarily as a low ambient light in our bedroom at night, but this thing could easily be used for so many other uses. Need a camping light? This thing would make a great tent light! Especially because the neck is so adjustable! Need a reading light while traveling? Bingo! Need a nightlight by your kids bed when they don't have plugs nearby? Yep! This is perfect! And, because it's LED powered, the thing goes forever!Overall:I really like it! It's been awesome to have as an ambient light at night when you don't want the bedroom lights on but still need a little light in the room. It's a little brighter than your average night light would be and the head is directionally adjustable so that makes it sweet! Outside of the quirky charging cable (kind of wish they'd gone with a micro USB slot as I have so many of those cables), the light is just about darn near perfect. I love that it's LED, love the battery life, and love how low the "low light" setting is for ambient light at night. If you're looking for a nice little portable LED lamp that's easy to use, you'll love this thing! I think it also makes an awesome portable camping light too!* I received this item from the manufacturer in exchange for a review *

This set of headphones are extremely comfortable to wear and the sound quality is some of the best I've heard in a set of small corded headphones of this size. I tested them with an LG G3 cell phone.Sound Quality:I've tried several different in ear headphones out there and most of them sound ok, but they're either too anemic on the sound volume with practically no bass or, if they're big and "bassy", the bass overwhelms the mids and trebles so the sound isn't really well balanced and comes out kind of muddled.However, that's not the case with these headphones, they've hit the perfect balance. You get really rich bass along with nicely placed mids and high's at decent volume levels too. They can easily get loud enough that I can hear them over loud environments and even have to crank the volume down on my phone too. I like that!I listened to several different types of music through these too and was really impressed with how well these reproduced the sound and how evenly balanced the sound is too.Comfort:I have to admit I was a bit skeptical of the look of the headphones too, but I have to say these are some of the most comfortable in ear headphones I've ever worn. I'm not sure if it's because of how the cord comes out the end or what, but man are they comfortable to wear! I really like this car charger! It feels well built and it works extremely well.I've been using it in our minivan in the back seat port to let my daughter charger her iPod while we drive. I can also let my son charge a tablet as well while driving..and if needed I can also use the other 2 ports too. It works extremely well!The 2.4 amp charge ports really push out the charging power which gets her iPod fully charged in no time flat. The Nexus 7 that we've charged with it on the high speed port also charges up really quickly as well.It's a breeze to use, just plug it in, plug in a USB cable and you're all set!With all ports maxed out you can draw just over 80 watts. The power port on my van indicates that it can handle up to 120 watts, or about 10 amps, this can draw about 6.8 so I'm fine. Just a note though. If you have this plugged in and have all the ports being used, you might want to watch the battery level on your car or start it up every now & then to make sure you don't end up with a dead car battery after too long.Volts x Amps = Watts for those interested in figuring how much juice you'll draw.In most cases, USB devices don't really pull the full 2.4 amps that can be delivered, but I liked knowing the max that the charger is capable of pulling.I like the blue light on it too as it lets me know when it's powered (ie. when I've pushed it in far enough or if I need to turn the key on to get the juice flowing). All in all it's a simple USB charger that can power 4 USB powered devices, two of which at "high speed charging" (or 2.4 amps), and the other at 1 amp.Overall it's a great little charger that we'll continue to use in the van that really comes in handy; especially for those long trips that drain the batteries.* I received this item in exchange for a review
