If you like bright flashlights you're going to love this one! It uses an odd size battery called an 18650 which wasn't available at any of my local stores and that I had to get elsewhere, so if you don't have access to these batteries, grab one on amazon if you pick one of these up. They're slightly larger than an AA battery (see pictures)Brightness:- Holy cow this thing is bright!- Bright enough at night to cast a beam up into the sky- This means it's AWESOME for pointing at a star in the sky with your kids "See that star?" (point using the flashlight) and the kid actually sees what you're pointing at.- It has 5 different modes that are all accessible by pushing the button multiple times--- 1: Super Bright - yeah, like scorching brighter than the 4th of July bright- It's BRIGHT!--- 2: Still Dang Bright - Not quite firework bright, but man, still pretty dang bright. still casts a beam at this level--- 3" Sorta bright - Not all that bright; reminds me of an analog flashlight at this intensity--- 4: Blinks really fast - Wanna get someones attention? Yeah, this will do it--- 5: Blinks SOS - slow-slow-slow-fast-fast-fast-slow-slow-slow, repeatIt's kind of annoying that you have to cycle through all of the modes to get back to super bright mode. Kind of wish there was a switch on it somewhere to manually set what mode it always turns on to, but if you press the button half-way you can cycle through them pretty fast.Construction:- All metal (I'm assuming anodized aluminum) all the way through. It has an o-ring on the battery end too so I'm assuming this thing can get pretty wet and it won't hurt it at all (granted, I didn't dunk it in water, but I doubt using it in the rain would bother it at all).Zooming:There's a magnification lens mounted to the front that intensifies the light and wow does it work!Zoom all the way in and you've got a piercing sharp light that's nice and focusedZoom out and you get a really nice open beam of light that spreads wide openSomething kind of quirky, when you're zoomed all the way in and you point it at a wall, instead of a round beam of light, you get this square looking thing with lines through it. I took the cover off the lens and sure enough the LED lightbulb was square looking. Unless you're pointing it at a flat white wall you won't see it, but it's still a little odd to see a square beam of light instead of a round one. It's still super, super bright though!The strap:Yeah, not worth much. Mine fell off within the first few days of playing with it. It's pretty flimsy and felt like the core was made of fishing line. But, you aren't really buying the light for the strap, so it didn't bother me. Just know not to rely on it or just remove it altogether and you'll be setThe button:It's a weird color green. I have no idea why someone chose a green button on a light like this. Looks kind of out of place (I'm guessing someone in China thought pea green soup green would be a cool color). It's a little strange, but it still works fineZooming smoothness:After about the first week of constantly playing with the zoom on it (in, out, in, out, showing the kids, etc), I noticed it started to get a little resistance to the zoom action. But I sprayed a bit of silicon spray on it and it went back to being buttery smooth.Overall:For the price, this thing is a bargain! It really is brighter than just about anything out there in this range and man, talk about an awesome focused beam! Just be sure to pick up the battery that fits it as your local walmart won't have it. Also, don't count on the strap holding up too long.  Besides these few quibbles I still really like the light and how bright it is. Man it's bright! My kids love playing with it too! Being able to zoom it in and out is pretty cool too.* I received this product from the manufacturer in return for a review *

This is one of the easiest to use IP camera's I've ever used!I was able to get it set up and broadcasting on my network and out onto the internet really quickly. The software can be a little quirky and sometimes the camera can freeze up requiring a reboot, but for the most part it does a great job. I was able to view my front door on my own IP network in the house, on my cell phone over it's data network, and over a wi-fi connection somewhere else through my cell phone.Using the cell phone software (an app called MIPC on Android), I was able to control the camera's pan and tilt, could listen to the camera, and could talk to the person standing at the camera (2 way communication). My kids absolutely LOVED that part of it!Setup:- Connect the camera to your router through the included CAT 5 cable- Power it up & wait for the LAN light to go green- Download and install MIPC app on your phone- Create a new MIPC account using the included instructions with the camera- Scan for the camera with it's Q-Code on the bottom or enter it's ID into the software- Set up your account all the way and test the camera- In the settings, set up the camera's wireless settings so it recognizes your wireless network- Unplug the camera, plug it in somewhere in the house where it can use your wireless network- Wait for the green light to come on under the Wi-fi light- Fire up the MIPC app and enjoy seeing what the camera see'sUsing the App software:- It's really, really basic software- You use your finger to swipe left or right to pan the camera.- Swipe up or down to move the camera up or down- Push the mic button to enable 2-way communication- Hold your finger down on the phone display to talk through the camera- Your voice will come through on the camera- You can also hear who's at the camera through the mic on itSound Quality:- It's actually really clear and very sensitive. I put it on my front porch and can easily hear cars driving up & down the street or even people talking out on the sidewalk. Yep. That sensitive. I liked it!- People at the camera could hear my voice very clear as well (my kids got the BIGGEST kick out of this!)- Occasionally the phone app wold report ERROR when I did the Push To Talk. I rebooted the camera & the app and it started working againPC Software:- You can also download software onto a PC (I used Windows 7) as well to view the camera- Called mipc as well- The PC software isn't nearly as responsive to moving the camera around as the phone app is, but it still works well- You can also access the camera through a browser by going to it's IP address too- The settings on the camera are much easier to set on the PC software vs typing them in on your phone- The camera works well though and is pretty responsiveUsing other IP Camera Software- fugetaboutit!- Unfortunately because Turcom is somewhat of an unknown brand I wasn't able to find any other software that I could use with it. It's just not a recognized brand.Alarm/Motion Activation- I tried but couldn't figure out how to make this work- There's a bunch of settings I messed with but the only thing I got it to do was once it took a snapshot of me walking past it but then the camera froze & I had to reboot it- It might need a micro SD card inserted into it (there's a slot on the back) for it to work- There's also some sort of Alarm input jack thingy on the back that I had no clue what it was for (instructions didn't say anything about it either)Camera Performance:- It has night vision (which works really well! The little lights around the lens all come on at night)- You can switch between night vision and full color manually or let the camera do it for you (I just left it on auto)- When it gets dark enough in the room it's in, it switches to night mode- It absolutely works over a cell phone data network without having to add a DNS or DHCP server or anything like that. It just works.- It's kind of cool to show off to friends and family, "Hey look! That's my front door!"Quibbles:- The software sometimes would freeze up requiring a hard-boot of the camera- Sometimes the PC software would freeze the image while the phone still showed the image moving- Same with the phone app freezing while the PC app would still continue showing an image- This is somewhat common with all IP camera's I've used though, they all get stuck sometimes. A good reboot & they're backup & runningWish List:- Wish I could use other IP camera software with it- Wish the alarm and motion sensing worked without the SD car- (ie. my D-Link would send me an email with a shot of what triggered the motion)Overall:- It's a great camera! It pans & tilts. Setup to be able to access it from anywhere on the net is a breeze, picture quality is great and so is sound.- If you need a basic IP camera that sets up fast and works over the net, here you go!* I received this item from the manufacturer in exchange for a review *

This thing rocks! My wife is really enjoying using these and I've been really impressed with the quality of the metal and the thickness of the glass on the glass measuring cup.The kit comes with 5 spoons, 5 metal measuring cups, and a glass measuring cup.Pros:- All stainless construction- THICK metal construction (these don't have that "cheap" feel to them at all)- The wife said she ABSOLUTELY LOVES that it comes with a 3/4 cup measuring cup- She also loves that a 1/2 tablespoon spoon is included too!- They go through the dishwasher extremely well, no problems at all- The glass measuring cup is nice and thick and a great size- Red markings on glass cup are nice and clear and easy to readCons:- Wish the measuring cup had "cup" increments- Quickly removed the stainless rings that hooked the measuring cups & spoons together (they got in the way)- Round spoons aren't as easy to get into spice containers as oval spoons, but that's more a preferenceOverall, we really like these measuring set. The cords also look to be reinforced where they go into the connectors which should help with the durability.I tested them on several devices (LG G3, Moto G, 2013 MacBook Pro, Anker Charger, car charger, etc) and they connected well every time.I absolutely loved the gargantuan length of these things! I've had this now for about 2 years and STILL absolutely love it!I'm in about a 4000 sq foot home with 2 levels with the router located in a bedroom in the upstairs on one side of the home.I can still pull a solid signal in the basement on the opposite side of the house as well as from outside the house within about 100 feet of the home.I have 5 computers, 2 cell phones, a tablet, a Roku, a Canon wireless printer, a wired HP printer, and an iPod all running off of the router.I have it connected to a Comcast modem.I can easily pull 125 MBps down and 10 to 12 up through speedtest (that's as fast as Comcast offers me) via the 5 Ghz Signal. Switch over to the 2.4 Ghz signal and it's a little slower. My 2013 MacBook Pro particularly LOVES this router. Lightning fast run times.Over the years I have had to reboot it a few times when it was acting kind of flaky, but that's always been very rare, otherwise it's always on and runs great.I get significantly stronger signal through the 2.4 Ghz signal when I'm further away from the router (say 20 feet +), but that's just a characteristic of 5 Ghz having lousy range. Close up though, the 5 Ghz is lightning fast.Software=======The router is a breeze to work with. Log in and you're presented with "basic view" or "advanced view".If you're just into basic stuff, you can do pretty much all the administrative tasks needed from the basic screen.However, if you need the more advanced features it's available and easy to get to as well.Reboot times are fairly quick (about 30 to 45 seconds) when rebooting from within the software.I've updated the firmware a few times using the administration panel over the years too and it's always gone well.I've also tested this router out against a few other routers (Apple's basic router, a cheaper Netgear, an off brand router, and Comcasts wireless router). The Netgear in every instance has blown all of them away. In terms of signal strength and speed and staying connected.I get VERY few (if ever) drops on this router. About the only time it happens is when I walk too far away from it (take the cell phone for a walk down the sidewalk).Over all, I've been thrilled with the router. It's a bit bulky on the size side, but it's done exactly what I wanted it to do; offer exceptional range and speed across multiple floors and through walls to several pc's, cell phones, and other wireless devices.Also, I've read a few people have had issues with their routers not working with wireless printers. I have a Canon MX892 and it's been rock solid with it. When the power goes out, it even finds the router again on boot up without any issues.If I needed another router, I'd definitely buy another one of these! It's been great!

This router is OK, but that's about it.It's an inexpensive router that you can use to run wireless (or wired) devices through that's super cheap. Unfortunately, you get what you pay for. The range being the major issue. Great for single room applications or small apartments, but not great for multi-floor or large homes with lots of walls to go through.Installation:==========It's pretty easy to get it up & running. I tested it in tandem with a Netgear Nighthawk R7000 and a Motorola Surfboard (two separate locations). Plug an ethernet cord into your modem or router you're connecting this to, kick on the power & wait for the lights to light up.You can access the software via a wired connection or by connecting to it wirelessly. Default SSID is JCG xxxxxx. The default login & password are located on a sticker on the bottom. Once signed in, open your browser to 192.168.1.1NOTE: Do this BEFORE you connect it to a modem or a separate router. Particularly if you're using it with another router. Otherwise the other router will assign it a different IP and you won't be able to connect.Once in, you can set the router up as a standard router, repeater, hot spot, or a couple other options.I set mine up as a router.  While you're in the software, you can change your SSID to whatever you want it to be (FBI Van is always popular!) and can change the wireless login and password as well.Connecting once set up:==================Once set up, reboot it (usually does that when you apply the settings anyway), scan your wireless network for the router, and attach to it.Here's the problem I ran into. If you're not within a couple feet of this thing it DOES NOT like to always connect.iPhone 6 = Had a devil of a time connecting. It saw it, I put in the login credentials but it kept saying the password was bad. Walked up to the router w/ the phone in my hand and it connected. What the heck?LG G3 = Fairly easy time connectingMoto X (1st Gen) = Pretty easy time connectingMoto G (1st Gen) = Fairly easy connectingMacBook Pro 2013 = sometimes it'd connect, sometimes it wouldn'tBut then, get too far away from the router (say maybe 15 to 20 feet) and it'll randomly drop the signal.I used a Wi-fi Analyzer on my LG G3 and found this to be the case. Over and over the router would drop it's signal and then come back.All the while the other router in the building still had a solid signal (especially the Netgear Nighthawk--that thing rocks!)What was strange was that it seemed to go in waves too. And before you crucify me about channels, the other routers in the room I tested it with were both using separate channels far away from the channel this broadcasted on (Netgear broadcasts on 3, this was on 8. Motorola was on 4, this was on 8), so it wasn't channel interference. It legitimately would just "drop" it's signal and then come back.I even tested the router without it being attached to another router too. Yep. Same thing. It usually happened though when you were a good 15 to 20 feet away from it through a wall.However, when it was working, I could get a good signal from it a good 40 to 50 feet away...but again, then it would drop at random and you're now without a connection. Tried rebooting a few times, etc. But to no avail. Even tried repositioning it.Size:====It's quite a bit smaller than my Netgear Nighthawk (see pictures), but the Nighthawk is a beast! So size wise, the JCG has a much smaller footprint. The three antennae's on the back are pretty easy to adjust too.Recommendation:===============If you need a super basic router and you're in a tight space (say a smaller apartment) or if you're going to use it in the same room, this is probably a great little bargain of a router. But if you need something that'll broadcast further (say down the hall and into the living room) and stay on consistently, I can't really recommend it for that. The signal just dropped too often for me to feel comfortable using it as my primary router.When it was on, it was pretty nice. Good, solid speedtest numbers, nice features, but it doesn't seem to like to broadcast very far away from itself and stay on consistently.* I purchased this router at a significant discount in return for a review *

If you're into jumping rope, this is a great option!It easily adjusts to your height and can quickly be adjusted to other heights as well by pulling the caps off the bottom and adjusting the length sticking out of the handles. Really nice set of compact earbuds. Really clean sound, good mic positioning, A little low on volumeTech Specs (from box):Normal Impedance: 16 ohms +/- 20% at 1KhzNormal Power Rating: 3 mWMaximum Input Power: 5 mWOutput S.P.L.: 100 +/- 3 dB SPL at 1 KHz with 126 mVrms InputR/L Output Difference: <= 3 dB at 1KHz 1 mWDistortion: 3% Maxium (1 KHz/1 mW)Frequency Response: 20-20,000 HzBuzze & Rattle: 50-3KHz (0.28V)Weight: 13.5 _/- 2gMy measurements:Length from plug to splitter - 29"From splitter to mic - 9"From splitter to headphones - 16.5"Total length - 45.5"Full review (Used these on an LG G3 phone):I've had a chance to try out several ear buds recently so I was excited to try out this set of SoundPeats.The packaging is awesome & shipping was lightning fast.Cord length is a little on the shorter side of other ear buds, but still adequate.I can still stick my phone in my pocket and walk around with the earbuds on (I'm 5' 9").Build Quality:They appear to be plastic all the way through, but still have a nice feel.There's no metal on the mic or the plug, but it still doesn't look bad.I'd call it an understated look & feel.The ribbon cord is reinforced at the earbuds and at the plug, but not at the mic or the splitterThe cord also looks a little narrow than others I've tried, but still feels robustThey also come with 2 other sets of rubber ear inserts.The set that came on mine were very comfortable and I didn't have to switch them out.Sound Quality:The clarity of sound that comes out of these is great! Nice, crisp highs, good mids, and good bass.They're not particularly loud, so you don't get a LOT of bass, but it's a good, crisp sound with minimal distortionThe drivers themselves are somewhat on the smaller end so that contributes to the lower sound outputI've definitely had louder earbuds, but the clarity and sound quality is really clean coming out of these.You can turn them up all the way and they won't overpower your ears, so that's nice.If you're looking for a loud set (ie. outside use or in a noisy environment) these probably aren't what you wantBut if you want a nice, crisp set of headphones, these are really nice.I'd call the sound somewhat understated, but crisp and cleanIt's a nice, lightweight set of headphones.Mic/Button:I really like the position of the mic button theseIt's nice and close to my mouth which means it's easy to find without "hunting" for it.It's also very responsive. Push it once, the song pauses. Push it again and it starts back upPush it twice and it advances to the next song.I also like that it's square shaped. It makes it much easier to grab the button vs. round mics that leave you hunting for the button.I didn't test out the mic on it though, so can't comment on how well it works.Cord Length:I actually really like this length. It's a little on the shorter end but it keeps from getting tangled in things like longer ones can do.The thinness of the ribbon is also nice too. Definitely on the "lightweight" end of things.Overall:I really liked this set of headphones. While they're on the "lightweight" end of things and not as loud as others out there, they make up for it in their crispness of sound and overall sound quality. They're also extremely comfortable and easy to put in my ears. Love the position on the mic and how short the cord is. Solid 4 out of 5 stars. I wish they were slightly louder and had a little more bass to them, but still a great set of compact headphones.*Product was provided by the manufacturer for a review *

Really nice set of headphones that can REALLY crank out the volume. Nice, thumping bass with good sound.I tried these out on an LG G3 phone.Of all the earbud style headphones I've ever used, these by far can crank the loudest.As in much louder than I could even stand loud (Yeah, THAT loud! They totally rock!)Packaging:They come packed in a nice tin case with a foam insert. Showed up in great shape and was easy to unpackage.They also come with three sets of the rubber ear inserts. The ones that were on them when they arrived fit my ears great.Sound Quality:Oodles and oodles of volume! (Seriously, you'll be floored by how loud they can get).Mids & highs are somewhat subdued though. But man, bass? oh yeah! It can thump it!The only set that's come close to these are a set of Cootree's I tried a while back.Cootree BE318 3.5mm In-ear earphones/earpiece/ earbuds with Microphone Built-in & Universal 1-Button Control for iPhone 6 6Plus, 5S 5 4S, Galaxy Note 4 3 2 S5 S4 S3,any IOS or Android cell phones, and Music Player - Blanou series (Black&Silver)The bass does have an ever slight tinge of distortion though to my ears.Overall though, sound quality is still really nice. And man, talk about that Bass!Mic Button:Press it once and it pauses the song, press it again and the song starts again.Press it twice quickly and it'll jump to the next song.Didn't have a chance to try the mic.As others have said the mic does sit lower (about mid chest on me--I'm 5'9")Comfort:These are really comfortable to wear. Easy to place in the ear and easy to remove.I love that there's some "chunky-ness" to the earbud itself. It makes it easier to grab and put in and pull out of my ears.Cord Length:From the plug to the mic is 31"From the mic to the earphone is 15"Total cord length is 46"Plenty of length to put in my pocket and jog, bike, or walk withCord is a ribbon style too and feels really sturdy.The mic has a metal jacket on it, the plug has a metal jacket on it and looks really niceThe cord is reinforced with rubber at the jack, the mic, and at each earphone which should help the cord last much longer than normalNiggles:When you put these in your ears or push on them they pop. Like the plastic driver is popping in and out from the air pressure.That may just be a side effect of how big the driver is in them, but it was still there. Also, if I moved my jaw in just the right way I could make the right one pop as well.It doesn't seem to effect the sound quality at all, but it was a little strange for them to pop like that.Overall Appearance:I really liked the packaging. Simple, crisp & clean.The headphones themselves have a really nice quality feel to them and I love the metal jacket on the plug and mic.Gives them kind of a premium feel.I also really like that they've labeled the left & right ear buds too. You don't have to guess what ears to put them in.Overall Impression:I absolutely love how loud these get and love the rocking bass, but the slightly muffled mids & high's are noticable if you listen for it.There's also a slight distortion to them when they're up about 1/2 way too. Not bad, but it was noticable to my ears. Kind of like you have the bass turned up too loud on your equalizer. So not a perfect 5 for sound quality, but definitely a solid 4 stars.If sound clarity was a little clearer and if they didn't pop when you push on them they'd definitely be a 5 star set.As far as value though, for the price on these, they're definitely awesome.If you want some of the loudest earbuds around with absolutely kicking bass (seriously, these things can THUMP!), and you're on a budget, this is a no-brainer. If you're a bit more of an audiophile and like crisper mid's and high's and don't want any distortion, you may not be as thrilled with these (the Cootree's I mentioned above may be more suitable).Still, they're definitely a great set of earbuds and with as loud as they can get, they'll DEFINITELY block out any outside noise so you can rock to your tunes.* These headphones were provided to me at a discount in return for a review *

*offered to me for free for a review*My wife read through this book and really enjoyed it. She is a self-proclaimed unorganized person who hates to organize ANYTHING.Things she enjoyed about the book- Kept nice & short. About 25 pages. A really easy read- Simple, easy to follow steps to get organized- Discussion on ways to approach organizing a cluttered messThings she wish it had:- Examples. She really wanted examples of how the author might organize a bathroom drawer, or a kitchen cabinet- In some ways it was almost overwhelming as the book was really detailed (the OCD guy in me LOVES that though, not so much on my wife's end)Overall, she really liked it and is already planning on using some of the strategies she learned from the book to attack some kitchen "miscellaneous" cabinets, drawers, and rooms that need some serious de cluttering. She said it would be an easy book to recommend too. Just don't try to bite off more than you can chew at a timeAdditional Note:It works! She cleaned the van out today and used the approach! Great stuff!

These came labeled as Cootree 240's to me, but they go by many different brands. They look identical to the QCY version.Short version:By far the best Bluetooth Headphones I've had yet!They sounds great, nice, rich bass, easily connect, and stay in my ear well.Great for exercisingTech spec's:Bluetooth 4.2+EDRBluetooth profile: HFP1.5, HSP1.2, AVRCP1.4, A2DP1.2RF Range: 10mNoise Reduction: CVC6.0Standby Time: about 175 hoursCalculating Conversation Time: about 5 hoursCharging time: about 2 hoursDimensions (LxWxH) 9.8x4.5x20.0cmWeight: 16.4 gramsCord length: 22"Complete Review:I've used quite a few Bluetooth headphones by Cootree and these are by far the best so far.I've used the C230, C230s, and C250. These are my favorite!They're by far the easiest to connect to my phone, easiest to disconnect, and the most comfortable to wear.I use these with an LG G3 phone and take them on bike-rides.They seal up ambient sounds so well that I usually leave one earphone out & leave it loose so I can hear traffic around me.They've held up extremely well!Things I like:Easiest connecting (by a landslide!) Turn them on, turn on bluetooth on your phone, and they connect.I fought the 230's and 252's constantly to get them to connect, but these are a breeze!The loose wire is really nice. The 230's are spring loaded and tend to put pressure on my ears, these being loose just sit in my ears. I really like.On/Off Button much easier to accessLong lasting batterySits well in my earReally rich sounding deep bass (blows the 230's away!)Instruction manual is pretty good too!Cons:Sometimes a little difficult to get into my earSometimes cuts in & out with my phone in my pocket (LG G3) (could be the phone, other Bluetooth headphones do the same thing)Volume button a little hard to find by touchStuff that comes with it:Charging cable3 sets of earbuds3 sets of the wing thingy's (still haven't figured out what they're for)Overall, I really like these.*these were sent to me by cootree to review*

I used this device exclusively in repeater mode. I used it in two different fairly large homes (3500 sq/ft + w/ two levels).In the first home I was trying it with a Netgear Nighthawk R7000 and a generic JCG router.In the second home I was trying it with a JCG Basic Router.With the Netgear R7000:- I found area's of the house that were furthest away from the router and plugged the repeater into a wall socket and connected it and then measured the signal with a Wi-Fi Analyzer App on my phone and also did a speedtest on my computer.- I moved the repeater to different areas of the home with the test checking signal strength and speed- In every case, my Netgear Nighthawk still produced a far superior wi-fi signal and just flat out blew it away on speed tests.- Granted, the Netgear is one heck of an awesome router, but I expected the repeater to at least give it a run for it's money. Wasn't to be- Speeds on my router are consistently about 50 to 125 Mbps down and about 10-12 up (up is governed by Comcast though, I'm sure it could push more)- Speeds on the repeater were about 12 to 20 down and about 3-5 up even when I was standing right next to it- Granted a repeater "repeats" the signal, so you'll never have the same results, but I was hoping for betterWhen tied to the JCG Router I saw mildly higher signal strength near the repeater vs the routerSetup:- Pretty straight forward. Plug it in, connect your browser to the repeater (it shows up as JWA something, something), loging & pass are admin, admin, then go to 192.168.10.1 and you have access to the controls- You choose repeater mode and then select a wi-fi connection for it to "repeat". Enter the login credentials for that network and you're in business- It then creates it's own wi-fi network with [name of wifi connection repeating]-ext ie. if your wifi connection is home, the repeater wifi connection would be home-ext- Kind of annoying because a true repeater would simply repeat the same SSID, not make you log into another oneInstructions:- They're ok, not great. You can tell it's a translation. But it gets the point across and if you're mildly familiar with configuring a router, you'll be able to set it up.Lights:- You know it's connected and working when all the lights turn green on itProblems:- This thing messes with your router. When in repeater mode, it causes the router signal to disconnect, then reconnect, then not run the internet, then run it- When connected to the Repeater, it'll sometimes do the same thing.- This happened on both my Netgear Nighthawk and with the generic JCG router- I would have a computer hooked to the router and a phone hooked to the repeater. Almost without fail, with the repeater turned on it'd cause the signal or internet connection to drop on my computer while the phone stayed connected- As soon as I pulled the plug on the repeater, the signal on the router would get picked right back up on the laptop and stay strong- I'm not sure what the repeater was doing, but it happened on both routers testing various phones and computersAs far as a repeater, yeah, it'll repeat the signal, but if you have a half-way decent router, this thing really isn't all that beneficial, plus it really does mess with your router wi-fi signal and causes it to drop (couldn't figure out why, but it did it at both locations and on two separate routers).Recommendation:Pass on this and spend the money to buy a better router* This product was provided to me at a significant discount for a review *

These suction cups are really cool! Really useful too. You place them on whatever you'd like them to stick to, press the center button and then release and the cup "sticks". They work on any non-porous material but not on porous or semi-porous surfaces.The back of the suction cup is 2.5" wide and it sticks out away from whatever it's stuck to about 1.5". The metal hook is 2" long x 1.5" wide and can be removed from the suction cup.From the very top of the suction cup to the bottom of the hook is about 4.5" tall. The hook also swivels inside it's mount. Mine weighed just under 3 ounces.The suction cup itself, the button, and the mount the hooks attach to are a chromed plastic while the actual hook looks to be stainless steel.Ease of use:Stupid simple. Clean the surface, put the suction cup up to it, push the button, and release. Bam! Your suction cup is attached.Then just attach whatever you want to it.Uses:For kicks and grins I saw just how many surfaces I could get it to attach to.1- Metal front door (did ok, paint was a little bumpy so it let a little air in & didn't let it stick well)2- Glass on front door (rock solid)3- Shower Door (rock solid)4- Glass Mirror (rock solid)5- Inside of a fiberglass hot tub (seemed ok, not sure how well it'd stay there)6- Refrigerator Door (smooth metal, stuck perfect, bumpy metal on side, slid down)7- Glass rear door (rock solid)I found that I could use this on the bathroom to hold towers on the shower glass walls, hold a squeegee, a poufee (or whatever those things are called--the wife uses it), oven pads, or just about anything else that's fairly lightweight. Right now one of them is mounted inside our shower to hold the squeegee and puff ball and the other is in the kids basement bathroom to hold my daughters puff thing. They're holding up really well too.Niggles:The swinging hook does swing and if the cup is attached to glass, the back of the metal hook can swing and touch the glass. Over time (probably several years of use) if you hook stuff on it that swings the hook into the glass I could see it possibly leaving a mark, but so far ours doesn't move at all. Granted, it's holding a puff ball and a squeegee, but it's still holding up well.As far as suction cups go, man these things are awesome! They're much bigger than your average suction cup (kind of like a suction cup times 2 in size), which is really cool as you're getting extra suction strength on the back.They come packaged extremely well and have some instructions with them that were written in different languages, but the instructions had pictures on them so I got the idea of what I needed to do to use them (clean surface, attach cup, push button, you're on your way).If you need a fairly big suction cup with 2 fairly good sized hooks on each one, this thing is the one to get! It'd be cool if the whole thing was made of plastic, but man, for the price you really can't beat it as far as value goes.* This item was provided by the manufacturer to me in return for a review *
Works great! Always has

Lasted about 2 months in the hands of a 4 year oldMirrors broke off pretty quickly, Antennae came loose pretty fast, remote finally quit working.It was cheap, so I can't complain and my boy liked it while it lasted.

Quick Review:Super small computer with Windows 7 that's smaller than a Wii (really!). All self-contained too. Includes a basic Keyboard and Mouse.The hard drive is slowwwww (5400 RPM) which results in sort of slow boot-ups, shut downs, anything hard drive specific, but once it's up & running it does a good job. Get it with an SSD instead if you can (I'll probably swap my HD out with one soon).I picked mine up with 8 GB of RAM, a 500 GB 5400 RPM Hard Drive (not a good choice), Celeron processorLonger Review:Holy Cow! A REAL computer for under $300? Yep! Really!Once you get over how cool it is to get a fully operational computer WITH included Wi-Fi, keyboard, and mouse and enough ports to get by, you'll notice some of the downsides of this little ditty. Namely the 5400 RPM Hard Drive is one slow spinning platter that puts sort of a black-eye in this otherwise awesome computer.Reason For Buying:We had an old Windows XP Tower that was having a hard time going to "sleep" when it was supposed to (it'd just stay on) and because it was a full size tower it was like leaving a 300 watt lightbulb on--all the time. So my main reason for buying was to get an energy efficient replacement for the kids but with some higher tech specs (the old computer was a 2008 dinosaur). I wanted a computer that the kids could walk away from and it would turn itself off (because they ALWAYS left the old one on). I also REALLY wanted Windows 7. Trying to teach the kids Windows 8 or 8.1 wasn't on my to-do list (seeing as I've not even used it). So that was high on the list. Didn't want to spend a bunch of cash.Pro's:==================It's REALLY small!It's super compactIt draws--get this--65 Watts! (oh yeah!)I could mount it to the wallIt had Windows 7 (not 8, not 8.1, and not 10--I purposely wanted 7!)Cons:Hard drive is an absolute dog! (Boot up, shut down, switching users isn't very quick at all--like tar slow by today's standards)It has a hard time going into "hybrid sleep mode" Like it'll Blue Screen of Death whenever it doesI went in & disabled "hybrid sleep" and it went away, but still. Kind of sucky that a brand new computer would BSOD.But, it'll go into sleep mode and hibernate mode so I'm still happy.Setup was quick & easy (well, kind of if you don't count all the updates).Pulled it out of the box (arrived in excellent shape)Put everything together.Discovered that I didn't have a VGA cable for my monitor (had an E-VGA or whatever that digital port is called) so a trip to walmart and $17 later I had the right cable.Once it was up & running and I've jumped through all the crap Windows 7 makes you jump through to get started, we had the computer up & running. Then comes the Windows Updates. Holy Crap! I swear that literally took half the day going through all of those. Something like 350+ of them too! (think to myself, "Shoulda bought an iMac for the kids" but then remembered this thing was sub $300 so I'll live with it. But man, what a TON of updates!With all the updates out of the way it was ready for action. Mounted it to the wall with a Lenovo Tiny VESA System Mounting Bracket (GET ONE! Seriously. Just do it! They're cheap and sooooo worth it!) plugged in the mouse, keyboard, speakers, and a USB cable for the webcam on the monitor and we were up & running.Windows found the webcam and installed the software for it. Printers got installed (Painless--this is Windows 7 after all). And it was ready for prime time.So far the kids have absolutely loved it! Dad loves it because it turns itself off (once I got the BSOD problem out of the way anyway).I'd buy another one of these in a second but with an SSD drive. That 5400 RPM Drive can suck it! It's an absolute pig. But, it was sub $300, so hey, ya get what ya pay for.Ports:=========Front:Two USB ports. No clue what the yellow one is. USB 3.0?Mic and headphone portBack:Power PortDisplay port3 USB Ports (one marked for keyboard so that it'll wake the computer from sleep)VGA Video portEthernet portAntennae jack for wirelessMouse and keyboard are definitely bargain basement, but hey, they threw them in so I can't complain (and the kids don't mind it).Value Question:Oh heck ya! For under $300 I got a fully functioning computer with Windows 7 that only draws 65 watts and will put itself to sleep. I love it! However, if I get another one it's definitely coming with an SSD drive. That 5400 drive would drive me nuts if I had to use it (but it's the kids so I don't have to).

I absolutely loved this mount!It's made of METAL (not Plastic) and the fit is absolutely perfect for a Lenovo ThinkCentre M series computer.I mounted it to a 2x4 in an unfinished basement, slid in my Lenovo, screwed in the thumb screws and I was set!It let me mount it up and away from the computer too (off to the left of the monitor in my case where the kids can reach it).It comes with a set of thumb screws, three really tiny screws (not sure what they're for) and a bunch of VESA mount screws (which I didn't use).It has some rubber bumpers on it too so that when you slide in the computer it doesn't scratch metal on metal.I like that it fits it so well and absolutely LOVE the price! If you're getting a Lenovo Tiny ThinkCentre this should be a no-brainer. Pick one up. Or else you'll be picking one up later. Highly recommended

Used with a set of PediFix Visco-GEL Heel-So-Smooth Heel Sleeves.The cream lasted about 5-6 months with nightly use.My wife said it really made a difference with her cracked heels too. She likes it because it's thicker than lotion and does more to help her cracking heels too. Definitely worth buying if you're getting a set of gel socks.It's already on my "honey, will you buy me some more of this" list.

Bought these for my wife. She REALLY, REALLY, REALLY likes them!Have had for over a year +I bought them with some O'Keefe's Healthy Foot Cream and they've done really well for her cracked heels.She wears them almost every single night and they've made a big difference.The heels are kind of rubbery gel like fitting and the actual socks are more like a spandex material.Worn nearly every night for well over a year, loves to use them, and say's they make a big difference--especially when combined with some foot cream. I accidentally washed them once (got in trouble with the Mrs.--guess I'm not on laundry duty anymore). They survived though. Even in the dryer. The rubbery sole on them looked a little deformed after going through the dryer but the Mrs. says that they "Still work".She's just about worn them out and is asking for another pair, so if that's anything for them.Yep. I'll be buying them again. Bonus points with the Mrs. Gotta love that!

Quick Review:I really like the chime. It's a full size chime that rings loud and clear.It'll chime in the slightest breeze too. If you like em loud, this one's the one to get too.Nice construction with great hanging ring. Great customer serviceLonger review:Specs:======Top of ring to bottom of wind catcher - 30"Wood chiming disc (thing chimes hang from) - 5 3/4"Top of wood to bottom of hanging ring - 3 1/2"Hanging Ring - 1 1/4" outer diameterBottom of chime hanging wood to top of wooden chimer disc - 9 1/2"Shortest chime - 10 1/4"Longest Chime - 14 3/8"Chimes - 6, each tuned to a different noteMaterials:=========The wood is laminated bambooThe hanging ring is made from aluminumThe chimes are made of aluminum and have a cool sand blasted matte finish on them.They each have a rubber grommet through the top that a string goes through and attaches to the big wooden disc above them.The hanging ring is a hefty piece of aluminum in and of itself. I'd guess 1/8" thick?I was really excited to get this chime as it's the first 6 tone one I've ever owned. It's a beautiful chime and seems to be well built.It arrived EXTREMELY well packed. Big Amazon box with packing material, smaller box inside that, chime inside smaller box shrink-wrapped. Very easy to open and get to as well.The chime itself arrived in excellent shape and was easy to attach to my home.I first placed it on my back patio but it's so windy back there that it was ringing all the time and I was worried about it bothering the neighbors (any noise carries pretty fast in my back yard). I relocated it to my covered front porch where it's less windy and it's perfect there! (More on that a bit later).Mounting it is a breeze. Find something to hang the ring on and you're setSound Level:=========With a good wind pushing the chimer around this thing is L-O-U-D! So loud that I thought it would bother my rear neighbor whose house is probably 20 feet away from mine. Granted, sound carries in my back yard like crazy (cement patio, vinyl fence, yeah...pretty loud back there).If you're looking for a loud chime, this one is definitely for you. It's a full size chime that can chime nice and loud under a good wind.Under a light breeze it's much more quiet and easier to live with. My front porch is shielded from direct winds so even in a rain storm it wasn't chiming near as loud as it was in the backyard. Also, my front neighbors are much further away from my front porch than the rear ones (front lawn, big wide street, their front lawn, their house- you get the picture).Tonal Quality:===========Wow! This thing rocks! I absolutely love the sound the 6 chimes make! Absolutely heavenly sound.Under a good wind, the notes carry true & strong for quite a distance too. Under lighter wind, it's an absolutely gorgeous melody that lightly rings out.Size:============It's on the bigger end of chimes as wind chimes go at 30" tall and nearly 6" wide.Also, it'll sway in the breeze too so it'll need a fair amount of ring to swing around and chime in the wind.I've mounted mine 21" away from the nearest pole on my front porch and that gives it plenty of room to move around (ie if the wind was blowing like crazy the chime won't hit anything).Build Quality:============This looks like a high end chime. The laminated bamboo is absolutely beautiful, the chimes are decked out in a beautiful matte finish and don't have any rough cut edges or sharp edges, the chimer and wind catcher also look top notch. I also like the plastic or rubber black insert they put in the chime that the string goes through. That'll keep the strings from fraying against the aluminum and will help it last much longer. The big hanging ring at the top is nice too. Nice & beefy! I fully expect this chime to last several years under minimal careOne little niggle. When it arrived, the wooden chime holder thing with the strings attached, wasn't sitting level. Kind of sat to one side. But, I discovered that the strings aren't super tight in the piece that hooks them to the hanging ring so I was able to adjust the strings such that I got the chime to sit perfectly level.If I was looking for a cool "room ambiance" decoration, it's classy enough that it could hang out in an informal living room and it's definitely great for the back patio (just be warned, if you have neighbors close by and they like to leave their windows open and it's windy, you'll BOTH be enjoying a melodious chime that'll sing out nice & loud).Cool Customer Service==================Not sure if they do this for every chime they sell, but I got a personal email right from the seller with some great tips & tricks for caring for the chime, the bamboo, and the tube. They also mentioned how to personalize the wind catcher too. Cool! Very nice touch!Recommendations:=================If you want a really loud chime, place this in a fairly windy area. She'll sing out like fireworks on the 4th of July.If you want a much more muted chime, find a less windy area to hang it and it'll chime occasionally at a much lower volume.I fall into the latter (I like chimes, I just don't want to hear them all the time) and love it where it's currently mounted.The Value Question:=================I'm not terribly up on how much chimes are supposed to cost, but for what you get, I think it's a really fair price. The build quality is top notch, the packaging they ship it in is awesome, and it arrived in excellent shape and it chimes an absolutely beautiful chime!If you're looking for a full size chime with beautiful tonal quality that'll ring nice & loud, look no further. This one's the one for you.If you still want full size but not as loud, this could still be your friend if you put it in a less windy place.If you want a chime (cause they look cool, but don't care for the sound), mount it inside somewhere.Overall, this is a full size, full bodied chime that'll do exactly what it's designed to do. Chime out nice & loud under a good gust of wind or lightly chime under a less windy conditions. Plus, it just looks cool!

This is a great book for those interesting in seeing what it takes to make Biodiesel on a small scale.I've known both of the authors for years and they're some of the best in the industry. The writing style is really easy to read and understand but still detailed enough technically that you get a good grasp of what this whole Biodiesel stuff is, how it can be made and the pro's & con's of producing your own renewable fuel.It's not a difficult read at all plus they've added several tips & tricks to help save you a ton of time when you make it. It's my go to book that I recommend to anyone wanting to get started making Biodiesel or just those interested in seeing what it would take to make biodiesel. While there's a lot of books out on how to make it, many of them delve into politics and get way off base. This one just keeps it simple. Here's how you make it, here's what it requires, here's some of the things you'll run into and want to plan for when you make it and heres how to do it right. Short, simple, to the point, and sweet. It's also accurate (something a lot of the books on making your own biodiesel are seriously lacking).As a Biodiesel enthusiast, promoter, and retailer of biodiesel production goods and such, I really, really like this book and highly recommend it to anyone interested in getting started.- Graydon Blair, Utah Biodiesel Supply

XSKN sent this to me to review on my 2013 MacBook Pro 15".Overall:I've used several of these over the years and this one is definitely one of the tops. It stays in place, it doesn't feel obtrusive, and it has nice key feelLonger review:Installation:The keyboard cover came in a cool package that was fairly unassuming and easy to pull open. Installation is really quick. Just lay it onto your keyboard, press a few keys to "set it" in place, and you're good to go.Keyboard Feel:I've used several of these over the years, but never one on one of my MacBooks so I was curious how it would work. I'm happy to report that it actually feels really nice on my fingers! You can tell that you're typing on silicone instead of the actual keys. It's sort of a rubbery feel to it, but it's not an obtrusive, sticky, overly rubbery feel like you get on some of these keyboard covers. So far, I've really liked it and it hasn't hindered my typing ability at all. I'm actually writing the review from the very MacBook Pro it's installed on with it installed.Staying In Place:This is where this thing really shines. Usually all of the keyboard skins I use either fall off, move around, or the ends stick up and you can really tell that they're there and they look...well...tacky! This one I'm happy to report has been staying put. It's not slid around once yet and I've used the keyboard quite a bit. I'm particularly impressed with how well it fits the keyboard. Some of the one's I've used have ends that stick up or they just flat out don't fit the keyboard, but this one is a perfect fit. I especially like how clean it fits into the grove around the outside edge of the keyboardLooks:You really can't tell it's there--which is what I like. If you look REALLY close you can see the slight cutout of the skin around the arrow keys, but outside of that, it's just a really clean fit.How well it works:So far it's really done a great job of keeping dust, stuff I'm eating, or general junk off the keyboard. I haven't tried spilling anything on it (I paid too much for the MacBook to give that a go), but I'm sure the occasional spill should be just fine with it.Value Proposition:Man, for as cheap as this is, it's a no brainer if you need one. It sticks to the keyboard well, has a good tactile feel, and looks classy on my mac. Can't ask for much more than that.Recommendation Factor:Yep. I'd definitely recommend this to a friend if they were looking for one for this computer. Especially given the clean looks and exact fit.

Worked great! Plugged it in, laptop found drivers, and away we went!I bought this to add Blue-tooth to an older Acer Laptop that didn't have Blue tooth.I plugged it in, Windows found the device and started installing device drivers for it.I heard my speaker get recognized and then unrecognized. I downloaded the recommended software (the included CD wouldn't play on my laptop), and Windows found the new drivers and installed them and the speaker was re-recognized and works great!I love being able to use my Blue-tooth speakers with my laptop! It's gonna rock!I also love the size of this thing. Man, teeny, tiny. It'll be nice and unobtrusive. Love it!

Brightech sent me a set of these to review to see what I thought.Packaging:========These are packed extremely well. Each bulb is in it's own cardboard section with the wires sitting below in another section of the box. I have no doubt that these would always show up without any broken bulbs unless the UPS guy drove over the box or something. A+ for packaging a fragile set of bulbs.Setup:========Basically pull the set out of the box, unstring all the wires and you're ready to go.Experience Using Them:=================My friend gave these a try in a couple different places. The first place she used them was in her kitchen. She strung them near her counter. She said the lightbulbs being incandescent gave off a fair amount of heat. With the kitchen already being a "hot room", she looked to where she could use them outdoors. With such a great length of cord, the possibilities are endless!She decided though to give them a try around a cool, new bar-b-que area they just built in her backyard (check out the photos). She said they work really, really well! In the evenings when you're sitting out on her back patio they really add to the ambiance of the evening.Being near the bar-b-que, the heat doesn't bother them at all (they're mounted pretty high up). They hold up well to the hot summer sun and don't mind being rained on either.She said they feel like a really nice quality product too (these ain't your cheap "dollar store string of lights", these are the real thing).In looking at them I'd have no problem stringing these up around the back yard and leaving them there all the time. Through wind, rain, snow, heat, etc. I really think they'd hold up well.The glow from the bulbs is awesome! It's just a nice, light glow that really adds to the ambiance. She loved it and I loved how it added to their backyard area. Just a really, really nice set of lights. Great value for the money too.

Short version:Really strong suction cup, rock solid on the windshield, flexible arm, vibrates too much to use while moving.Long version:I was really excited when this showed up, I tried it with an LG G3 and a Moto G; both while in cases, both of which easily fit in this long neck mighty grips. The grips held it rock solid. I had absolutely no worry about either phone falling out over the worst roads. It grips it like a pit bull on prey and won't let go until you open the clamp. The suction cup must have super vacuum strength because wow does it grab well! The only problem is that it's pretty much useless to use once the car starts moving. Let's say you wanted to use it for GPS. Yeah, ain't gonna happen.The problem comes from that really long arm on the mighty grip. Any bump or undulation in the road gets amplified through the neck and by the time it gets to your phone, it vibrates like crazy. So bad that the screen is pretty much blurred due to the movement. If you're on an absolutely flat road with no variations it was usable, but man, hit a bump (either at high or low speed) and the harmonic balance vibration from the tires comes right up through the windshield and down that long arm and gets amplified onto your phone. Granted, it's not wobbling from being loose, it's rock solid, the arm is just so long that it vibrates like crazy.It would make an awesome grip for stationary use (like when the car isn't moving), but once the wheels start moving it was pretty much useless.Installation:Super easy. Pull the protective layer off of the suction cup and you're ready to go. And, like a leach on skin, it'll grip your windshield like no other. There's some sort of sticky rubber on the bottom of the suction cup that makes it not only adhere with vacuum pressure, but with the sticky adhesion too. It worked great. That sucker wasn't coming off until I released the vacuum release.The head is easy to assemble too. Just twist off the nut, slide the head onto the arm, twist the nut back tight and your all set to go.Grip:The grip easily held my LG G3 and my wifes Moto G phones. It seemed to have just the right amount of tension to it too. Easy to open and easy to shut onto the phones. It gripped both of them extremely well.Pivoting Action:The head pivots around a ball on the end of the arm and is extremely easy to move around. I was really impressed with how easy it was to position the phone in pretty much any direction I wanted it to be. It worked really well. It also stays put where you put it too.As A GPS Holder For Your Phone:You aren't going to like it. Trust me. I tested it with my Garmin sitting next to it and drove around all sorts of roads with my phone on Google GPS. Both at day and night. During both day and night tests the screen on my phone vibrated way too much to really be useful while the Garmin was rock solid. My garmin sits on one of those bean bag mounts. Not a stitch of vibration on the Garmin vs the almost constant vibration with the Ipow arm.As A Stationary Device:If the car isn't moving, it's an absolutely awesome phone holder! It stays where you put it, holds the phone in a herculean grip and the suction cup grips the window like a rock. I loved using the phone when at a standstill.Conclusion:If you need a really long arm to hold your phone in the car and only need to use it when the car isn't moving, this is awesome! The arm is long, it grips like no other, and is really easy to reposition. If, however, you're looking for something to use while you're moving in the car (say for GPS use on a cell phone) I'd pass.* Disclaimer: This product was sent to me by the manufacturer to review

It fits like a glove, will charge your iPhone 6 up, and will help extend the battery life, but don't let your kids play with it or else it could spell certain death for your iPhone. For details read on.My mom, a grandmother of 21 grandkids, recently got an iPhone 6 and I received this in the mail to review for Brightech, so I thought it'd be a match made in heaven. Big, nice battery to extend the life of her new iPhone, help protect it on the sides, let her use the iPhone longer in the day. But, alas, this wasn't to be. One of the young grandkids grabbed her phone w/ the case on it when she wasn't looking and started tugging on the iPhone to pull it out. The case is extremely strong, in fact strong enough to bend the bottom of an iPhone if you're a 3 year old kid and you keep tugging hard enough on the phone straight up. (See the unfortunate carnage). Luckily, the phone has a Square Trade on it, but if you have younger kids and you let them play with your iPhone, don't let em touch it with this case on. It could spell certain doom for your expensive phone.Aside from that.....The case is really nice! It snugly holds the phone and the rubber bumper all the way around does a fairly good job of keeping the phone in the case nice and snug. It's no otter box, but it definitely is rubberized at the corners enough to take a blow and keep your phone looking great.Battery Life:The battery on this thing rocks! It definitely will extend the use of your iPhone by about double. My mom tested it over several days and said that usually, about half way through the day her iPhone was dead, but with this on, she could easily go all day long and into the evening without any problem. The battery indicator on the back is cool too. She said it's really easy to see what the charging status of the battery is.We stuck her pretty much dead iPhone in the case and it immediately started charging up the battery. Once the battery was at 100%, it kept it there for quite a while longer as she used the phone.Charging Connection:Occasionally, she said that she'd notice it not always connecting to the battery, so the jack may be a bit on the finicky side (but again, grandkids may have messed with it a few times so take that into consideration).Cables:It comes with a USB to mini-USB charging cable and a headphone jack extender that fits in the bottom of your phone. If you don't have a USB charger, you'll need to plug this into your computer to get a charge into it, but we have so many other USB powered devices that we just plugged it into one of the charges and away it went.Bulky-ness:She said that while it was on the phone, it definitely added some bulk to it and she noticed the size, but it wasn't much of a problem. It'll extend the phone since the jack on the bottom has to stick into it and the back of the device is a battery. So, if you don't mind the added bulk that it brings along, it's not too bad to use.Buttons:With the case on the iPhone it was still really easy to use all of the buttons. It fit the back of the phone really well too and the camera was still very accessible.Installing The Phone:The iPhone easily slides in and out of the case, especially if you do it an an angle. However (and this is important) DON'T try to PULL straight up on your iPhone to remove it from the case. It WILL bend the bottom of your iPhone if you tug on it (as a 3 year old was able to do). If you remove the phone the way it's made to be removed though (angle upward slightly and then pull out of the case) it won't ever be a problem. Just don't pull it out like you'd open a door on a hinge.Overall:If I didn't have kids and I needed a battery extender, I'd probably swing for it. However, where I have kids and I saw the damage that it was able to do to my mom's iPhone 6, I'd probably pass. Great if you don't have kids, not great if you have kids and let them use your phone.*Disclaimer: This product was sent to me by the manufacturer to use and review for Amazon.

These starry string lights are amazing! They project a very nice, white light, and are incredibly durable! They're the perfect lights for a craft project or just decorating an area. If you're looking for a set of white LED lights that can withstand repeated twisting, bending, tieing, and even a hot glue gun, look no further! You've found your lights!These lights come boxed in a small box and include a 3.6 volt power supply. The cord between the lights and the plug is extra long, making it really nice to be able to hide the adapter somewhere and run the cord to the lights.I wanted to find a unique way to test these lights out so I gave them to my neighbor to try out. She quickly came up with an art project to use the lights with and was extremely impressed with how well they worked!In comparison to your average christmas lights, these things just flat our rock!Pros:======- Extremely flexible (twist, bend, turn, pull, you name it, they'll take it)- Very, VERY durable (all that twisting didn't bother them a bit)- Easy to bend (my neighbor said this over and over and over, she was REALLY impressed with that feature)- Don't fall apart, quit working, or break like other lights- Can be glued with hot-glue and still work (see the pictures)- Really really long cord for easily concealing the plug- Extremely well built- Impressive technology LED light- Great for crafts- Nice & bright- Make excellent "stars" in projectsCons:=====- A bit on the stark white light, if that bothers you go with the soft-white versionMy neighbor said that she bend, pulled, scratched, glued, and even twisted the heck out of these lights and nothing fazed them. They literally "took a lickin' and kept on tickin'". She said they worked perfect for the art project she put together with them too.The only down side she offered was that the white is a bit on the bright side and when the lights in the house are dim, it can be a little "too white", but she said that's easy to overcome by using the soft white lights.She's used Christmas lights in her projects before and hasn't been really impressed with them (you bend them wrong, they go out. You twist them wrong, and they go out, you glue them, and they break), but she absolutely loved these ones!Also, and this is big, because they are LED, they don't give off any heat, which is perfect for permanent installations and for art and craft projects.Check out the awesome art project she was able to make with them.** NOTE: These lights were sent to me by the manufacturer in return for a review **

This thing is an amazing little speaker with a battery life that'll put the energizer bunny to shame! It sounds incredible, gets nice & loud, and has incredible range.Short Version:Holy cow this thing rocks! And man can it pack a punch on volume! If you need a really powerful little speaker with deep, rich sound, and incredible range, your search is over. Throw this bad boy into your cart & call it good.Size:- 3" wide x 3" tall x 3" deepWeight:- 9.6 ounces (with strap on)Stuff it comes with:- (1) 24" dongle w/ a USB, mini-usb, and stereo headphone jack- (1) carrying strap- (1) set of instructions.Long Version:I honestly wasn't expecting all that much out of a speaker this small but wow......I mean holy cow wow! This thing can rock (and by rock I mean it can get REALLY loud!) Also, the sound that comes out of it is surprisingly really, really good (it'll put your best lap top speakers to shame!!) The other thing that just floored me is how long it'll run on a charge. When it first arrived I decided to see how long I could get it to run before it'd die. About 8 hours later the thing was still chugging along on it's original charge out of the box (granted, I didn't run it at full volume--trust me, you don't NEED to run it at full volume, half-way up is plenty loud in a small room).Sound Quality & Volume:I'd say it's really good from low all the way up to about 7/8 volume. At full volume I heard some distortion coming from it, so I backed it down a notch & it was great. For kicks I downloaded a decibel meter on my phone & decided to see "just how loud" this thing can get. Unfortunately, at 98 dB my cell phone mic maxed out and wouldn't read any higher although the speaker wasn't even up all the way. So, uhm...yeah, this thing can get THAT LOUD and more. I compared it to the speakers on my 2011 iMac from a loudness standpoint. While the iMac's aren't going to blow you out of your chair they can still get pretty loud. The Remix 5 hung right there with them. At full blast, the Remix 5 was actually a tad louder than the iMac but the music was distorting at that point vs the iMac remaining rich & clear even at full blast. But yeah, this thing can REALLY get loud.Movie Watching:Netflix movies are terribly under volumed. Not sure what the deal is but they're always quieter than running the same movie from a DVD so I was really curious to see how this speaker would do with them. The verdict? Oh yeah! It's awesome! It can get a Netflix movie so loud that you have to turn down the volume on the speaker or else it's just "too dang loud!" My wife watches netflix all the time in our kitchen on her Acer laptop. The speakers on the Acer are TERRIBLY underpowered and when you combine it with a Netflix you get a lot of "What did she say?" But with the Remix we set the volume up half-way and it was plenty loud. We also took it with us on a night out at a hotel so we could watch Netflix on my laptop (MacBook Pro) and still have decent sound. I'm happy to report that did an awesome job! It was like you were watching the movie (sound wise) on a full size TV. I even put the speaker on a table away from where we were sitting. I still didn't have to turn the sound on the speaker up more than half-way and it was still plenty loud. So this would make a great "hotel room" speaker.Listening To Music:I tested the Remix out on several devices (LG G3, Motorola Moto G, 2011 iMac, Acer Laptop, 2014 MacBook Pro) while listening to a wide variety of music (everything from deep bass hip hop to classical music) and can say that this thing is really good. If you're an audiophile, it may not suffice (treble is fairly pronounced due to it's size and some classical music came out a little "brassy"), but it never sounded "tinny" or "am radio like".Volume wise, you can crank the tunes up all the way and rock it all day long. I tried the speaker out in various locations throughout the house (bathroom, living room, kitchen, bedroom, out on the deck) and it worked extremely well where ever I put it. In a 2000 square foot home, I could hear it in every room on the main floor with the volume up about 3/4 of the way. I turned it on in the kitchen on a saturday and we could clean the whole house from room to room and still hear the tunes really well.The "+" & "-" buttons will navigate your music player really well (I tried Amazon Prime Music, Google Play, and iTunes and it worked on all of them). Pressing the "Play" button on the speaker will pause or resume playing a song. PretytUsing As A Speaker Phone:I made a couple "speaker phone" calls using the "blue-tooth speaker" functionality on it and it worked extremely well (much better than I thought it would). The person on the other end could hear me really well and I could hear them clear as day as well. Pretty cool! If you have a bad cell phone speaker or if you're just in louder environments all the time, you may like this functionality.Versatility:I decided to see just how many different things I could use this for.Kitchen - This is a great little speaker for watching movies while cooking or cleaning in the kitchen The wife LOVES it for this purpose!Kids watching YouTube Videos - I have a 4 yr old & 7 yr old that loved being able to hear their YouTube video's with the other kids still running around making noiseIn the car - I have an old Mercedes diesel (240D) that doesn't have a radio. Out to the car this went for a road trip. Yep! works great! I could definitely hear the tunes with the engine running at full tilt down the roadWhile showering - Stick it on the counter top, kick on the tunes, and jump in the shower. It's PLENTY loud even over water going full blast to clearly hear the lyrics of any song you can playWhile cleaning the house - Yep! Worked great! We stuck it in the kitchen and went from room to room cleaning the house and could hear it every where we went.While browsin' the web - Stick this next to your computer, sync it to your phone, & kick on your favorite play list & rock it out! It made doing the taxes MUCH easier!Connection:You can sync it using Bluetooth or through the included headphone jack. Our Acer Laptop doesn't have Bluetooth, so we connected it with the dongle and worked perfect! (Man, it REALLY made the laptop come alive because of how loud this speaker can actually get)The dongle has two 24" long cords connected to a mini-usb port that connects to the back of the speaker. One cord has a standard USB port while the other has a stereo headphone jack. I tested them both out and both work really well. Standard USB charges the speaker, headphone jack lets you do exactly that--connect it through the headphone port on any device.Bluetooth ConnectionWhen you turn on the bluetooth part of the speaker, it gives an audible set of tones to tell you it's on. Then, a few seconds later if it finds a device to connect to you get another tone. If it doesn't find anything you get another tone. We were able to connect it with ease any bluetooth device we could find. One odd quirk is that if you set it next to an Apple Bluetooth Mouse, the bluetooth on the mouse causes interference with the speaker and you'll get pops & cut out's on songs--I moved the speaker away from the mouse and it went away. Guess they were competing for bandwidthBluetooth Range:In clear site....LG G3 - 50 feet clear as a bell, from 50 to 100 feet, it was cutting out periodically. At 100 feet it lost the LG signalMacBook Pro - Clear out to 100 feet it was still playing clear as a bell. At about 210 feet it finally lost the signal completely. WOW!!!Inside our 2000 square foot rambler style home, I was able to walk around with the speaker into nearly every room while the cell phone was left in the master bedroom and still get a really good signal. When I took it downstairs, I started losing the signal and it got a little choppy, but still, really, really impressive!TIP: If you're connecting it to multiple bluetooth source devices, you may need to turn off bluetooth on the devices that you don't want it to join because it WILL find them and WILL join them...sometimes before you're able to get the device you WANT it to connect to set up. Pretty impressive!By the way, when I did the outside test, at 200 feet you could still clearly hear the music coming from the speaker. Like I said, quite the amazing little speaker!Volume Level Comparison:2011 iMac - Same loudness, although the iMac speakers had a more refined sound2014 MacBook Pro - totally blew it out of the water. MUCH louder, MUCH better sound quality2012 Acer Laptop (walmart cheapie) - Absolutely blew it out of the water. No comparison. Like going from a cell phone speaker to a hi-fi. Yeah, that much of a difference!LG G3 - MUCH louder (and much better sounding)!Motorola Moto G - MUCH, MUCH louder (and better sounding too!)Battery Life:I've honestly yet to run it completely dead. It's THAT good! I purposely left it running hooked to our laptop (through the headphone jack) while the kids & wife watched several Netflix movies. Then I played several hours of music (Pandora) with it. Then I watched another movie with it. Yep. It was still going. We did accidentally plug the USB in about half-way through these tests for about 2 hours, but other than that, that's the only charge it's had so far and it just keeps on going.Ease of Use:Connecting it via the dongle is a cinch. Plug in the headphone jack, hook the other side to the speaker, turn the switch on to the middle slot and you're set. Bluetooth connects very quickly too (if you have the other devices it's connected to turned off--sometimes it'd grab the cell phone Upstairs on the other side of the house before I could get bluetooth turned on on MY cell phone)The buttons are placed in somewhat of an awkward place (why not right on top?) but they still work really well.Look & Feel:The rubber surrounding the speaker feels pretty nice. It's nice & "grippy". The red is a nice looking red too on the back & speaker grille. The included strap is also pretty easy to attach and use. I have fairly big hands and I could still get my wrist through the strap. I will say that the rubber is somewhat of a dust collector though. It's easy to clean off, but because it's black & rubbery it'll collect lint & dust pretty easily.Water Resistant:I didn't test this part out, so I can't say, but the rubber does fully surround it and the flap on the back will cover the ports really well. I'm curious how well the speaker on the front will fair to getting wet though.Summary and "The Value For The Money" Question:If you'd like an all around versatile Bluetooth Speaker that actually can get really loud yet not be too bulky, this thing is an excellent choice! I would definitely recommend it to my friends and family (and have been showing it off to everyone because of how cool I think it is!) I think it'd easily go a full day at half volume (say at your work desk or in the kitchen) on a single charge (I've yet to kill the battery). For the money, it's an awesome deal!This product was provided to me by the manufacturer to review (and I REALLY, REALLY like it & keep showing it off! It's a sweet little speaker! I'd definitely buy one!)

I REALLY like these lens cleaning wipes! I bought them to clean the screen protector on my LG G3 cell phone. My screen protector is a fingerprint magnet and these wipes work perfectly to clean the screen! It only takes one wipe too to get the screen protector looking squeaky clean again.The wipes have a little bit of alcohol in them to make them moist. The alcohol smell isn't strong at all though and the wipe isn't overly wet; which I've found is perfect for cleaning with. The wipe will pull the greasiest of smudges right off the screen too!If you have a cell phone with a screen protector and want to keep it clean, then you've gotta try these! I love em!

I installed this on my 2008 vintage MacBook Pro back in 2009 when I bought it. It's been on it ever since and the MacBook just died a few months back while the PalmGuard is still doing great! It protected my computer extremely well and always "took a lickin' and kept on tickin". It also was always nice to rest my hands on as it had a slightly different feel to it than the aluminum and really resisted scratches well. Highly recommended.

By far one of my more favorite accessories. I've used this on my Canon Rebel XSi and my Canon T5i to remotely fire the shutter. It works great! Easy to use, easy to control, and it just works. I've since switched out to a remote with my Canon T5i, but I still occasionally bring this out when I'm working behind the camera and don't want to reach around for the IR sensor to grab the remote.

I used these in a Canon HV30 and love them. Sometimes they're a bit more expensive than the other ones out there, but I've never had a single issue with these and when you're capturing video that matters (ie. for your business), I figure go with the best. They've always held up extremely well and I've loved using them every time.

I got about a year's use out of this thing before it started slowing down. It also made this faint crackling sound anytime heavy data was going through it. Not sure what the noise was, but it was there and audible. I replaced it with a Netgear and haven't looked back since.

This thing is awesome! As in it impressed the heck out of my 9 year old son and me too!We gave this to my son for Christmas because he wanted a rocket (and I didn't want to buy rocket fuel). When he first saw it he read on the front that it'd go "nearly 200 feet in the air" and he said, "Yeah, right! No way!" Uhm...yes way...as in this thing FLIES!!!We took it outside & set it up and I jumped on the air bag and the thing shot really high into the air and impressed the heck out of my son. "Holy cow! That IS AWESOME!!!" Yep! This thing rocks!Setup is pretty straight forward, although the stand is kind of a pain to assemble (it's hard to put the third piece between the other two). But once you get it set up, it's all fun! We shot the rocket several times; each of us trying to get it higher than the other. I even jumped on the air bag with both feet (all 185 lbs of myself) and that sucker shot sky high! Oh yeah! It rocked!What's cool too is this thing is pretty robust. I wasn't being gingerly about my jumps at all (basically jumping as high as I could & landing on the bag to get the most pressure). It took it all and still lived to see another flight.The rockets are fairing pretty well too. So far we haven't landed one on a roof somewhere and the ends are all still in great shape. If you're looking for a fairly inexpensive toy that'll bring a ton of fun to your kids and that won't break after the second use, you gotta try this thing! It'll put a grin on the face of anyone who uses it (this "adult guy" turned into a giddy kid while using it--HUGE grins produced!)The airbag is a fairly pliable plastic material that is holding up extremely well (even to repeated jumps from a 185 lb guy--with both feet!). Get it for nothing more than the priceless look it'll produce on your sons face when he see's just how high this thing flies. The price is great; especially for the sheer joy & entertainment it'll bring to everyone using and watching it.

I think boys would like this, too, if it didn't say girls only. This is a cute little kit that allows you to write secret messages in invisible ink to your bestie. You get two cases in this kit. One for you and one for your BFF.  Each case includes a UV light pen, a mini spray bottle, code and cipher wheels, a message mask, a phonetic alphabet code card, a sticker sheet, and more. A great way to introduce girls to the sciences and chemistry. It comes with a booklet that teaches girls how to create and write in code and how to decipher that code. It's interesting and fun, but I really think this should have been made in a way that either a girl or a boy could use it.
