Works great, especially for the cost. I tested this on the inside and outside walls of my home, and on a hot stove. The inside walls registered within  a degree or so of the measured temperature in the room, and the stove and outside walls were plausibly hotter and colder, respectively. The integrated laser is a very nice feature, and appears to coincide well with the actual spot temperature reading, at least based on my tests from several feet away (aimed at my stove). Over all a very useful tool that's intuitive to use and well-designed.

The video quality is high, and as a nice touch they include an 89 GB Kingston SD card. These are the high points, and given their importance and the cost, it's enough to give this four stars. The reason it doesn't get five is that the instructions and interface couldn't be worse. I pretty much just had to play around with the counterintuitive buttons to figure out how to do anything, because the English was so poor in the instructions. So, I can recommend this, but only on value for the price. If price is no object, I recommend finding a higher end brand with better design.

We have a variety of Z-Wave lights in our house, both from Leviton and GE, and I can say without reservation the the Levitons are worth the extra money. They respond faster and more reliably, they are much smaller and easy to install, especially in older electrical boxes, and they look a heck of lot better, too. We've also had a couple GE-branded Z-Wave light switches die on us, but never a Leviton. The Levitons also have the option of integrating with Leviton scene controllers, which lets you do neat stuff like program in complex "scenes" that activate with the single button. For example, in your living room you can have one button that makes all the lights on bright, like you'd want during the day, and another than dims some of the lights, and turns off certain other lights to avoid glare while watching a movie at night, etc.One thing to be aware of when installing these is that a neutral wire is required. If you don't know what that is, have an electrician install these. Many light switches, especially in older homes, are wired without access to a proper neutral wire. You might be able to get by wiring in ground instead of neutral, but I wouldn't recommend it; it's not safe. So, before you order this check out the wires in the switch you're going to replace and make sure that a neutral wire is available.

BOTTOM LINE UP FRONT: Very well-built camera, with the highest quality picture and video of any home webcam I've tested. While others advertise HD, this is the first camera I've tested that truly is. The setup is relatively easy, though I had a few hiccups due to the instructions leaving out a few details (see below for some tips). The only caveat to this camera is that it, like any other web-service-based camera, is a potential security vulnerability. If Nest ever got hacked, somebody would potentially have access to a device inside your home's LAN.WHAT IS GOOD:- Relatively easy setup for a webcam- High quality video- Easy to use mobile device app- Reliable web service owned by Nest, not third-party company- Free to use web service with reasonable functionality- Very solid and heavy metal construction makes it easy to positionWHAT IS NOT SO GOOD:- Setup is almost too simple; there is little help if something goes wrong- Not possible to use completely secured within LAN; will only work with internet-based service- Can take a while to start up- Requires subscription for full functionalityTIPS FOR SETTING UP: There are a few things you should know when setting this up that aren't included in the two sentences of instructions that come with the camera. First, even though it will happy to let you try, you CAN NOT use 5 GHz WiFi networks with this camera. The setup will fail but it won't give you any helpful feedback on why. Had to learn this the hard way. Second, you need to stand very close (or leave your phone close) to the camera until the entire setup process is completed. They don't tell you this, but the setup is done by connecting to the camera over a short-range bluetooth connection, so you can't stray too far from the camera while the setup is being processed. If the setup process did a better job of handling these errors (I never got any useful feedback from the app) I'd give this five stars.

Very well constructed headphones, with decent weight and heavy duty materials. The sound is very bass heavy, so it's clear these are oriented at consumer tastes, not the flat response of professional headphones. The high end is not as clear as some headphones I've used, but overall the sound is excellent for this price point. I recommend them, especially if you like bass and listen to pop or hip hop. The iPhone-compatible microphone is a nice touch, and between that and the high sensitivity of the headphones (i.e. they can get very loud without any need for an amplifier) they are a great match for an iPhone.

BOTTOM LINE UP FRONT: Fairly high quality camera, easy to configure with any web browser. Works either over the internet via a service, but can also just be used on a LAN without needing any cloud services. My only complaint is that the device attempts to talk to servers on the internet without your permission, even if you disable the cloud features.GOOD-High quality images-Pan and tilt with memory-Night vision works well, at least indoorsBAD-"Phones home" even if you don't have cloud settings enabled. (I know this by looking at my firewall logs, which show the camera trying to connect to IP address 50.18.57.254, which is evidently a server running on Amazon's cloud services infrastructure.)I don't think the unauthorized "dial out" is nefarious, so I recommend the camera with the only reservation being that if you are really paranoid about security, you should block the camera from dialing out at your firewall.

The glove did come pretty much broken in, as they claim. It's not perfect, but you can play catch right "out of the box" with this. So far it's held up well, after a few weeks of use. Granted, the dude I play catch with is only six, and isn't exactly bringing the heat, but the glove is clearly made pretty well. The adjustable wrist strap is nice, and works well to give the glove a custom fit feel.My only complain about the glove, and it's rather minor, is that there is no hole for your index finger. They include a pad for your finger, but it doesn't work as well as the hole used in other gloves.All things considered, it's a very good value and I recommend it.

THE BOTTOM LINEThis is an expensive and inefficient way to poorly press your clothes and make them smell nice. It will yield good results for a fraction of your clothes, and yet not save much time over ironing. This is only worth buying and will only save time and money if you live far away from a dry cleaners and predominantly wear clothes that must be dry cleaned. That said, given that it doesn't actually clean, and is only marginally effective at removing wrinkles, I'm not sure it's even remotely fair for the company to compare this to the cost of dry cleaning. At the end of the day, this is not cost effective for the quality of result.WHAT IS GOOD-For a few shirts and pants I tried, they actually came out less wrinkled than they went in (but not nearly as good as if they'd been ironed).-For outer wear like sport coats and suits the process is very easy, and it does yield an noticeable improvement. There is legitimate time savings, though perhaps not money, from using this on such items.WHAT IS BAD-Getting pants or dress shirts to hang right if you're tall is not easy. The hanger comes off way too easily while you're trying to get the stretchers attached, and there is barely enough room.-The results are mixed, and highly dependent on the material used. For many items, the Swash did absolutely nothing other than make it smell pretty.-It only does one item at a time. So, doing a shirt, pants, and a jacket will take 30-45 minutes, and will cost you about $8-$10, when you consider amortizing the cost of the Swash itself over its life. I'm not sure that's all that convenient or cost effective given that very marginal results you get from this.-There almost no way you're going to save money unless you live in Manhattan. I live right outside of Boston, an an area that's fairly expensive for most thing, and I can get a shirt dry-cleaned for less than $2, and a coat for about $7. Using the Swash costs about $1 for a pod (based on Amazon's lowest price) and the device itself is unlikely to last more than a few years (based on the warranty). So cleaning something with the Swash actually costs a couple dollars for most people. Unless you're only using this for jackets, you're not likely to save much money. Oh, and dry cleaning actually CLEANS and effectively removes wrinkles. This doesn't clean at all and removes wrinkles with mixed effectiveness. Not sure it's really fair to compare it to dry cleaning when it doesn't clean.I got this for free, and yet I don't plan to buy any replacement pods for it, the results were so underwhelming. I would be extremely disappointed in this if I'd paid hundreds of dollars.

This is my second waterproof case. The first (which was from another company) was way more expensive, bulky, and the gasket on it kept coming out, making it very difficult to use and giving me little confidence in it.This case, however, has given me no trouble. It's easy to attach (just make careful bite of the instructions, which let you know that there is one place on the lower left corner you need to start attaching the two halves, and another spot right next to it that you pull on to separate.The mechanism for attaching the two halves is rather clever, and acts sorry I'd like a zipper, creating a very solid and reliable connection.I tested the case for several hours in about a foot of water, and there were no noticeable leaks.Touch ID works just fine when the case is on.Highly recommended.

Bottom line: This is well-designed, easy to use, and accurate. Results matched what I recently got from my doctor, and are repeatable to within 5%.Pros:- Nice interface using your cell phone- Logs all readings on phone- Integrates into Apple HealthKit on iPhone/iPad- Both accurate and preciseCons:- Short range Bluetooth protocol used; may not work if phone is even a couple feet away from device or blocked by your body. Given that you will probably be holding your phone in one hand while the pressure monitor is on your other arm, this is pretty minor issue.

The lamp is more than bright enough to read by, but probably not much more than that. My wife has been using it as a nightstand lamp for reading, and it's been great. The disadvantage of being USB-powered is that you need to find either a very long USB cord or some sort of extension. However, the convenience of being able to use this wirelessly is more than worth it. It's probably not a great idea for camping, however, as the base does not have enough weight for this to stand on its own reliably on anything other than a hard surface. In fact, it's pretty easy to knock over even on a tabletop, which is my only criticism of this and why I'm giving it four, instead of five, stars.

I was interested in this wallet because my current leather one keeps bending and damaging the magnetic strips on my credit cards. However, I was a bit concerned that a metal wallet would be uncomfortable to have in my back pocket, especially when sitting. That fear was completely unfounded; this wallet is thin enough that you don't notice it at all. In fact, the first few times I went out with this one, I kept thinking I forgot my wallet.This is big enough for six plastic credit cards, or you can stuff multiple paper cards (like coffee stamp cards) and bills in one of the slots. You really can't double-up credit cards, however, so if you have more than five credit cards you're going to have trouble using this wallet.The construction is solid, with heavy spring steel used for the clasp mechanism, and a solid metal hinge on the back. I don't expect this to wear out any time soon.The only possible disadvantage to this wallet (besides the obvious space limitation inherent in a thin metal wallet) is also probably an advantage for some. As they claim, this wallet does indeed make it impossible for a hacker to pull information off of any RFID cards you have (such as subway cards or building access card). However, that means that in order to use any of those cards, you'll have to open the wallet and take them out. This is obviously less convenient than just taking your wallet out and holding it up against the card reader, but if you're really paranoid (or live near MIT) you may think the extra security is worth it.

I have the waterproof version of this camera, and was disappointed that the interface was only available to Windows users willing to use IE and ActiveX. Worse, however, is this: I decided to turn on the outbound firewall on my router to see if anything on my network was dialing out, and discovered that this device has been communicating with at least one external server on its own. In other words, without me doing anything (and, in fact, without me even setting up the device) this camera has been sending information out (I can't tell what) on the internet. There is no good reason to do this, and some pretty nefarious reasons why they might do it.I will NEVER buy anything from this company, and I encourage you all to do the same. In fact, given recent headlines on Chinese state-sponsored hacking, I don't think I will ever put another device on my network sold by a Chinese company. (I know that's going to be hard, and the components for a lot of things are made in China, but I think there's less risk of a Chinese supplier trying anything shady with components bound for another company's product.) For all I know, a portion of Chinese consumer electronics companies are fronts for Chinese hackers, trying to get people to put cyber implants on their home networks. To be clear, I am not suggesting this company's device is doing anything malicious, but there is absolutely no reason a device should be talking to anything on the internet without your permission, and without you initiating the connection.

Many Chinese made cables are not actually Apple certified, but are actually using reverse engineered chips. Unfortunately for people trying to save money with these knock-off cables, Apple has ways of breaking these fake cables with iOS updates. So, even if a cheap cable works now, you have to wonder if it will work after an update.Well, I can answer that for you, unfortunately, in the case of these cables. I'm currently beta testing iOS 9.0, and I can tell you these appear to be fake cables, not truly Apple certified. Neither my iPhone nor my iPad recognize these cables. However, the Belkin cable I bought recently still works, so I'm confident there isn't a bug in the beta version of iOS 9 that is causing them to break. Most likely, iOS 9 includes a firmware update that breaks some reverse-engineered, non-MFi certified cables, and everybody who has these cables will suddenly find them to be useless when iOS 9 is officially released later this year.I wish it weren't so hard to trust these Chinese companies, but this isn't the first time this has happened, and it won't be the last time. Fraud and corruption is pretty much standard business practice in China these days. For more information on the issue of fake cables, see this article:http://www.cnet.com/news/why-im-done-buying-cheap-lightning-cables/

UPDATE: I was given this for free in exchange for an honest review. My initial review of this was two stars, based on the fact that this only works using Windows ActiveX, something not available to Mac users, and something not all PC users will be comfortable using from a security perspective. If you just try to use the local web interface, everything is in Chinese, with no option to switch to English. However, I've uncovered a much worse issue than any of this which causes me to drop this down to one star, and recommend that NOBODY purchase this. I decided to turn on the outbound firewall on my router to see if anything on my network was dialing out, and discovered that this device has been communicating with at least one external server on its own. In other words, without me doing anything (and, in fact, without me even setting up the device) this camera has been sending information out (I can't tell what) on the internet. There is no good reason to do this, and some pretty nefarious reasons why they might do it.Given recent headlines on Chinese state-sponsored hacking, I don't think I will ever put another device on my network sold by a Chinese company. (I know that's going to be hard, and the components for a lot of things are made in China, but I think there's less risk of a Chinese supplier trying anything shady with components bound for another company's product.) For all I know, a portion of Chinese consumer electronics companies are fronts for Chinese hackers, trying to get people to put cyber implants on their home networks. To be clear, I am not suggesting this company's device is doing anything malicious, but there is absolutely no reason a device should be talking to anything on the internet without your permission, and without you initiating the connection.

I had a lot of trouble connecting to this, initially. It turned out that this isn't yet compatible with iOS 9. (It's currently in beta test, so it's fair that they don't work with it yet, but be aware that when it's released early this Fall, it may still not work.) Once I tried using an old iPod that was using 8.4, everything worked. It's not a flawless setup, as it takes a very long time to connect to the Guardzilla WiFi, but it worked.Video quality is fine. Not great, but perfectly serviceable for security purposes. The night vision doesn't work terribly far if there are objects in the field of view nearby (which get too much IR, causing the camera to underexpose far objects). The best place is in a corner away from furniture. This will also give the motion sensor a good view of the room.I tried talking to my kids with the build-in microphone and speaker, but the sound was too weak for them to hear me. I tested it myself, and it's indeed weak but could be used to talk to somebody if they knew to be standing next to it. You just can't expect to get anybody's attention in the house with it.The other reviewers are right about the loud clicking sound; for some reason the motion detector must be firing a relay that makes a really loud sound. I'm not sure why they needed a relay, but my guess is they used a prefab sub circuit designed for hard-wired security systems that needed a relay. They clearly don't need a relay for this application, so that's a bit of a design flaw, in my opinion. There's no need to make that much noise for something that should be all transistor.The industrial design is interesting, but unfortunately not very well-considered. The device is very unstable, and wants to tip forward. It just barely rests upright and any jostling will cause it to tip over. Not exactly what you want in a security device.All in all, while the device has some short-comings and could use some redesign, it does do what it is supposed to do. For $99, you probably aren't going to get a similarly capable device, so I recommend it for people protecting a small apartment or studio. For a whole house, it's not going to work, but if you just have one entrance, this is actually a very cost effective way to get some peace of mind.

I was very pleasantly surprised by the quality of this light. It's bright as all heck, and has a nice feature where you can set the light level by how many times you click. However, unlike other multilevel flashlights I've used, this one is smart enough to know that once you've chosen a setting, the next time you hit the power button it should just turn off, regardless of the light level. In other words, if you set it to dim, you don't have to cycle through "bright flashing" mode to turn it off.The flashlight doubles as a cell phone charger, and itself charges off of any USB port. Given that most cars these days have USB ports in the glovebox, a nice use for this light is to keep it charging in your glovebox, ready for use in an emergency. You'll be guaranteed to never be stranded without a charged cell phone if your car ever breaks down!

Bottom line: While not commercial quality, the microscope is good enough for home use and introducing kids to the science of microscopy. The image quality is not great due to over compression (at least on the Mac version of the software), but is more than good enough for educational purposes, especially considering the price.What is good:- Camera is easy to setup and use- Integrated lighting- High quality opticsWhat isn't so good:- Stand not very stable. The course focus adjustment has way too much play, making it hard to keep centered on a specimen- Lighting interferes with image when zoomed out- Mac software doesn't work well- Images overly compressed. (See some of the images attached.) Since this is actually just a video camera with a macro lens, the data coming off the microscope is compressed video. When taking snapshots, you're really just getting a frame of video, with all the blocking artifacts inherent to compressed video. The quality could have been MUCH better had they written firmware for the camera that allow high quality JPG frames to be sent over.Tips:- Zooming is handling by moving the entire camera up and down using the knobs on the stand (or manually, if you're holding it). Once you have the image the size you want, then focus the image using the knob on the camera itself.- Unless your sample is reflective, you generally want to use as much light as possible. At first the image will wash out, but just wait a second and it will adjust the exposure. The more light you have, the less noise you'll have in your image.NOTE: If your computer doesn't have a CD drive, you're going to need to download the software over the Internet. As far as I can tell, Crenova doesn't have a website for this purpose. However, this microscope is exactly the same hardware as the Celestron digital microscope, and I've confirmed that their software works on the Crenova. (It's likely all the same, provided by the same company that made this white label for both Celestron and Crenova.) Links are below:Windows software: http://www.celestron.com/creative/downloads/44308-windows.zipMac software: http://www.celestron.com/creative/downloads/44308.zipHope this helps.

My hair is thick, and grows pretty much straight out my head. The only way to have my hair take a style other than “mid-electrocution” is to use some sort of product. I’ve tried lots of different things (pomades, styling creams, not showering, Mobil 5W30) but I generally hated using them because they made my hair look and feel like that of a New Jersey bouncer. I really don’t like having greasy hair.I’m really glad I got to try this stuff. While it goes on like a regular styling cream, once it dries it actually makes your hair softer than before, and yet somehow stays in place. Basically, if you have thick unmanageable hair, this stuff will somehow change your hair on a molecular level to the normal hair of a person that dated in high school.It smells fine, but not something you normally associate with hair. Sort of like standing between a hair salon and an Italian restaurant, in terms of scent. I assume that's due to the Rosemary.So, given that this stuff is so great, why four stars instead of five? Because it’s overpriced. Jack Black recently lowered the amount of product, but kept the price the same. The tube you get is far less than half full. Unless they were losing money before, they are price gouging now.  You used to get about 18% more in a bottle than you do now. Unlike a pomade, you’ll go through a bottle of this fairly quickly with daily use, so I think $15 is a bit high. In fact, it works out to be about as expensive per ounce as the historical value of silver. Or $550 per gallon. No matter how you look at it, this is a lot of money for stuff you put in your hair. (Incidentally, the company is named not after the actor, who would never overcharge for hair product, but was a name completely made up by the company before the actor became well-known. Apparently, it sounded like an approachable name, somebody you would trust enough to not bother to check the weight on the package.)At the end of the day, I can definitely recommend this stuff, but also recommend that you try other less expensive options first.

Kwikset appears to make locks for people who want to save money and time, but who don't really care that much about the stuff on the other side of the door. While the lock looks very nice, and the keypad seems well-built, the lock core itself is light and doesn't seem to be very substantial. The bolt itself is hollow and lightweight.Doing a bit of research, it appears that these locks are, indeed, not very substantial. They are easily cracked in a few seconds by anybody with a screwdriver and a wrench. See the following Wired article for examples:http://www.wired.com/2013/08/kwikset-smarkey-lock-vulns/I know that no lock is impenetrable, and any residential door can be kicked down, but locks should at least slow down a burglar or force them to draw attention to themselves in order to get in. These will do neither.

Bottom line--------------These aren't as healthy as they imply. The sugar content is hidden by using at least three different sweeteners in the ingredients list. Were they combined, sugar would be the second ingredient.Taste------This is subjective, but they tasted fine, like an oatmeal cookie. And an cookie is essentially what these are, despite the "healthy" spin they try to put on these. There is way more almond flavor than I'd like, and they are much sweeter than they need to be, but it's not bad.Health--------Unlike taste, this is objective, and why I'm only giving it three stars. Nature Valley is known for making candy and selling it as health food. I was hoping they were turning over a new leaf with this product, but they most certainly are not. They brag that they aren't using corn syrup, which is true, and sugar is the third ingredient. What they don't tell you is that there are three forms of sugar in the ingredients list, and when added together, they essentially make sugar the second ingredient. So, don't let the packaging fool you; these are cookies, plain and simple. They have the same amount of sugar as an oatmeal cookie, with some protein thrown in.

Really well constructed cable. I'll update this review if it proves otherwise, but I expect this cable will last far longer than the rubber ones that come with the iPhone. The cable is made of braided fabric, which gives it a rely nice, high quality feel to it. I have had no problems with the cable either charging or syncing, so I suspect this is a legitimate Apple-licensed cable

Bottom line: Does the job, but is cheaply made and poorly designed, with a metal cover that gets extremely hot very close to the knob that lowers the bread. More details follow.What's Good:Well, the toaster works, and it does toast bread and bagels fairly quickly and evenly.What's Bad:The construction is very cheap, with many of the mechanisms made out of plastic, and the controls with a flimsy feel to them. It doesn't feel like something that will last very long; I will update this review in a few months to say more about how well it holds up.The worst thing about this toaster is the poor design, however. Our prior toaster, a Kitchenaid, would get hot on the outside, but nothing that would burn you. Somehow they insulated the outer surface from the heat of the interior. However, after just toasting once, the top surface of this unit gets hot enough to really burn you. So, fine, just don't be an idiot and touch the top surface, right? Well, if you look at the picture you'll see that they made the poor choice to wrap the top piece of metal around to that it's very close to the handle that pushes down the bread. It's thus very easy to accidentally brush your hand against this when pushing down a second or third piece of bread. Not a brilliant design choice.

These work well and are a good value, compared to ones we've seen at the big name orange hardware store. Just be aware they aren't that bright, because fluorescent lights don't have tremendous amounts of red in them to begin with, so if you filter down to only the red you're not left with much. That said, it's enough to make a small room glow a very satisfying, deep red. Fun for kids, and immature adults like me.Are there any practical uses? Supposedly red light has health benefits, but I'm guessing much of that is psychosomatic, given that all regular white lights have red in them. That said, it is well known that red (or orange) light is better for use before bed so as to not fool your brain into thinking its day time. So, perhaps it's worth replacing one light in a room with these for use as a "night light" that won't mess with your sleep cycle if you need to get up in the middle of the night. Plus, the nuclear submarine-like atmosphere created by the light during your midnight bathroom runs may be the only cool thing about having an enlarged prostate.

When I first put this in a wall sconce, I thought there was something wrong, as we weren't seeing much "glow" from white or fluorescent objects. I then realized that the glass of the sconce was probably absorbing all the UV. Removed the glass, letting the bare CFL project in to the room, and: *boom* it was disco night at the roller rink. So, make sure you mount these bulbs in a bare socket, without glass or even a shade impeding direct light from these. Most materials absorb UV pretty well, so you really need these bulbs to be completely exposed to get the full effect.

These bulbs were a good deal, and work well. We used them indoors in the kids' room for fun, so we can't vouch for the efficacy in dealing with bugs. The only reason I didn't give them give stars, given how good a value they are, is that the packaging is really inadequate for shipping. (I'm talking about the manufacturer's packaging, not what Amazon is responsible for. One of our bulbs was broken on arrival, and I'm surprised more weren't given how thin the box is.

There is no such thing as a free lunch, but in the case of LED lights we find that somebody has been stealing our lunch for a long time with standard bulbs. Most of the energy you pay to put in an incandescent bulb gets wasted as heat. Compact fluorescents are efficient and don't have that problem, but they are not as full spectrum as incandescent and take a while to get to full brightness. An LED light, however, has nearly the same spectrum as an incandescent, turns on instantly, lasts nearly as long as a human, and yet consumes a sixth of the energy for the same amount of illumination. The only cost is a higher upfront cost, but these pay for themselves in lower energy use and longer life. The future of lighting is clearly in LEDs.What's nice about these bulbs is that they have the smooth appearance of a regular bulb, and will fit anywhere a regular bulb fits, with only few exceptions. They are also a pretty good value, compared to other brands of LED light.

We've got two small kids in our family plus a father who is a nerd with lots of electronic toys. So, we are constantly recharging batteries. I got this to replace a Lacrosse BC-1000 recharger, one of the more popular ones out there. It worked well, but it eventually overcharged a battery which leaked all over the unit, a known problem with the BT-1000s. Furthermore, it had a horrendously complicated interface.I'm very happy to have switched to this. The interface couldn't be more simple; just a single button. Build it down to change modes, and click it to switch between charging rates. Unlike the BC-1000, you can change charging rates in the middle of a charge without having to take all the batteries out.The charger makes a noise as each battery is done, which is either awesome or infuriating depending on the time of day, especially since charging four batteries at once yields four alarms at slightly different times. Wish there were a way to disable the alarm.What do you lose in exchange for this simplicity? As far as I can tell, the only thing this charger is missing that the Lacrosse had was the ability to have a different charging rate for each battery. Of course, in five plus years with the Lacrosse before it died I never used that feature even once.I'll be sticking with this charger, and will update this review if anything goes wrong with it. If you don't see anything new below this line, you can assume the charger is working great since the original date of the review.

There are two greats things about these batteries. The first is the main point of using lithium chemistry: these really do last much longer than normal alkalines. I've used this in a home security camera and got way longer life out of them than normal batteries, by at least a factor of five (though I didn't measure exactly).The second great thing about these is that they are incredibly light, with regular batteries weighing almost 50% more, and rechargeable so even more than that. So, when you throw these in, say, a wireless mouse, not only will they last longer but you'll be amazed at how light your mouse feels.The only disadvantage to these batteries is that they cost more. However, when you consider that you're paying for power, and these deliver a lot more, in the long run these are actually a pretty good value.

3:21 MinsHighlights:- Clean industrial design- High quality materials and solid feel- Bright screen with great color- Large screen- FM radio- 8 MP cameraLow points:- Laggy interface- Visible refresh lines on screenNOTE: Amazon compresses the video so much for video reviews that you won't be able to see the vertical lines I'm talking about in the last section. You'll just have to take my word for it. (If Amazon allows it, you can also go to jonb.us/Blu%20Studio%20X%20Review.mp4 and see a higher-quality version of the video.)

If you buy this for fun, you'll probably be happy. But don't actually buy this to use seriously as an alarm for a kid. For one, the sound it makes is horrendous. But most importantly, you'll have to remember to turn the alarm on every night. The reason is that there is no way to silence the alarm when it goes off without turning it off completely. It's also very hard to get the alarm set accurately. It's a fun toy, but not a real alarm clock.

I use this for spreading ice melt, something we got quite a bit of practice doing this winter in Boston. Went through a huge bag of the stuff. Anyway, I can recommend this spreader without reservation. Yes, it's plastic, but it's nonetheless quite well-built. The mechanism is smooth, and does a good job throwing. The best part of the design is the "loop" that you put your arm through, which makes it easy to hold without getting tired, since the weight of the contents are borne on your arm, and not your wrist.

Well, this is going to hurt my considerable street cred. Nothing says "bad @$%" like a five star, excited review for triple action dust wipes. But these are AWESOME! Among my many manly qualities lurks a particularly manly species of obsessive compulsive disorder, which, to the consternation of my wife, will result in me stepping over mounds of laundry and half eaten plates of food to dust our TV, or piano, or computer. The inside of my car? An operating room. The living room? Mayhem. With most things I'm pretty slovenly. But if it's electronic or moves, I'm like Martha Stewart after a cocaine binge.What's so good about these? They are impregnated with something that makes them dust magnets. Not sure what it is, but there is a very subtle tackiness to these such that they just grab dust, and don't spread it around not matter how much you dust something. I tried them on a really dusty table in the attic, and the wipe came away dark with dust, but the table was perfectly clean.Keep in mind, though, that these are ONLY good for dusting. Because of the stuff in them, these probably won't absorb liquid very well, and aren't useful for general cleaning.

I was skeptical of how good these would be given the cost, but they are now my favorite wired headphones. They are extremely light, and very comfortable. They don't protrude uncomfortably far into the ear like a lot of other in-ear phones. The cord is a nice touch; high quality braided nylon, not rubber. It looks like it will hold up much better than rubber, will is not as likely to deteriorate, discolor or crack.The sound quality, however, is probably the most important thing. The sound is crisp and natural. The bass isn't overdone, but it's solid. For the price the sound is just excellent. The only better sound from headphones I've used were from a very expensive pair of Etymotics, which cost about 10 times more and hurt my ears after wearing them for more than 30 minutes.I recommend this without reservation, especially when they are selling for less than $50.

WHAT'S GOODThe fit is probably the best part of the headset. It's the first in-ear headsets I've tried that stay firmly fixed in place and yet don't hurt after a long while. I wish other companies would figure this out, but the Soundpeats folks have come up with a very nice design here. It's very easy to forget you're wearing this, since they are comfortable and the cord is so light and short.The sound quality is good, but not stellar. You don't buy a Bluetooth headset to get phenomenal sound, you do so for convenience, so I consider the sound quality more than adequate.I've used this for a few weeks now, and I've found them to be very reliable.WHAT'S NOT SO GOODI've only found two issues with it: if you pair this with two or more devices, it can get in a loop where it keeps bouncing from one to the other in rapid succession. If you avoid trying to pair this with multiple devices, you'll be fine.The second issue, and why I'm giving this four, instead of five, stars: the microphone is very poor. When I tested it, the person on the other end had a tough time hearing me. I was in an area of strong signal, so I assume it was the microphone. It's not surprising; the location of the microphone is not great. Unless you have an incredibly tiny head, the microphone will be on the right side of your neck. Assuming the cord is going behind your neck, as designed, there's really no good way to pull it closer to your mouth.

When we got this, we were a bit worries that the kids might bore of it quickly. After all, there's just a single loop, unless you have one of the compatible track sets to link this to. However, I should know better than to underestimate the imagination of young children. They have a ball with this, and have been playing with it quite a bit, taking it off the track and making up stories about the broken track and so on.The way Thomas tips over is pretty cool, and you think it's going to fall when right at the last minute it goes up on two wheels. A nice "special effect" in real life.The train is well designed, and stays on the track reliably.

You put your phone in the special holder, and on the back of the case there is a mounting bracket. That bracket is the exact opposite of the spring loaded mount that you attach to your bike, except rotated 45 degrees. When you put your phone in and then rotate it the two halves snap in place very precisely and securely. Ok, so I'm having trouble explaining this in words, but trust me when I say it's very solid. If you crash your bike, you and the bike will probably break before your iPhone separates from the mount.The only reason I can't give it five stars is that the case is a bit of a pain to get the phone in. Maybe that's a good thing for protecting your phone, but unless you plan to keep the bulky case on your phone all the time, you are going to spend a bit of time taking your phone in and out of the case. View used bike mounts that used a latching case that was much quicker to take the phone in and out of.

The keyboard itself is well-built, and pairs easily. For a small keyboard, it's quite easy to type quicklyu, and they made the nice design decision to make the keys rather small, leaving plenty of space between them and limiting misses. That said, there are other poor design choices that keep from from rating this higher. First, it's very difficult to get the iPad in and out of the case. Given how bulky the folio is, you probably won't want to use this all the time, so that's a problem. When I tried to get my iPad out, I was afraid I was going to break it; there is no good way to grasp the iPad when trying to remove it so you end up having to pull it out by the corner. The other unfortunate thing about the case is that when closed the keyboard contacts the iPad at only three rubberized points along its perimeter, leaving a large gap in the center. When in a bag I'd be concerned that any pressure on the case will put push the keyboard into the screen, possibly scratching or cracking the glass. It would've been better had they added a few more contact points to keep the hard plastic keys from contacting the iPad's screen.

We've tried three different blue tooth speakers in this price range, and this is by far the best constructed and designed. The commonly used buttons are entirely on the side, and are large and easy to press. There is a cover for the rarely used configuration buttons and charging port. There are no visible buttons on the speaker, making for a very clean look. There is also an integrated five LED battery charge indicator, a very nice touch.The sound quality is quite good, but not stellar. The bass is a bit overdone, and the middle frequencies are somewhat muddy. If you want really crisp sound, you'll have to pay way more and get a bigger speaker. However, given that it's the best sound I've heard at this price point, I'm still giving it five stars.

BOTTOM LINEThese are the best wipers I've ever used, and employ a unique design to hold the curve of the windshield without lifting in the center. While they are expensive, it is worth the money.WHAT'S GOODThe performance, so far, is stellar. It's the quietest wiper I've ever used, which I assume is due to the graphite coating on the blades. I've only used them for about a month, but I will come back an update this when I see how long they last. If they are anything like the ICONs (and these should last longer given the coating) they should go for the better part of the year, at least.The installation is very easy. It's got a universal adapter that works with most wiper mounts. In my case (a J bracket) you just slide it in place until it clicks, snap the cover back down, and you're done. About five seconds on each side, no exaggeration.The spring steel does a good job holding the wiper to the windshield, regardless of the speed. I have a pretty curved windshield that is sometimes hard to find wipers for, at least on one side, but these leave no streaks where the wiper missed the glass.The spring is encased in a spoiler that is built as a series of articulating links. Not only does it look pretty cool, the way it's built means that they spring can have a lot of force at the edges (to hold the curve of the windshield) while not lifting up in the center due to that force. It's very ingenious, and nothing I've ever seen on wipers before.WHAT'S BADWell, the only thing that's bad about these is that they are more expensive than just buying the rubber wiper inserts. When these need to be replaced, you'll be throwing out the whole thing and buying a new one, even though the only part that will be worn is the rubber insert. It's not a huge expense, but I wish Bosch would figure out a way to let you just replace the rubber. I'm guessing they could do that easily but would never want to give up having us all pay to replace the entire wiper blade even though the most expensive part of it doesn't wear out.

This pairs easily with a WiFi network through a very clever set up process where you use your phone's WiFi settings to configure the scale. The scale is accurate to about half a pound, but the heart rate monitor significantly underestimates my heart rate as compared with a medical grade pulse oximeter. I guess you just can't get a reliable pulse through the feet... The air quality measurement is suspect as well, given that it changed significantly over the few minutes I tested it. Same with temperature, and I'm guessing they didn't go a great job isolating the temperature sensor from the effects of your feet heating the scale. Either that, or it's just not a good temperature sensor.Overall, I'm glad I bought this, but just take the measurements other than weight with a grain of salt. They are probably only worth using for trending, and not absolute measurements.

I've been using this product for several years, and it's the ONLY thing that has cured my seasonal allergies. Before taking it, I would not only have the usual runny nose and itchy eyes, but I would also have what felt like asthma. A doctor suggested that it might all be due to allergies affecting my nose (rhinitis) that was causing the other symptoms, and they were absolutely right. Once I started on Flonase, after about a week or two all the other symptoms went away, especially the problems in my lungs. Evidently if allergies are causing a runny nose, that can drip into your lungs and irritate them, and all the sneezing can cause problems with your eyes.So, if you suffer from bad allergies and are taking inhalants and doing eye drops, etc. try starting with this and see if it solves those other problems.Because this is a topical steroid, and not an antihistamine, it's going to take about a week or so before you see the full effect. In fact, just one dose probably won't yield a noticeable improvement. That's the relatively small price you pay for a drug that has so very little side effects. I generally don't tolerate allergy medicines well, and most make me feel groggy, even the second generation ones that aren't supposed to. I have no side effects with Flonase, however.

Given how thin the iPhone 6 already is, adding this case doesn't actually make the phone unreasonably thick. It's about the thickness of one of the original iPhones. It's not much heavier, either. So, what you get for that small increase in weight and thickness is absolutely worth it: you get more than twice the battery time.I confirmed the extra battery time by running my iPhone down to nothing, and timing how much usage I got. I then charged up the phone and this case and repeated the experiment. The result was a little more than twice the battery life with the case, just what they advertise.The unit also includes an integrated battery indicator, a series of small LEDs cleverly hidden in the case that let you know how much charge is left in the case. A very nice touch.This case would be perfect for anybody who travels, as you could watch movies or do e-mail on the phone on a long flight without the phone coming close to discharging. I recommend this without reservation.

Nice concept, but terrible execution. Ours was broken out of the box, and one half of one of the tracks was dead. So, so much for both of our kids playing with this. It probably wouldn't have mattered anyway, as our three year old couldn't spin the crank fast enough to keep the car moving.

We decided not to use these, so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt that they would catch mice had we left them in place. They are easy to load, and much safer than normal mousetraps if you are worried about you or your curious kids coming across them and accidentally getting whacked. You'd have to really try hard (or be a small hungry mouse) to set these off.So, why one star? These aren't even remotely humane. I assumed that inside was a regular trap that would quickly kill the mouse. However, all this does is slam the mouse up against the side wall with a little scoop and trap it. I'm guessing it's a slow death, either from starvation or slow asphyxiation. If you catch a mouse, you'll likely throw it in the garbage still alive. The entire point of this trap is to insulate you from having to deal with the idea of killing a mouse, which is fine, but I can't really support that if it comes at the expense of being the least bit humane. Seems kind of weak to needlessly hurt the mouse just so you don't have to deal with the idea of looking at it.I'm no PETA zealot, and I have zero problem with killing rodents. But I think if you have two options for how to dispatch the little buggers, and one is a quick death and one is a slow one, it's not fair to choose the latter for the animal just so you don't have to look at it after it's dead. Had I known how these worked, I would not have ordered them. I understand if people can't deal with normal traps, but in that case, I suggest calling a professional rather than using these poorly designed ones.

Prior to this set, we had a rather expensive set from a well-known store with the initials W.S. They were nice, but they were made out of single pieces of brushed aluminum, pressed into the shape of measuring cups and spoons. They were solid and heavy, and yet they bent all the time when scooping dense ingredients (such as brown sugar). This set of measuring cups and spoons don't look as good, to be honest, but they are clearly meant for serious duty in a kitchen, and are about function over form. The handles are much more solid, and are welded to the cups. They won't fold over when scooping heavy ingredients, no matter how much force you use. It's clear these will stand the test of time, and I'm glad we finally moved from the trendy to the functional. This isn't what you'd buy from an expensive catalog, but it's probably what you'd find in the kitchen of your favorite restaurant.

Right up front, let's be clear: this is meant to be a fun book. It's about fun, not actually teaching you anything useful. Some of the facts are interesting (such as how dry cleaning works), but don't take it too seriously. For the subjects where I'm actually knowledgeable, I found enough errors that it's clear this book was not well-researched. For example, it repeats a common misperception about aerodynamics in the chapter on sailing, but most of what it says it right on. Does that take away from it? A bit, but I still think it's a great book that gives the reader a peak into worlds they probably aren't familiar with. And it does so in an entertaining way and covers a broad array of interesting areas. Anybody with a good dose of curiosity will enjoy it.

I've got through four (!) of these Bluetooth wireless transmitters in as many years. This one has far and away the best sound quality. I don't know how they are doing it. Maybe this thing is blasting away with more FM radio power than authorized by law, but this is the first wireless FM transmitter that actually sounds good and doesn't constantly drop in and out of stereo. I live in the Boston metro area, so there really aren't any completely dead frequencies, and this is the only one that can overpower the out-of-range station on the "dead" frequencies in the area.The only reason I'm not giving this five starts is that the speakerphone on this is absolutely the worst of the four units I've used. I don't know what they did, but when people talk to me it sounds like they are coming through the radios in "Battlestar Galactica", and the other party has a terrible time hearing me. I've called myself with this device and left a voicemail and can confirm that the microphone quality is next to useless.So, I can recommend this highly if you're planning to just use it to listen to streaming sound on your phone. If you want to make calls, however, look elsewhere.

This works great with an iPhone for listening to music or news radio in the shower. As an added bonus, if you hold down the Phone button, you can activate Siri and ask "her" questions while in the shower: you can ask about your schedule that morning, check the time, or start any song in your collection by request. Kind of a cool thing to be able to do while standing naked in your shower; most personal assistants will sue under such conditions!The sound quality for music is surprisingly good. It's not stereo, obviously, but it's actually not a problem. The shower acoustics seems to create its own stereo! I got this to listen to the news while in the shower, but was pleasantly surprised that it's actually quite nice to listen to music, too. Just be careful; you're likely to waste a lot of water with this thing!The only caveat I have is that this is next to useless as a speakerphone, especially in the shower. The microphone is very low quality, and has no noise canceling. As such, nobody will be able to hear you if you're in the shower, and they will barely be able to hear you otherwise. (I've tested this a few times by leaving voicemails for myself and checking the voice quality.)I can recommend this without reservation so long as you don't actually expect to use the speakerphone feature.

This is the best baster we've ever used. (No, that's not a sentence I ever thought I'd say, but it's true.) The bulb is well sealed to avoid messes, and is made of silicone, compatible with disinfecting cycles on modern washers. In fact, this was engineered with proper cleanup in mind. The tip comes off, and a brush is included which allows the interior to be completely cleaned. This is pretty important when considering that this will likely be used on poultry. With the tip attached, the baster is gently curved, making it possible too use in a much more natural grip. It's hard to explain why without venturing into way more baster-related prose than I'm comfortable with, so you'll just have to trust me that it's a much better design than typically used.

I wouldn't consider myself an audiophile, but just somebody who really likes music and who thinks that good speakers/headphones can help you appreciate a song more. These headphones have a very full, balanced sound, but without being overwhelming in bass. I have the same experience with these that I did when I got a pair of etymotics in-ear headphones; when you hear a song with these that you've only heard with the stock iPhone headphones, you notice all sorts of details you didn't hear before. However, unlike in-ear headphones, these are actually comfortable to wear for long periods of time, and have a more solid bass. In fact, these are probably the most comfortable over-the-ear headphones I've ever owned.

After two months, the box started to become flakey, hanging and crash. At some point, the box wouldn't even boot up. It just hangs at the Roku icon screen upon start up. Customer support is awful, and they want me to pay to have this shipped back to them for replacement, even if they deem it to be defective.It's clear Roku's policy is try to make something reliable but cheap (which they seem to succeed at, given the high average review) and then not really support the few people that get bad units. Maybe that works as a business model, but it's infuriating if you get one of the bad ones.Down vote me if you will, but I'm just adding my experience. The review system only works if you get a good statistical sample from across all the experiences. I'm glad it works for most people, but those considering buying this over an Apple TV or Amazon Fire TV should know that if something goes wrong, you won't get much help from the company and will have to pay to have it shipped back to be fixed. So, my advice: if you have an option to buy a supplemental warranty with it, do so. Otherwise, be sure to keep ALL of the original packaging and accessories, because you will need them if you have to make a warranty claim against Roku.

I wanted a better way to type notes in my iPad than the touchscreen keyboard. This has worked perfectly. The keyboard basically feels like a slightly smaller version of the keyboard on a MacBook. There are keys to bring up the home screen, and if you're using a Windows tablet, the Start screen/menu. (I've only used this on an iPad, but I presume the Windows key works on a Surface.) The construction is aluminum, and it feels like they used a pretty solid gauge all around. Pairing worked well, and was very easy. The stand holds the iPad very securely. All around a very nice addition that greatly increases the utility of a tablet.

It is indeed blue, flat and provides a stable horizontal surface for a mouse. All for less than $2 and without having to suffer the indignity of going inside an Office Depot or Staples. For that reason alone, it would be a bargain at twice the price.

I wanted to add Z-wave controllability to a cool old bakelite switch that was probably installed around 1930-1940 in our old house. One of the big heavy old switches in a ceramic housing, back when they used BX wiring and small metal workboxes. However, there was not even close to enough room to fit this behind the switch. It's not Aeon Labs' fault, it's just that there is no way they could possibly make something small enough to squeeze in the tight spacings that were the norm in old electrical boxes, given how fat the old switches were and how small the workboxes were. So, please be aware that if you're looking to use this to retrofit existing switches, they really have to be relatively modern switches installed in modern, large workboxes. That's absolutely the only way you're going to have a chance of sneaking this in behind. Fortunately, one of the switches in the five gang panel was not being used anymore, so I pulled that out and used the empty space for the Aeotec switch. Even then, it was a very tight fit!The way this works is that you hook up your existing switch to some low voltage terminals on the Aeotec device. These are low voltage and just used to sense when somebody toggles the existing switch, and so that's why the terminals are so small: you're supposed to use small gauge wires. The reviewers who complained about stripped terminals didn't read the darn instructions and used full 14/16 gauge high voltage wires. You have to use something more like thermostat wire. In fact, that's exactly what I used and it worked great. You then hook up the high voltage terminals of the Aetec switch to your house power and load. You can either turn the light on and off with the old switch or with a zwave command; it doesn't matter which position the old switch is in. Flipping it always flips the state of the light. Very clever.One more piece of advice: unless you are installing this in new construction, you may not have all the wires you need. This product requires access to a neutral wire, and a lot of old installations didn't bother to run neutral to switch boxes. If you're in this boat, you'll have to either give up on this or do something potentially unsafe: use ground as neutral. I don't advise doing this, however, because you're completely doing away with all the safety advantages of a separate ground path. So, open the box you're planning on installing this in and making sure you've got all three wires you'll need before buying this.In summary, this is an extremely clever device that allows any switch to be used as a Zwave device if you have the right wiring and enough room left over in your box.

It's ugly and big. But while they won't win any industrial design awards for it, it's the most solid and well built inflator I've ever used. The hose is heavy duty gauge, and all the fittings are brass. I checked the gauge against two other pressure meters, and it was right on. My only complaint is that the chuck requires you to constantly push in on the valve or it will leak quite a bit of air. This is not a huge problem, however, because the inflator is easy to operate with one hand, leaving your other hand free to just hold the chuck on the stem.UPDATE: I'm dropping this from five to two stars. The battery will die after less than a year, even if you almost never use it. I suspect there is some sort of leakage in the system that causes the batteries to die (as others have found). Unfortunately, replacing the battery is not at all easy. My recommendation: skip this tool and buy Astro's excellent tire inflator that uses a manual gauge. The digital version is a complete PITA, and I'm guessing most people (like me) just write a glowing review right after they get it, and before they discover how quickly the battery dies and how it is to get at it.

If you've gota Kohler sink that is leaking around the base, replacing both of these O-rings will likely save you the expense and trouble of having the whole thing replaced. A good indicator that these rings need replacing is if there is even a tiny bit of "wobble" in the sink spout, or if the spout has very little resistance to rotating around the base. With a properly sealing set of rings, the spout should feel very firmly set, and have a bit of resistance to swinging around side to side.

I got a small construction staple stuck in my tire. Right on the tread, small holes. Exactly what this product is designed for. I followed the directions to a 'T', the Slime "clotted" in the hole and stopped the leak, and then I drove a few miles slowly to get the stuff well distributed in the tire. I measured the pressure over a few hours and it held. The next day I drove to work and when I came to my car that evening, the tire was flat. Lost pressure faster than when I had the staple in. It's been extremely cold here (Boston in February) and we've got a lot of snow, so my guess is that this stuff doesn't work too well in those conditions.I know people seem to have good luck with this, but I figured it would be useful to temper things a bit with the perspective of somebody for whom this product didn't work at all. Most importantly, watch out when using this in very cold weather.One more thing: if you look at the reviews you'll see that's it's pretty much either 5 stars (worked for people) or 1 star (didn't at all) with not much in between. It appears to work for about 4 out of 5 people, resulting in a pretty high average review (hence the four star overall rating). However, put another way, THERE IS AT LEAST a 20% CHANCE THIS PRODUCT WILL BE A DISASTER FOR YOU. In other words, a 20% chance this will cause you far more trouble than if you'd just had the tire patched or used a more conventional tire sealant, and that will make you deeply regret buying this. I'd actually say that for a product like this a 20% chance of failure is WAY too high. So, consider the 4.5 star rating in that context. That might be a good rating for a TV, but for a product that is fixing something as important to your safety as a car tire, having 20% one star reviews actually isn't so great. Would you buy a tire that had that rate of failure?

I got a small construction staple stuck in my tire. Right on the tread, a few very small holes. Exactly what this product is designed for. I followed the directions to a 'T', the Slime "clotted" in the hole and stopped the leak, and then I drove a few miles slowly to get the stuff well distributed in the tire. I measured the pressure over a few hours and it held. The next day, however, I drove to work and when I came back to my car that evening, the tire was flat. Lost pressure faster than when I had the staple in! It's been extremely cold here (Boston in February) and we've got a lot of snow, so my guess is that this stuff doesn't work too well in those conditions.I know a lot of people seem to have good luck with this, but I figured it would be useful to temper things a bit with the perspective of somebody for whom this product didn't work at all. Most importantly, watch out when using this in very cold weather.One more thing: if you look at the reviews you'll see that's it's pretty much either 5 stars (worked for people) or 1 star (didn't at all) with not much in between. It appears to work for about 3 out of 4 people, resulting in a pretty high average review (hence the four star overall rating). And that's assuming the Slime people are uncommonly honest and don't post false positive reviews.Put another way, THERE IS AT LEAST a 25% CHANCE THIS PRODUCT WILL BE A DISASTER FOR YOU! A 25% chance this will cause you far more trouble than if you'd just had the tire patched or used a more conventional tire sealnt, and that will make you deeply regret buying this. I'd actually say that for a product like this a 25% chance of failure is WAY too high. So, consider the 4/5 star review in that context. 4/5 might be a good rating for a TV, but for a product that is fixing something as important to your safety as a car tire, having a 3:1 ratio of five to one star reviews actually isn't that great.

I'd actually say that for a product like this a 25% chance of failure is WAY too high. So, consider the 4/5 star review in that context. 4/5 might be a good rating for a TV, but for a product that is fixing something as important to your safety as a car tire, having a 3:1 ratio of five to one star reviews actually isn't that great.

I got the low cut socks.  I was very impressed with the way they kept my feet dry when I wore them.  They also leave no odor, at all.  They are definitely as described and fit my size 8.5 to 9 women's feet, perfectly.  I only received one pair to evaluate.  I think they are great.  It doesn't matter which foot you put them on, they fit great either way.  I am so glad I was chosen to receive these, gratis, in exchange for an honest, unbiased evaluation and review.  I absolutely recommend these to any active person who suffers from sweaty socks after you walk, jog, or work out.

I gave a similar Wine Chiller to my sister-in-law in a big gift bag for her wedding.  She loves it. You take the chiller out and place it in the freezer to chill a couple of hours prior to opening the wine.  She enjoys a glass of wine with dinner, but doesn't always finish the bottle.  This is a great gift because it keeps the wine fresh for several days.  The aerator keeps fresh air flowing to the wine while it is being stored, and prevents your wine from spoiling between uses.  A good bottle of wine can be expensive and I am so glad I was able to present her with a gift she truly uses on a regular basis.  It also pours the perfect glass each time.  It is a well thought out design and I am so glad I was able to give her this gift.  I am honored to have been chosen to provide my honest, unbiased opinion of this after it being thoroughly tested.  BasicWu supplied this, gratis, in exchange for my thorough testing and review of the awesome little gadget.  I am quite impressed and so are several others.  i definitely recommend this win chiller to anyone who loves a bottle of wine.

While Scalpels are not a common household item, my mother was a registered nurse and we always had one in our home.  There are plenty of uses for them.  I keep them on hand for some pesky skin tags that I seem to get occasionally.  With a super sharp blade, I don't even feel it when my husband cuts them off.  This is an easy process and saves money at the doctor's office, because they deem the procedure to be cosmetic, when it really isn't.  I hate the skin tags and this is the best way to get rid of them.The box arrived sealed and each of the ten disposable scalpels are sterile.  I put the rest of them into a baggie, immediately, trying to preserve their sterility.  I had two skin tags that needed removing and my hubby was able to easily remove them.  The scalpels have a plastic handle, and they are disposable.  However, the blades are VERY sharp.DISCLAIMER....  I do not recommend doing medical procedures at home.  I DO recommend going to your doctor about any problem.On the other hand, I HIGHLY recommend these exceptional scalpels.  They work perfectly and are super sharp.  It is great to have these on hand as you never know when an emergency will arise.  I am so glad I was chosen to receive these at a great, promotional price, in exchange for my honest, unbiased evaluation and review.

Everything about this set of Essential Oils thoroughly impressed me, as soon as I received them.  First of all, the box they arrived in was completely sealed in plastic wrap.  This stood out to me because I know they are untouched, and it added a layer of protection that is a welcomed relief over many other similar products I have received.The matte black gift box is embossed in metallic silver on top and bottom.  The top has the EA logo and the bottom includes a description, ingredients, uses, and contact information for the company.  It looks very professional and is ready for gift giving.Inside are a total of Six, 10ml bottles.  Each bottle is also safety sealed.  These oils are of superior quality and they smell amazing.This is the absolute perfect gift for introducing beginners to the wonderful world of essential oils, and even friends and loved ones who already use these products would be proud to receive this awesome gift.  The oils included are what I consider to be the essential, essential oils.  Every home should have these on hand.  There is a myriad of uses for each of these and don't be discouraged by the 10ml size of the bottles.  You only use a couple of drops at a time, so they will last for a long time.Lavender is very calming and relaxing.  I love putting it in my aromatherapy diffuser.Peppermint is invigorating and also works as a natural repellent for many insects.Eucalyptus is a natural antiseptic and it also mixes well with other oils in my diffuser.Tea Tree is my #1.  It can be added to shampoo and conditioner to prevent dandruff, it is also used to treat nail fungus.Bergamot smells divine and I love using it in my diffuser, it has a crisp citrus scent.Lemongrass is new to me, but it has a citrus scent as well and I love mixing it with peppermint.There are so many wonderful uses for these oils.  Simply Google their names and tons of uses and recipes will immediately be at your disposal!I am very impressed with the quality and purity of these oils.  I have nothing but great things to say about them.  I am thrilled to have been selected to receive these at a great promotional price, in exchange for my honest, unbiased evaluation and review.  I highly recommend these for any household.

My husband and I both fell in love with this set of brushes the first time we used them.  He is really the artist, but we paint together a couple of days a month, and it's like a date night for us both.  The quality of this set is impeccable.  I could immediately tell they were made with superb attention to detail and care.  They feel great and balance perfectly in my hand.  The brushes are lightweight, which is a huge bonus because I have carpal tunnel.  I can paint all evening and my hands don't cramp up at all!The precision I can achieve when I use these is just amazing.  They hold paint very well and my strokes are even, each time.  They come in a really nice, zippered pouch that holds each brush, perfectly.  I am so glad I was chosen to receive this set of brushes, gratis, in exchange for my honet, unbiased opinion.  I have thoroughly tested them and they are absolutely worth my 5 star rating.  I highly recommend this versatile set of art brushes.  They are great for beginners as well as novices.

The Black Rubber and Stainless Steel Design of this Door Stop by DelTucci provides excellent support and is strong enough to keep any door propped open.  It's very nice to have a door stop with such a sleek look.  It matches my modern appliances and fits in seamlessly with my decor.  Considering the alternatives to this product, it truly stands out and unlike all the other ones on the market, it isn't an eyesore to have out in my home.  I think this is a great product and I am so glad I was chosen to receive a sample of this, gratis, in exchange for my honest, unbiased opinion and feedback.  I absolutely recommend this door stop!

The MyBand Armband for iPhone 6 is absolutely unique in design and it is also very comfortable to wear, while providing excellent support and security for the phone.  Of all the different armbands I have tried for various phones, this is, by far, my favorite.  It holds the phone perfectly, while allowing me to wear it on my lower arm, instead of my upper arm.  I have always found the upper arm versions to be awkward to wear and most of them are down right painful and aggravating.  This band that allows me to wear my phone in an alternative location is simply amazing!  I love the pink terry cloth, too.It also has a small, zippered compartment that provides adequate space for my house key and ID.  To top it all off, they also added a reflective strip, which surrounds the phone and since it is positioned on the outside of my forearm, I can rest assured any oncoming traffic will see it and be aware of me as I take my nightly strolls around the neighborhood.  I love the design and execution of this product and I am so glad I was chosen to receive a sample of this, gratis, in exchange for my honest, unbiased opinion and feedback.  It is definitely worth a 5 star rating.

This Breathe Essential Oil Blend works wonders for my respiratory system when I put 4 to 5 drops in my diffuser at night when I am getting ready for bed.  It helps greatly when my sinuses are stuffed up, and I also use it by putting a few drops on a cotton ball and inhaling it directly from there.  I got the 10ml bottle, and while it may not seem like much, I only use up to 5 drops at a time, so quite frankly, this will last a very long time.Prime Cosmetics also sells it in an amber glass bottle.  The dark glass prevents any light from penetrating the bottle and damaging the oils by breaking it down.  I am so glad I was chosen to receive a sample of this, gratis, to evaluate and keep, in exchange for my honest, unbiased opinion and feedback.  I highly recommend this amazing essential oil!

I had been looking for a long tank with the cute side split for a bit and came upon this one. I just recently discovered (or shall I say re-discovered) my love for coloring and all things art. Before I got this Adult Coloring Book Id gotten two others, one that was great and the other...not so much. I have tried getting coloring books with very different designs and themes to see which I like more- I love this one!First let me note the the pages are serrated so you can tear them out- a great option if you want to photo copy a page or keep each page in a book of your own art (I created one with a binder and some slip covers). The paper is thinner than construction paper, but thicker than a regular sheet of paper so any color you use is soaked into the page. I chose to use Prismacolor Colored Pencils but fine tip Sharpies or Prismacolor double tipped markers would do great too- really any medium that allows you to get very detailed and incorporate multiple colors but also color the full design.One Adult Coloring book I purchased either had too intricate of designs or very boring, repetitive ones. This one has neither, entertaining the eye with almost 3 dimensional designs that look almost Dr. Seussian. With just a mix of color you can make a part of the picture stand out or fall into the background because of how it is drawn. The designs leave room for multiple colors if you like to blend but not so much space that you waste a ton of color in one area. They are intricate but in sections so as you tackle each one the picture really comes alive.I am so glad I got this Adult Coloring Book and would recommend it to anyone who loves coloring imaginative, unique designs.

I bought this dress knowing it had a unique fit but I like unique, one of a kind clothing so this looked like a fun addition. I absolutely love it!First let me say I am pretty small: 5'1" and around 105 lbs so I bought the Small. The straps are adjustable so you can change the neckline to be a little higher or lower. When I got it I noticed there is no tag on the inside so I had no idea which side was the front and which was the back- both are deep vee's. I found I can wear it either way and the desired result comes out fine (the pockets arent at an angle so you can do this).The pockets are a fun touch and if you put your hands in them and pull out you see that the dress is shaped like a diamond, with the top and bottom areas tighter than the hips which have a lot of roomy fabric.One of my favorite things about this dress is how it hangs on the body: like its draped horizontally (if that makes sense : ) ) Its a really fun fit and reminds me a lot of Harem pants.I can already tell Im going to get a lot of wear out of this dress. Its light enough for summer and easily paired with a sweater or jacket and boots in the fall. Its also well made so it wont fall apart after a couple wears (though I will probably never put it in the dryer).Funky dress with a different silhouette- love it.

I just recently got back into art and intricate coloring and found after getting the tips of 2 of my Prismacolor Colored Pencils chewed off by a sub par sharpener that I needed something better (to say the least. Prismacolor stuff is not cheap.). After searching a short bit I found this Prismacolor sharpener and figured since it was made by the company and "colored pencil" was in the title it would be perfect. I wasn't wrong.This is a simple little sharpener that sharpens my colored pencils to a long point- almost like when I just got them. It doesn't break the tips off or mangle the wood below the color. Plus it sharpens to really fine points so when I am coloring more intricate patterns I can get multiple colors in the space.A great little sharpener for a nice price : )

What fun and unique pants! I am so glad that I gave this style a try because they are incredibly comfortable, well made and versatile.The Design: The cotton fabric is soft and lets air flow so they dont feel too heavy- I wore them out yesterday (it was around 85 degrees) and didn't feel too warm or like all the extra fabric impeded movement. They actually are great in the movement department because you can sit down and not worry about crossing your legs if you have a skirt on yet you get the flowy-ness (lol) of a skirt. There is also a pocket on the leg that, brilliantly, has a zipper to close it. With the pant having so much fabric and movement to them anything you'd put into such a big pocket may have fallen out so the zipper is great!The fit: on the label it says "32-44" so I was a little worried, being on the smaller side, that these pants would not fit. I was pleasantly surprised when I tried them on and they fit in both the ankle and waist/hips (you can wear them up higher or a little lower on your hips like in the picture). I have 33 inch hips and I was worried that these would fall off if I walked around but I wore them all day and they were both incredibly comfortable and stayed on. The waist and ankles are definitely designed to stretch so anyone with bigger measurements will fit into these as well- I call them the magic shrinking (or growing) pants I am 5'1" and the length fit perfectly as well. Im not sure if they would fit, length wise, anyone over 5'6" though.
