I felt clean after using it without dryness, however, I wouldn't call this product moisturizing as "replenishing" implies. I used to love Neutrogena's clear bars for washing my face (too drying for my skin now), and fans of Neutrogena will love this.

Like everyone getting all the phones and tablets charged from one outlet is a pain (No, you BETTER NOT unplug my phone!). This charger helps with some limitations. It's got a relatively small footprint (about the size of a cordless phone base) and 3 USB slots to plug into. You do have to provide the USB>MiniUSB cords yourself but that's not a big issue. I like that the power cord stows away in the base and it's decent length. The slots to place your phone or tablet works with my Kindle Fire 7" and the original Kindle Fires my kids have. BUT unfortunately the slots are too narrow for the Kindle case on my Kindle so I have to remove it to set it in the slot. But actually that's inconvenient, so I just plug in and lay the Kindle next to the charger on the counter. I do wish the slots were either wider or various sizes for both narrower (phones) and thicker (tablets) to fit better. Charges great though!

My local floral dept at the grocery store often marks down unsold orchids that are done blooming. I decided to buy a  Phalaenopsis (it's only $5) and repot it as the store pot has no holes for drainage or air. I like the mix is designed for this type  of orchid including the feed. I need some time to see a real outcome, but I hope for a good result.

The fondant comes out of the box soft and pliable and ready to roll out. It takes color well and is easy to handle to sculpt figures or decorations for a cake. I like that. The flavor is not particularly pleasant nor unpleasant....sort of a bland marshmallow. My concern is that although the package proclaims a "special blend of ingredients" "all natural" and "high quality" the ingredient list includes a lot more additives and preservatives than I want to eat in _anything_. I think it's a choice between good quality ingredients and usability. You'll save a lot of time and hassle with this fondant but I wouldn't want to eat it on every cake I make (and I bake a lot).

Goes on easily and doesn't clump. The polish dried quickly (surprisingly!), with lots of glittery shine, even more so in the sun or direct light. This color has a golden tone with silvery bits and some translucency that you can layer over other colors. Terrific!

The Kenwood dicing attachment will tackle almost anything you put through it! I am thoroughly enjoying my Kenwood Chef mixer (KMC010) and I find the attachments make the mixer an all-in-one workhorse. The dicer only _dices_ fruit, vegetables and meats, you cannot slice or shred with it. However, I am a busy cook--who cooks often from scratch--and dicing is the #1 chopping I do because I use alot of recipes that call for onion, carrot, celery and potatoes. This weekend I went through 5 lbs of carrots, 3 lbs of onion and 3 lbs of potatoes for 3 separate meals in one session, quick and easy. If you do alot of big family meals or a small catering service, the dicer will be a  big time saver.The pluses: Great power, comes apart for easy cleaning, parts fit together easily, does pound after pound of dicing with no strain on the motor.The cons: only dices, VERY sharp blades so be aware when taking apart and putting back together, cannot change the size of the dice (there's only one size).I HIGHLY recommend you keep the included manual/instructions in order to know what each part is and how it goes together. I was very glad to to have the manual when I needed it. Also, I do recommend cleaning out the hopper when changing ingredients otherwise you will get a mix of two ingredients once you start dicing a new one.NOTE: I received this Dicing Attachment from Kenwood in exchange for my honest review.

In the gospels, namely Mt 19:8 and Mk 10:6, when Jesus responds to questions on the institution of Marriage, he points to the truth of God's design as is reflected in the creation accounts in the Book of Genesis. He is pointing to the state of Marriage as God established it as His own design "in the beginning." Rabbi Lapin gets to the bottom of what this means and what happened in his very meaningful verse by verse interpretation of these creation accounts and many key Hebrew words that shed much light on marriage "in the beginning." The Rabbi provides us with a humorous, but also telling, compelling and enriching commentary on this brief but very important section of Sacred Scripture.

Based on my experience reading Bill O’Reilly’s other books, this was pre-ordered since the day I heard it was coming. I am not a history expert, but thrilling books like this encourage me to continue learning about it. In each of the "Killing ..." series, I surprisingly have learned much more than I formerly did on the subject and about the person. With Ronald Reagan comes personal history like facts connected to his days in the actors guild and of course the facts leading up to the shooting. The story unfolds as only O'Reilly can tell it, very well--with great emotion! The master story-teller! Maybe Bill's reading, and later Robert Petkoff's, is the best ingredient for this (I bought the audiobook) as they present a "big picture" of all this. It is a quick read, because you want to get to the highlights. It is written in a way that there is a gradual buildup, chapter by chapter. Even if you know what's coming, the authors are all about maximizing the suspense by delaying what is anticipated. And, it's done masterfully by adding more and more details to the story in a way that moves like a mystery novel. It thickens the plot, pushing the culmination further out. Great suspense! Engaging! Informing! Highly recommended!

We are using 4 of these in each of our Church chandeliers in conjunction with a G7 Elko LED Recessed Can 100W Replacement BR30 Flood Light Bulb, Dimmable Warm White Light 2700K 15 Watt 1210 Lumen, E26 Base, Smooth downlight. These unique-looking bulbs not only distribute great light to the Church, but also diffuse the light in such a way as to light up the side walls and ceiling, where sometimes additional "up lights" or directional lights are necessary to accomplish this.

We are using them as a downlight in a Church with 16.2 foot chandeliers and they give enough light for reading. They provide a very warm light which gets very evenly distributed across the entire pew width and provides coverage for just about 5 pews perfectly. We are using these in conjunction with 4 Philips 452789  13-Watt (75-Watt) SlimStyle A21 LED Light Bulb, Soft White, Dimmable which not only distribute great light to the Church, but also diffuse the light in such a way as to light up the side walls and ceiling, where sometimes additional "up lights" or directional lights are necessary to accomplish this.

I have been using Roxio for quite some time now, but basically only the distribution software that comes with a new system. I wanted to upgrade from Roxio Easy Media Creator Suite 9, having had some problems with it on Windows 7. I saw a used copy of Roxio Easy Media Creator Suite 10 (OLD VERSION) for $17 including shipping. It seemed like a bargain. However, I got more than I bargained for. This was a complete media software package. It seemed to do too much and wanted to be the default software for everything and all file types--kinda bloatware! All I normally do is rip & burn CDs. So, I streamlined and bought this. It's all I need. Installs and works on Windows 10!

This is a great, and let me add, a necessary concept presented here in this day and age. I think it is isolating something that requires attention and focus in all of our lives, something to integrate into our daily living or just our life. This was referred to me by Amazon during a search for something I was fascinated by after reading Eric Metaxas' fabulous work: Seven Men: And the Secret of Their Greatness. Somehow, I did not record the reference, however, the recommendation was for a spiritual benefit that would be gained by reading this. The recommendation was on target. It was a quick read, about three days. McKeown's focus was what would be considered "Simplicity" in the Spiritual Life. This is quite critical if one is to practice detachment and be rid of the distractions that divert us and the obstacles that set us back. And speaking of "essential," there is not much more important in the Spiritual Life than what he presented fabulously: learning to live in the "NOW!" The whole thing resonated well. He gave very good examples. However, about two-thirds into it, it grew very monotonous. That's why I took off a star. He could have said the same with a lot less ink. Instead of repeatedly harping on the "Essentialist mantra," he could have used imaginative analogy to communicate his thoughts and not have worn out the reader. Still, the concept is great. I am left with vivid memories of action that can be of great benefit if incorporated into my life, or maybe better as he said simply lived and not another task to perform. I can speak for myself, but I think he succeeds in showing we all live cluttered, over-committed, over-complicated lives with no on to blame but ourselves.

This is one of the best set of tires I have ever owned or driven on. For decades I have been an exclusively Michelin buyer & driver. I had only bought Continental tires once & hated them. When I began to look into buying tires for an AWD Cadillac STS, I was very surprised by the research I did and the reviews that I read. So, I took a chance, based on others recommendations. These tires have been excellent on wet and dry ground. They wear extremely well, so far. After more than 25,000 miles they were still looking fairly new. If I could fault them in any way, it would be that they are a little soft on hard turns, and are a bit noisy on badly paved roads--not too bad though! They are fun to drive on and handle well in almost every way. If I could fault them in any way, it would be that they are a little soft on hard turns, and are a bit noisy on roads with poor pavement conditions--not too bad though! They hardly ever hydroplane--it takes torrential downpour to happen, or an unavoidable incredibly large puddle to appear, before this occurs. They drive well in snow and have better than average traction on ice. These would be a confidence-builder to anyone afraid to drive in snow on highways or major thoroughfares. I was forced to have to drive home one evening in over 12 inches of unplowed snow. I was genuinely surprised by the grip and control I had while driving a good number of miles. I am sure that some of this was due to the car's all-wheel drive, traction control, and ABS braking. Still, I say these tires are a winning combination to work with these. I cannot recommend them too highly. These allowed me to look forward to the snow!With the performance package on my STS, these are the rear tire size. The front tires are a different size: Continental ExtremeContact DWS All-Season Tire-235/50R18 97Z.
This is an inexpensive, handsome, rugged, mountable or "sit flat" unit that can double as a wall switch with its lighted pilot switch.

I was very pleased with the speed of my desktop using a Crucial m4 256GB 2.5-Inch (9.5mm) SATA 6Gb/s Solid State Drive CT256M4SSD2 for quite some time. I had not even heard of mSATA devices. Somehow I stumbled across this. I was curious about this different and funny-looking slot on my Dell motherboard. I only bought this out of curiosity and the fact that the Amazon Warehouse Deal was so good and I had a coupon to go along with it. It installed very easily, except for the fact that I needed to find some Team Associated 21130 M2 X 3 BHPS Screws motherboard screws to secure it. I used Acronis WD Edition to clone my Windows 10 drive. However, although the cloning went fine, Windows ran but did not display anything. I could access the Task Manager, Log On & Off, Restart and a few other things, but could not get to or display the Desktop. An inquiry led me to two programs: the Samsung Magician and Samsung's Data Migration software, the latter of which clones, optimizes Windows, and does other enhancements so as to maximize the speed and efficiency of this drive. It booted right up, and I had no idea that there would be such a noticeable difference in speed between this and the Crucial. I was dead wrong! It beat the pants off it!

There are some drinks that do not require much hardware or equipment. You can just measure, pour, and mix. Something like a Jack Daniels Old-Fashion, or one of those fruity summer cocktails, is quite different. At minimum, you have the slice of orange and the cherries (and maybe other things like mint or spices) you have to "muddle" or you have to combine ingredients in the bottom of a cocktail glass. For this you need a muddle! I already own a heavy duty KegWorks Wooden Cocktail Bar Muddler, which I think is about the best out there! However, it does not work in all (smaller) glasses. It is simply too big. I suppose none of them are perfect. So, I bought this smaller unfinished wooden one to solve that problem. Compare with Oenophilia Wooden Muddler or Drink Muddler, Stainless Steel Mojito Bar Tool with Nylon Tip. I guess I would call this heavy duty for smaller glasses.

When I was much younger, I did very well in the subject of undergraduate Philosophy and so I went go on for further studies. I already had a degree in Computer Science and had done well so far in an Engineering career. I now enrolled in the graduate program at Fordham University. I spent a year doing some of the most fascinating studies and research in my life. With the books and articles that were part of my curriculum, I read about 6,000 pages that year. At lot was spent studying the human mind, knowledge, and how we come to know. A good part of the remainder was spent studying evolution from a philosopher's point of view, i.e. what makes sense and what doesn't. Philosophers then take those things that make sense and show why they do and vice-versa. I was not able to finish the program. I tried later on, but after a semester found I could not give it the time it deserved. The Masters and Ph.D. I had to forgo, but I walked away with another priceless addition to my education. One of the riches came from a microbiologist, Michael Denton, and his work Evolution: A Theory In Crisis. He painstakingly showed the complexity of life down at the molecular, cellular and atomic levels. He showed how incredibly ordered it was also. Using these scientific facts, he compared them with the supposed "randomness" of evolution and also of the mechanism of what we have called "natural selection." His conclusion was that the probability for something like a molecule to mutate to another kind of molecule was very high. But the probability for the number of molecules to mutate in the same way (like in the case of the human eye from an animal) and result in the same basic changes in every creature was astronomical. This idea is worth following. It is worth investigating. So many people continue accept the things of evolution as fact. It would only take a small number of our people, with minds that question and search for the truth about things to follow Denton's ideas and premises further and reach the bottom of this argument once and for all.Years later, I read some more by Michael Denton. I found Nature's Destiny: How the Laws of Biology Reveal Purpose in the Universe to be another of his enthralling works. You'll get a look at how many are being duped by the "carbon" theory.

In autobiographical form, a comprehensive account of this brilliant and scholarly Anglican priest's conversion to Catholicism. This man was an intellectual giant--head of the Oxford Movement. They were going to reform the Church. They were sure they had it all together and were on the right track. Like many others, he was fine until he began to read the Church Fathers. It was there where he first saw his error. He then began to study and master the history of the heretical Monophysites of the 5th century. He was also convinced that he was on the side of the Early Church and vice-versa. However, here he found that Rome stood exactly where it did currently in the nineteenth century, and his Anglican stand reflected the heretical sect. He said, "I saw my face in that mirror, and I was a Monophysite." Case closed! He explained, "Of all the passages of history, since history has been, who would have thought of going to the sayings and doings [of this heretical sect] in order to be converted to Rome!"

In the "Preface" of this spiritual treatise, Father Eugene Boylan tells us,"There is a phenomenon in the natural order which illustrates a great principle of the supernatural order; it is the structure and the growth of crystals. Each crystalline substance has its own characteristic shape; wherever complete crystals occur, not only the whole crystal, but also each unit of it, has that particular shape. If a crystal be suspended in a suitable solution of the substance of which it is composed--the "mother liquor" as it is called--that crystal will grow by drawing to itself material from the solution, forming it to its own image and likeness, and then uniting it to itself, yet so that the new and greater unity is an exact replica of the original nucleus and of each of the component units."Father Boylan tells us what we already know that "On the cross, Christ 'summed up' in one sacrificial act His whole life and His whole love." Yes, it was in His life and death that He still "sums up" the whole life and destiny of His Church, and also the whole life and death of each member of that Church. What he "summed up" we have received in Baptism. It is in Baptism that we have become this "exact replica of the original nucleus." As Saint Gregory of Nazianzus tells us, "Christ is bathed in light; let us also be bathed in light. Christ is baptized; let us also go down with him, and rise with him." We share in his life; we bear his resemblance in Baptism.Father Boylan explains that this book is his attempt to outline the love story of God and the human race. He also wants to show that the Spiritual Life is a partnership of love between God and us which has taken place in Christ. This union, although actually occurring in Baptism, must be perfected individually in the lives of each man and woman--growing by being drawn to what we resemble until we become the replica. This is to remove the obstacles that plague us because of Original Sin and the fall of our first parents, and our own personal sin--the obstacles that obscure and thwart this replication. This is similar to the concept Pope John Paul II developed in "Familiaris Consortio," and insisted we must do, "Become what we are"--become what we became at Baptism. Hence, the Spiritual Life is also a pursuit of the perfection of this union that completes this loving relationship between God and us. It is like Saint Paul proclaims that, "the love of Christ urges us on" (2 Cor 5:14, ff) to become that which he began and wants to complete.Father Boylan takes us chapter by chapter showing us the many ways in which we must seek Christ and the means by which we can attain union with him and his will (see Table of Contents using "Look Inside"). Perhaps my favorite--the one I continually return to--because it is extremely practical is Chapter 17, "Union with Christ through Humility."Not only does he stress the importance of humility; he indicates its necessity. Father's methodology is extremely helpful because, instead of trying to specify what humility is, he takes the approach, which I believe is much easier to grasp, describing what humility is not, or presenting situations and circumstances where humility is lacking. And so he says that our lack of humility is the reason why we are "so touchy, so resentful of criticism, so impatient of opposition, so insistent on getting our own way, so eager to be known, so anxious for praise, so determined on ruling our surroundings."Humility can seem vague; hitherto, Father Boylan suggests an attitude of mind and some examples that can help us to understand the virtue better. His advice is to ask ourselves questions he proposes: Do I speak as little of my own affairs as possible? Can I mind my own business? Do I avoid curiosity? Do I want to manage other people's affairs? Can I accept correction or criticism? Do I insist on my own opinion? Can I pass over the mistakes of others? Can I hide my abilities? Can I accept blame when innocent? Can I accept being slighted, forgotten or disliked? Can I accept insults and injuries? Can I refrain from seeking special love or admiration? Can I accept my own clumsiness, mistakes or failures? Can I be gentle and kind even when provoked? Am I ambitious for showy success? And the list goes on....I think we can see: humility is not easy! There are probably very few who could not see themselves lacking under the above circumstances. These things trouble all of us. We could also ask, "Well, if I am being shown I am lacking in humility, what then is the reason, what is it that causes me to be this way?" Also, we can add, "But, how can I become humble?"The answer to the first question is "Pride." Real humility of heart is found only where pride has been overcome. The answer to the second is, Father Boylan says, "by the grace of God." What's scary is that we are all called to "conduct ourselves with humility" and "humble ourselves." Just as we are called to holiness; each of us is called to humility. We cannot attain the former without the latter.Thankfully, Father Boylan gives us plenty of insight on how to proceed and to do it with humility. But make no mistake; this is a demanding and challenging book. I guess it should be. Living the gospel and choosing Christ, and following him as a disciple, is about as challenging as it gets.

This is an incredible book of Sacred Scripture. I have used it when teaching the Books of Genesis and Exodus. It is the complete TANAKH in Hebrew with their own English translation, which many times provides great insight for us Gentiles. Especially rich and helpful is the commentary which borrows from the great Rabbinic tradition and gives us Christians a look at the Jewish perspective of things. We are all familiar with the Books of the Prophets, but this intersperses passages from the Prophets, which they call the Haftorahs, into the places where the text is referring to the original Torah texts. It's like a term we use in interpreting Scripture: it is best to use Scripture to interpret Scripture. And so it does here. If you are serious about reading or studying the Jewish Scriptures, or their Bible, or as we Catholics and also the Protestants call the Old Testament, You might want to try using this. The price here really doesn't make it prohibitive for anyone.

The only thing better than listening to Perry Como in our house when we were growing up, was listening to his Christmas Music. Although the Carpenters Christmas Portrait at one point, sure gave him a run for his money.

My mother loved Perry. She always told us about him too. He was a good man. He also had a beautiful voice which she said he shared with other Catholics in his parish somewhere in Long Island. We therefore grew up listening to him and loving him too! It's not only great to hear his voice. It's nostalgic too!

While most people are accustomed to speak of Mother Teresa in a glowing sense, as a very holy woman, a woman of great faith, someone of outstanding virtue, this book is a revealing look at her inner world. The Spiritual Life of Mother Teresa was not filled with the ecstasy that we hear with many other saints. No, hers was a Spiritual Life that over-abounded in desolation. The sense of God's presence in her life all but vanished for most of the time that the world knew of her as Mother Teresa. Since we are created as individuals, God does not treat us all the same. As disciples of Jesus, he knows how to treat us as individuals, meaning so as to bring about in us the most good and also to give the Father the most glory. How this works itself out in individual lives can produce remarkable differences in persons. Lest we think that some get "off the hook" we must remember: for all of us there lies before us the decree of Jesus who summoned the crowd with his disciples and said to them, "Whoever wishes to come after me must deny himself, take up his cross, and follow me" (Mk 8:34). Saint Paul declares that in become his followers, from baptism on, "we have died" (see Rom 6:3-8)! If this is reality, then our growth in the Spiritual Life must be such that we must become what we are. We must become dead.Archbishop Fénelon, in his book Let Go, tells us that all that really needs to die is "the living." In reality, we look for all sorts of solutions, which are not solutions at all. They only prolong the agony. Likewise, he says, "You asked for a remedy, that your problems might be cured. You do not need to be cured. You need to be slain. Quit looking for a remedy and let death come. This is the only way to deal with self." The author of the book The Cost of Discipleship expresses this well. To open it and read the Forward is enough to scare anyone. It begins, "'WHEN CHRIST calls a man,'" says Dietrich Bonhoeffer, "'he bids him come and die.' There are different kinds of dying, it is true; but the essence of discipleship is contained in those words."And so we see in the life of Mother Teresa the shadow of the Cross. Following Christ brought the gospel to life for her. As Bonhoeffer said, "When a man really gives up trying to make something out of himself--a saint, or a converted sinner, ...a righteous or unrighteous man... when in the fullness of tasks, questions, success or ill-hap, experiences and perplexities, a man throws himself into the arms of God... then he wakes with Christ in Gethsemane. That is faith...."We see here that Mother Teresa paid the price for responding to the call of Jesus. She's happy now, though! More than we can imagine!

On Friday, August 2, 2002 Peggy Noonan penned an article in the Wall Street Journal called "John Paul the Great." It began with her addressing the pope's recent trip to the Americas which had ended in Mexico with the canonization of Juan Diego, the young man who received the image of Our Lady of Guadalupe on his tilma. She also reflects back on her travelling to Rome for a business trip in June 2000 when she happened upon a private audience with John Paul II. Noonan has a great art in explaining experiences like this. This book gives her the opportunity to elaborate on what this pope has meant to her. It is especially nice that she reads the audiobook because, even though her words are expressive, her emotion carries through as she reads and we get a bigger picture of what this whole thing really meant to her.Although the book is also entitled "John Paul the Great," it is not entirely about him. Yes, she speaks a great deal about him. It offers us one of the early biographical works on the Pontiff, but she also speaks about the current affairs of the Church and what is going on within it, how they relate to him, etc. She is a true journalist in this aspect of her writing. She is Reporting! It is also partly autobiographical because she takes us through her own conversion and a host of experiences that were part of that time in her life. She recounts other personal experiences and how they relate to the pope, his leadership, and the teachings of the Catholic Church towards which she was certainly moving. One of the climaxes is her description of the Pope coming to New York and Saint Patrick's Cathedral and how she kind of unexpectedly found herself with the Cathedral to witness this first-hand.It is a nice, pleasant, enjoyable read of someone who penned and then read what she penned for us. It leaves parts of her message stamped indelibly on our minds and in our imagination.

There are some drinks that do not require much hardware or equipment. You can just measure, pour, and mix. Something like a Jack Daniels Old-Fashion, or those fruity summer cocktails, is quite different. You have the slice of orange and the cherries (and maybe other things) you have to "muddle" or you have to combine ingredients in the bottom of a cocktail glass. For this you need a muddle--and this is about the best out there! Compare with Oenophilia Wooden Muddler or Drink Muddler, Stainless Steel Mojito Bar Tool with Nylon Tip. This is heavy duty compared to the rest!

This is a great natural relaxer. I have found when circumstances bring on anxiety, unrest, or just lack of peace, then four of these, twice a day can really make a difference, especially about how well you sleep.
We use it in our Church for the "little ones." It has many uses. It is relatively light and it is very strong and stable. The handle is a great idea.  It makes it easy to move and use.

This was a great practical and also economical solution for our Church bathroom. The initial cost was a bargain. The replacement rolls are a bit expensive, but there's a lot less waste since we stopped using regular paper towels. The rolls last a lot longer and people take from the dispenser only what they need. The dispenser keeps everything very neat. Installation was also very easy.

It's been a long time. I am at least a few years behind on upgrades. I really haven't had any reason to do so up until now. I recently had been concerned about my old software working correctly with Windows 8.1, which I moved to, and also with the coming of Windows 10. This was a very reasonable offer that motivated me to migrate from OmniPage 15 to 18. I like OmniPage very much. I have been using it for much more than a decade. I have tried other OCR software, but I believe that I am spoiled by OmniPage. Their new editions, however, are very expensive--better put: cost-prohibitive--and provide little new functionality as far as I am concerned in proportion to the money that is spent. This edition installs and seems to work well on Windows 8.1. It registered quickly with the given Serial Number, Activated flawlessly, and so I am satisfied. I knew eventually I would have to upgrade to newer software, but was hanging on waiting for an opportunity like this to come. Hopefully, it will allow me to be able to seek another reasonably priced upgrade in the future, but as you can see, I am not in a hurry to spend more money on this!
Every now and then you run into T5 screws and you need a Torx driver. There's no getting around it. This is a quality product.

I used to work in a bank and had to add up thousands of checks each night. We depended on heavy-duty adding machines. This is nowhere like that, but it's about as good a desktop calculator as you can get for home. There must be a standard-size keypad that is used, because this has the feel of the bank's. It uses Sharp Electronic Calculator Ribbon Twin Spool Black & Red Ribbon to be able to zero in quickly on things like negative numbers. It's a printing calculator, so you can use two-ply rolls of paper, which provides good receipts. I like the color, the size, the quality. It has a bit more functionality than I need, but I like it!

In my opinion, this is one of the best and most informative books I've found on the Book of Revelation. It came highly recommended by Dr. Scott Hahn in his university based course on the subject The End: The Book of Revelations. Dr. Hahn follows a lot of the historical aspects put forth in this book which interprets the timing of the writing of the Book of Revelation and the meaning of this Sacred Scripture as centered around 70AD and the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem. He also follows Chilton's proposal that the structure of the book is something that resembles the structure of Catholic Mass, the new worship and sacrifice that replaced the temple sacrifices, which Dr. Hahn later put to pen more concisely in his well-known The Lamb's Supper: The Mass as Heaven on Earth. David Chilton draws heavily on the rich historical sources that we have from that time, namely Josephus and other Roman figures. I view this as one of the classics written on this book.

Maybe the nicest small form factor wireless mouse being sold right now. Purchased this as a gift for someone with a new laptop. I bought this primarily based on the recommendations found here and also because of the claim of a long battery life. No complaints so far!

This was recommended to me as an alternative to the 33 day preparation found in Saint Louis de Montfort's Preparation for Total Consecration or Preparation for Total Consecration to Jesus Through Mary. It is different in that the focus is on daily meditation rather than the recitation of prayers for which de Montfort included as part of his method. They both lead to the same goal, either initial or renewal of consecration to Mary. I bought this on Kindle to get started. I also ordered the paperback 33 Days to Morning Glory: A Do-It-Yourself Retreat In Preparation for Marian Consecration. Father Michael Gaitley has received a lot of attention lately because of his fine work. I am hoping to benefit from this as I have from the other method in the past. Should I find any surprises, I will update this in this future.

This was a good choice as a microphone to replace a Audio-Technica AT899cW Omnidirectional Condenser Lavalier Microphone used with a Audio-Technica ATW-T310b UniPak Transmitter and at less than 20% of the price. Have not yet noticed any difference in quality between the two mics.

Just adding more of these to the collection! I already purchased a set of 12 of these Sassy Deco Diaper Pins. I found that these are very beautifully colored and/or decorated, much nicer in person than in the picture. These probably are also some of the strongest and most well-made pins I have owned. So, I am buying more to replace some of the cheaper ones I've picked up over the years.A few decades ago, I was living in a residence for a summer which had a housekeeper who took care of dinner, cleaning, and laundry. In explaining the rules of the residence, one of them was unlike any I have ever heard before. The housekeeper made it clear, "I don't sort socks! If you want them sorted, pin them together with Safety (Diaper) Pins." So, in the next few days, I bought a bunch of these at the local supermarket and did as I was told. I found that pinning them at the bottom of the heel area made them easy to fold and put away.These are sometimes hard to come by these days. Yes, I still use them! And, it's been over 25 years since I started. I never stopped pinning my socks together after I left the residence that year and assumed responsibility for doing my own wash once again. First of all, in all this time, I have never lost a sock! I might have lost a pair, but I never kept track of them that closely. I also learned something new that summer. I do not like to sort socks either! With this new knowledge, I was not going to go back to old ways. That would be quite stupid. What I thought might have been a cranky complaint, was actually a mouthful of wisdom.I still have most of the pins I bought that summer. Every now and then I restock. Occasionally, I lose a pin or the plastic breaks for some reason or another. These, however, are constructed for the safety of babies. They are stainless steel and do not rust. When they close, they lock in a way that they must be deliberately opened. They are strong and can last through several decades of weekly washings. If you do the wash for a family, you can assign different colors (like these fancy ones) or one color like Stainless Steel Traditional Safety Pin or use Cloth Diaper Assorted Color Safety Pins to each person so that you never have to figure out who belongs to which socks (another trick of the housekeeper). They are also a bargain when you consider the price.You may not see another review for these like this. But, I thought I would share the wealth by sharing the wisdom of that summer's housekeeper. I'm sure there are more than two of us in this world who have not liked sorting socks!

Pope John Paul II taught us that the parish is not principally a structure, a territory, or a building, but rather, "The family of God, a fellowship afire with a unifying spirit," "a familial and welcoming home," the "community of the faithful." (Christifideles, 26, pg. 63). Many others and much more has been said on the subject. However, Pope Francis has taken things to a whole new level for most people. He says, "This is the mission of the Church: the Church heals, it cures. Sometimes, I speak of the Church as if it were a field hospital. It's true: there are many, many wounded! So many people need their wounds healed! This is the mission of the Church: to heal the wounds of the heart, to open doors, to free people, to say that God is good, God forgives all, God is the Father, God is affectionate, God always waits for us." He says also that we must take part in this. We must also build the structures or organization to do this work. As experience has shown over two millennia, and with any apostolic work, most of the groundwork must be in the Spiritual Life. If the Church is a "Field Hospital" and we are going to work in it, we need the training that will support us in this work. It was kind of prophetic that Father Heilman named this a "Field Manual" for Special Forces Training. As one other reviewer notes, the author does not reinvent the practices of the Spiritual Life, but rather draws on the tradition of the Church. Just a look at the table of contents will show you that. Very much like The Spiritual Combat, called the "favorite book" by Saint Francis de Sales, this is preparation that requires readiness, weapons training, and practices that must be learned and must become second nature. He had to learn it. Sometimes we do not know where to begin the work of the Church, or how to begin. You can find this described as things like "inertia" and "beginning" and "momentum" in an easy but good read like A Travel Guide to Life: Transforming Yourself from Head to Soul. You won't be disappointed. Anyway you look at it, the "Field Hospital" requires that you go back to the wisdom of others like Saint Francis de Sales, Saint Ignatius, and Saint Vincent de Paul, and others as Father Heilman does here. This is nothing new. For 400 years, the Church has been eager to promote things like the Discernment of Spirits, penned in The Spiritual Exercises of St. Ignatius, pg. 313, ff., or the application of which can be found in The Discernment of Spirits: An Ignatian Guide for Everyday Living). The concept of Father Heilman is surprisingly right on target. If you have read The Soul of The Apostolate, you know that much ink is devoted to speaking about "shock troops." Yes, Dom Chautard claims, "Next to the official clergy, have risen, beginnings of Christianity, companies of volunteers, shock-troops, whose continued and abundant growth will always be one of the clearest signs of the vitality of the Church (pg 6)." He explains that Pope Pius X judged the effectiveness of his priests by their ability to develop and use these "shock troops" (see pp.165-172 for an in-depth look at this). As important as this sounds, Chautard stressed that priority always must be given to the Interior Life over the Active Life. So, this is solid stuff. There is a convergence of many great ideas from many great people and of holiness, which is the Church! Join in with Father Heilman. Join with him and the other great teachers of the Church. This is a good place to start and to prepare to become part of the History of the Church and one of its Saints!

As other reviewers and I have previously indicated on other product pages, these Arrid Clear Gels are becoming increasingly harder to find. The fact is, this is one of the two brands and type of deodorant that I like the most and look for on the store shelves. Amazon is therefore providing a great service for some of us. It's nice to buy in bulk. Who wants to run out! Their price is competitive also. At the same time, I also like and buy the other variety: Arrid Extra Dry Anti-Perspirant & Deodorant, Clear Gel, Morning Clean. I like to stay stocked up for months!

This is another variation of the one I heard first, One Day (New Album Version). It has an extra lead-in before getting to the main song. This is a good basic hasp/latch. It does what it needs to do. If you want something with a little more pizazz (it swivels so you can latch it without a lock) you might want to look at National Hardware V32 4-1/2" Swivel Staple Safety Hasp in Black in nice enamel and you can match it up with a black Master Lock 131Q Covered Aluminum.

If you like to drink soda, and the sugar is too much for you or you must stay away from it, or those artificial sweetener chemicals you no longer want to put in your body, this may be right for you. Although it lacks some of the sweetness that we're used to enjoying, it is still flavorful and very refreshing. It does not take much to get used to it. The Stevia is a natural sweetener coming from a leaf. I began using this by purchasing Zevia All Natural Soda, Rainbow Pack, 12 Ounce (Pack of 24). There are 12 different flavors. You get two of each. This lets the household sample everything until everyone's favorites are determined. Then you can buy different flavors by the case. The Black Cherry is my favorite. I usually buy it: Zevia All Natural Soda, Black Cherry, 12 Ounce (Pack of 24 like this. It was unavailable at this time, so I bought this Fruity Pack. It has my four favorite flavors.

These are great boxes! Don't just buy these randomly. Make them work for you and others! When planning your move, make a determination how much heavy stuff and how much other stuff you will be packing or shipping. Then, buy boxes by size, accordingly. For example, for books or anything of similar weight, you do not want to use anything bigger than a small box. You will be surprised at how many books one of these can hold. I've done this a number of times. I just finished a shipment. My experience has shown that a full small box of hardcover books averages about 40 pounds. You do not want to go more than that. You also want to be able to stack them in the same size boxes. Whereas, for pillows, comforters, and other bedding, you can probably use the large boxes without any serious weight problems. The fit is one thing. The weight is another. Someone has to carry these! You will be thanked and appreciated for taking this into consideration. I've heard it frequently from the everyday pickup and delivery shippers!
Great! Perfect for additional storerooms and a sound system without having to carry an extra key!

I was sure I wrote a review on this, but recently I found I didn't. I bought and read it four years ago and have been talking about it ever sense. Three years before that, I went through a period where I read The Total Money Makeover: A Proven Plan for Financial Fitness, The Dream Manager (Audio CD), a bunch of Patrick Lencioni's works beginning with The Three Big Questions for a Frantic Family (Audio), then The Five Temptations of a CEO (Audio CD), "The Five Dysfunctions of a Team," The Four Obsessions of an Extraordinary Executive, and there were others about General Patton: General Patton's Principles for Life and Leadership, and Alan Axelrod's "Patton on Leadership" to name a few. During this whole time I kept hearing about this book, "First, Break All The Rules." It came highly recommended, but I did not even like the title. That's not how I think! Finally, I gave in and found this to be a groundbreaking and life-changing book on management and leadership. It first of all introduced me to Marcus Buckingham, who introduced me to his ideas and the results of 25 years of research by the Gallup Organization with great managers and their organizations. This was groundbreaking! I began to understand: to make things work effectively, you can't go by the "rules" as we have been led to believe. Secondly, following the trail of Buckingham, he then led me to Now, Discover Your Strengths, then to taking the Clifton Strengthsfinder Test, a code for which came with the book, then StrengthsFinder 2.0, then finally Living Your Strengths, or the Catholic Edition Living Your Strengths: Discover Your God-given Talents And Inspire Your Community.Life has been different. Priorities have changed. Focuses are no longer the same. Thinking has been transformed. Work habits are no longer what they were. Working with others is more important. Outcomes now are always so much better!

I bought this simply for sleeping comfort. I have been using it for a few weeks now. I bought it to replace a memory foam mattress cover that never worked as I had hoped. The only complaint is that it does not fit tight enough around my twin-size mattress, although it stays in place and doesn't seem to move around. I kind of has the feel of an old "feather bed." It is very comfortable. It is very breathable. It stays cool while sleeping.

This is a great and unique kind of honey to use in this day of over-processed foods. I have been using it for about a decade. I have always bought their Honey Gardens Raw Orange Blossom Honey. I saw this kind recently and thought I would try it. To tell you the truth, I can't tell the difference between this and that. Maybe it's the way I use it! If you go to the Honey Gardens website and look under "Honey Education" you will get an insight to all of this. One of the things you will read is: "Apitherapy honey has never been heated or filtered, and thus it retains the beneficial traces of pollen, propolis, and beeswax, which the flowers and bees have provided. These contain healthful minerals, vitamins, enzymes, amino acids, and carbohydrates. " They also have a comment that "Scientists at Cornell University, Geneva, New York report 'Honey has been used as a topical and gastrointestinal remedy for thousands of years, and has recently gained recognition from the medical field. The growth of many microorganisms associated with disease or infection is inhibited by honey.'" I think the more you learn about this product, the more you will use it and its by-products.

2:32 Mins The Samson MediaOne BT4 Active Studio Monitors with Bluetooth were sent to me (at a discounted cost or free of charge) so that I could provide an honest and an unbiased review.They are very well made.They look great.They work flawlessly.They sound incredible.When I first connected these to my LG G3 via Bluetooth, there was a noticeable and annoying skip every few seconds while playing music.I had never seen my phone do such a thing, so I suspected the Bluetooth on the speakers may be not up to par.I connected the phone via a cord to the speakers and the skip was gone.However, I wanted to be certain of where the issue was, so I connected the MediaOne to my Nexus 7 2013 tablet and there was NO skipping, so, it would appear that the issue is with the ROM on my G3.These are versatile and can be used in many different places. I will be trying them out the next time I watch a movie out in the yard, I will connect them to my projector.More details in the video.

Just an amazing show.There is something for everyone of all ages.I am 55 and enjoyed every moment of it.The cinematics are outstanding, the acting is wonderful.Watch it with the entire family and enjoy.

3:07 Mins The Self Balancing Scooter Two 6.5" Wheel Self Balance Electric Board Drifting Personal Transporter Mini Unicycle with Led Light was sent to me (free of charge or at a discounted cost) so that I could provide an honest and an unbiased review.This is some really impressive engineering.It works perfectly.It's incredible fun.It takes patience and practice to be able to enjoy it to it's fullest.I have been cursed with being clumsy my entire life. I do good to walk and chew gum, simultaneously.I AM the proverbial "Bull in a China Shop".So, when I was asked to review this dandy device, I was just a bit apprehensive, but I have too much "kid" in me to turn it down.After I charged it for about 90 or so minutes, I loaded it up and headed to my buddies shop.He has a really large, flat parking lot and is almost ideal for a beginner. We tried it in his shop for a few minutes, before we ventured outside.The first time I stepped on it, I was more than apprehensive, not scared, just very aware of my lack of equilibrium and good sense.However, we only live one time!I was able to ride, and balance on it at a very slow pace with zero problems.It will take practice to master, that much is for certain.In all my days, I never thought I would meet another person more clumsy than myself. My buddy, Jesse is. He is duck footed and has a low center of gravity. He was just not able to get a balance on it while in the shop, he looked like a windmill and the scooter was only teetering back and forth just a teenincy bit. His wife and I almost busted our guts laughing at him.So, we ventured outside to see how well I could do on the asphalt. I did about as I had done inside and took it a little further. I was gaining momentum, when I hit a very small crevice and it tipped me. I landed on my right side.Jesse decided to give it another try and he did a bit better than when we were indoors, but still needs some practice.I went to my wife's school and decided to take it for a little spin on the campus side walks.JUST my luck, I hit another small crevice and it tipped me again and I suspect I may have broke my left wrist with that fall.This is a very well made and fun device.My ONLY complaint is that I would like to have seen some rubber bumpers on it, because when it spills the rider, it CAN and sometimes WILL whirl away and get scuffed and scratched.

I landed on my right side.Jesse decided to give it another try and he did a bit better than when we were indoors, but still needs some practice.I went to my wife's school and decided to take it for a little spin on the campus side walks.JUST my luck, I hit another small crevice and it tipped me again and I suspect I may have broke my left wrist with that fall.This is a very well made and fun device.My ONLY complaint is that I would like to have seen some rubber bumpers on it, because when it spills the rider, it CAN and sometimes WILL whirl away and get scuffed and scratched.

The Zenoplige Newest S6 Quad Core Android Tv Box Smart Android 4.4.2 H.265 Quad Core 1080p Amlogic S805 1gb Ram and 8gb Rom with Bluetooth was sent to me (free of charge or at a discounted cost) so that I could provide an honest and an unbiased review.It's very small.It looks great.It's hardware feature rich.It has a customized version of Android, KodiOS that is chocked FULL of surprises.LOADS of preloaded repositories and ad-ons.As usual, (in my experience) some worked well, others not so much.The remote worked very well and as a matter of fact, worked FAR better than any other remote I have used with an Android based TV box.It was not awkward or clumsy in the least for me.It may be that the KodiOS is optimized for the remote.Storage is on the slim side, but it can be expanded via the micro-SD card slot or one of the 2 USB ports.It connected to my wifi with no issues and Ethernet worked perfectly fine too.It set it self at 1080p, which my monitor is and looked great.Streaming worked good.

5:00 Mins The iRULU Walknbook 10.1 Inch Tablet PC, 32GB Hybrid Laptop, 2-In-1 Tablet, Microsoft Windows 10 OS, Quad Core, IPS Display,1280*800 Resolution, Detachable Keyboard With Stand (Dark Grey) was sent to me (at a discounted cost or free of charge) so that I could provide an honest and an unbiased review.I own 7 other devices with the same SoC, 3 tablets and 4 of the small form factor boxes, so I believe I have a good idea as to how it should perform.It's not the fastest thing on the block, but it is efficient, responsive and a very pleasant experience.The build quality is very impressive and it is hardware feature rich.Full size USB port - on the tabletMicro-USB port - on the tabletMicro-SD card slot for storage expansionMini-HDMIAudio outputHardware volume rocker buttonBluetoothFront and rear camerasIncluded wall charger and micro-USB cable.When I first powered it on, I was VERY, VERY pleasantly surprised to be greeted with the initial Windows 10 setup, as it finalizes it's installation. Which allows me (the Owner) to choose those final settings as I want to, not what a merchant chooses.A few of the other devices I have gotten for review, the merchant had setup and used some activators on the device, which bypasses the Windows licensing. (In other words, they had installed bootleg copies of Windows).After I set my privacy options and finished the initial settings, it loaded the desktop and I went to see if it Windows was activated. It was not.I connected it to my wireless network, and about 30 or so seconds later, I checked it again and it was indeed activated.The display is fantastic, and the IPS panel is sharp, clear and crisp.The speaker is not impressive, however since it has both Bluetooth and an audio out jack, that is easily fixed with an external speaker.More details and then some in the video.

This review is for the 64GB model.It is currently upgrading to Windows 10. Aside from being a slow process, all is going well so far.I found something very odd when I was looking at the drive via Windows Drive Manager. It shows 14 RAW partitions in varying increments of 32 and 64 MB.I have no idea why the OEM would do such a thing.Through some good old fashioned googling, I discovered there is a BIOS update, however I do not know if it is the same version that is currently on the device, since there was no "read me" in the file I downloaded. The OEM has no support links on their site. I have also discovered that some units have heat issues which can cause the touch screen to artifact. I have not seen my unit do this yet and it has been on for the biggest part of 5 hours.The OS switch program is buggy. It works, but not exactly like it should, in Windows anyway.It comes as a simple and small executable that is on the Windows desktop and is baked in to the Android KitKat install.In Kitkat, it works great. It is accessed via the pull down settings on the upper right corner.It comes with a 1 year Office 365 subscription.There was no bloat or junk installed on either OS.The touch screen performs well and does exactly as it should. When loading Windows, some of the time it will not set itself to landscape and I have to give it a knock with the hammer...err I mean pick it up and tilt it.Windows 8.1 ran smooth and was exactly what I expected.Connecting an external monitor via HDMI works fine and perfectly in Windows, under Android it is not a pretty sight.The display lags and does not scale correctly under Android.When I powered it on the first time, I truly expected some kind of boot options so that I could select what OS I wanted it to load. It did not do that, it booted to Windows.The option to choose what OS to boot to only shows itself some of the time.These are my findings, thus far of about 5 hours of tinkering.Windows looks and runs like Windows and Android looks like Android and does not run as well as I would have expected.Windows 10 installed and is working exactly as it should and as I had hoped.All drivers installed and Windows 10 is activated.Video added on 8-7.I have discovered that the OS switch DOES work fine and I was wrong in what I said on the video.The return arrow on the screen is "Enter" and after getting the circle around the OS you want to boot in to, pushing the return is what does the magic.I got Android rooted on it, using Kingo Root, it works fine rooted and everything is working as it should.I did discover that plugging an HDMI cable in to it, put it back in landscape mode.

The VStarcam C7815WIP 720P 1.0 MegaPixel P2P Plug&Play Wifi Infrared Bullet Waterproof Onvif Security HD Wireless IP Camera was sent to me (free of charge or at a discounted cost) so that I could provide an honest and an unbiased review.It looks good.It appears to be really well made.The manual that came with it has instructions for setting it up via an Android or iOS device.I just don't like to do that, because (for me) it is hit or miss. Some times it works well and other times, not.I would rather not waste the time with trying it with a mobile device, because the browser UI works and works quickly, every time, provided the hardware is working as it should.Fortunately, the website for Vstarcam has the software for download and it has a search tool, which enables setting it up via a browser UI.Once I logged in to the browser UI, it was as easy as can be to set it to my network and allow it to reboot.The clarity is good, as it is 720p.I plan on mounting on one corner of my home.

The TRENDnet AC1750 Dual Band DD-WRT Open-Source Wireless Router with StreamBoost Technology (TEW-824DRU) was sent to me (free of charge or at a discounted cost) so that I could provide an honest and an unbiased review.I am using the TEW-824DRU as an access point and the 828DRU from TrendNET as my main router. I have 7 IP cameras on my network, all set to wireless.Getting the 824 set as an access point was easy as can be, as soon as I remembered how!The IP cameras I have are from different OEMs such as Edimax, HooToo and Wanscam.I set one of the wireless channels as a dedicated camera, so that only the cameras use it. The 824 has enabled me to get better coverage from the outdoor cameras that are further away from the 828.The only issues I encountered were that the 824 was NOT happy when I logged in from Internet Explorer 11. We tried it in his shop for a few minutes, before we ventured outside.The first time I stepped on it, I was more than apprehensive, not scared, just very aware of my lack of equilibrium and good sense.However, we only live one time!I was able to ride, and balance on it at a very slow pace with zero problems.It will take practice to master, that much is for certain.In all my days, I never thought I would meet another person more clumsy than myself. My buddy, Jesse is. He is duck footed and has a low center of gravity. He was just not able to get a balance on it while in the shop, he looked like a windmill and the scooter was only teetering back and forth just a teenincy bit. His wife and I almost busted our guts laughing at him.So, we ventured outside to see how well I could do on the asphalt. I did about as I had done inside and took it a little further. I was gaining momentum, when I hit a very small crevice and it tipped me. I landed on my right side.Jesse decided to give it another try and he did a bit better than when we were indoors, but still needs some practice.I went to my wife's school and decided to take it for a little spin on the campus side walks.JUST my luck, I hit another small crevice and it tipped me again and I suspect I may have broke my left wrist with that fall.This is a very well made and fun device.My ONLY complaint is that I would like to have seen some rubber bumpers on it, because when it spills the rider, it CAN and sometimes WILL whirl away and get scuffed and scratched.

2:17 MinsThe UX5C RC Quadcopter with 720p HD Camera and Headless Mode 2.4GHz 4 CH 6 Axis Gyro RTF Includes BONUS BATTERY (*Doubles Flying Time*) - USA TOYZ EXCLUSIVE!! was sent to me (free of charge or at a discounted cost) so that I could provide an honest and an unbiased review.It looks great.It's robust and well made.Extra props and extra battery, 2GB micro-SD card, and card reader.It charges via USB and does not take long at all.The transmitter is big and fits well in my extra big paws.The instruction manual is VERY easy to read, with nice illustrations.I would recommend getting a fast card, so that the camera is able to write at it's capabilities.More details in the video.

Midnight Sun is the second book in Jo Nesbo's Blood on Snow series.What ties these two together is The Fisherman, crime kingpin of Oslo. Jon worked for The Fisherman selling drugs and other 'special' jobs as needed. Except Jon couldn't do it - he couldn't kill. So now he's run to a remote village at the top of Norway where the sun never sets. And he took along drugs and money that weren't his to take - and The Fisherman wants it back....A local woman, Lea, and her son Knut, give Jon shelter in an old hunting cabin. But after a few days of the sun never setting, the flat unending landscape and being alone in the small cabin, he craves people - and alcohol. So he heads to the village....Nesbo's description of the village and the landscape creates an sense of otherworldly isolation that mirrors what Jon is feeling. The eclectic residents and their behavior keeps both Jon and the reader wondering what could happen next.Even though Jon, aka Ulf, is a 'bad' guy, he's a bad guy with a good streak and a conscience. The reader can't help but hope that he escapes those after him and that maybe, just maybe, he's got another shot at a good life. Sami culture and the Laestadian religion are woven into the story - redemption is a major theme and plays a part in more than one character's life.I love the noir, staccato pace of Nesbo's writing - think of a Tarantino movie put to print. For me, another great read from Nesbo.(I have no idea if Nesbo will ever resurrect Harry Hole - but I do miss him.)

3.5 Have you started your holiday reading yet? No? Well, here's one to add to your list - The Further Adventures of Ebenezer Scrooge by Charlie Lovett. (And I have a copy to giveaway as well as a bonus book!)You read that right - further adventures. Lovett imagines what might have occurred after Scrooge was visited by the three ghosts and changed his outlook on Christmas - and life - in Charles Dickens' book A Christmas Carol.Well, Scrooge is celebrating year round - wishing everyone he meets a Merry Christmas each day of the year. But those who benefitted from Scrooge's change of heart twenty years ago have also lost their way. Partner Bob Cratchit is a workaholic, nephew Freddie ignores the plight of those around him and Scrooge's creditors can't see the human side of his largess, only the debts. So one summer's day, Scrooge calls upon the ghosts to help them as they did him so many years ago.Lovett writes in the style of Dickens (sometimes employing phrasing and referencing Dickens' other works) to recreate the tenor, tone and message of A Christmas Carol.The Further Adventures of Ebenezer Scrooge is a lovely reminder that "...scores and hundreds understood the ways of wealth and money and even of philanthropy, but their hearts lacked the true wealth of love, of family, of Christmas joy, which, he now saw, might have been theirs all the year round."The Further Adventures of Ebenezer Scrooge is a quick little one night read.  Guaranteed to put you in the holiday spirit - hopefully year round!

I've been a fan of Catherine McKenzie from her first book. She's just released her fifth novel - Smoke. Each of the previous four books have been completely different reads - I never know what to expect when I start one of her books. But what I do know is that I'm going to enjoy it.Elizabeth fought wildfires as a profession for over ten years, travelling to where she was needed. Its taken a toll on her personal life though. So, now she stays put, living with her husband in a quiet mountain town in the Rockies. Instead, she works as an investigator for the town's attorney. But when an out of control fire threatens the entire town, her skills as an arson investigator are called into play again.Elizabeth's ex-friend Mindy is also worried about the fire. She knows something is 'off' with her teenage son - and has been for quite a while. And whether or not she wants to admit it, she wonders if he might have had something to do with starting the fire.Smoke is told in alternating chapters from both women. I really enjoy dual narrative novels - a second look at a same event and/or two stories that will intersect farther down the road as more is revealed.Although the fire is the stage for the novel, there's much more to Smoke. The personal lives of Elizabeth and Mindy are explored - motherhood, friendship, love, marriage and secrets. While Elizabeth is the 'lead' character, I found myself more drawn to Mindy. I didn't like Elizabeth's secret keeping from her husband - and her justification for those choices. Mindy has made some questionable choices as well, but I was more inclined to forgive her. Her 'redemption', if you will, appealed to me more. McKenzie does a great job of creating a 'mean girls' group that Mindy hangs out with. (But I do want to know what happened to the siphoned library money?) The petulant and aggressive teens are also well drawn.The mystery of who started the fire runs through the entire book of course. I did have the 'whodunit' sussed out before the end, but quite enjoyed the journey to the final reveal. The fire, the methods used to fight it and the mindset of a firefighter were well researched and believable.I'm always intrigued by cover choices and titles. I'm not overwhelmed with this cover, but the title made me think of the old adage - "Where there's smoke, there's fire." And its applicable in so many ways to much of the plot line and many of the characters in Smoke.Smoke is another engaging, easy read from McKenzie. Those who enjoy contemporary women's fiction with a touch of mystery will enjoy Smoke.

3.5 I'm not sure why, but there's a plethora of 'dying teen' movies being made. Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is recently released from Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment. It's based on the novel of the same name by Jesse Andrews.Greg Gaines has worked hard at blending in, going unnoticed and being on good terms with all the different groups at his high school. Oh, and he makes quirky little films with his 'co-worker' Earl. He's coasting along just fine. Until his mother insists he spend time with Rachel who is battling cancer. They really don't know each other very well....but things change as he and Rachel become unlikely friends. Greg is forced to confront the truths that Rachel lays out - about both herself and him.Great casting! Thomas Mann is wonderful as Greg - his glib banter and self-deprecating manner hide his lack of confidence. The connection between him and Rachel (Olivia Cooke) is absolutely believable. Cooke masterfully underplays her role - any louder or affected would not have worked. I must admit that Earl (newcomer R.J. Cyler) kinda stole the show for me. Again the relationship between Earl and Greg really works. Molly Shannon as Rachel's mom brought me some Saturday Night Live flashback moments. Jon Bernthal plays teacher Mr. McCarthy. Although his appearance is quite different, I still had a hard time not associating him with his Walking Dead role.Now you might think that the plot would veer off into doomed dying girl teen romance territory. And I thought it was going to as well. Not so. Instead, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl explores friendships on many levels, coming of age, loss, love and more. Humorous, sad, quirky. An indie kind of take on what seems to be a newly recurring style of 'teen' film.Cinematically, I found some of the long lens and fish eye shots took away from the movie for me. I started focusing on whether or not that staircase could truly be that steep instead of the dialogue happening. But, movies play a large role in Greg's life and the film, so I can understand why director Alfonso Gomez-Rejon would add some artistic touches. (Now this is just me, but I really didn't enjoy Greg's movies - and while Greg's final film has it's moments, I wasn't blown away)All in all, I enjoyed Me and Earl and the Dying Girl - winner of the Audience Award and the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival.

3.5 I started with the first book (Postmortem) in Patricia Cornwell's Kay Scarpetta series way back in 1990 when forensic mysteries were becoming popular. Her latest release, Depraved Heart, is the 23rd entry in this series.Now, I must admit, I just haven't enjoyed the last few books - they seemed mired in extraneous detail and became repetitive. But I was willing to give this latest a go. And up front, I want to say, I did enjoy Depraved Heart.Scarpetta and Marino are at the scene of what appears to be the accidental death of a wealthy young woman when a video link appears and starts playing on Kay's phone. Although her policy is to never interrupt a scene investigation with personal calls, she is powerless to stop watching. The video is a twenty year old video of her niece Lucy - and her then lover Carrie Grethem. Grethem was thought to be dead, but surfaced in the last book and attempted to kill Kay. It looks like she's back and still determined to wreak havoc with Kay and her family."The FBI placed the niece I raised like a daughter into a psychopathic monster's care, and that decision changed the course of our lives. It has changed absolutely everything."Depraved Heart picks up two months after the abrupt ending of the last book, Flesh and Blood. Readers who have kept up with the Scarpetta books will have a better understanding of this perpetrator and plotting.One key element of Depraved Heart is the concept of 'data fiction'. "It's what can happen if we're so reliant on technology that we become completely dependent on things we can't see. Therefore we can no longer judge for ourselves what's true, what's false, what's accurate, what isn't. In other words if reality is defined by software that does all the work for us, then what if this software lies? What if everything we believe isn't true but is a facade, a mirage?" I was fascinated - and somewhat disturbed - with this notion. (I thought of how much time I spend online...) Are the videos (yes there's more than one) true? Or false? Is Benton lying to her? Who and what can she believe and trust? The reader sees the entire book unfold through Scarpetta's eyes and thoughts.Marino is a perennial favourite of mine and this time Scarpetta seems to be a little kinder towards him. For the life of me, I have no idea why she stays with Benton. Lucy just annoys me, but I think there's more of a forthcoming story with her new partner Janet.The book takes place during a twenty four hour period. The book moves along quickly as Kay and Marino attempt to deal with both their latest case - and the apparent danger to Lucy.  The tension is palpable as everyone's actions and motives are called into question. I was easily caught up in the story and possibilities. Cornwell does weave an intricate plot, one I appreciated. (But one glaring omission by investigators, that is mentioned and is part of the final whodunit, will be caught by sharp eyed readers.)The title? "Legal definition of Depraved Heart - 'Void of social duty and fatally bent on mischief.' Mayes V. People, Illinois Supreme Court. 1883."The ending leaves the door open for a continued story in this vein. Although I quite enjoyed this latest entry more than the last few, a wee bit of me thinks it's time to end this ongoing storyline and give readers a fresh mystery and investigation next time 'round.

Poles Apart is the fifth novel from best-selling and award winning author Terry Fallis.Blogs are de rigueur reading nowadays. I must admit I read and follow many, many blogs on widely varying topics. (And thank you you're reading this one!) Some bloggers share personal details, but others choose to remain anonymous. Such is the case with the blog that is at the center of the plot in Poles Apart.Eve of Equality is a new feminist blog that becomes an overnight success when it posts a story on the owner of a chain of 'high-end' strip clubs that are opening up across the country. Why would the author not acknowledge their success? Television shows, radio hosts, newspaper articles and even a book deal await this feminist movement advocate! Well, the author happens to be a man named Everett Kane, who truly is an ardent feminist. But who will take a man's writing on feminism seriously?As Everett attempts to keep his identity private, there are others just as determined to find out who he is. Everett's location choice for his new apartment is a great comedic plot device. It also brings in a great cast of supporting players and a romantic possiblity. Everett is in Florida to help his father recover from a stroke. Dad is a unique personality with some good lines, as is the recuperating feminist pioneer also in residence at the home.The dialogue is great fun, witty and smart and the characters are all a little left of centre -  you can't help but mentally cheer for them. The plotting is somewhat telegraphed but is great fun. But mixed within this comic tale are many grains of truth. Everett's blog posts, musings and beliefs can all be read and taken quite seriously as they contain many valid points.Poles Apart is another witty, charming read from Terry Fallis, again underscoring whey he has earned the Stephen Leacock Medal for Humour more than once. Although No Relation remains my favourite Fallis book, I quite enjoyed Poles Apart.

The Improbability of Love is Hannah Rothschild's debut novel. And what a debut it is!The Improbability of Love is actually a painting - although the title can be applied to many of the relation. Annie's fourteen year relationship has ended, she is a talented chef, but works for two sketchy art dealers, her mother is a life long alcoholic and her attempts to find friends - and love - have fallen flat. When she comes upon a dusty little painting in a junk shop, she just likes the way it looks. She has no idea that it's a lost masterpiece. But others who spy her with it are aware.....the cast of art collectors, art dealers and art thieves is large and eclectic.Rothschild has a keen eye and wit, skewering the art world with tongue firmly in cheek.  I suspect insider knowledge has much to do with this - Rothschild is Chair of the Trustees of the National Gallery - UK.Her character are all richly drawn and fleshed out. The art aficionados were by turns evil, funny and desperate. (Some readers may find this cast too large) It's impossible not to fall in love with Annie and hope that she does indeed find happiness and love again.  But the character I enjoyed the most came out of left field - the painting itself has a sardonic voice - and memories. Through those recollections we learn the provenance of the picture and the details of the man who painted it.Annie is a talented chef, using food as her empty canvas. Rothschild's description of Annie's meals and their inspiration mirror her evocative descriptions of the paintings and art history used throughout the book. Both were equally fascinating for me.Clever, very clever, is the first description that springs to mind in describing this book. Those looking for a literary art novel with a distinctly satiric tone mixed with history, romance, dodgy dealings and more, will enjoy The Improbability of Love.

You can find me glued to the television during national and world sports coverage - especially the Olympics. I remember watching Clara Hughes race over many Olympics - she is a six time Olympian with six medals to her credit - in two sports - speed skating and cycling. She has numerous other accolades and victories.But what you don't see on television is what's going on behind the scenes, what it takes for an athlete to rise to this level, the obstacles they've met, the obstacles overcome and who they are besides being a public figure and athlete.Clara Hughes' newly released memoir, Open Heart, Open Mind, lays all of that bare. Hughes' father was a verbally abusive alcoholic, Clara drank, did drugs and skipped school. When she did start to channel her energy into competitive sport she landed with a coach who was results driven, caring little about her mental health. Hughes has suffered from depression for most of her life. In 2010, she put her own struggles in the public eye when she became the national spokesperson for the Bell Let's Talk mental health initiative - "A wide-reaching, multi-year program designed to break the silence around mental illness and support mental health all across Canada."I am always appreciative of reading someone's memoir - the bravery in sharing your life with the public. Hughes shares both professional and personal. I was fascinated by the behind the scenes look at a professional athlete's training and performance. Clara's athletic accomplishments are extraordinary. But it is her personal triumphs that are outstanding. Hughes has taken that same energy and drive that she used in sports, applied it to her mental well being and advocating for others through numerous projects, such as Right to Play.The title? Hughes participated in a Squamish First Nations brushing-off ceremony in 2010........"Another elder addressed each of us in turn, opening our hearts to the energy of the flame and brushing away negativity. He told us, I cannot heal you of your pain. Only you can heal yourself with your open heart and your open mind."Wise words. Great read. Amazing and inspiring woman.

You might just be saying to yourself - Christmas books already Luanne?! Well, I've had snow at my place already. And yes, I'm going to say it.....only nine weeks 'til Christmas. I absolutely adore reading Christmas stories in the weeks leading up to the 25th.And here's one feel good read you absolutely need to put on your Christmas reading list - The Great Christmas Knit-Off by Alexandra Brown.Sybil's life has unraveled - she's been jilted, left at the alter by her ex-fiancee - who took off with her twin sister - at work, she may be the one responsible for a large amount of missing money, transferred with a mistaken key stroke - and more. When her bestie takes over running a wee little pub in the village of Tindledale, Sybs decides to visit and get away from her life for a weekend.Uh huh, you know what's coming don't you? Warm, wonderful, friendly, quirky characters inhabit the village of Tindledale and Sybs is immediately welcomed. When she discovers a wool shop, she knows she's found a kindred spirit in Hettie, the aged owner. But Hettie's nephew is determined to put her in a home and take over her property. Oh, and did I mention the handsome (single) village doctor?Sybil is a character the reader is immediately drawn to - she's someone you'd love to have as a friend. The reader can't help but cheer her on as she starts to reclaim her life and move forward. There's a lovely sense of community as the residents work together to save Hettie's store. Romance of course figures into the plot - with the requisite missteps, mistakes and miscommunication. Good and bad (that nasty nephew) battle and there are many poignant moments with Hettie as her past is explored and revealed.Me? I'd love to be part of the knit and natter group. (There's also a pattern included at the back of the book for one of Sybil's projects.) Or settle in for a pint at the Duck and Puddle and catch up on the latest. Make yourself a warm cup of tea - or better yet a cup of cocoa - and settle in for a perfect, heartwarming Christmas read. (This is the first book in Brown's new series set in Tindledale.)

3.5 Blessed Are Those Who Mourn is the fourth book in Kristi Belcamino's Gabriella Giovanni series.Belcamino's choice of lead characters opens up a world of possibilities in terms of  plots. Gabriella is a crime reporter in San Francisco and her partner Sean Donovan is a police detective.The past plays a large part in Blessed Are Those Who Mourn.
